DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Countdown Proceeding Smoothly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with astronauts' arrival, quotes. PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `Leinbach said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's seven astronauts arrived full of confidence Thursday night as the countdown proceeded uninterrupted toward a weekend liftoff of the shuttle with an observatory. ``We're back. We're ready, and we're wanting to get on with it,'' Columbia's commander, Vance Brand, said after flying in with his crew from Johnson Space Center in Houston. Earlier in the day, NASA test director Mike Leinbach said the countdown was going smoothly. Three of Columbia's four previous countdowns since spring came to an abrupt halt about six hours before liftoff because of hydrogen leaks. Numerous repairs were needed. ``It's been a long, hot summer for us filled with a couple of major disappointments, but the team is really upbeat now,'' Leinbach said. ``Everyone is feeling good, looking forward to a nice Christmas present, which will be getting the thing off the ground Sunday morning.'' Columbia is scheduled to blast off at 1:28 a.m. EST Sunday. Meteorologists said Thursday there is a 70 percent chance the weather will cooperate. Four of Columbia's astronauts are astronomers who will operate the on-board observatory, called Astro. Leinbach said ``the one big worry for everybody'' - a leaking fuel system - was no longer a threat. Columbia, grounded in late May, was cleared for flight during a fueling test last month. Atlantis also was found to be free of dangerous hydrogen leaks during an October tanking test and returned last week from a secret military mission. Still, ``there are thousands of other things that can get us ... anything can bite you,'' Leinbach said. Columbia's second countdown, for example, was halted because of problems with the observatory. Among those afraid to get their hopes up are scientists who have been working on the Astro mission since the original 1986 launch date. The Challenger accident that year was responsible for the lengthy delay. ``We're just as excited. The only qualifier is we've learned to be somewhat skeptical if it will actually happen until we see it get launched,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, the principal investigator for one of Astro's four telescopes. ``The whole goal is the science we're going to do. That's just as exciting as it was several years ago,'' Davidsen said. The three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope that constitute the $150 million observatory will focus on some of the hottest objects in the universe. The approximately 240 targets include one of the most distant, visible quasars, a half-dozen binary stars and a supernova. Ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from these objects are invisible from Earth. Astro consequently will ``provide our first detailed glimpse of the universe in the extreme ultraviolet portion of the electromagnetic spectrum,'' Davidsen said. ``We'll see things that can't be seen (normally) and hopefully solve some very important things in astronomy,'' Davidsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Operation Contributing to Shortage of Drug Used Against Hepatitis
DOC.TEXT: A drug used to contain outbreaks of hepatitis A and measles is in short supply nationally, in part because of the military buildup in Saudi Arabia, the manufacturer says. Armour Pharmaceutical Co. has begun producing the drug around the clock in response to the shortage, said spokeswoman Jane Green of Armour's parent company, Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. of Fort Washington, Pa. Some supplies of the drug, the intramuscular form of gamma globulin, have been diverted for sale to the military because of Persian Gulf buildup, she said Thursday. In addition, the nation's only other maker of the drug stopped selling it in August, Green said. She said she had no information on the severity of the shortfall. Armour has not raised its price because of the situation, she said. Dr. Louis Polish of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said his agency has gotten calls from state officials who have had ``a bit of a problem'' getting intramuscular gamma globulin, but that as far as he knew the states have been able to get what they needed. Doctors use the drug during outbreaks of hepatitis A or measles to keep healthy people from contracting the disease. It is also given as a preventive measure to travelers who plan to go to areas where hepatitis A is common, such as Africa, the Middle East, Asia, and Central and South America. The drug is given by shots into muscle. Another form of gamma globulin, given intravenously for treating some other diseases, is not in short supply.

DOC.HEAD: Chrome-Domed? Flaunt It, Baby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Drain clogged with what once was your hairline? Friends complaining about the reflection off your scalp? Women observing, ``He's awfully cute ... too bad he's losing his hair''? Balderdash. Skin is in, so take pride in your pate, says Richard Sandomir, the anti-hairpiece activist who wrote the book on baldness. ``Bald men are the equal of haired men. I'm tired of people talking to the top of my head, or asking why I don't use minoxidil. Keeping your head natural is the way of the '90s,'' says Sandomir, author of ``Bald Like Me: The Hair-Raising Adventures of Baldman.'' Sandomir, 33, has watched his follicles falling for the past 13 years. But the self-proclaimed ``Baldman'' isn't turning to toupees or rubbing Rogaine on his head. Instead, he's asking his chrome-domed associates to rise up against the haired. Answering the call: some of America's best-known baldies, including weatherman Willard Scott and sports announcer Dick Vitale. ``It's almost like a brotherhood, like people who pass each other on Harleys. It's simpatico,'' Scott says of baldness. ``You're just one of the group. ... Bald people know each other that way.'' Willard, by the way, started balding at the tender age of 20. Vitale started losing his hair at about the same age, and the hyperactive color man couldn't be happier. ``By 30, I was bald big time, baby. But I was sexy. ... Bald is beautiful, baby, bald is sexy. No rugs get on my scalp. It's what I am. I'm a bald, one-eyed wacko,'' says Vitale, who wears a glass eye. This is what Sandomir lives for: the few, the proud, the hairless. Sandomir, born Sept. 4, 1957, started going bald in 1978. By 1985, he was resigned to a world without hair, amen. Sandomir's idols - his princes of pate, his rajahs of recession - are those guys who are bald and boastful. Indeed, he provides an 10-man list of the patron saints of baldness. The honorees include Scott, Vitale, ``Today'' show co-host Joe Garagiola, U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson, ad exec Jerry Della Femina, syndicated columnist Mike Royko, best-selling author Dr. Bernie Siegal, retired NFL great Y.A. Tittle, actor Ken Howard and actor Louis Gossett Jr. Gone but definitely not forgotten: Yul Brynner, ``his Royal Baldness'' and a personal idol. ``The most fully evolved bald man to ever walk the planet, God rest his pate,'' Sandomir says reverently. He goes on to dish the dirt about who's under a rug: Burt Reynolds and Frank Sinatra own about 20 pieces each. Howard Cosell doesn't take care of his. Charlton Heston owns one of the world's most frightening toupees. William Shatner's piece is indiscernible to all but the most practiced eyes. He also met Sy Sperling (who declares in TV ads shown around the country: `I'm not only the president of the Hair Club for Men. I'm a client.'') Sy is a nice guy, Sandomir concedes, but ``he remains an enemy of my people.'' The author did have one unpleasant experience: Telly Savalas, the ``baldo di tutti baldi,'' declined to sit for an interview. The ``Kojak'' star maintained that he's not bald, he just chooses to shave his head. ``Incomprehensible!'' complained Baldman. ``For 25 years now, Telly's been the bald man's bald man. He won't talk about being the shining example of bald saintliness, a beacon for any of us who doubt the manly value of our bare pates.''

DOC.HEAD: Cultures Clash Over Stanford `Domestic Partners' Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs repport.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX1 Nov. 28.
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Velez came to Stanford University seeking a safe place to live openly with her lesbian lover, but a policy expanding the rights of homosexual couples on campus leaves her feeling threatened. Velez and others in the homosexual community fear a backlash, particularly from religious groups. The policy, which began this fall, guarantees unmarried couples the same housing, health care and campus privileges as married couples. ``I'm getting nervous about what's going on,'' said Velez, a graduate student in education. ``What the administration has done is satisfying. But the fundamentalist groups - Islamic and Christian - are creating incredible tension, and they can erupt at any time.'' Stanford's effort to build a tolerant, diverse, body of international students has led to verbal clashes and occasional harassment over attitudes about race, religion and sexual orientation. The latest involves the backlash to the ``domestic partners'' policy. ``I think Stanford is probably one of the best places to be openly gay or lesbian or bisexual, and it's still scary,'' said Susan Mizner, a third-year law student and gay activist. ``It's still got a number of people who I would unabashedly call bigots, and even more people who would prefer not to deal with anyone they know is gay, lesbian or bisexual.'' Two-thirds of the students said in an informal survey they support the new policy. Foreign students, particularly from the Middle East, Asia and Africa, are among the most vocal opponents. Of Stanford's 12,600 graduate and undergraduate students, nearly 2,500 are foreigners. Foreigners comprise about a quarter of the 6,100 graduate-student population, which dominates the married student housing village. University officials say they won't revoke the policy, which allows unwed couples with ``long-term commitments'' to rent low-cost campus apartments, and have ``spouse'' privileges, such as subsidized medical care and access to the libraries and gyms. The policy applies to six couples this term. Officials expect the number to rise to 20 to 30 during the next few years. ``We have a strong belief that what we did was the right thing to do,'' said Norm Robinson, dean of student affairs. ``I think some of the (objections) that are based on religion also reflect quite a high degree of homophobia.'' Stanford's policy is being studied by other schools. Harvard has a non-discrimination housing policy, while several other schools allow unwed couples to live together on a case-by-case basis. The Stanford administration's staunch support brought praise from homosexuals, who now want unwed couples covered by health insurance. ``It is making a big difference in our lives,'' says David Bradfute, a graduate student in biological sciences and member of the Lesbian, Gay & Bisexual Community Center. ``The university is saying, `We'll recognize you. We value you, who you are and the kinds of relationships you get into. No state is recognizing us, the federal government is far from recognizing us, and in many ways we're a target for official discrimination. It means a lot to us in this society.'' Opponents, however, attack the policy on religious, moral and cultural grounds. ``It devalues the sanctity of marriage, and of the family unit, both of which Asians have traditionally taken very seriously,'' said Grace Tan, a chemistry graduate student from Singapore. ``Also, this more open policy is susceptible to abuse by people seeking lower-cost university housing, with all its fringe benefits.'' Abdullah Bature, president of the Stanford Islamic Society, said his group of about 100 students wants university trustees to revoke the policy. ``The Koran says sex relations are allowed only between husband and wife, not between woman and woman, man and man or unmarried man and woman,'' Bature said. ``All the members of my society are fundamentalists,'' he added. ``We cannot change the law of Islam, which does not permit acts of unnatural intercourse. But we are not terrorists. We want to live with everybody in peace.'' Jon Osborne, who lives in student housing with Steve Mims, a senior in electrical engineering, argued homosexuals pay the same tuition as heterosexuals and should have the same rights. ``For years, people said that gays don't really have relationships, that we're promiscuous or that gay relationships don't last very long,'' Osborne said. ``Now when we get together in long-term relationships on campus they say we don't want you next door.''

DOC.HEAD: It's Green Light for Stop Signs, Red for No Parking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The city's fiscal crisis has given a red light to No Parking signs but the Streets Department says Stop signs are still go. ``We have stopped temporarily installing non-safety-related signs and poles,'' Deputy Streets Commissioner John Heany said Wednesday. Inventories of sign poles and of the 12-by-18-inch blanks used for parking signs are dwindling, he said. The department has a purchase order for the blanks and expects to have one for poles in a few days, he said. ``I don't expect to run out,'' he said. The department is still printing signs, he said. Poles are being saved for Stop, Do Not Enter and other traffic-control signs, which are still being installed, Heany said. No Parking, limited-time parking, residential-sticker parking, reserved parking for the handicapped and some loading zone signs are on hold, he said. ``Our first responsibility is to make sure that signs that are necessary for public safety and control of traffic are installed,'' Heany said. ``We have enough materials right now to perform that responsibility.'' The work on hold is prinicipally ordered by the Philadelphia Parking Authority, he said. The authority has 367 outstanding work orders, spokeswoman Linda Miller said. ``It causes confusion for the motorists when they go to park,'' she said. ``There may be missing signs and they don't know what the parking regulations are.'' In turn, that creates a problem for parking enforcement. ``If there's no sign there, they (officers) cannot write the ticket,'' Ms. Miller said. ``And if the ticket is written, it has to be recommended for cancellation.'' The situation arose as the Finance Department put the brakes on spending to try to keep the city from going broke in December. A $375 million note issue collapsed in September amid investor worries about the city's fiscal condition. City officials now hope to float about $300 million in notes with backing from the pension fund, local banks, the state treasury and private investors. Even with the cash infusion, the city projects a $229.5 million deficit during the fiscal year that began July 1 and a $278 million deficit during fiscal 1992. ``Before you get any orders processed, you have to make a case that it's necessary work,'' Heany said.

DOC.HEAD: Stolen Tag Leads to Ticket Torrent
DOC.TEXT: Marjorie Roth stalks Philadelphia's streets with a screwdriver, searching for the stolen license plate that has made her life a nightmare. Last spring, someone stole the expired tag from Roth's 1984 Toyota station wagon and put it on a different car. Since then, the car has been parked illegally all over town, racking up tickets that were charged to Roth. Thirty-four of them in about five months, carrying a total of $1,503 in fines. The car was once cited four times in a single day. It's been ticketed for parking on sidewalks, in front of bus stops and at expired meters. ``I will continue to get tickets because this car has not been found,'' Roth said Wednesday. ``This is going to be an ongoing problem forever.'' At a hearing Dec. 10 before city parking violation officials, Roth will argue that she should not be responsible for the fines because the plate was stolen. In the meantime, she has staked out Market Street, where many of the tickets were issued, and plans to remove the license plate if she spots it. ``It's not a matter of the 34 tickets, it's a matter of this person continuing to get tickets. Which is why I've been stalking him with a screwdriver in my car,'' said Roth, a 51-year-old flight attendant. This week, she got a notice that the car would be booted or towed if cited again. The last ticket was Sept. 13. Because of the gap, Roth hopes the car has already been towed, but she doesn't know for sure. Another theory: ``I thought maybe somebody else stole the plate, and the car it's on is being parked somewhere where it's not getting tickets.''

DOC.HEAD: Blunt Reality of Troop Reductions Hits Home in Germany
DOC.TEXT: For years, walls throughout Germany were spray-painted with graffiti telling U.S. troops to go home. Now that major troop pullouts in the Cold War's aftermath are granting that wish, many Germans are finding out just what the homeward trek will mean for their nation. Thousands of local civilian workers have been picketing U.S. bases, protesting the loss of their jobs and underscoring the impact of the pullout on local economies. Members of the OETV Public Service and Transport Union working for NATO forces based in western Germany held a third day of warning strikes on Wednesday to demand protection from expected layoffs. Germans employed by the military have been jolted by recent announcements of pullouts. The United States plans to send home 40,000 troops. Another blow came in Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney's Nov. 9 announcement that one of two U.S. army corps, or an estimated 100,000 U.S. military personnel in Germany, would be sent to Saudi Arabia to beef up the multinational forces. The union says the reductions mean that up to 23,000 of the 100,000 civilian employees working for the U.S., British and other NATO forces are expected to be laid off in the near future. In the city of Zweibruecken, about 90 miles southwest of Frankfurt, Mayor Werner von Blon says the planned closure of the U.S. Air Force base there will ``badly hurt'' the town of 63,000. About 10,000 service members and their families from the U.S. Army and Air Force live at the base, Blon said, and between 1,600 and 1,700 Germans from the town work for the U.S. military. ``Originally U.S. officials said the base would be closed by 1993. Now that has been suddenly moved up to September 1991. It's too short a time for us to do something to make up for the closure,'' said Blon. He said a military survey showed the base brought in $94.6 million a year to the city. Unlike large cities like Frankfurt, Zweibruecken has no shortage of housing, the mayor said. ``About 600 Americans rent homes on the local economy. It won't be easy for the landlords to find new renters here,'' Blon said. He suggested the U.S. military keep the base and move in troops from crowded cities like Frankfurt and Mannheim. The OETV union said Wednesday that a total of 23,000 civilians working for the U.S. military and other NATO forces held two-hour warning strikes over the past three days at bases throughout the country. The strike would not be continued because the military appeared ready to negotiate, said OETV's deputy chief, Wolfgang Warburg. During the 1980s, when hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets to protest the deployment of U.S.-built Pershing II and Cruise nuclear missiles in Germany, buildings throughout the country often bore the spray-painted slogan ``Ami Go Home.'' Warburg laughed about the old graffiti. ``That is now forgotten,'' he said. He said the union welcomed disarmament but needs time for the workers to find alternative jobs. The union also wants guarantees of retraining for the thousands of civilians who will lose their jobs, he said. He said many of the civilians have worked for the military most of their adult lives. Military officials have said that the strikes have not interfered with their operations of deployment of troops and hardware to the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Jailed Democracy Activist Ill, Wife Appeals for Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The symptoms appeared in the spring - half a dozen lumps about the size of peach pits on the prisoner's neck. After nearly 10 years in jail, democracy activist Xu Wenli shows signs of lymphatic tuberculosis, said his wife, Kang Tong. His sentence runs five more years, but she is appealing to China's leaders to release him early on humanitarian grounds. ``He suffers from malnutrition. Many of his teeth have fallen out,'' she said in an interview this week. ``They shouldn't treat a person this way.'' Xu, 47, is one of China's best-known democracy activists, a precursor of last year's student protesters. His case has been championed by Amnesty International. Kang said the cause of Xu's lumps has not been diagnosed because he refuses to allow the prison doctor to take a blood sample. ``The needles are reused and he is afraid of catching a communicable disease,'' Kang said. But she said the prison doctor prescribed anti-tubercular medicine and a doctor she consulted outside prison agreed that the symptoms could indicate tuberculosis. When Deng Xiaoping became China's paramount leader in 1978 and proposed economic and political reforms, Xu was one of many Chinese who rushed to offer suggestions in magazine articles and posters tacked up on a streetside wall that was dubbed Democracy Wall. Xu, an electrician and army veteran, issued an unofficial journal from his Beijing apartment called ``April Fifth Forum.'' He wrote that a multiparty system and public supervision of the leadership could help avert disastrous policies such as the radical leftism of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. He was arrested in 1981 and convicted of trying to undermine socialism and the Communist Party. Xu maintains his innocence and says he was merely trying to help the party improve itself - a kind of loyal dissent that has a long tradition in imperial China. Kang and their daughter, who is 17, still live in the same apartment. Kang, a slightly built woman whose neatly curled hair is starting to gray, teaches accounting at a vocational high school. She said she also has been ill - doctors diagnosed her as having a non-malignant brain tumor. She said she has learned caution over 10 years of being labeled a ``counterrevolutionary's relative.'' But she said publicizing Xu's illness was one way to bring her plea to the attention of the authorities. Kang acknowledged it could backfire. ``I seem calm but I'm afraid. They might watch us more closely.'' Xu's chances of winning early release are hurt by his refusal to admit guilt. Kang said she won't ask him to. ``He's very earnest,'' she said. During her monthly, 20-minute visit with Xu in October at Beijing's No. 1 Prison, a guard asked Xu if he acknowledged his crime. ``He said: `I committed no crime. I never opposed the party,''' Kang recounted. Admission of guilt is considered extremely important in the Chinese penal system, and an unrepentant prisoner may have his sentence lengthened. Still, Kang is encouraged by improvements in Xu's treatment. Although he remains in solitary confinement, he has been moved from a cell so tiny he could not stand to one that has 9 square feet of walking space. Xu was put in the small cell in 1985 after he smuggled out of prison an essay defending himself. Kang said she was unsure how long he remained there. His diet, like that of other prisoners, has almost no meat and few vegetables. Kang said prison rules set the food budget for each prisoner at $7.11 per month. Some participants of last year's massive pro-democracy protests have been sentenced to long jail terms. Hundreds more remain jailed awaiting trial. But hundreds also have been released, giving Kang hope. ``My argument is this: He never said the Communist Party was not good or that he wanted to hurt the party. There is nothing he can reform. And it's already 10 years,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Could Saddam Survive Without Kuwait?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: With international approval for military force against Iraq increasingly possible, Middle East analysts are focusing on a key question: Could Saddam Hussein stay in power if he loses Kuwait? Publicly, at least, Saddam has insisted that he would fight to the finish rather than relinquish the oil-rich emirate he invaded on Aug. 2. But his private assessment of whether his political career would survive a bloody clash with a U.S.-led force or an ignoble retreat could shape his next steps in the Persian Gulf crisis. The United States says it has gathered enough votes to win approval of a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing a multinational army to oust Iraq from Kuwait. The council was expected to vote on the measure on Thursday. Saddam ``hasn't given any clear signal about what his intentions are,'' said Richard Murphy, a former U.S. assistant secretary of state and now senior fellow for the Middle East at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. ``The best we have is that the Soviets indicated he is not as adamant about holding onto Kuwait in private as he is in public,'' Murphy said. He said Saddam has been faced with two questions: How determined is the United States to dislodge him from Kuwait? And can he ``survive a war better than he can survive a peaceful withdrawal?'' ``It would be extremely difficult for Saddam to maintain his grip on power'' if he reverses course on Kuwait, said analyst Philip Robins of London's Royal Institute of International Affairs. Robins noted that Saddam conceded to Iranian peace demands not long after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Part of the deal, seen as a move to free his eastern front and restore ties with his Moslem neighbor, was sharing the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, once Iraq's only outlet to the sea. Kuwait, which he has declared Iraq's 19th province, provides Saddam with a port. ``If he loses that as well, that would be a major foreign policy reverse,'' Robins said. But most analysts agree that Saddam's chances of survival are greater if he gives ground without war. He has few worries when it comes to public opinion in Iraq or opposition from the country's rubber-stamp parliament. ``Personally, I think he can survive,'' said Murphy. Saddam has survived several assassination attempts and at least seven attempted coups since he took power in 1979. He has no serious rival and no obvious heir has emerged. Those known nationally owe their positions to their loyalty to him. Religious figures appeal only to their own constituencies, Robins said. Saddam regularly purges his officer corps to prevent moves against him, and has been careful to ensure that military heroes are eliminated, at least from positions of strength. ``My judgment on the army is that he has a pretty firm hand on the high-command level, the senior officers,'' said Bernard Trainor, a former U.S. Marine general with knowledge of the Iraqi military. ``Senior officers are totally under control either out of fear, or devotion, or both,'' said Trainor, now head of the national security program at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. Trainor added, however, that there could be a considerable threat from the elite Republican Guard and other sections of the military if an overwhelming air strike inflicted heavy casualties on Iraqi forces in Kuwait and damaged the military and industrial infrastructure. ``If these forces feel they're on the way to national suicide, there would be some inclination to remove Saddam,'' Trainor said. Most foreign envoys who have traveled to Baghdad have told Saddam that the multinational force will be used against him. Some 230,000 U.S. troops make up the bulk of the 300,000-strong force, and President Bush says 200,000 more U.S. troops will be in place by January. What position Iraq will take after the U.N. Security Council votes on the use-of-force resolution vote is uncertain. ``Only Saddam Hussein can give the answer to that, and I'm not sure even he knows it,'' Trainor said.

DOC.HEAD: Guardsmen Worry About Families, Prepare to Report Friday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dwan Cantrell is cq.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tears ran down Dwan Cantrell's cheeks as she talked about the chance her father may have to fight a war thousands of miles from the fish ponds, peanut fields and pine forests of southern Georgia. ``I don't want him to go,'' said the 12-year-old daughter of Staff Sgt. Tommy Cantrell, a National Guard infantry squad leader. ``I'm afraid he might get hurt.'' Cantrell's unit is a part of the Georgia Army National Guard's 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized), the nation's first combat reserve unit called to active duty for possible deployment in the Persian Gulf crisis. The brigade's 4,000 soldiers will report at armories around the state on Friday and will leave for Fort Stewart in eastern Georgia on Monday. After a few weeks of training, they will go to Fort Irwin, Calif., for intensive desert training. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the 48th and two other National Guard combat brigades, from Mississippi and Louisiana, will be evaluated at Fort Irwin before a decision is made on whether to send them to the Middle East. Cantrell, a divorced single parent, sees the call-up as a patriotic duty but worries about his daughter and has made provisions for her care in his will. His daughter will stay with relatives while he is away. ``I've been having knots in my stomach and it's hard to sleep,'' Cantrell said. ``But I figure if my time is up, I'd rather go in the service of my country than in a traffic accident.'' Family concerns are common in Cantrell's unit, but his commanding officer, Capt. Paul Joiner, an Albany bank branch manager, said morale is the highest he's ever seen. Members of the unit include college students, police officers, firefighters, a high school principal, a newly elected school board member, mechanics and civil service workers. ``You can't find a more dedicated group of men,'' Joiner said. ``I don't have any doubt that whatever mission we're given, they'll accomplish that mission.'' Some Guard members and their families attended a three-hour briefing Wednesday night at the Albany armory. The speakers included psychologist Nick Carden, who discussed the emotional impact of the mobilization. Carden said some relativesmay need therapy to overcome anxiety and depression. Phoebe-Putney Memorial Hospital is sponsoring a support group for relatives and offering private counseling. The psychologist also has trained more than 100 children to provide peer counseling in school. Sgt. 1st Class Terry Cosper, a family assistance counselor, said many parents of young Guard members are terrified. ``The parents, especially the mothers, get all teared up,'' he said. ``The mothers lived through Vietnam. It's a flashback to the '60s and it scares them.'' Spc. William Stephens, 33, a communications specialist, said it will be tough for him to leave because his wife, Dollie Mae, needs help and support following the birth of the couple's third child on Nov. 21. ``She doesn't want me to go,'' he said. ``But I can't help it because I signed the papers to be there.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Film Director Defamed Far Right Leader
DOC.TEXT: A court has fined film director Constantin Costa-Gavras $10,000 for defaming extreme-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen during a television talk show. The controversial Le Pen sued the Greek-born director of such widely acclaimed political thrillers as ``Missing'' and ``Z'' for remarks he made March 4 during a widely viewed political talk show. Costa-Gavras discussed Le Pen's past, his personal life and his wealth based on allegations that had led to fines in the past for others. Le Pen sued both the director and the show's host, Anne Sinclair, saying she immediately should have forced her guest to temper his remarks. Presiding Judge Huguette Le Foyer de Costil ruled Wednesday that Ms. Sinclair could not place controls on her guests, saying this would amount to an attack on the freedom of expression. Le Pen, president of the anti-immigration National Front, has himself lost numerous defamation suits and, notably, has been fined for racist and anti-semitic remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Antarctic Climbers to `Warm up' in Freezer
DOC.TEXT: Brigitte Muir is cooling off to warm up for a planned assault on Antartica's tallest mountain. Mrs. Muir, 32, who hopes to become the first woman to climb the highest peaks on each of the world's seven continents, plans to spend 40 hours with her four-man support crew plan at 22 below zero temperatures in a fish market freezer starting Saturday afternoon. ``The freezer will simulate Antarctic conditions for my support team as we prepare to climb Mount Vinson, which at 5,140 meters (16,863 feet) is Antarctica's highest mountain,'' she said Wednesday. Since reaching the summit of Mt. McKinley, North America's tallest mountain, in 1988, Mrs. Muir has conquered Mt. Kilimanjaro (Africa), Mt. Aconcagua (South America), Mt. Kosciusko (Australia) and Mt. Elbrus (Europe). ``After climbing Mount Vinson, I will then tackle the big one - Mt. Everest,'' she said. ``An American woman has already climbed all but Mt. Everest, so I've got to do Mt. Vinson this year and Mt. Everest early next year, so I can take the record before her.'' Joining her in the freezer will be her husband, cameraman John Muir; freelance photographer and writer Jonathan Chester, cameraman Glenn Singleman and sound recorder Michael Gatehouse.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Organist Pulls Out All the Stops for Garbo and Chaplin
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Silent movies disappeared more than 70 years ago, but nobody has bothered to tell theater organist Ray Brubacher. The plump, rosy-cheeked Brubacher has performed as a ``one-man orchestra'' for screenings of silent film classics at the American Film Institute Theater in the Kennedy Center for the past two decades. ``I'm never at a loss for music,'' says Brubacher, a master of improvisation who can play for hours at a stretch without following a score. Whether he's setting the syrupy mood for a wordless Greta Garbo embrace, or creating musical chaos for a Keystone Kops chase scene, Brubacher pulls out all the stops. Until the silent film era was doomed in 1927 when Al Jolson spoke a few lines in ``The Jazz Singer,'' even the smallest towns boasted a movie theater with a pipe organ for musical accompaniment, with somebody like Ray Brubacher at the console. Today, says Brubacher, there are only four theater organists left in the United States. Three of them travel the country giving occasional organ recitals and playing at silent film festivals. Brubacher says he's the only surviving resident organist at a movie theater. Growing up in Washington, Brubacher began a ``lifetime fascination'' with pipe organs at age 6 at his mother's church. As a teen-ager, he improvised piano music for 8 millimeter reels of silent films he had bought with his allowance. He thrilled to the sounds of the mighty Wurlitzer at the Capitol Theater in downtown Washington. The Capitol stopped presenting stage shows along with its movies in the mid-1950s, and the Wurlitzer fell silent. The theater was demolished in 1963. Many theater organs across the country were sold to private collectors. Brubacher earns his living giving piano and organ lessons at his suburban Maryland home. He is the proud owner of a 1,139-pipe Aeolian concert organ that once belonged to composer Sigmund Romberg. When the AFI Theater opened 20 years ago, Brubacher signed on as organist. His first assignment was playing impromptu music for ``Broken Blossoms,'' a 1919 film by D.W. Griffith starring Lillian Gish. Brubacher, 50, says he's provided organ accompaniment for more than 1,000 silent films over the past 20 years, from Charlie Chaplin comedies to a Greta Garbo festival to a series of obscure Soviet propaganda films about collective farms. ``It was tough coming up with my International Harvester music for all those tractors,'' he said. His most demanding performance was supplying six hours of organ music for a revival of Abel Gance's 1925 film, ``Napoleon.'' Most of French composer Arthur Honegger's original score had been lost, but Brubacher found photocopies of 35 pages and improvised the rest with snatches of period French military and folk music. Because its limited space cannot accommodate a theater pipe organ, the AFI Theater uses a Conn electronic organ. But Brubacher says he can manipulate its 50 stops to produce just about any effect he wants, from a symphony orchestra to the rat-a-tat of a machine gun or the hissing of a steam locomotive. Brubacher prefers to keep his eyes on the screen rather than burying his nose in a musical score, so he won't miss any of the action. And he says it's more difficult to play for a Buster Keaton or Harold Lloyd comedy than for a heavy, dramatic film. ``The love scenes are much easier because I can weave in a lot of classical themes,'' he said. ``But the comedies, all those pratfalls and chases and custard pies in the face, there's just so much funny stuff you can play before it gets boring.''

DOC.HEAD: Texans Hope to Find Ways to Profit From a Pest
DOC.TEXT: A Texas congressman who represents more mesquite trees than people has persuaded Congress that the stubborn and spindly pest has profit potential. The thorny tree, which defies bulldozers and herbicides and soaks up scarce ground water, has long been the bane of ranchers across the Southwest. Rep. Kika de la Garza, however, believes a cash crop could be wrestled out of the dense thickets of mesquite that have taken over millions of acres of Texas farm and rangeland. Under legislation sponsored by de la Garza and included in the 1990 farm bill, the Agriculture Department is to conduct a research program to develop better production methods and commercial uses for mesquite. The bill, signed into law Wednesday by President Bush, also authorizes $500,000 over five years in research grants to develop ways of producing mesquite for use in flooring, furniture or other items, and to improve production and harvesting techniques. Mesquite is so abundant, however, that some Texas and ranchers are happy just to give it away. ``The raw material is virtually unlimited with 55 million acres of mesquite timber in the state, of which only about 10,000 cres are now commercially exploited,'' according to the Texas Department of Agriculture. ``As many as 4,500 trees can grow on an acre of pasture, which means that there could be as many as 2.5 billion mesquite trees in the state,'' the state agriculture department said in a recent report. While mesquite chips are popular for grilling, the demand hasn't made a dent in the supply, according to Herman Mayeux, range scientist for the USDA Agricultural Research Service's grasslands, soil and water research laboratory in Temple. Some ranchers are getting about $10 a cord, or $50 an acre, for cooking-wood mesquite. In other parts of Texas they're not getting a penny and ``they're just glad to get rid of it,'' Mayeux said. While mesquite has been used in flooring and furniture in some of Texas' major ranch houses, museums and even the U.S. Embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, it hasn't been widely used for furniture and flooring, officials said. Mesquite is described as a beautiful wood, with a striking, swirling grain, but using it for furniture and flooring is difficult because the logs are short, small and crooked, Mayeux said. ``The problem is that no one has been able to envision a use although they've thought about it and thought about it,'' he said. ``It's difficult to envision a use, envision a product that would be highly desirable in large quantities.'' ``We have the crop, we have to figure out a way to make it useful,'' says Peter Felker, who has been studying mesquite since 1977. ``Mesquite has a lot of potential domestically and internationally.'' Felker, project leader for semi-arid forest resources at Texas A&I University in Kingsville, is looking at ways of improving harvesting techniques to produce larger logs. He's also working with sawyers to mill the lumber for use in furniture, picture frames and flooring. The problem, he says, is that there's no forest industry in south Texas, home of much of the mesquite. ``We're trying to create the industry and develop a market for it,'' he said. ``The very characteristics that make the mesquite a bane to the farmer and rancher also make the trees attractive for development as an alternative timber crop,'' the Texas Agriculture Department said. The wood is excellent as a cooking fuel for meats and fish and is increasing in popularity as an ornamental tree. Felker also is interested in developing a harvester to harvest the wood to burn as fuel, as well as developing a marketing plan touting mesquite and beef. The most profitable use, however, would be expanding the furniture and flooring market. Mesquite sold for fuel is worth $25 a ton; as mesquite chips it's worth $300 a ton; and as flooring and furniture, $3,000 a ton, he said.

DOC.HEAD: One in 500 U.S. College Students Infected with AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: The first nationwide survey of AIDS at colleges shows that the virus has gained a small by worrisome foothold on America's campuses, infecting about one in every 500 students. Based on this and other data, the federal Centers for Disease Control estimates that between 25,000 and 35,000 of the nation's 13 million college students are infected with the AIDS virus. That makes AIDS about as common on university campuses as it is elsewhere in American life, the study shows. ``This is both good news and bad news,'' said Leighton Ku, a public health specialist at the Urban Institute in Washington. ``It's good that it's not sky-high, as some might have feared. But it's bad that it's there at all.'' While its presence among college students is still small, experts fear AIDS could spread substantially. ``I think probably the most important thing from this study is that it shows us the potential,'' said Dr. Richard P. Keeling of the American College Health Association, a co-author. ``The combination of a sexually transmitted disease tossed into campus behavior has the potential for very serious consequences in the future. It also shows us we have an opportunity to prevent that.'' The study was based on random testing of blood samples drawn from 16,863 students at 19 schools, most of them large state universities. Thirty students -or two-tenths of 1 percent of the total - were found to be infected. All but two were men. Among other results of the study, published in today's New England Journal of Medicine: -The infection rate was half of 1 percent for men and two-hundredths of 1 percent in women. -Those over age 24 were seven times more likely than younger students to be infected. -At 10 of the 19 campuses, the survey turned up no AIDS infections. Keeling said the study underscores the need for students to use condoms, limit their number of sexual partners and otherwise reduce risky behavior. Keeling, who also runs the student health service at the University of Virginia, said many students believe AIDS won't affect them. Other factors that may increase its spread include widespread casual sex among college students, a lack of safe sex practices and the frequent combination of sex while drinking, which makes people less cautious. However, Ku participated in a recent study that found that condom use among teen-agers has doubled over the past decade. ``Young people are aware of AIDS and are doing things to prevent AIDS,'' Ku said. Dr. Steven Weinstein of the University of Massachusetts Medical Center recommended more intensive programs by colleges to change students' behavior and attitudes toward sex, drugs and alcohol. ``We want to create a new milieu on campus, where safer sex is the in thing, and it is unacceptable to be blitzed out of your mind,'' he said. The blood samples analyzed had been drawn for other purposes at student health centers. Even though the researchers promised not to reveal AIDS rates at individual campuses, Keeling said many schools refused to participate because they feared being labeled as ``an AIDS college.'' Taking part in the survey were Central Missouri State University, Emory University, Mississippi State University, Northwestern University, Rutgers University, San Diego State University, Southern Illinois University, University of California at Berkeley, University of Colorado, University of Connecticut at Storrs, University of Georgia, University of Kansas, University of Maryland at Baltimore County, University of Maryland at College Park, University of Massachusetts at Amherst, University of New Hampshire, University of Southern California, University of Texas at Austin and the University of Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Floating Fun: Pentagon Seeks Cruise Ships for Gulf R&R
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is looking for a few good ships - complete with swimming pools, bars and enough beds to sleep at least 600 troops. In a new twist to its efforts to provide recreation to the thousands of troops deployed in and around Saudi Arabia, the military hopes to hire cruise ships as floating R&R spots, and wants to get them dockside in the region by year's end. Tuesday was the deadline for sending bids to the Defense Department's Military Sealift Command, and shipping industry officials say a number of proposals were submitted. A military spokeswoman confirmed that much, but said she could not provide additional details until she received clearance from the Pentagon's Central Command, which is in charge of U.S. forces in the Middle East. Alcohol is illegal in Saudi Arabia and rowdy music and dancing is frowned upon in the Islamic culture as well, leaving the military with few local options for R&R. And none of the neighboring countries that allows drinking and reveling is willing or able to serve thousands of airmen, soldiers and sailors, most of whom would be getting their first break in months. Owners of ships that would meet the Pentagon's specifications also are a bit wary of taking on the job, according to industry officials. An official of a consulting firm serving as an intermediary for several steamship companies that explored the Pentagon proposal said he knew of several proposals submitted by the Tuesday deadline and had spoken with other brokers who said they submitted bids as well. ``The interest has been varied because there could be some risks,'' said the official, who spoke on condition that neither he nor his company be identified. ``The owners are also concerned about the wear and tear on ships and also about taking them out of the itinerary for future cruise service. So it's not likely that many of the modern ships are going to be looking for this type of job,'' the official said. The commander of U.S. forces in the region, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said in September that chartering cruise ships would allow troops to ``relax and dance and have music and air conditioning and swimming pools and just sort of live it up.'' The Pentagon's request for bids said the ships should be able to hold at least 600 passengers, provide full hotel services, including food, bar service and entertainment, and have English-speaking crews. The specifications said priority would be given to vessels flying the U.S. flag, but that bids would be accepted from ships registered elsewhere. Most major cruise liners are of foreign registry. The Pentagon said it wanted to get ships to Bahrain by mid-December and would charter them for periods of up to six months. Bahrain is an island emirate in the Persian Gulf connected to Saudi Arabia by a 12-mile causeway. The Pentagon has ships and aircraft stationed in Bahrain as part of its deployment in the gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Rebuffs U.S. Bid to Back U.N. Resolution on Eve of Vote
LaserPhoto BEJ2, DHA1,WX11
DOC.TEXT: The United States held its highest-level meeting with Cuba in more than 30 years on Wednesday night but failed to win its backing for a proposed U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Earlier Wednesday, on the eve of a vote by foreign ministers on the measure, China's top envoy, Qian Qichen, said his country would not back the resolution either. China is one of the five permanent members of the Security Council and could veto the measure. But at the United Nations, diplomats said they didn't expect such a move and predicted the resolution would pass. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Qian in New York early Thursday, part of a last-minute lobbying effort before the planned Thursday afternoon vote. Both men refused to answer questions before their talk, which began shortly before midnight at Baker's hotel suite in midtown New York. The United States is asking the Security Council to approve force against Iraq if its 450,000 troops do not quit Kuwait by Jan. 15. Baker met earlier with another holdout, Cuban Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca, who said he found the draft resolution's text ``not acceptable.'' China wants Washington to lift economic sanctions imposed following the June 1989 military crackdown that crushed China's pro-democracy movement. Former heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali was expected to leave the Iraqi capital on Saturday with at least 14 American hostages, said a spokesman for Ali. Ali met Saddam for 50 minutes on Tuesday after traveling to Baghdad at the invitation of the Iraqi government. Iraq has kept hundreds of foreigners from leaving since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But it allowed some to leave this month with visiting politicians, prominent figures and peace groups. Three former U.S. hostages left Iraq Tuesday after relatives went to Baghdad to plead their case. John Stevenson, 44, of Panama City, Fla., a computer specialist who was in Kuwait for 11 years, flew into New York late Wednesday. The two other former captives, Clyde Jesse of Buffalo Grove, Ill., and Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash., arrived Wednesday at a military medical center at Wiesbaden, Germany, for physical examinations, a U.S. Army spokesman said. Roland Dumas, the foreign minister of France, issued a ``final appeal'' to Iraq to pull out of Kuwait, warning that Baghdad had six weeks to ``allow reason to triumph.'' President Bush has gathered support abroad for military action, but he faces trouble in Congress. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Wednesday he did not support use of force against Iraq any time soon - even U.N.-authorized force. Appeals for peace also came from Baghdad. Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, urged Bush to open talks on the Persian Gulf crisis, although he did not offer concessions regarding Kuwait. Baker asked that foreign ministers represent their countries at Thursday's Security Council vote. Before leaving Beijing on Wednesday, China's Qian said his country would not back the use-of-force resolution. U.N. diplomats were divided over whether China would abstain, or eventually vote in favor after wringing political concessions out of Washington. ``It seems rather clear that they're not thinking of vetoing,'' said British Ambassador David Hannay. Oil prices were stable Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with many traders waiting for the Security Council vote. In Washington, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said soaring oil prices are in part responsible for substantially weakening the American economy. He said economic growth probably would be negative in the October-December quarter. Gephardt said Washington should stick to sanctions. ``Stay the course. ... Do not try to mount an offensive military action in the near future,'' the Missouri Democrat said in a speech. Iraq's Ramadan said Bush ``is leading the entire world to a ruinous war'' and ``has no choice other than to come to his senses and initiate a dialogue.'' About 230,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of the 330,000-strong multinational force arrayed against Iraq. Iraq holds hundreds of Westerners as human shields at key military and civilian installations. Washington has condemned Saddam's sporadic releases of hostages as aimed at dividing the alliance against Iraq. In hostage developments Wednesday: -The official Iraqi News Agency said Saddam Hussein had directed Parliament to discuss the status of the 30 Belgian hostages, the procedure used in the past for freeing French, Bulgarians, Swedes, Swiss and others. -Canadian member of Parliament Robert Corbett, said in Baghdad that six of the 47 Canadians held in Iraq and Kuwait would be allowed to leave Thursday. -An Iraqi Foreign Ministry spokesman denied Soviets were being held like other Westerners in Iraq. He said they would be allowed to leave once their work contracts were up. More than 8,000 Soviets were in Iraq and Kuwait before Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Fewer than half that number remain.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Rejects Appeal to Support U.N. Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf `He arranged...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Baker-Qian meeting. Pickup 20th graf `China, one...'
DOC.TEXT: Cuba on Wednesday rejected a U.S. appeal that it support a resolution in the United Nations authorizing the use of force to liberate Kuwait from Iraqi invaders. ``The text that we have before us in not acceptable,'' Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca said after a 90-minute evening meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The meeting was the highest-level U.S.-Cuban formal session in more than 30 years. Baker was trying to line up a unanimous vote Thursday in the Security Council to approve force against Iraq if its 450,000 troops do not pull out by Jan. 15. Malmierca told reporters, ``We are confident that these consultations could bring modifications to that text so that it could be accepted.'' But a senior U.S. official, speaking on conditioan of anonymity, said no such consultations were under way. He said the Cuban was simply expressing his own hopes. Baker's meeting with Malmierca in a midtown hotel completes a cycle. Baker has now met with all 14 nations that are on the Council with the United States. Malmierca commented Wednesday night as he was going into his talks with Baker, ``We (Cuba) want to contribute to a political solution in the gulf.'' At this point, he said, ``We don't construe the resolution contributing to such a solution.'' Cuba also is a member of the Security Council. It does not have full diplomatic relations with the United States. Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz met briefly and informally with Malmierca in New York two years ago at the conclusion of negotiations to remove Cuban troops from Angola. There also was a secret, unofficial 1981 meeting in Mexico between Secretary of State Alexander Haig and the Cuban vice president. But State Department officials said Baker's meeting with the foreign minister was of a formal nature - it is believed to be the highest-level session with a Cuban official since then-Vice President Richard M. Nixon met with Cuban leader Fidel Castro in 1959. The United States and Cuba have carried on a number of contacts, many through third-party intermediaries. Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt, a close aide to Baker, met with Cuban officials here on Sunday. Cuba has opposed a series of U.S.-sponsored resolutions designed to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which it seized on Aug. 2. A vote on the possible use of force against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is expected on Thursday, when Baker presides over the 15-nation Security Council. The administration is believed to have a clear majority for passage. But to give the resolution the greatest force, Baker wanted to persuade Malmierca to back military action too. Baker flew here from Washington and met first with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at the Soviet Mission. He met at midnight with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen. Asked if he had China's support, Baker declined to reply. Qian also refused to answer questions before the meeting began. China, one of the five permanent members of the Security Council, has said it won't back the measure, although U.S. officials have said Beijing has notified Washington it will not veto the resolution. The Chinese government has said it is against the use of force, which leaves open the possibility of abstention. Shevardnadze, meanwhile, told reporters: ``We want to prevent a military clash. That would be the worst possibility.'' He said he expected ``a positive vote'' on the U.S. resolution to authorize force, which has Soviet support. Baker struck a compromise with Shevardnadze earlier in the week, delaying the deadline on Iraq from Jan. 1 to Jan. 15, in part to allow mre time for conciliatory actions.

DOC.HEAD: Ballet Hispanico Begins 20th Anniversary Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Ballet Hispanico is beginning the celebration of its 20th anniversary season with a two-week season at the Joyce Theater and two new, very exciting dances. George Faison, whose choreography includes Broadway's ``The Wiz,'' created ``Cafe America,'' which had its premiere on opening night, Tuesday. We saw it Wednesday. The music consisted of recordings sung in Spanish, Ruben Blades' ``Patria'' and ``Buscando America'' and popular Latin songs including ``Amapola'' and ``Adios'' by Julio Iglesias. Jose Costas, Pedro Ruiz and Eduardo Vilaro danced, in front of a green Volkswagen `bug.' They used ballet gestures but sometimes conveyed in modern dance terms frustration, anger and feelings of being threatened. Faison touched very quickly on those emotions and later on an argument, without developing them. A voice said, ``This is the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. You are in violation...'' But the three changed from jumpsuits to sharp, bright suits and did a dance in Broadway style, adding Latin-style hip shaking. Then they began crossing their ankles before they spun around, which looked even more Latin. When Iglesias sang, they danced with big, sweeping gestures and romantic glides, often miming dancing with women. They ended wearing the jumpsuits, sitting near the car, conveying that the bright-suit part might have been a dream of American life. ``Stages,'' which also had its premiere on Tuesday, was choreographed by Graciela Daniele, who currently is represented on Broadway with ``Once on This Island.'' It is dedicated to Tina Ramirez, who came to the United States from Venezuela at 7, danced and in 1970 founded Ballet Hispanico and its school here. ``Stages'' refers to the parts of a dancer's career, starting with young Jorgelina Sabez at a piano, dreaming of being part of the eight dancers who come on stage carrying, and using, two practice barres. James Kowal played the music commissioned from him for ``Stages,'' on piano, in front of the stage. In the second part, the dancer, now played by Nancy Turano as a ballerina, and Pedro Ruiz are taught a pas de deux by an imperious Jose Costas. Costas steals her heart, looks at his watch and leaves, breaking her heart. Then 11 of the 14-member company dance, dressed in colorful peasant garb to lively Latin rhythms. Finally, Turano is the choreographer, instructing a fantastic flamenco. And at the last Turano melts away and Tina Ramirez is instructing. She goes to the piano, plays and is joined by the little dance-struck girl she once was. The evening ended with ``Inez de Castro'' about intrigue at the Portuguese court, choreographed in 1988 by Vicente Nebrada, artistic director of the National Ballet of Caracas.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Disabled Children to be Newly Eligible For Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of poor and disabled children will become eligible for government benefits under a $2.5 billion Bush administration plan completed this week. The plan required by a Supreme Court ruling nine months ago would bring Supplemental Security Income benefits to additional youngsters with severe physical and mental disabilities. Administration officials say as many as 37,000 children would become eligible annually. The expansion results from a court-ordered broadening of the way disability applications are evaluated. More than 310,000 needy, disabled children currently receive SSI benefits averaging $387 per month. About half the applicants qualify, but officials expect that figure to rise to as high as 65 percent under the new plan. The Social Security Administration this week sent the 200-page plan to Philadelphia attorneys who have filed suit, asking eligibility for thousands of disabled children. Jonathan Stein, one of the attorneys, expressed hope the plan put an end to cases such as one involving Jennifer Cox, a second-grader from Iowa City. She has twice been denied benefits despite kidney, bowel and bladder problems and a lack of peripheral vision, said Virginia Stratton, aide to Rep. David Nagle, D-Iowa. ``What is this for, if not to help people like this?'' Stratton said. The Supreme Court on Feb. 20, in a 7-2 decision, voided a regulation under fire as unfair to children. It denied benefits to youngsters not suffering from specific ailments named on a government list. Looser standards applied to adults. For example, if they were judged unable to work they became eligible. The new plan will enable authorities deciding whether to grant benefits to consider the impact of disability on the daily lives of the youngsters. Since the decision, the administration has been using a temporary standard under which each child's abilities must be assessed. SSA officials said Wednesday that the changes, subject to a public comment period, could cost $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion over the next five years. The court decision also means the government must re-evaluate the cases of at least 280,000 children rejected under the old criteria. SSA estimates that could cost an additional $3 billion. Backers of the plan are pushing the administration to move faster. They note officials have yet to begin hunting for youngsters rejected earlier. Stein questioned the administration's commitment to securing the money to get moving with the plan. ``We are very surprised that no effort has been made ... to seek a supplemental appropriation from Congress,'' Stein said. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said the administration had adopted ``a minimalist response'' to the public's interest in the case. ``The law says poor, disabled children are entitled to public support,'' Heinz said. ``It is not the prerogative of the administration to decide a congressionally mandated program is `too expensive' and stall on implementation in the interest of savings.'' Social Security Administration Commissioner Gwendolyn King, however, said she was ``committed to turning this around.'' ``We have to start somewhere,'' she said. ``I would start by asking for anywhere from $100 million to $125 million. There isn't an obstacle that should hold us back from doing what we have to do. These kids have already waited more than enough time.''

DOC.HEAD: Winter Forecast: Bad News for the East
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Californians hoping for an end to their drought will find scant comfort in the government's new winter forecast, which gives them only a 50-50 chance of a wet winter. And the news is even worse for the energy-dependent East, with the National Weather Service calling for colder than normal conditions over the next 90 days. Winter is the rainy season for the West Coast and the mountain snowpack there provides much of the water for the rest of the year. Californians have been hoping for a snowy winter to break drought conditions going back three to four years. But Dr. Robert Livezey of the federal Climate Analysis Center reported Wednesday that the conditions seem likely to produce a stationary high pressure area over California and the Southwest. When such centers form they can block incoming moisture from the Pacific Ocean, he explained. On the other hand, if the center weakens storms could come ashore - hence California's 50 percent chance of wet or dry winter weather. The colder than normal forecast for the East could cause problems if oil supplies become short because of the Middle East crisis, but Livezey declined to discuss the potential energy impact. He did point out that a forecast for colder than normal weather implies an average of a degree or two below the usual readings. But that could occur as periods of severe cold rather than being cooler on average, he noted. The general forecast for the three winter months calls for cold east of the Mississippi, with the region of highest likelihood focused along the Appalachian Mountains in West Virginia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Virginia and North Carolina. California and Arizona have the greatest chance of above normal readings, and a broad strip running north-south through the center of the country has equal chances of warmer or colder than normal conditions. Livezey said there is a potential for wetter than normal weather easing droughts in the Southeast and in Oregon. The wetter than average conditions are forecast for the Gulf Coast and Southeast in general and for Washington and Oregon. A drier than usual region is expected in the central part of the nation, extending south and west to New Mexico and Arizona. In addition to California, there is a 50-50 chance of being either wet or dry in New England and the Middle Atlantic region. Livezey explained that a warm region in the central Pacific Ocean is expected to increase the looping effect of the jet stream, the high-speed upper air current that helps guide weather patterns around the world. That should result in storms moving north into Washington and Oregon from the Pacific, and pulling warm air north into the Southwest. This wind then is likely to turn back to the south in the nation's midsection, pulling cold Canadian air into the eastern states. Livezey noted that last year's forecast for a warmer than normal winter in the East came to pass despite near record cold in December. Overall, long-term climate forecasts tend to be fairly accurate in the East and West, with less skill in the high plains and Rocky Mountains, said Livezey.

DOC.HEAD: Children Encouraged to Study and Chew Gum at the Same Time
DOC.TEXT: Chewing gum in school is not just OK around here. It's required. Some 4,000 elementary school students in Polk County will take part in a two-year study on sugarless gum and cavities. ``We're certainly not going to have to fight to get kids to do this,'' said Stephen White, principal of Hillcrest Elementary School in Lake Wales, one of 13 Polk County schools participating in the University of Florida study. The schools' teachers, who have been telling students for years to ``spit out that gum,'' agreed to the study after a presentation Tuesday by Anthony J. Conti, a professor of dentistry. Research has shown that sugarless gum prevents tooth decay in children by reducing plaque, Conti said. The study will compare two sugar substitutes used in gum, sorbitol and xylitol. Starting next week, the students will be required to chew gum for 10 minutes each day at school, as well as at home. Participants will receive toothbrushes and annual dental checkups at no cost to parents. The university also will donate $325,000 to the schools and the school district's scholarship fund, Conti said. The students are good test subjects because drinking water in the central Florida county lacks fluoride, which also prevents cavities, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Farm Prices Seen Slowing Rise in Consumer Food Costs
DOC.TEXT: Lower farm prices for major commodities such as milk, eggs and poultry will be a big factor in slowing the 1991 rise in consumer food costs, says an Agriculture Department economist. ``Larger supplies of (farm-produced) foods will have a strong influence on food prices in 1991,'' Ralph L. Parlett Jr. told the department's annual outlook conference on Wednesday. ``The farm value of food, that portion of the consumer dollar which goes to farmers, is expected to average nearly 6 percent below 1990,'' he said. Parlett's comments followed the USDA's forecast on Tuesday that consumer food prices in 1991 would climb only 2 percent to 5 percent, compared to a 6 percent gain this year. That 6 percent gain plus an increase of 5.8 percent in 1989 represent the sharpest back-to-back increases since an 8.6 percent jump in 1980 followed by a rise of 7.8 percent in 1981. After that burst, food prices rose mostly at an annual rate of 2 percent to 4 percent - until the last two years. Parlett said farm prices, costs of processing and distribution and consumer demand are the three major factors affecting food prices. And all have played a role this year. ``Farm prices were pushed up in 1990 because of tight supplies of some farm commodities,'' he said. ``Costs beyond the farm gate for processing and distributing food increased about 7 percent, reflecting increased use of inputs and higher input prices.'' Also, consumer demand for food remained relatively strong in the first half of 1990, although Parlett said decreasing real disposable income in the second half has probably dampened that demand. Looking at the new forecast for 1991, Parlett said it involves a number of uncertainties about the general economy and the crisis in the Persian Gulf. But larger supplies of some commodities, including dairy products and poultry, will keep the overall price average from soaring. ``In any case, a slowdown of the economy will have a dampening effect on retail prices,'' he said. ``Declines in personal income weaken consumer demand and reduces inflationary pressure on prices.'' Parlett said higher oil prices ``will have a limited effect on the costs of processing and distributing foods'' next year. Retail prices of beef and pork have been at record levels this year, rising about 7 percent and 14 percent, respectively, from 1989. ``In 1991, beef supplies are expected to remain about level with 1990, but pork supplies are expected to expand slightly,'' Parlett said. ``As a result, prices for red meats in 1991 will not rise nearly as much as in 1990.'' Poultry prices, overall, are forecast to drop next year by as much as 5 percent from 1990. Dairy products, which climbed 9 percent this year, may rise no more than 2 percent in 1991 or even decline by 2 percent. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department urges consumers to think safety when buying mail-order food for the holidays. ``Many consumers mistakenly think that because a meat or poultry product is vacuum packaged, canned or smoked, it doesn't need refrigeration,'' advises Sue Templin of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. ``In fact,'' she said Wednesday, ``most of these products must be refrigerated. Consumers should check the label or ordering information to see if refrigeration is required.'' Templin, who manages the agency's toll-free consumer hotline, said mail-order companies are responsible for shipping perishable meat and poultry products safely, often using frozen gel packs or dry ice and insulated containers to keep products below 40 degrees Fahrenheit during shipment. Food technologist Robert Savage said turkeys, hams and other meats are smoked for flavor, not preservation. Country hams, on the other hand, have a high salt content and are dry. These are safe at room temperature for up to a year if uncooked and unsliced. Also, he said, hard dry sausages or processed cheeses can be kept at room temperatures for four to six weeks if unopened. But some do require refrigeration. Questions about food safety for mail-order gifts may be referred to the department's meat and poultry hotline weekdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST at 1-800-535-4555. In the Washington, D.C., area, call 202-447-3333. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Doc Watson's nose has proved effective in a pilot program to sniff out fruit in the Honolulu post office that is being illegally mailed to the mainland, says the Agriculture Department. Doc Watson is an elite member of the department's Beagle Brigade, a band of dogs put to work some years ago to sniff arriving overseas luggage at U.S. airports to detect illegal fruit, meat and other items that might contain harmful agricultural pests. The U.S. mail is a different challenge. A 1989 federal law prohibits the mailing of forbidden fruit. But USDA officials in Honolulu had to seek criminal warrants to search suspected parcels headed for the mainland. So Doc Watson last May was called in as part of a pilot program to narrow the odds of finding contraband. The department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service said that as of Oct. 31, the beagle had sniffed out 477 illegal parcels of produce. Overall, the take weighed 4,229 pounds and included 177 interceptions of fruit flies, foreign weeds, diseases and other exotic pests. ``Some fruits sniffed out by Doc Watson are small - a few miniature oranges mailed with other goods,'' the agency said. ``Some finds are huge, like a 30-pound jackfruit that outweighed Doc by about 10 pounds.''

DOC.HEAD: Views from a Retired Sailor
With PM-US-Gulf Bjt
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Settling down in the witness stand, the old admiral told the senators that his wife asked him as he was leaving home, ``I thought you were retired. When are we going to actually retire around here?'' Crowe told the Senate Armed Services Committee at hearings Wednesday into the crisis in the Persian Gulf - and the possibilities that America will be drawn into war - that one advantage of being retired is that he is free to speak his mind. Born in Kentucky in 1925, Crowe retired in 1989 as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Reagan. An unusual sailor, he took leave of the Navy to obtain a master's degree in education from Stanford University in 1956 and turned down an invitation from Adm. Hyman Rickover to join his nuclear submarine program so he could earn a Ph.D. in politics at Princeton in 1965. His view of the Iraqi crisis is one of wariness. ``I counsel patience,'' he told the senators. ``War is not neat, it's not tidy, and once you resort to it it's uncertain and it's a mess.'' Some other views from his testimony: ON THE EFFECT OF THE EMBARGO:

``Given the standard of living Iraq is used to and the increasing sophistication of Iraqi society, it is dead wrong to say that Iraq is not being hurt. It is being damaged severely. ... It is the most effective peacetime blockade that I have personally witnessed. ``The issue is not whether an embargo will work, but whether we have the patience to let it take effect. ... ``I personally believe they (sanctions) will bring him to his knees ultimately but I would be the first to admit that is a speculative judgment. ``If, in fact, the sanctions will work in 12 to 18 months instead of six months, the tradeoff of avoiding war with its attendant sacrifices and uncertainties would, in my estimation, be more than worth it.'' ON SADDAM'S OPENNESS TO COMPROMISE:

``I genuinely believe we have already seen some - the first subtle hints that Saddam Hussein is seeking a way out, in other words, a face-saving way to withdraw.'' ON THE PRICE SADDAM IS PAYING: ``Hussein has excited the resentment, contempt and suspicion of the nations he historically depended upon. In essence, under no circumstances can he return to the world he left of August the 2nd. ... The argument that Saddam is winning and being rewarded, I believe is both weird and wrong.'' ON WHAT'S NEXT:

``The burning question now confronting the president as well as our public is, what next. This is not a mean question, nor is it any easy one. In its most extreme form, we are talking about deliberately initiating offensive military operations. In other words, war. War is always a grave decision, and one which deserves both deep thought and wide public discussion. ...'' ON THE MIDEAST AFTER SADDAM:

``Put bluntly, Saddam's departure or any other single act, I'm afraid, will not make everything wonderful. ... Income differences on both national and individual levels are a constant source of tensions and envy throughout the region. ... Moslem fundamentalism is spreading and the process highlights the cultural, religious, and ethic differences that are bound in the area as well as the widespread distrust of the West. Boundary disputes are legion and they've been a part of the region for many years: Qatar vs. Bahrain; Abu Dhabi vs. Oman and Saudi Arabia; Yemen vs. Saudi Arabia; Kuwait vs. Iraq; and many of the Emirates vs. Iran. U.S. links to Israel and the dominant position of American oil companies have turned large segments of the Arab world against the U.S. in particular.'' ON THE LARGER QUESTION: ``The critical foreign policy questions we must ask are not whether Saddam Hussein is a brutal, deceitful - or, as Barbara Bush would put it - a dreadful man; he is all of those things. But whether initiating conflict against Iraq will moderate the larger difficulties in the gulf region and will put Washington in a better position to work with the Arabs - the Arab world in the future is, in my estimation, the more important question. ``I would submit that posturing ourselves to promote stability for the long term is our primary national interest in the Middle East. May I repeat it: that posturing ourselves to promote stability for the long term is our primary national interest in the Middle East. It is not obvious to me that we are currently looking at the crisis in this light. ``Our dislike for Hussein seems to have crowded out many other considerations. In working through the problems myself, I am persuaded that the U.S. initiating hostilities could well exacerbate many of the tensions I have cited and perhaps further polarize the Arab world. Certainly many Arabs would deeply resent a campaign which would necessarily kill large numbers of their Moslem brothers and force them to choose sides between Arab nations and the West.''

DOC.HEAD: With Elections Over, New Lawmakers Learn About Congress
LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.TEXT: There were talks on ethics, how to organize an office, how to watch expenses. But Barbara-Rose Collins had a more practical concern: the cost of housing. ``It's amazing,'' said the Detroit Democrat, one of 44 new House members. ``They expect you to pay $125,000 for a little condo, so little you can touch both walls. ``It looks like the only way you can get a decent-sized house is to spend a quarter of a million dollars,'' she said. ``But my constituents would run me out of office if I did that.'' Wearing blue name tags in the fancy confines of the Cannon Caucus Room, the freshman class of 1990 today wrapped up two days of bipartisan sessions on how to be a member of Congress. Some pledged to seek influential committee posts. Others said they would change the way elections are financed. Many promised to be aggressive within their respective parties. Bernie Sanders, the socialist elected as an independent from Vermont, said voters told him to go to Washington ``and give them hell.'' Veteran Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, urged the new lawmakers not to miss the talk on spouse's perspectives. ``Please take good notes,'' he said. ``Your job will be a lot easier if your spouse is happy.'' New Jersey Democrat Robert Andrews, who won the House seat vacated by Gov. Jim Florio, said he intends to travel frequently between Washington and his state. ``The biggest mistake I think anyone could make here is to think all wisdom flows from here,'' Andrews said. ``The best ideas about government and the country come from outside.''
