Ohio Republican David Hobson said he wasn't prepared when reporters asked him to take a position on the U.S. military's role in the Middle East. ``We haven't had an opportunity to concentrate on meaty issues,'' Hobson said. ``Meaty issues so far have been, `How do I find this room?''' There were no Petersons in the 101st Congress but there will be two, both of them Democrats, in the 102nd. ``We've got a caucus - it's in a phone booth,'' said Pete Peterson of Florida, who was huddling with Colin Peterson of Minnesota near the coffee and danish buffet. Since the Nov. 6 election, Democrat John Cox of Illinois has been thanking his supporters, planning the sale of his law practice and preparing for the move to Washington. A walk past the Capitol, he said, put everything in perspective. ``I remember thinking, `Wow, this is getting very close to the real thing.' I will soon be in a position to be casting votes as one of the congressmen of the United States,'' Cox said. At the ethics briefing, Minnesota Republican Jim Ramstad learned that he'll have to be scrupulous in writing down the gifts he gets at his wedding next summer. The House wants to know how many toasters he receives, or at least gifts worth more than $75. ``I wasn't aware of that limit, but certainly I agree with it,'' Ramstad said. Getting a dose of how he looks in print, New Jersey Democrat Richard Zimmer laughed when he noticed his hair was cropped out of his picture in the freshman directory. ``This is really awful,'' he said. ``... They gave me the opposite of a frontal lobotomy.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Begins Fifth Countdown for Columbia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs with countdown under way. PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Three of ...'
DOC.TEXT: NASA, confident this time will lead to liftoff, began shuttle Columbia's countdown on Thursday for a long-overdue astronomy mission. The countdown clock began ticking - for the fifth time - at 1 a.m. EST. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:28 a.m. EST Sunday. Three of the four previous countdowns were halted during fueling by leaking hydrogen, most recently in mid-September. Another was stopped because of problems with the $150 million observatory aboard the shuttle. As of Wednesday, everything was going smoothly, said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of Columbi''s prelaunch operations. ``Columbia's really behaving. Everything looks real good,'' Murrah said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been trying since late May to launch Columbia with seven astronauts and the observatory, called Astro. Holes in plumbing between the orbiter and external tank were fixed last summer, but leaks remained in the engine compartment and required additional repairs. Columbia was cleared for flight during a fueling test in October. The shuttle Atlantis also was found to be free of dangerous hydrogen leaks during a tanking test last month. Atlantis returned to Earth last week following a secret military flight. Discovery completed a satellite-delivery mission in October. Few problems were reported on either trip. If Columbia goes up as planned, it will be the first time since 1985 that NASA has launched three shuttles in such quick succession. Murrah said the mood among workers, as a result, is the best it's been in months. ``It feels good. You can see it start to peak. People are happy,'' Murrah said. During Columbia's 10-day flight, the four astronomers aboard will work in shifts to operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope. Some of the hottest objects in the universe will be studied, including a supernova. ``We are doing fewer observations'' than initially planned, said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``But each observation is longer.'' It will be the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. The mission originally was scheduled for 1986 but was delayed when Challenger exploded early that year.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Disputing Administration's Alarm Over Iraqi Nuclear Threat
DOC.TEXT: The White House is vigorously ringing alarm bells about Iraq's nuclear capabilities. But government and congressional experts are questioning the warnings and the evidence on which they are based. President Bush first raised the nuclear specter during a morale-boosting visit with U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia on Thanksgiving Day. Standing within rocket range of Iraqi troops, Bush said Iraq is further along in its nuclear weapons program than was previously thought and that this lends a sense of urgency to the U.S. mission in the Gulf. No one knows for sure when President Saddam Hussein will actually have a bomb, but one thing is certain: ``he has never possessed a weapon that he hasn't used,'' Bush said. Over the next few days, the president's aides amplified the message. But as they talked, other experts questioned the administration's interpretation of intelligence data. The former head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, retired Adm. William Crowe, told Congress Wednesday that ``recent reports of near-term (Iraqi nuclear capability) are not right. They are exaggerated.'' Across town, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters Bush had received briefings from intelligence officials that led him to conclude Iraq had a nuclear capability ``that could come to fruition within months.'' The administration shared this top secret information with some members of the United Nations Security Council, said one official, in an apparent attempt to win votes for a resolution authorizing military force to remove Iraq from Kuwait. When the International Atomic Energy Agency announced this week that its inspectors visited nuclear sites in Iraq but hadn't found any evidence of atomic weapons development, the White House got angry. ``We think the International Atomic Energy Agency is wrong,'' said Fitzwater. ``They see only what Iraq wants them to see. And we disagree - we disagree quite strenuously.'' His comments prompted other officials to point out that the IAEA always inspects only what a host country allows it to. ``The agency has no other pretensions,'' said one official. The president's warnings of urgency on the matter surprised many experts, who had previously predicted Iraq was at least five to 10 years away from having a ready-to-be-delivered nuclear weapon. In public and private, administration officials stressed that they didn't believe Iraq would have a nuclear arsenal in less than three years, and probably closer to five or 10. An intelligence assessment commissioned by the White House following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait did raise a new threat, described as a ``worst case scenario,'' that Iraq could put together a crude nuclear device, said several officials. Such a weapon, probably composed of two tubes of nuclear material that would explode once the tubes were banged together, would be highly inaccurate. But it could cause nuclear fallout of the type induced in a reactor accident, said one expert. Even Defense Secretary Dick Cheney expressed doubts about the effectiveness of such a device. ``It wouldn't be anything you could deliver from an airplane. It wouldn't be anything that would be weaponized,'' he said in a television interview. In the highly unlikely event that Saddam decides to use such a weapon against U.S. forces, said one government expert, he would risk killing as many of his troops as those of the enemy because of his inability to target the weapon precisely. All experts agree Iraq doesn't have the ability to enrich uranium - that is, to turn it into weapons-grade explosives - although it is working hard to obtain the necessary components and know-how. ``If Iraq could import the technology, materials and supplies ... it probably could produce weapons-grade uranium and make crude but destructive nuclear bombs in perhaps five to 10 years,'' said a report by the Congressional Research Service. Cheney said Iraq could seize the enriched uranium it now has - that same material now under IAEA safeguards - and use it for one crude device. But Iraq would need at least 33 pounds of uranium, while the quantity under IAEA inspection is only 27 pounds, said Peter Clausen, a nuclear non-proliferation expert at the Union of Concerned Scientists. An Israeli official agreed with the U.S. assessment that Iraq could assemble a primitive weapon, but wondered whether Saddam would risk the inevitable retaliation by the United States and its allies. ``He would only have a one-shot deal with this one primitive'' weapon, said the official, who spoke only on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Countdown Begins - Again
DOC.TEXT: A confident NASA started the countdown today for its fifth attempt since May to send Columbia on an astronomy mission. The countdown clock began ticking at 1 a.m. EST. Liftoff with a crew of seven is scheduled for 1:28 a.m. Sunday. ``Columbia's really behaving. Everything looks real good,'' said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of Columbia's prelaunch operations. Leaking hydrogen halted three of Columbia's four previous countdowns, most recently in mid-September. Another countdown was stopped because of problems with the $150 million Astro observatory inside the shuttle's cargo bay. After repairs to the shuttle's plumbing, Columbia was cleared for flight during a fueling test in October. Atlantis returned from a secret military flight last week. Discovery completed a satellite-delivery mission in October. If Columbia goes up as planned, it will be the first time since 1985 that NASA has launched three shuttles in such quick succession. Murrah said the mood among workers, as a result, is the best it's been in months. ``It feels good. You can see it start to peak. People are happy,'' he said. During the nine- to 10-day mission, the four astronomers aboard will work in shifts to operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope. The astronomers will study some of the hottest objects in the universe, including a supernova. The observatory will stay in the cargo bay throughout the flight and will be brought back to Earth. Columbia's mission will be the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. The mission originally was scheduled for 1986 but was delayed by the Challenger explosion that year.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Says Kenya Persecuting Opposition
DOC.TEXT: The Kenyan government has detained many of its leading political opponents without trial and some have reported being tortured, Amnesty International charged in a report released today. At least 20 people face trial simply for owning publications critical of the government, the London-based human rights organization said. Amnesty said the government action began four months ago when riot police beat, tear-gassed and killed participants in demonstrations against the one-party rule of President Daniel arap Moi. Police arrested at least 1,500 demonstrators, including politicians, lawyers and journalists during the July protests, it said. ``Some of those arrested since July have reportedly been tortured or ill-treated, and have been held in prisons with no access to medicine or their relatives, poor food and sometimes permanently in solitary confinement,'' the report says. Amnesty said it feared those facing trial could be sentenced to long jail terms. ``Many political prisoners have been sentenced to long prison terms in recent years after they were unlawfully detained, denied lawyers and tortured to make them plead guilty,'' it said. The report says judges in political cases usually fail to investigate reports of torture or illegal detention. It urges the government to release immediately all those arrested in July and anyone jailed ``for peacefully expressing their opinion.'' Amnesty said those arrested in July included Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, both former Cabinet ministers, and Raila Odinga, son of Kenya's former vice-president Oginga Odinga, who all favor a multiparty system of government. Former legislator George Anyona, arrested in July with three friends, reported that they were being kept permanently handcuffed in dimly lit cells and given food which was ``unfit for human consumption,'' the report says. ``He said they had been stripped naked for interrogation and held in cells flooded with water, a common torture method in Kenya and sometimes nicknamed `the swimming pool'.'' The four are due to be tried on sedition charges in January, Amnesty said. The human rights organization said eight other activists, including former legislator Koigi wa Wamwere, had signed affidavits alleging torture. Arrested last month, the eight are charged with treason and related offenses but have been denied proper access to lawers, Amnesty charged. Moi, who came to power in 1978, has consistently rejected opposition calls for a multiparty system.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Put Under Police Hypnosis is Out to Crack Prosecutor's Immunity
DOC.TEXT: Nobody is arguing with Cathy Burns' claim that police wrongly hypnotized her before charging her in the shootings of her two sons. Whether she can sue the prosecutor who advised police beforehand is the question confronting the U.S. Supreme Court. Muncie authorities charged her in the 1982 shootings at her home after surmising from the questioning under hypnosis that Burns suffered from multiple personality disorder and that a personality named Katie shot the boys. Psychiatrists later determined she did not suffer from the disorder, and the police department paid $250,000 to settle a wrongful prosecution lawsuit she brought. But she still wants to sue Richard W. Reed, the Delaware County deputy prosecutor who counseled the officers in the bungled case. The Supreme Court heard arguments Wednesday and should rule by July whether a prosecutor can be held liable for recommending that police violate a person's rights. ``What we're arguing is that he actually directed the police at each critical stage of their investigation,'' said Burns' lawyer, Michael K. Sutherlin. ``If he had said `Don't do it,' they would have stopped.'' While police have limited immunity from such lawsuits, prosecutors nationwide have absolute immunity from lawsuits targeting actions taken in the performance of their official duties. All charges against Burns were dropped and the shooting remains unsolved. Evidence gathered with a search warrant that was obtained on the basis of the hypnosis ``confession'' was ruled inadmissable because the judge who issued the warrant wasn't told about the hypnosis. ``We wanted to make absolutely positive that those children would be safe in the future, and that they would not be put back into a home where they would be in jeopardy again,'' said Capt. Paul E. Cox, Muncie chief of detectives and one of the officers sued after the hypnosis. ``Whether or not justice was served, that's what the court has to decide.'' Both boys survived the shootings. Eddie, now 20, returned to his mother's custody in 1985. She still does not have custody of Denny, 15. She remarried about a year after her release from a psychiatric ward, where doctors concluded she did not have a split personality. During the shooting probe, Cox and his partner, Donald Scroggins, now Muncie's police chief, were stumped in the investigation even though Burns had submitted to a lie detector test. The officers asked her to undergo hypnosis. But Cox remembered from training that hypnotizing suspects is unacceptable. The officers asked Reed for advice. ``I said, `Yes. If you've got nowhere else to go you might as well do that,''' Reed recalled. Reed, the county's newly elected chief prosecutor, blamed himself for not letting the judge hearing the search warrant request know about the hypnosis. ``I wasn't very careful in examining Officer Scroggins on the witness stand,'' he said. ``It looked like I misled the court.'' The mistake prevented police from using as evidence a Halloween mask, wig and coveralls found in the Burns house that matched Burns' description of the attacker. A federal judge ruled the prosecutor was immune from her lawsuit, but Sutherlin hopes to revive her claim with help from the Supreme Court. Indiana Deputy Attorney General David A. Nowak, who is representing Reed, said limiting immunity would force prosecutors to defend themselves against so many lawsuits they couldn't do their jobs. ``While it might eliminate the avenue of relief for someone like Mrs. Burns, who arguably has a valid claim, it also limits the many frivolous claims that would be filed by criminal defendants,'' Nowak said. Justice Department lawyer Michael Lazerwitz argued Wednesday that prosecutors will be less willing to share their expertise with police if they risk being sued.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Gets Vatican Apology Over Abortion-Statement Flap
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican has sent Milwaukee Archbishop Rembert Weakland a rare letter of apology for denying him an honorary degree from a Swiss university because of his commentary on abortion. ``I deeply regret the pain that you have suffered. I share it with you and I sincerely assure you of my prayers that the wound so inadvertently caused will be healed,'' Archbishop Pio Laghi, head of the Vatican's Congregation of Education, wrote last week. Laghi also apologized for not consulting with Weakland before withholding approval of the degree from the University of Fribourg and for the way the action was interpreted as a rebuke of the archbishop. The Vatican did not rescind the veto of the degree and did not indicate Weakland has been cleared of questions about his statements on abortion. ``I greatly appreciate Archbishop Laghi's words of clarification and support in this matter. With his correspondence, I consider the matter closed,'' Weakland said in a statement Wednesday. The university's theology faculty is affiliated with the Vatican, which has the right to approve the awards it bestows. In failing to approve the honorary degree for Weakland's work in economics, the Vatican said he had taken positions on abortion ``which are not without doctrinal importance and which are causing a great deal of confusion amongst the faithful.'' The archbishop has maintained the Roman Catholic Church's position against abortion, but a statement he issued after a series of meetings with women last spring questioned actions of some abortion opponents and expressed concern about circumstances that lead to abortions. Laghi said the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith was still evaluating the archbishop's statement on abortion. He said he withheld approval of the honorary degree because the evaluation was not completed. ``I sincerely regret that that decision, which this congregation took in prudent patience, should have been so negatively perceived,'' he said. The Rev. Adrian Holderegger, director of the Swiss university's Institute of Moral Theology, expressed surprise at the letter. ``That's the first time I've heard of Rome apologizing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Barney Frank Back To Work, Attends Bill Signing Ceremony
DOC.TEXT:
A dozen days after a blocked coronary artery sent a sustained ache through Rep. Barney Frank's chest, the Massachusetts Democrat is back at work. Frank, who attended a White House signing ceremony on housing legislation Wednesday, said his mild heart attack on Nov. 17 will require him to give up weight lifting and cigar smoking but won't cut into his work on Capitol Hill. An awareness of his family history of heart trouble saved Frank's life hhen he felt chest pains and took himself to the hospital after working out at the Metropolitan Health Club in Boston. ``I got there early,'' Frank said. ``None of it was pleasant but it was a lot less unpleasant than you might think. I did not have any postoperative pain.'' Doctors used a balloon angioplasty procedure to open a clogged coronary artery. Frank's father died of a heart attack at age 53 and his grandfather was even younger when he died of what was believed to have been a heart attack, said Frank, who is 50. Frank won re-election in November by a wide margin after a yearlong ethics battle over his relationship with male prostitute Steven Gobie resulted in a House reprimand for fixing parking tickets for Gobie and writing a memo that contained misleading information about Gobie's background. The House rejected more serious punishment such as censure or expulsion.
---
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sends Ambassador To Lebanon
DOC.TEXT:
The United States has sent an ambassador back to Lebanon after pulling out all U.S. officials from Beirut last year because of heavy fighting among rival Lebanese militias. Ambassador Ryan Crocker arrived in Beirut Wednesday after a U.S. security team inspected the situation in the Lebanese capital last weekend, said deputy State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. The State Department wants to return additional diplomats to Beirut once their security can be guaranteed, he said. The decision to send in Crocker despite the still-tenuous security situation reflects the administration's strong support for the new government of Elias Hrawi, which is trying to impose its control over the divided country.
---
DOC.HEAD: Bush Backs Bennett as GOP Chief
DOC.TEXT: The White House has confirmed that President Bush wants William Bennett to be chairman of the Republican National Committee. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also indicated Wednesday that Bush is likely to nominate outgoing Florida Gov. Bob Martinez as Bennett's successor as director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. ``Those are the worst kept secrets in the history of the world, but we're not ready to make those announcements yet,'' Fitzwater said. Bennett will ``be the president's candidate'' when the Republican National Committee meets to elect a new chairman, Fitzwater said. GOP Chairman Lee Atwater is being treated for an inoperable brain tumor. Fitzwater also said that while there was no official announcement on Martinez being nominated for Bennett's old job, ``I would not deny either one of those moves.''

DOC.HEAD: Scholar: Noriega Tapes Case Casts Shadow on Press Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The case of the Manuel Noriega tapes casts a shadow over freedom of the press even though a federal judge lifted his order blocking their broadcast, a constitutional scholar says. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler brought one legal battle between Noriega and Cable News Network to a close Wednesday when he lifted his 3-week-old order barring CNN from airing tapes of the former dictator's jailhouse phone calls. Rodney Smolla, head of the Institute of Bill of Rights Law at William and Mary College in Williamsburg, Va., said he was disturbed that the U.S. Supreme Court refused to intervene earlier to throw out the judge's order and that the high court will not get another chance to review the order. ``It died with a whimper and I think it's unfortunate the case ended this way,'' he said. ``It left on the books precedents that cast some doubt on First Amendment protections that many people thought were well settled.'' Noriega's attorneys said they will still ask for contempt penalties against CNN for broadcasting excerpts the day after Hoeveler's ban. Defense attorney Frank Rubino also has requested that all charges against Noriega be dropped on grounds the taping, a dispute over Noriega's legal fees and other alleged government misconduct ruined his chances of a fair trial. A decision on that request awaits, among other things, the outcome of an FBI investigation into how the tapes were leaked. The judge lifted his order after he and attorneys reviewed transcripts of seven tapes the network submitted last week. During Wednesday's hearing, Rubino withdrew his request to stop the broadcasts, saying the only tape that appeared to violate attorney-client privilege already had been broadcast. ``It does no good to close the barn door after the horse is out,'' he said. Prosecutors also said they had no objection to lifting the ban, again insisting Noriega's rights were never violated by the taping. Later Wednesday, CNN broadcast portions of the previously aired tape. Spokesman Steve Haworth said the network had no immediate plans to air the others. CNN President Tom Johnson said the judge's decision would allow the network to pursue its story on the government's taping of Noriega's conversations. ``CNN's coverage of this possible misconduct was delayed by this judicial prior restraint on press freedom,'' he said. Scholars said the possible precedents from the case include allowing prior restraint of news reporting, something most believed to be strictly prohibited by the First Amendment. ``The fact that the Supreme Court has tolerated this gag order for this length of time will unfortunately send a sign to judges and lawyers around the country that a little prior restraint is OK,'' said Jane Kirtley, head of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press. Rubino said the Drug Enforcement Administration or State Department leaked the tapes to the government of Panama, which in turn gave them to CNN. He said he wants the source of the leak identified. ``We had to go along the road and put out fires - now we're going after the pyromaniacs that started the fires,'' Rubino said. To head off more leaks, Hoeveler also ruled that the Bureau of Prisons, which routinely records inmate conversations for security reasons, cannot share any of Noriega's tapes with other agencies without the judge's permission. The tape that touched off the dispute was of a conversation between Noriega and one of Rubino's investigators, with the lawyer's Spanish-speaking secretary serving as an interpreter. In the conversation, Noriega is asked about two recently arrested Panamanians and speculates that prosecutors intend to use them as witnesses against him. Rubino on Nov. 8 got Hoeveler to order CNN to halt broadcasting of any tapes that might interfere with attorney-client privilege. The network aired a tape for a day but stopped when a federal appeals court backed Hoeveler. The Supreme Court then refused to intervene on a 7-2 vote, forcing CNN to submit the tapes to the judge for review. Noriega is in a federal jail outside Miami awaiting on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Thinner Prevents Strokes Caused by Abnormal Heartbeats
DOC.TEXT: A widely used blood thinner can dramatically reduce the risk of a form of stroke triggered by an irregular heartbeat, says a study released today. The research in the New England Journal of Medicine involved the drug warfarin and strokes triggered by atrial fibrillation, abnormally rapid beating of the heart's upper chambers. Such strokes afflict 75,000 Americans annually. In March, another major study found that aspirin, also a blood-thinning drug, also significantly reduces the likelihood of these strokes. In atrial fibrillation, the heart's rapidly beating chambers can produce blood clots that can travel to the brain and clog up blood vessels, causing strokes. Both aspirin and warfarin interfere with the formation of clots. The study, directed by Dr. J. Philip Kistler at Massachusetts General Hospital, was based on 420 patients who were randomly assigned to take warfarin or serve in an untreated comparison group. It found that warfarin reduced the risk of stroke by 86 percent. After two years, there were two strokes in the warfarin users and 13 in the comparison group. Warfarin is routinely used to prevent strokes in people with severe atrial fibrillation caused by damaged heart valves. However, doctors have been reluctant to use this medicine in people with milder cases because of the chance of serious bleeding. The new study found that the bleeding risk is slight when the drug's use is monitored by doctors. More research is needed to determine which patients should receive warfarin and which should get aspirin, the doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Rivals Agree to Ban The Bomb But Refuse To Sign Non-Proliferation Pact
DOC.TEXT: Brazil and Argentina have agreed not to produce atomic weapons and will allow inspection of their nuclear facilities. But the former rivals still refuse to sign a world non-proliferation treaty. Wednesday's agreement effectively eliminates the possibility of a nuclear arms race in South America, officials say. The two countries are the continent's most advanced in nuclear technology. The agreement was signed Wednesday by Presidents Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Carlos Menem of Argentina in the border city of Foz do Iguacu, nearly 1,200 miles south of Brasilia. ``We have taken a decisive step to eliminate nuclear rivalry between the two countries,'' Collor said during the signing ceremony. However, the two presidents reiterated their countries' decision to not sign the 1968 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty because it is ``discriminatory'', discouraging the transfer of nuclear technology to developing countries. Menem said Brazil and Argentina did not have to offer each other additional guarantees regarding the peaceful purposes of their nuclear programs. Menem said he would ask Argentina's congress to ratify a treaty for nuclear non-proliferation in Latin America. Brazil signed and ratified the so-called Tlatelolco Treaty in 1967. Menem said Brazil and Argentina had banned the production of missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads. The two countries also prohibited nuclear tests inside their territories, even for peaceful purposes. Brazil and Argentina are the only countries in Latin America that have perfected the complete nuclear fuel cycle. The International Atomic Energy Agency will start supervising a mutual safeguard system within the next 45 days. The agency's executive secretary, Hans Blix, attended the signing of the agreement. The two countries will inspect each others' research centers, military installations and nuclear reactors. The agreement comes two months after Collor personally presided over the scrapping of a nuclear test site at a Brazilian air force base deep in the Amazonian jungle. The site was never used. The hole at the Serra do Cachimbo Air Force Base, 930 miles northwest of Brasilia, was excavated in 1979 when Brazil was ruled by its last military president, Gen. Joao Figueredo. Civilians took the reins of government in 1985 but full democracy was not restored until last December's election victory by Collor. Argentina's defense minister said in April that his country had halted development of the Condor 2 project, a medium-range missile that arms control experts said could carry a chemical or nuclear warhead. Argentina was ruled by eight years of military dictatorships until 1983, when President Raul Alfonsin was elected. Menem succeeded Alfonsin last year. Both countries have nuclear reactors - Argentina has two, Brazil one.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Death Comes Early Without Routine Medical Care
DOC.TEXT: Illnesses that could be cured or corrected successfully with routine therapy are killing thousands of impoverished American blacks because their access to health care is limited, a new study says. The study in the November issue of the International Journal of Epidemiology examined the number of Americans between the ages of 15 and 54 who died between 1980 and 1986 from a dozen disorders that normally are not lethal if treated early. During that period, there were 121,560 premature deaths - almost 80 percent of them among blacks - related to the 12 ailments, the study said. Only about 13 percent of the total U.S. population is black. Correcting the problem and preventing the early deaths, Dr. Reed V. Tuckson said Wednesday, will require a change in national attitude. ``The nation has to decide whether or not citizen survival is of the highest priority,'' said Tuckson, a senior vice president of the March of Dimes and a co-author of the study. ``We have to decide as a nation to care.'' Examined in the study were deaths caused by tuberculosis, cervical cancer, Hodgkin's disease, rheumatic heart disease, hypertensive heart disease, acute respiratory disease, pneumonia and bronchitis, influenza, asthma, appendicitis, hernia and cholecystitis. ``If detected early and quality treatment is provided, nobody should be dying of these things,'' said Dr. Eugene Schwartz, an executive in the District of Columbia commission of public health and a co-author of the study. ``Either they (patients) are not seeking the care, or they are being blocked from the care.'' The study said that ``for some of these diseases, such as appendicitis, the occurrence of even a single event should warrant further investigation.'' Yet, during the study period, 1,186 people died of appendicitis, about 75 percent of them black. Among people aged 15 to 44, the study said, the leading cause of death was pneumonia and bronchitis, conditions that readily yield to early therapy. Blacks died of those conditions almost four times more frequently than whites, the study said. Pneumonia and bronchitis were treated as one illness in the study. ``We don't know all of the reasons why these deaths are happening,'' said Dr. Marc Rivo, president of the District of Columbia Academy of Family Physicians and a co-author of the study. ``But we know that people are dying of diseases that a family physician could treat.'' He said that assuring routine, periodic medical attention could help prevent such premature deaths, but added: ``We don't have a system that encourages poor people to see a physician on a regular basis.'' The study said 37 million Americans have no access to routine health care services and that impoverished blacks, mostly in cities, are ``more likely to encounter delays or be denied access to care.'' ``Blacks are four times more likely than whites to rely on emergency rooms and hospital clinics for health services,'' the study said. ``A similar trend is observed among low-income individuals, irrespective of race, who must postpone seeking primary care until their need for treatment becomes urgent and who then turn to hospital emergency rooms.'' Often, Rivo said, it is too late. Tuckson said regular medical care for the poor, including many blacks, isn't delivered because of such ordinary things as transportation problems, child care responsibilities or clinics that close before most of the working poor are off. Many of the excess deaths, he said, could also be related to behavior, ``the choices that people make.'' ``Those choices are often a function of hopelessness, a disenfranchisement from the community, that are related to ethnicity and poverty,'' Tuckson said Wednesday. He said there are 33 million Americans without health insurance or other means of paying for medical care. According to the statistics reported Wednesday, life expectancy for black people in the United States fell to 69.2 years in 1988 from 69.4 years in 1987. Life expectancy for whites in 1988 was 75.6 years, unchanged from 1987. The National Center for Health Statistics said because of the decline in the black rate, overall life expectancy dropped from 75 years in 1987 to 74.9 years in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Major's Cabinet Changes Hailed As Indication He's No Thatcher Puppet
DOC.TEXT: New Prime Minister John Major has reorganized the Cabinet he inherited from Margaret Thatcher, a move seen as demonstrating his intent not to be a Thatcher clone. Major assumed the office on Wednesday, a day after Conservative deputies of the House of Commons elected him party leader. Major - who was Mrs. Thatcher's protege and her favorite among those seeking the party leadership - kept all but three of her 22 Cabinet members but gave many of them different jobs. He also took on Michael Heseltine, whose challenge of Mrs. Thatcher's leadership led to her resignation. ``By making such extensive changes, Mr. Major has demonstrated that he is his own man and not, as critics have suggested, Mrs. Thatcher's puppet,'' the British Broadcasting Corp. observed today. The Times of London said in an editorial: ``The back-seat driver - if Margaret Thatcher ever pondered the role - has been thrown from the car at the first turn.'' Heseltine was appointed environment secretary, with responsibility for the promised reform of the widely unpopular ``poll tax'' that was one of the major factors in bringing down Mrs. Thatcher after 11{ years as prime minister. The tax, to help fund local government, was leveled on a per capita basis and many critics saw it as evidence that Mrs. Thatcher's government was favoring the rich at the expense of the lower classes. With the Persian Gulf crisis deepening, Major kept the other leadership contender, Douglas Hurd, as foreign secretary. Tom King remains as defense secretary. That indicated a continuation of Mrs. Thatcher's pro-U.S. policies, including backing the massive U.S. deployment in the gulf with thousands of British troops. Before she resigned, Mrs. Thatcher promised to double the British contingent to 30,000 soldiers. One of Major's closest associates, Norman Lamont, was appointed chancellor of the exchequer, or treasury chief, the post Major held in Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet. Kenneth Baker, who was Conservative Party chairman under Mrs. Thatcher, was appointed by Major as home secretary responsible for police, law and order, prisons and a variety of other matters. The new Conservative Party chairman is former environment secretary Christopher Patten. A Harris opinion poll broadcast by Independent Television News on Wednesday night showed the Conservatives under Major to be 11 points ahead of the opposition Labor Party. The Conservatives had lagged behind in the polls for 16 months. Based on interviews with 1,092 people, it put support for the Tories at 49 percent to 38 for Labor, 9 for the Liberal Democrats and 4 for other groups. It stated no margin of error. A Harris poll last spring showed the Tories under Mrs. Thatcher trailing Labor by a whopping 28 points. By law, the next general election must be held by mid-1992, but the prime minister can call one any time before then. Major, at 47 the youngest prime minister of the century, had displayed both talent and tenacity in overcoming childhood poverty and rising rapidly through the government. The son of a former circus performer, Major was raised in the rundown Brixton section of London and left school at 16. He was briefly on welfare and worked as a laborer before becoming a successful banker. It was his fortune to be the popular choice of a party torn by rebellion against his patron, Mrs. Thatcher. Major said Wednesday he hoped to build on the achievements of his predecessor. He said during his campaign that he would stick to Mrs. Thatcher's policies of tight spending and privatization, but would review the ``poll tax.'' The government also announced Wednesday that it was resuming diplomatic relations with Syria, completing a rapprochement which began under Mrs. Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: Eccentric Billionaire Leaves All to Poor
DOC.TEXT: In life, Harry Weinberg was an abrasive and ruthless businessman often accused of letting downtown Baltimore go to seed. In death, his $1 billion legacy will go toward improving the lives of the poor. When Weinberg died in Honolulu earlier this month at age 82 after an eight-year battle with bone cancer, the real estate magnate left an estimated $900 million to $1 billion to the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation. Overnight, the largely anonymous foundation started in 1957 was transformed into the nation's 12th-largest private foundation - one to be solely devoted to helping the poor. Half the money will go toward the poor in Baltimore. ``What did John D. MacArthur, Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller and now Harry Weinberg have in common?'' asked Honolulu businessman John D. Slocum, who tangled with Weinberg. ``All were geniuses at making money, sometimes ruthlessly trampling over obstacles, even people. But when the end came, all left fortunes for good works.'' Last year, Forbes magazine ranked Weinberg 70th on its list of the 400 richest Americans. By all accounts, his only interest was making money. He was estranged from his only son - whom he excluded from his will - and never bothered with the trappings of the huge wealth he accumulated in real estate, municipal transit companies and other ventures. Weinberg moved to Honolulu in 1968, and as in Baltimore, his offices were drab, his car was 10 or 15 years old, his clothes came off the rack and he hated publicity. In Hawaii, a state that thrives on consensus, he loved to battle Hawaii business leaders. Some praised his foresight in recognizing the state's tourism potential; others said he exploited the land and ignored the wishes of neighbors. Nearly all describe his personality as abrasive at best. One of his foes, Colin Cameron, president of the Maui Land and Pineapple Co., called Weinberg an ``obnoxious'' man who did ``nothing with money except make it'' and regarded his financial activities as ``a game for his own sake.'' But after he was diagnosed with the cancer, Weinberg announced he would give all his money away and developed an interest in the elderly. On a humid day in 1989 while visiting several nursing homes in Israel, he wrote a $1 million check on the spot to pay for air conditioning in every nursing home in the country. In Baltimore, when a patient at Levindale Hebrew Geriatic Center and Hospital complained of never getting ice cream, Weinberg ordered $20,000 be spent for ice cream twice a month. Morton Weinberg said his father simply loved the city where he grew up and wanted to give something back. Weinberg's will indicated he would like half the money distributed in Baltimore, a city of severe drug problems and thousands of homeless. Its dropout, teen-age pregnancy and infant mortality rates are among the nation's highest. As Baltimore's tax base shrinks from the middle-class exodus to the suburbs, city leaders and charitable organizations are counting on Weinberg's largesse to help solve the problems of poverty. ``There are so many needs,'' said Robert C. Embry Jr., president of the Abell Foundation, previously the city's largest charity. ``Foundations are not permitted to lobby, but they can put out reports on things. They can fund demonstration projects, programs to train people. There are a lot of things they can do to help.'' Under federal law, the foundation must disburse at least 5 percent of its assets every year within two years. Weinberg stipulated that one-quarter of the money spent - $45 million to $50 million - go to Jewish poor, another quarter to non-Jewish religious groups and the rest without regard for affiliation. The foundation's trustees declined to discuss their plans as they seek advice from national experts. The Weinberg trustees also must decide what to do with an estimated $58 million in real estate under their control in downtown Baltimore. For years, the properties provoked clashes between Weinberg and the city and business leaders. Weinberg left many buildings vacant and refused to sell or renovate them, which stymied efforts to revitalize the area. Gov. William Donald Schaefer, who as Baltimore mayor railed at Weinberg's refusal to develop his downtown holdings, sees things differently now. ``I applaud Mr. Weinberg's legacy which he's left to the city,'' he said. ``Many thousands of disadvantaged people will surely benefit from his generosity.''

DOC.HEAD: Development Bank Grants First Loan to China Since Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: The Asian Development Bank today granted China a $50 million agricultural loan, its first to the Beijing government since Chinese authorities crushed a major pro-democracy movement in 1989. The United States is a principal shareholder in the bank and the loan may be linked to U.S. efforts to get China to support a U.N. resolution to authorize the use of force in the effort to drive Iraq from Kuwait. The resolution was expected to come up for a vote in New York today. The bank never publicly acknowledged it was withholding loans to China because of the June 1989 crackdown, in which hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed. But bank sources said the United States and others were holding back on new loans to pressure Beijing into reforms. There was no explanation for the apparent change in the unofficial policy toward loans to China, and bank spokesmen refused comment. The multinational lending institution today also approved a $480,000 technical assistance grant. The loan and grant to the Agricultural Bank of China will be to help Beijing modernize and expand agricultural facilities in the provinces of Jilin, Shandong, Jiangsu, Fujian and Guandong, the bank said. According to the bank, the loan will be for 15 years including a three- year grace period with an undisclosed interest rate. The Asian Development Bank, organized in 1966, raises funds from public and private sources for development projects in Asia. The United States and Japan are the principal shareholders, followed by China, India and and more than 25 other member countries. The United States and other countries shunned China diplomatically after the June 1989 crackdown. Since the Persian Gulf crisis, however, the United States invited Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen to a meeting in Washington with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. They met again early today. Qian flew to the United States to be present for the U.N. Security Council vote on the U.S.-sponsored use-of-force resolution. Qian said China would not back the resolution. But he did not say whether China would abstain. As a permanent Security Cuncil member, China could veto the U.S.-backed resolution. Diplomats suggested he would be seeking concessions. Those might include an end to U.S. opposition to World Bank loans to China, a resumption of defense cooperation and military sales and agreement not to link China's human rights record to its most-favored-nation trade status.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam And U.S. Begin 12th Joint Search for Remains
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese and U.S. experts are conducting their 12th joint search for evidence of what happened to 1,676 Americans missing from the Vietnam War, a U.S. official said today. Two U.S. military teams arrived in Vietnam on Wednesday for the 15-to-20 day search in six provinces, said the official of the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok, who asked not to be named. In these searches, investigators inspect plane crash sites, interview villagers who witnessed crashes and collect other evidence of missing soldiers. The embassy official said Washington hoped that the results of the current search would reflect Vietnamese promises of greater cooperation in joint projects. Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach made the promises in a meeting with U.S. presidential envoy John W. Vessey Jr. in Washington on Oct. 17. The U.S. military experts are from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army's Central Identification Laboratory, both based in Hawaii. These agencies are entrusted with accounting for America's wartime missing. The Army laboratory is still analyzing 10 sets of remains that Vietnam returned Nov. 20, its most recent repatriation, to determine if they are those of missing Americans. The Pentagon lists 2,294 Americans as missing in action from the war that ended in the Communist defeat of the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government in April 1975. Of the total, 1,676 are missing in Vietnam, 529 in Laos, 83 in Cambodia and six in Chinese coastal waters. The first joint search was in September 1988, a year after the United States secured a Vietnamese commitment to greater cooperation in return for help with humanitarian problems in Vietnam including rehabilitation of disabled soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Axl cq 2nd item.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors decided against bringing sexual battery charges against Milli Vanilli's Rob Pilatus. Pilatus, who with partner Fab Morvan lip-synced his way to stardom before being stripped of a Grammy award last week, was arrested Tuesday at his Bel-Air home for investigation of sexual battery against a 25-year-old woman. ``The district attorney does not doubt the credibility of the victim, but the conduct described does not rise to the level of a sexual crime,'' said police Lt. Ron Hall, reading a memo from the district attorney's office. Pilatus said his arrest may have been set up by people in the record industry. ``We said we were warned that if we make troubles, our lives will be ruined, and it looks ... it just looks like to me that that's what certain people are interested in,'' he said Wednesday. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Axl Rose, lead singer of the rock band Guns 'N Roses, won't be prosecuted for allegedly bashing a neighbor with a bottle. The district attorney's office said Wednesday the case was dropped for lack of evidence. The 28-year-old singer and Gabriella Kantor had been bickering for some time before she alleged he hit her over the head with a wine bottle on Oct. 30. Ms. Kantor claimed Rose was too noisy; he said she was a bothersome groupie trying to get into his inner circle. Rose eventually got a restraining order preventing Ms. Kantor from coming near him, his wife or their guests. --- LONG BEACH, Calif. (AP) - Bob Hope was 90 minutes late for mess aboard the USS Peleliu but still found time to joke with his Navy honor guard. ``I'm thrilled just to find this place,'' the comedian said Tuesday after finally boarding the amphibious assault ship for a dinner saluting his 50 years of volunteer work. Hope and his wife, Dolores, were caught in a traffic jam and then couldn't find the ship at Long Beach Naval Station. ``You're my honor platoon, huh? Let's go into Long Beach and find the hot spots, guys,'' the 87-year-old entertainer said. Hope received the National Volunteer Center's George W. Romney Citizen Volunteer Award for his many years of entertaining U.S. troops abroad. The award is named after the former Michigan governor. The center coordinates services by 800,000 volunteers nationwide. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Mayor Marion Barry's wife, who stood by her husband during his three-month drug and perjury trial, has moved out on him. ``There is no official change in the marital status,'' Lurma Rackley, the mayor's press secretary, said Wednesday. ``That is all we can say right now.'' Effi Barry moved out of the house the couple share and into an apartment complex Monday with their 10-year-old son to be closer to his school, sources close to Barry said. ``She has said Christopher needed to be out of that situation where there were so many bad memories,'' an unidentified friend told The Washington Post. ``She needed to be in a situation where he could have a fresh start.'' Barry was arrested Jan. 18 in a hotel room after being lured there by Rasheeda Moore, a former model who cooperated with an FBI sting. Ms. Moore testified during his three-month trial that she and Barry used drugs more than 100 times during an intimate two-year relationship. Barry is appealing a misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction and a six-month prison term. He lost a bid for a city council seat Nov. 6. --- ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) - Billionaire H. Ross Perot returned to his alma mater and said the U.S. Naval Academy taught him perseverance. ``I think a lot of my business success comes from my inability to recognize that I had failed,'' the Texas businessman said in a speech Tuesday. Perot grew up in a family of modest means in Texarkana, Texas, and said the academy was his best hope for a college education. He spent three years trying to get admitted and still treasures the telegram announcing his acceptance. He urged midshipmen to apply the academy's ethics code to their lives. ``Don't run your life by what's legal or illegal. Run your life based on what's right or wrong,'' he said. ``If you don't learn anything else, it's worth the time you spent here.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Whoopi Goldberg, a star of the Paramount Pictures hit ``Ghost,'' has signed a multi-picture deal with the studio. Terms of the contract were not disclosed Tuesday. David Kirkpatrick, president of the company's Motion Picture Group, Ms. Goldberg's first role will be in the comedy ``Soapdish,'' also starring Sally Field, Kevin Kline, Robert Downey, Jr. and Carrie Fisher. No release date was set. Ms. Goldberg played psychic Oda Mae Brown in this year's blockbuster ``Ghost,'' also starring Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore. She also is in her third season playing a bartender in ``Star Trek: The Next Generation'' on television.

DOC.HEAD: Episcopal Church to Hold `No-Frills' Convention
DOC.TEXT: Episcopal Church leaders, acting to quell dissension in their ranks over plans to hold a convention next summer in Phoenix, say they will go ahead with the gathering - but spend less money while they're here. Church leaders will hold a ``no-frills, basic convention and use some of our economic impact'' to make the point that Arizona should adopt a holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr., said church spokeswoman Diane Porter. The decision came out of a meeting Tuesday between Presiding Bishop Edmond Browning and black church leaders concerned with Arizona voters' rejection of a King holiday earlier this month, Ms. Porter said. The meeting came after two bishops threatened to boycott the 10-day convention and five dioceses passed resolutions criticizing its being held in Phoenix. ``Everyone is interested in the same thing - not punishing Arizona but determining how best to help Arizona come into the 21st century,'' she said. Ms. Porter said there were no firm plans for cutting frills at the convention, which starts July 11 and is expected to draw at least 10,000 delegates, but said the gathering usually includes many receptions and dinners. ``We've got to eat, but we don't have to order all those drinks in the bar or keep all those banquet halls filled,'' she said. Delegates may also be discouraged from bringing family members to keep expenses down, she said. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa has said he will come to Arizona to lead a rally against racism on July 10.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Drop, Dollar Surges
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell for the third consecutive day today over the continuing Middle East crisis, while the dollar surged against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 341.28 points, or 1.48 percent, closing at 22,712.60. The index shed 569.63 points on Wednesday and 139.35 points Tuesday. A total of 300 million shares were traded on the first section today, down from 340 million shares the previous day. The dollar's rebound against the yen, weak bond prices in Japan and higher oil prices in New York combined to dampen the stock market, securities dealers said. Investors also were nervous about the U.N. Security Council's expected passage later in the day of a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq, said Masahiko Nozaki of Wako Securities Co. The dollar closed at 130.15 yen, up 1.25 yen from Wednesday's close of 128.90 yen. After opening at 130.20 yen, it ranged between 129.95 yen and 130.60 yen. Some $12.62 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, up from $8.37 billion Wednesday. Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said many traders were refraining from selling dollars ahead of the planned U.N. vote. The dollar often is seen as a safe haven in times of international tension. The dollar's strength in Tokyo also followed its overnight advance in New York, boosted by comments by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan voicing concern about the dollar's recent weakness. ``The dollar's underlying sentiment remains strong,'' said Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slid to 86.11 from Wednesday's close of 86.42. Their yield rose to 7.480 percent from 7.395 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Hawaii Has Lowest Rate of Preventable Deaths, Michigan Highest
With PM-Death Rates List
DOC.TEXT: Hawaii's seafood-rich diet may have helped give it the nation's lowest rate of preventable deaths from nine major diseases, while Michigan's industrial lifestyle was blamed in part for its having the highest. The rankings of all 50 states and the District of Columbia came from a Centers for Disease Control study published Wednesday. It looked at deaths from stroke, lung cancer, coronary heart disease, breast cancer, diabetes, cervical cancer, chronic liver disease, colorectal cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in 1986, the latest year data were available. The study found that 26.4 percent of the 2,817 deaths in Hawaii from those nine diseases could have been prevented - the lowest rate in the nation. North Dakota and Utah, both with 33.2 percent, tied for the second lowest rate. Michigan had the highest rate - 53.5 percent - followed by West Virginia at 53.3 percent, New York with 52.6 percent, Ohio at 52.1 percent and Kentucky with 52 percent. The differences depended on several variables but could be explained, at least partially, with a little guesswork, said Steven M. Teutsch, a CDC epidemiologist who worked on the study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Michigan's high rate may be because it is highly industrialized and has large minority populations that might know little about disease risks, he speculated. In Hawaii, people tend to eat more seafood and vegetables; that contributes to lower cholesterol rates and less heart disease, he said. Researchers arrived at their figures using a model based on combining the lowest death rates for each disease to create a ``utopian state'' with an overall, combined death rate for the nine diseases of about 224 per 100,000 people. Then they compared each state to the ideal. Hawaii came the closest, with 304.7 deaths per 100,000, or 80.34 deaths above the ideal. Thus 26.4 percent of its deaths were considered preventable. The study found smoking contributed to the most deaths from the nine diseases, 33 percent. Obesity, a sedentary lifestyle, high cholesterol, hypertension and diabetes followed. Teutsch said researchers have found that reducing even one of the known risks for each disease - such as smoking for lung cancer and cholesterol for heart disease - dramatically lowers chances of developing the illnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Cleared of Conspiracy Charge
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli who claimed to be a former intelligence agent working on behalf of PrimeMinister Yitzhak Shamir was cleared of charges he arranged a $36 million deal to sell U.S.-made military cargo planes to Iran. A federal jury Wednesday found Ari Ben Menashe innocent of conspiring to circumvent State Department regulations on the sale of military goods. A co-defendant, businessman Richard St. Francis of Norwalk, Conn., also was acquitted. They were charged in a scheme to sell three Israeli-owned transports to Iran in April 1989. Menashe's attorney, Thomas Dunn, argued that his client represented Shamir in a U.S.-approved deal to sell transports to Iran in 1988 in exchange for the release of four American hostages in the Middle East. The deal fell through when Shamir insisted three Israeli soldiers also be freed, he said. Dunn said Shamir then sent Menashe to the United States to broker another deal involving the planes. The trip ended in Menashe's arrest. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said Menashe's claim he was acting on behalf of Shamir was ``utter nonsense, a fabrication from A to Z.'' ``The prime minister doesn't know this guy, nobody around here does,'' Pazner said. Menashe and St. Francis could each have received up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl, Lafontaine Head For The Wire; Polls Say Lafontaine Has No Chance
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl appears headed for victory in the first free all-German elections since the 1930s, but challenger Oskar Lafontaine hopes to draw enough young voters in time to win Sunday's vote. Lafontaine's center-left Social Democrats aim to persuade Germans that Kohl's conservatives will favor big business and neglect workers and the environment as eastern Germany makes the painful shift to capitalism. In his final campaign appearance, Kohl was to be in Stuttgart and Offenburg today. Lafontaine was to be in Saarbruecken. A new poll by the Allensbach institute predicted Kohl's three-party coalition would receive more than 53 percent of the vote in Sunday's election, while the Social Democrats would get about 34 percent. But a spokesman for the Social Democrats said the polls did not reflect Lafontaine's true popularity, especially among young Germans who like the quick-witted candidate's dynamism and persistence. ``We're not conceding defeat,'' said Social Democrat spokesman Eduard Heussen. ``We think Oskar has a chance.'' The leftist Lafontaine himself admits that Kohl, widely regarded as the architect of German unity, will be a tough man to beat. ``Unity came, and now it's a fact that the person in power is very fortunate because he can practically dominate the stage,'' Lafontaine said on Monday. The federal election, with 656 seats in a united Parliament at stake, will be the first free united German vote since 1932, just before Adolf Hitler came to power. In addition, a city council will be elected for Berlin, the capital of united Germany. About 59.9 million people are eligible to vote, 47.9 million from former West Germany and 12 million from former East Germany. The two Germanys agreed to unite before holding joint elections to keep the impoverished eastern loands from sliding into an economic abyss. Kohl, as West Germany's chancellor, steered both nations to unity and then served as caretaker head of united Germany. Once considered a bumbling leader, he has grown into one of Germany's most important figures since the end of World War II. The portly Kohl, 60, usually dressed in a conservative dark suit, stirs up support with promises of affluence and future German greatness. His rallies usually close with the crowd singing the national anthem. Lafontaine, 47, campaigns in a stylish dark shirt and skinny tie, sometimes accompanied by Christa Mueller, his attractive young companion. During the past few days, Peter Maffay, one of Germany's most popular rock musicians, has performed at his rallies. Earlier this year, a deranged woman tried to assassinate Lafontaine but he recovered from knife wounds suffered in the attack. Lafontaine has eschewed optimism for straight talk about unification's huge costs, maintaining that Kohl has misled Germans about unity's true price tag. Social Democrats maintain that Kohl is endangering the German economy by borrowing heavily to help rebuild former East Germany. The Social Democrats say they are the true standard-bearers of German ecology and peace movements, and they charge that Kohl favors big business over helping normal citizens. Eastern Germany is beset by high unemployment and mounting social ills as it converts to capitalism after more than four decades of communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: China Denies Using U.N. Veto Power As Bargaining Tool
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout to ADD quotes, details, background. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: China today denied it is using its U.N. veto power in the Persian Gulf crisis to gain political favors from the United States. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing said Foreign Minister Qian Qichen's vote today on a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq has no relation to Washington's invitation to Qian to make an official visit. ``There are no interactions between the two,'' he said. ``I don't think there's such a question as to using the power of veto as a bargaining method with the United States,'' he said. Qian's official visit to Washington begins Friday. The U.N. Security Council was to vote on the use-of-force resolution later today. It is the first official visit to the United States by a Chinese minister since the military's bloody crackdown in June 1989 on the pro-democracy movement in China. Western countries and Japan have gradually lifted sanctions imposed on China to protest the crackdown. Western diplomats have acknowledged this is due in part to China's cooperation in the international effort to force Iraq to quit Kuwait. The Asian Development Bank today granted China a $50 million agricultural loan, its first to the Beijing government since the crackdown. Bank officials denied comment, but the United States is a principal shareholder and the loan may be linked to U.S. efforts to get China to support the U.N. use-of-force resolution. Japan sent its education minister to Beijing in September and resumed low-interest loans to China. The European Community voted in October to lift all sanctions except the ban on arms sales and defense cooperation. Inviting Qian for talks appeared to be one more effort to smooth relations with China in return for its support on gulf resolutions. Qian met early today in New York with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The official Xinhua News Agency said they discussed the upcoming Security Council meeting on the Persian Gulf crisis, but it gave no other details. As one of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, China has veto power over resolutions. So far, China has supported all 10 resolutions aimed at forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. But Qian said Wednesday before leaving Beijing that China would not support the resolution to permit force against Iraq. He refused to say whether China would veto it or abstain. Li, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, also refused to say what China would do: ``As to what vote will China cast, it's not time for voting yet.'' China has stressed that all efforts to reach a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis must be exhausted before considering the use of force. Western diplomats said China apparently hoped to persuade Washington to lift remaining sanctions against Beijing in return for allowing the resolution on force to pass. Qian's visit to Washington is itself a concession by the Bush administration. After China's crackdown on protesters last year, the United States had refused to invite high-level Chinese officials. At the Beijing airport, Qian said he expected to meet with President Bush - something that would be a significant diplomatic victory for China. Qian also might seek an end to U.S. opposition to World Bank loans to China that do not address humanitarian needs, a resumption of defense cooperation and military sales, and agreement not to link China's human rights record to its most-favored-nation trade status. Asked if human rights issues would come up during Qian's talks with U.S. officials, Li said, ``I don't think that it is appropriate for some individuals to make some random remarks about internal affairs of other countries with the excuse of human rights. ``And it is not appropriate either to interfere in some developing countries' internal affairs with an excuse of human rights,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Traders said the dollar moved higher after the U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave the first recent indication that the United States is getting nervous about the dollar's decline. The dollar was expected to move higher, traders said, if the United Nations Security Council voted in favor of a resolution to use force in the Persian Gulf. ``The dollar will go up,'' predicted Kenji Kawahara, a senior dealer at Dai-Ichi Kangyo in London. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.25 yen to a closing 130.15 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 130.55 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.4880 German marks, up from 1.4845 -1.2685 Swiss francs, up from 1.2680 -5.0237 French francs, up from 5.0115 -1.6760 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6740 -1,117.50 Italian lire, up from 1,110.00 -1.1650 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9675, compared with $1.9723 late Wednesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $385.25 per ounce at midmorning, from $385.50 bid per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $385.25, up from $384.50 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.40 to close at a bid $384.83. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.13 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.10.

DOC.HEAD: Rainy Skies Seen Along Eastern Seaboard, Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: The East began to get back to normal today with rain and cold air breezing in to end nearly a week of unusually warm weather. The Pacific Northwest got heavy rain, while the rest of the nation had mostly clear skies and moderate temperatures. In the Northeast, temperatures were expected to drop as much as 40 degrees from Wednesday's record-setting marks, with highs ranging from the 50s to the 30s. Rain was forecast along the East Coast, and snow was likely in northern New England and near the eastern Great Lakes. A storm front bringing heavy rains and high winds hit the Washington and Oregon coasts. Snow was expected over the northern Cascades and into Montana. Temperatures were expected to reach the 80s in southern Florida, the 50s throughout the nation's middle section, and the 30s and 40s farther north. Highs in the 20s were forecast for northern Minnesota and Michigan. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 91 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. DOC.HEAD: People Rush to Buy Food During Break in Curfew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typo in editor's note. ^With PM-Bangladesh
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following story was submitted to a censor at the Interior Ministry, who deleted 10 paragraphs and made other changes.

After four hours of relaxation, the curfew in Dhaka and three other major cities - Chittagong, Khulna and Rajshahi - was re-imposed at 10 a.m. today. Dhaka residents jammed shops to stock up on food during curfew relaxation. Traffic, mostly bicycle-powered rickshaws, came out on the streets as people rushed to settle urgent business - mostly buying foods. Government troops and police circulated in the capital city of 7 million people to enforce the curfew imposed Tuesday. The government, in a press note issued Wednesday night, said the situation remained peaceful. However, it said there were several attempts to break the curfew by a section of people, but they failed after security forces took action.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Lincoln Investor Upset His Savings Would Not Help Children, Friend Says
DOC.TEXT: An elderly man who killed himself was upset that the life savings he spent on worthless junk bonds from Lincoln Savings and Loan never would benefit abused children he wanted to help, a friend said. Although some elderly people who had invested in the bonds were left in desperate straits, the death of Anthony Elliot, 89, was the first suicide blamed on the scandal, Burbank police Sgt. Don Goldberg said Wednesday. Marion Lovelace, a Los Angeles real estate agent, said his friend was despondent that the $160,000 he had bequeathed to a national child abuse group was lost when Lincoln collapsed. ``That was his greatest job, knowing he was doing something for those children,'' Lovelace said. ``When he lost his money, it took all his joy away. He lost his reason to live.'' Since 1980, Elliott had been a benefactor to Woodland Hills-based Childhelp USA, a national non-profit group formed to prevent child abuse and help victims. Elliot, a retired accountant, was found Monday in a bathtub by his part-time housekeeper. His wrists and forearms had been slashed by a razor, police said. ``There is no doubt in my mind that he committed suicide over the loss of his savings,'' Goldberg said. He said Elliott ``had talked with neighbors and his housekeeper who say he had become bitter and cynical about the S&L scandal. ``It appears that the loss of $200,000 pretty well represented his life savings. This is a very tragic, very sad, very pathetic death,'' he said. In a note found by authorities, Elliott blamed federal regulators for the loss of his savings. ``There's nothing left for me of things that used to be,'' Elliot said in the note. ``Government is supposed to serve and protect, but who? Those who can gather the most savings from retired people. It takes billions to fill the pockets of `spendocrats.''' Elliot was a plaintiff in a nationwide, class-action suit pending against thrift owner Charles H. Keating Jr. and other Lincoln executives alleging fraud, Burlingame attorney Joseph Cotchett said. Keating and the others are charged with misleading investors about the safety of junk bonds issued by Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix. Prosecutors allege nearly 18,000 investors, many of them elderly, lost about $250 million. Experts say Lincoln's failure will cost taxpayers $2 billion. The money will go to pay off depositors. The Senate Ethics Committee is currently holding hearings to try to determine whether the so-called Keating Five - Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. - improperly intervened for Keating because of the $1.3 million he and associates contributed to their campaigns and favorite causes.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Estrogen Use Slightly Increases Breast Cancer Chances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY that researchers, not the study itself, recommend consulting with physicians on further use of estrogen. SUBS 8th graf, `Women who...', to CORRECT attribution to Colditz sted Stampfer.
DOC.TEXT: Women who take estrogen after menopause run a slightly higher risk of breast cancer, a 10-year study concluded. But researchers said women should not automatically abandon the hormone supplements. An estimated 20 million prescriptions for estrogen are written each year for post-menopausal women to relieve the symptoms of menopause, fight the debilitating bone disease osteoporosis and battle heart disease. The study of more than 118,000 woman nurses over a 10-year period indicated that women who take estrogen are 35 percent to 40 percent more likely to develop breast cancer than those who didn't take the hormone. Only a small fraction of the women in the study developed breast cancer, so the increase in risk was considered small. The added risk is only about half what a woman might face if her mother had breast cancer, said epidemiologist Dr. Graham Colditz of Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital, lead author of the study in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Once women stop taking estrogen, the risk is eliminated, he said. ``I would not recommend that a woman change her current use of estrogen therapy based on these data alone,'' said co-author Dr. Meir Stampfer of the Harvard School of Public Health in Boston. Women who are at high risk for breast cancer and no risk for heart disease might choose to avoid estrogen use, while women who run a high risk of heart disease and little risk of breast cancer might still use it, Colditz said. The article analyzed data collected from 1976 to 1986. In all, 722 incidents of breast cancer were identified among the women. Breast cancer strikes one in 10 American women, and 44,000 American women will die this year from the disease, according to the American Cancer Society.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Settles with Parents of Caesarean Patient
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTs lead to make it Liberties, sted Liberty
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a cancer patient who died shortly after undergoing a court-ordered Caesarean section have reached a settlement that the American Civil Liberties Union calls ``an important victory for women's rights.'' The settlement reached Monday between George Washington University Hospital and the family of Angela Carder includes a monetary award and an agreement by the hospital to establish policies protecting pregnant women's rights to determine their medical treatment. Both parties agreed not to disclose the size of the award. ``We did not want the dollar amount to overshadow what we think is the more significant outcome of the case, which is the policy perspective,'' said Terry Thorton, an attorney working with the ACLU who represented the family. Carder, 27, a terminal cancer patient at the hospital, died in 1987, two days after doctors performed a Caesarean section, ordered by a lower court, in an attempt to save the life of her 26-week-old fetus. The baby died less than three hours after the operation, which was listed as a contributing factor in Carder's death. Carder's parents, who live in Clarksville, Md., appealed the order, saying that their daughter, who was conscious and coherent at the time of the operation, did not give informed consent. Further, the family charged that the surgery violated Carder's right to bodily integrity. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals ruled in the family's favor last April, saying, ``A fetus cannot have rights ... superior to those of a person who has already been born.'' On behalf of the Stoners, the ACLU brought a civil suit and a medical malpractice case against the hospital, charging that the hospital had not taken sufficient measures to determine Carder's wishes and did not consult the family before requesting the court order. In accordance with the settlement, the hospital has agreed to establish policies aimed at precluding court intervention in such cases. ``We have learned a great deal from the Angela Carder case,'' said Christine St. Andre of the hospital. ``When Angela Carder was a patient at GW, we had not yet developed policies which addressed critical questions concerning ... maternal and fetal rights.'' St. Andre said the hospital has established an ethics committee to address such issues and will provide a list of referrals specializing in reproductive rights for legal assistance. Patients will be informed of their rights prior to treatment and advocates will be made available to patients should conflicts arise. The hospital and the ACLU agree that the most significant part of the settlement is that it confirms that the court is an inappropriate place to resolve such conflicts.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Mortality Rate Still Unacceptable, Foundation Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS summary line to make it Mortality, sted Morality
DOC.TEXT: The nation's infant death rate among blacks remains stuck at unacceptably high levels that prevailed 20 years ago, says the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation. The group warned Wednesday the infant death rate for whites and blacks has shown little improvement. At the current pace, the country will fall short of its goal of reducing the rate to seven in 1,000 births by the year 2000, said Dr. Reed Tuckson, the foundation's senior vice president for programs. The comments came after the government announced the infant death rate in 1988 was 10 per 1,000 births, a 1 percent drop from the previous year. There were 38,910 deaths of infants under 1 year of age in 1988. Tuckson said President Bush should go ahead with recommendations from an unreleased White House report urging expansion of Medicaid and more money for community health centers. The White House task force report also recommends stepped up federal efforts to reduce smoking, drinking and drug abuse during pregnancy, Tuckson said. ``Babies are dying while a prescription for helping them sits on a shelf,'' said Tuckson. There is a sharp difference between the infant death rate for whites and blacks. The rate for white infants was 8.5 per 1,000 births in 1988 while for black infants it was 17.6.
