Tuckson said the black infant death rate today is nearly equal to the white infant death rate in 1970. The death rate for black infants historically has been more than twice the rate for whites. The government also reported on other mortality data for 1988. It said the national death rate from AIDS rose 20 percent in 1988, making it the 15th-leading cause of death in the country. The death rate for homicide also went up in 1988, while the decline of recent years in mortality from heart disease and stroke contnued, reported the National Center for Health Statistics, which is part of the Centers for Disease Control. There was a slight decline in the rate of death from cancer. Education and prevention efforts, which helped combat chronic disease, ``can also be effective in helping us deal with these new threats'' of AIDS and homicide, said CDC director William Roper. There were 16,602 deaths due to AIDS in 1988, 6.6 deaths per 100,000 population, said the CDC's National Center for Health Statistics. AIDS was the 15th-leading cause of death in both 1987 and 1988. The death rate from homicide rose 4.7 percent in 1988, to nine per 100,000 people. It was the 12th-leading cause of death.

DOC.HEAD: France Says Fighting Worse in Chad, Sends More Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: French officials said today that a rebel offensive in Chad is gaining strength, and the government ordered 150 Foreign Legionnaires to reinforce French troops in Chad but said they would not join the fighting. Chad's government contends the rebels are backed by Libya, a view shared by the U.S. State Department. Libya denies the claim, and France has described the 3-week-old war as an internal conflict between Chadians. A French Foreign Ministry spokesman said today ``the situation is worsening, and the battles are more severe.'' Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said the rebel offensive has grown in size, ``and government forces are encountering difficulties on the ground.'' Other French sources said rebel leader Idriss Deby's forces were moving western, away from the border with Sudan and toward the capital, N'Djamena. The French Defense Ministry said a 150-strong company of the Second Foreign Parachutist Regiment would be sent to N'Djamena. The move was aimed at ``bettering the security of our troops and assuring, if need be, the protection of our nationals.'' There are an estimated 1,250 French civilians in Chad, a former French colony. France already had 1,000 troops in Chad, and recently redeployed a company from N'Djamena to the northeastern town of Abeche near the main combat zone. France has said that President Hissene Habre's troops suffered considerable losses in the recent fighting. The two sides have claimed to take and retake several eastern towns, but neither has offered casualty figures. Habre was reported to be personally directing the battle last week and allegedly narrowly escaped capture by the rebels. Habre was reported back in N'Djamena this week and was seen on Chad TV Wednesday welcoming a foreign dignitary at the airport. Deby helped Habre take power in 1982 and was a military adviser to the president, but fled in April 1989 amid allegations he was part of a coup plot. French Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said on Tuesday that France was not involved in the latest fighting. France first sent thousands of troops to Chad in Operation Sparrowhawk in February 1986 at the height of fighting in northern Chad against Libyan-backed rebels. Libya then occupied the northern part of the poor, landlocked country, but was chased out in a series of battles in 1987. The two nations signed a peace treaty last year. The U.S. State Department on Wednesday deplored the attacks by the rebels. ``They represent the latest example of Libya's ongoing efforts to destabilize legitimate governments,'' the State Department said. It added that the United States ``fully supports'' the Habre government's efforts to resist the incursions.

DOC.HEAD: University Team Discovers `Whale Dinosaur' And Late-Surviving Brontosaurus
LaserPhoto DX8
DOC.TEXT: An expedition has discovered remains of a gigantic ``whale dinosaur'' and a brontosaurus that lived more recently than other known dinosaurs of its type, scientists announced. University of Colorado Paleontologist Robert Bakker said Wednesday that the two finds in the fertile dinosaur fields of southern Wyoming are providing important clues about dinosaur extinction. Bakker said the remains of a 70-foot-long Haplocanthosaurus, a member of the cetiosaur or ``whale dinosaur'' family, were found in the Como Bluffs area near McFadden, Wyo., last July. The team also is excavating a brontosaurus that is the only one of its kind known to have survived the Cretaceous Period that began about 135 million years ago. The excavation is under way near Rock River, Wyo., in a fossil deposit known as the Breakfast Bench. Rock River is just a few miles north of Como Bluff. Bakker said that before this discovery, no brontosaurus had ever been unearthed that was less than about 137 million years old. ``This means the Golden Book of Dinosaurs will need a slight footnote, since this particular animal apparently managed to slide just under the tag into the Cretaceous,'' he said. The brontosaurus bones were found last May by Don Kralis, a high school science teacher from Leadville who has been assisting Bakker with his Wyoming fieldwork. ``Finding this brontosaurus was a big surprise,'' Bakker said. ``Our initial reaction was that the animal was stuck in the wrong time zone.'' The whale dinosaur or cetiosaur, dubbed the ``Carlin Giant,'' was found by James Filla, an expedition volunteer and physicist at the National Institute of Science and Technology in Boulder. The find included a shoulder, thigh, tailbone, hand, forearm, shin and several vertebrae from both the Carlin Giant and another small specimen. The Carlin Giant is the largest member of cetiosaur family ever unearthed, Bakker said. ``It's not surprising that this particular animal was so big because it appears to be the last in its line,'' Bakker said. ``As a rule, the large dinosaurs tended to get larger before they went extinct, and we seem to have caught the last gasp of the cetiosaur.'' Cetiosaurs, large plant-eaters that were common during the late Jurassic Period about 150 million years ago, apparently were the victim of a worldwide catastrophe that struck about that time, said Bakker. ``One after another, the giant dinosaur families died out, and the cetiosaurs were the first to go,'' Bakker said. ``As far as we know, this was the first major extinction of a large dinosaur family during the late Jurassic.'' He said his paleontology team's work at Como Bluff has determined the cetiosaurs were the first dinosaur family to die off in a one-by-one, ``stepwise'' extinction sequence. It spanned a period beginning 150 million years ago and ending 66 million years ago. ``Stepwise patterns just don't agree with the popular theory that a cataclysmic disaster suddenly wiped out the dinosaurs,'' Bakker said. ``The fossil record clearly indicates that these mass extinctions were not the result of one Saturday night of cosmic mayhem.''

DOC.HEAD: Germany to Send Huge Food Reserves to Soviet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Germany to send Berlin reserves, CORRECTS amount Red Cross sends to 37 tons, ADDS details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Germany will send the Soviet Union huge food reserves that were stockpiled to help feed West Berlin in case of a repeat of the 1948-49 Soviet blockade of the city, a top government official said today. The announcement regarding the so-called Berlin reserves was the latest in a series of German actions aimed at helping the Soviets. It was made by Horst Teltschik, chief foreign policy adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Also today, the German Red Cross sent 37 tons of emergency food supplies on an Aeroflot plane to the Soviet Union, starting what officials hope could be a daily airlift to the Soviet Union. A telethon on Germany's ZDF television Wednesday night netted pledges of 3.8 million marks ($2.6 million) to help Soviets burdened by the onset of winter and empty shelves in state stores. Other campaigns are collecting millions of dollars more worth of donations and goods. If the pace keeps up, the relief effort could become the largest such humanitarian action Germany has launched. Teltschik, who just returned from talks in Moscow, told reporters that Kohl had agreed to send the Berlin reserves to the Soviets. He said details would be worked out next week. The massive stockpiles of grain, canned fruit and other foods and supplies are valued at up to $1.6 billion. Officials in West Berlin had built up the reserves in case of a repeat of the blockade that cut off all but air travel to and from the western side of the divided city. A U.S.-led airlift broke the blockade in 1949. Berlin officials urged that the supplies be sent to the Soviets as sign of good will in the current era of improved relations between East and West. In Bonn, the German branch of the CARE international relief organization said today it would soon be sending the first batch of 20,000 food packages to the Soviet Union. The packages contain such items as chocolate, rice and meat. CARE packages sent by Americans were vital in feeding Germans after World War II, and the memory of the welcome aid has become part of national history. Germany has been leading international efforts to aid the Soviets. Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher both have appealed for private donations for the action. ``Please help relieve the need in the Soviet Union. This is a work of charity and of good neighborliness,'' Kohl said in an appeal broadcast Wednesday night on ZDF television. Kohl also called to mind the Soviets' role in clearing the way for German unification less than two months ago. ``We all have to thank the Soviet Union in these months,'' Kohl said. ``I am certain that we all are ready to help.'' Genscher has said widespread hunger in the Soviet Union could lead to instability that in turn could threaten the rest of Europe. Teltschik was in Moscow this week discussing ways to get the German donations into the Soviet Union and to keep the goods out of the hands of black-marketeers. Teltschik said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised to expedite customs and visas for the aid program and Germans could accompany the aid deliveries. On Friday, large trucks and buses, also filled with supplies, are scheduled to head to the Soviet Union along with 16 Red Cross workers, Botho zu Sayn-Wittgenstein, head of the German Red Cross, said in an interview with Deutschlandfunk Radio. He said the food would start to reach the most needy people - those in retirement homes and homes for the handicapped - by the weekend. Red Cross officials said an enormous relief action is planned, although they could not give precise figures until they know amount of private donations and government support. Many republics and regions of the Soviet Union have halted shipments of fod and consumer goods to other areas as central control over the economy erodes. Rather than obey Kremlin demands for deliveries of food to the cities at state prices they consider too low, they are trading directly with factories and regions, bartering for other scarce supplies. Economic reforms have also freed farmers to sell more of their produce at market prices, leaving less for delivery at state-set prices to the state stores. Employee theft is rampant. The Soviet Union had a record grain crop this year, but millions of tons of wheat rotted in fields for lack of equipment, fuel and transport.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leaders Begin Summit on South African Factional Fighting
DOC.TEXT: A summit of black leaders called by Archbishop Desmond Tutu to seek peace in South Africa began today with the noteable absence of Zulu leader Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Buthelezi and two black homeland leaders turned down the invitation from the Anglican archbishop to take part in the meeting to discuss efforts to end apartheid and replace it with a democratic state. The summit will talk about problems confronting South African blacks, including black factional fighting that has claimed thousands of lives in recent years. Most of the fighting has been between members of Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha movement and African National Congress supporters. In calling in October for the summit, Tutu said those who did not attend would reveal themselves as enemies of peace and unity. Had Buthelezi turned up, it would have been the first meeting between him and the ANC's deputy president, Nelson Mandela. The meeting in part had been called to bring the two face-to-face to discuss the violence. The leaders of the Bophuthatswana and Ciskei homelands also declined to attend. ``Those who have turned down the invitation need to examine their motives,'' Tutu said today shortly before the delegates sat down to talk at his official residence at Bishopscourt. Tutu pointedly avoided a specific reference to Buthelezi in his rebuke. ``We would have wanted the meeting to be a great deal more inclusive than it is turning out to be,'' he said. ``The point is that when you want peace you talk to anybody.'' He said he hoped the meeting would be the beginning of a process that would ``make a difference'' in South Africa. He said he was particularly concerned about the intolerance among rival black groups that led to ``violence, carnage and mayhem.'' ``In a way we are looking for a miracle. We don't believe that the age of miracles has ended,'' he said. There was no immediate comment from Mandela on Buthelezi's absence. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to end white minority rule and share power with the black majority. The government and the ANC are expected to start talks next year on a new constitution. The 10 black homelands were set up by the government under the apartheid system of racial segregation. Four of them - Bophuthatswana, Transkei, Ciskei and Venda - are considered independent by South Africa, but no other countries recognize their sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Race Violence Law Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 5th graf, `Witnesses said...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled a state law against ethnic intimidation is unconstitutional, and dismissed a charge against a white man accused of setting fire to a black family's home. The 1989 law makes it a crime to harm someone because of race or ethnic background. Washtenaw County Judge Thomas Shea on Wednesda said the law violates the free speech provision of the First Amendment. Shea ordered Christopher Justice to stand trial on an arson charge but threw out the ethnic intimidation count. Justice, 21, of Superior Township is charged with setting fire Nov. 9 to the home of Sherwin and Tracey McDonald in a subdivision near his home. Witnesses said Justice called the fire victims ``a bunch of niggers.'' Shea said the ethnic intimidation law, which carries a maximum prison term of two years, was being used to prosecute language protected by the First Amendment. He said the racial epithet isn't the kind of violence-causing language that falls outside the First Amendment's protection. Assistant Prosecutor Mackie said his office will decide whether to appeal the dismissal.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Latest Anti-Iraq Resolution
With PM-Gulf-UN
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of U.N. Security Council Resolution 677 asking the United Nations to take custody of Kuwait's demographic records, adopted on Wednesday: The Security Council, Recalling its resolutions 660 (1990) of 2 August 1990, 662 (1990) of 9 August 1990 and 674 (1990) of 29 October 1990, Reiterating its concern for the suffering caused to individuals in Kuwait as a result of the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq, Gravely concerned at the ongoing attempt by Iraq to alter the demographic composition of the population of Kuwait and to destroy the civil records maintained by the legitimate government of Kuwait, Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, 1. Condemns the attempts by Iraq to alter the demographic composition of the population of Kuwait and to destroy the civil records maintained by the legitimate government of Kuwait; 2. Mandates the Secretary-General to take custody of a copy of the population register of Kuwait, the authenticity of which has been certified by the legitimate government of Kuwait and which covers the registration of population up to 1 August 1990; 3. Requests the Secretary-General to establish, in cooperation with the legitimate government of Kuwait, an Order of Rules and Regulations governing access to and use of the said copy of the population register.

DOC.HEAD: Denver Mayor Will Not Seek Re-election
DOC.TEXT: Federico Pena will call it quits after two terms as mayor. Pena, 43, made a suprise announcement Wednesday that he will not seek election to a third term in 1991. ``Sometimes people in public office continue to run, and run, and run, and I don't think that's what voters want,'' said Pena, a Democrat. He said 12 years in office non-stop - including four years in the Colorado House of Representatives - ``is a long time.'' This month, Colorado voters approved a limit of eight consecutive years for holding a single state office. The limit does not apply to the mayor's job. In 1983, Pena assembled a coalition of Hispanics, blacks and upscale whites to upset 14-year incumbent Bill McNichols in a seven-way non-partisan primary race. He won a second term four years later. Then the city found itself in the midst of a real-estate bust when the price of oil plummeted, and has been slow to recover. Pena pointed to some achievements - the completion of a new convention center and the start of a $3 billion international airport. The city also is trying to land a National League baseball expansion team. Pena, a lawyer, moved to Denver in 1973 from his native Texas and first drew attention pushing civil rights' causes for Hispanics.

DOC.HEAD: Dramatic Increase of AIDS in Women Feared
DOC.TEXT: AIDS among women is likely to increase dramatically over the next 10 years, with three out of four AIDS virus infections resulting from heterosexual contact, the World Health Organization said today. It estimated that of the 9 to 11 million adults and children now carrying the HIV virus, 3 million are women. Most of them live in the Third World. The new projections were released in advance of World AIDS Day Dec. 1. WHO said the share of global HIV infections resulting from sex between men and women will rise from 60 percent now to 75 percent to 80 percent by 2000. This will mean ``dramatic increases in HIV infection among women,'' WHO said. It forecast that by the end of the decade the number of carriers would rise to between 25 and 30 million worldwide, including 10 million children born to infected mothers. Scientists say women who have sex with AIDS-infected men are much more likely to catch the virus than are men who have sex with infected women. A recent finding suggested women were 14 times more likely than men to catch the virus that way. ``We certainly can say that the AIDS pandemic will continue into future generations, Dr. Michael H. Merson, head of the WHO's Global Program on AIDS, told reporters. The agency's monthly AIDS statistics, also made public today, listed 156 countries reporting a total of 307,379 cases, an increase of more than 8,000 over October. Updated figures from the United States, Burundi, Rwanda, Zambia, Brazil, Italy and Spain were mainly responsible for the increase. Because of widespread underreporting, WHO estimates the real cumulative total of cases at 1.3 million, one third of them women. Merson said the projected increase in heterosexual virus transmission was especially marked in developing countries. They are expected to account for 80 to 90 percent of all infections by 2000, compared with about 65 percent now. In sub-Saharan Africa, one out of 40 women is infected, against one in 500 women in Latin America and one in 700 women in North America, WHO said. ``In some cities in sub-Saharan Africa, up to 40 percent of men and women may be infected with HIV,'' it said. ``These infections will cause a doubling or tripling of the total adult mortality rate during the 1990s.'' In the developed world, less than 10 percent of the infections result from heterosexual contacts but that share is ``slowly increasing,'' Merson said. Merson said ``some scientists'' expect that ``some vaccines'' may be ready for testing within two to three years. But he made plain that he doubted that there will be an early breakthrough. ``We will be lucky if we have a vaccine by the end of this decade,'' he said in response to a question.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Gets Rare Late-November Warmth, But It Doesn't Last
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with record set early this morning in NYC, temperatures dropping by late morning. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Windsurfing and ...'. DELETES 8th graf pvs, `The warm...', now outdated. Madd is cq in 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: People in the Northeast used to bundling up this time of year got one last change to hit the streets in shirt sleeves, but things began returning to normal this morning as temperatures fell. Boston hit 74 degrees Wednesday, breaking the record of 68 for the date set in 1896. It was the highest temperature ever recorded in Boston so late in the year. New York City peaked at 69 degrees at midnight, tying a 95-year-old record for Nov. 28. The normal high for the date is 48 degrees. The temperature held at 69 at 1 a.m. today, two degrees warmer than the record for Nov. 29 set in 1968, according to the National Weather Service. But by 10 a.m. today, the mercury dipped to 50 degrees in New York and to 56 degrees in Boston. The heat Wednesday forced the first-ever postponement of a Boston Celtics basketball game at Boston Garden when condensation from the ice hockey rink under the court made the floor too slick to play on safely. Windsurfing and other warm-weather pursuits took center stage. ``On a day like today people don't waste time in the shop,'' said manager Ed Silvia at Madd Mike's Windsurfing Warehouse in Boston. ``If there's a good wind, people will just shoot right out, unless there's a few stragglers who need equipment.'' Ice skaters at Rockefeller Center in New York glided as usual around the rink beneath the complex's giant Christmas tree - except that most skaters abandoned their coats. Temperatures were expected to drop back down to the 40s over the weekend, and forecasters predicted a colder than normal winter for most of the East. ``Thus, in spite of our record 74-degree temperature in Boston today, you may want to keep that snow shovel handy,'' the weather service said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Arrives, Sign Of Tenuous Return To Normalcy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with ambasador presenting his credentials to Hrawi. Pickup 8th, `In Washington...'
DOC.TEXT: The new U.S. ambassador to Lebanon, Ryan Crocker, presented his credentials to President Elias Hrawi today after reopening the U.S. Embassy, which was evacuated 15 months ago during fierce fighting. The decision to send in Crocker despite the still tenuous security situation reflects U.S. support for Hrawi's government, which is trying to create a militia-free capital and end 15{ years of civil war. ``I have presented to his excellency, President Hrawi, my letters of credence accrediting me as ambassador ... of the United States to Lebanon,'' Crocker told reporters after the 30-minute ceremony. The ceremony, attended by the U.S. Embassy's first secretary, Patrick McCurary, as well as Prime Minister Salim Hoss, was held at Hrawi's temporary residence in the seaside Ramlet al-Baida district of Moslem west Beirut. Crocker, dressed in a gray suit, arrived at the president's residence after a one-hour meeting with Hoss at the government house in which he presented a copy of his credentials. Green-bereted soldiers of the Lebanese army's elite commando brigade provided security for Crocker, surrounding his car with seven jeeps that sped across the jammed streets of west Beirut with lights on and horns honking. The ceremony occurred one day after Crocker was flown by helicopter from Cyprus, to the U.S. Embassy compound in Beirut's northern suburb of Aukar. Crocker, 51, a career diplomat who joined the State Department in 1971, became the first American diplomat to enter the U.S. Embassy compound since it was evacuated by former Ambassador John McCarthy and his staff Sept. 6, 1989. Followers of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun had besieged the compound. The Christian general, who battled Syrian troops backing the government, was defeated in October. Militias have since been withdrawing from the capital. Crocker was based in Lebanon as a political officer at the embassy in the early 1980s. He also held diplomatic posts in Iran, Qatar and Iraq. In Washington, deputy State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said on Wednesday that Crocker was dispatched to Beirut after a U.S. security team inspected the situation in the Lebanese capital last weekend. A Lebanese Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Crocker and seven American security officials arrived at the embassy compound Wednesday morning aboard two U.S. helicopters. He said a third helicopter also landed supplies at the heavily-guarded embassy compound. A state department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States had discussed its decision to send in Crocker with Syria, which backs Hrawi with 40,000 troops deployed in most of Lebanon. The major Druse and Shiite Moslem militias have pulled out fighters from areas they controlled within ``Greater Beirut'' in line with government plans to create a militia-free capital. Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces right-wing Christian militia has withdrawn about 140 tons of ammunition from areas it controlled in east Beirut and said it would withdraw fighters later to the Christian heartland north of the Greater Beirut boundaries. Greater Beirut stretches along a 15-mile coastal strip from the Kelb River in the north to the Damour River in the south and extends east to the central mountains to cover the city's immediate suburbs. Crocker was based in Lebanon as a political officer at the embassy in the early 1980s. He also held diplomatic posts in Iran, Qatar and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pesky Zebra Mussels Found in Hudson
DOC.TEXT: The zebra mussel, a fast-breeding type of shellfish that clogs the intake pipes of power plants, has been found in the Hudson River for the first time, scientists said. The mussels, which had not been seen east of the central section of the Erie Canal, were found off Croton Point in Westchester County, New York City's northern suburbs. It was identified Wednesday by experts at the New York Zebra Mussel Information Clearinghouse at the State University of New York at Brockport. ``It is the first confirmed North American sighting of the mussel outside of the Great Lakes drainage basin,'' Charles O'Neill Jr., a supervisor at the clearinghouse, told The New York Times in a story published today. O'Neill noted that the zebra mussel, classified as a freshwater animal, is not usually found in saltwater like the lower Hudson. ``It raises a lot of questions that we don't have answers for,'' he said. The zebra mussel, a native of Europe, was first found in the United States in 1988 in Lake St. Clair, east of Detroit. Named for its dark brown stripes on a tan shell, the mussel breeds quickly and can clog the intake pipes of power plants and eats microscopic plants at the base of the food chain for freshwater fish. In areas where the mussels have taken hold, utilities have fought back by flushing pipes with treated water, cleaning intake screens by hand and using chlorine and other chemicals to kill them. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has estimated that the expanding population of the mussels could add $500 million a year in added costs for utilities, water companies and factories and loss of business in sports fishing, marinas and motels along inland waterways.

DOC.HEAD: `Empowering' the Poor Sparks White House Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 11, Darman's words, with 4 grafs White House reaction. Picks up 12th pvs, In an.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's quest to aid the poor by substituting self-help programs for government handouts is sparking friction among White House aides, administration officials and conservative members of Congress. It even prompted a call by Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., for Budget Director Richard Darman either to recant a recent speech or resign. A group of conservative policy makers inside the White House, with strong backing from HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, is pressing to make ``empowering'' initiatives in housing, education and welfare the centerpiece of Bush's next State of the Union address. The general philosophy, say those backing the concept, is to give people tools to help themselves, rather than having government social programs do it for them. For example, housing legislation signed by Bush on Wednesday aims to help poor people buy public housing apartments or vacant homes. ``A cornerstone of our effort to reduce the heavy hand of government is this idea of empowering people, not bureaucracies,'' the president said in signing the measure. The debate was sparked partly by a speech last April by James P. Pinkerton, Bush's deputy assistant for policy planning, in which he said the idea is to enact ``policies that empower people to make choices for themselves.'' But the concept drew a public rebuke earlier this month from Darman, who ridiculed the slogan of ``the new paradigm'' as pretentious and meaningless. Darman dismissed the idea of boosting the use of vouchers and decentralized policymaking as a throwback to old initiatives that did not work in the 1960s. ``We now find ourselves encouraged to embrace several programmatic ideas that are returning from a quarter-century hiatus, but which have not yet been seriously tested or evaluated,'' Darman said in a Nov. 16 speech to the Council for Excellence in Government, a private watchdog group. The ideas are ``little more than slogans,'' he said. Darman's words infuriated conservatives. Gingrich denounced the Darman speech as ``an assault on members of his own party'' and demanded Wednesday night that Darman either recant or resign. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Darman and Gingrich had smoothed over their differences in a telephone conversation today, and that Darman was not withdrawing the speech. ``Director Darman and Newt had a long conversation this morning and they `re great and good friends, and there's no problem,'' said Fitzwater. Asked if Bush stood by his budget director, Fitzwater said, ``Sure.'' In an era when communist regimes around the world are collapsing, Bush is warming to the theme of putting power back in the hands of people and out of the grip of centralized bureaucracies. The National Affordable Housing Act - including $25 billion this year and $27 billion in fiscal 1992 - provides grants for low-income families to buy their public housing units or homes that are vacant or have been foreclosed. The measure provides $155 million for such projects this year and $885 million for 1992. It also authorizes $123 million this fiscal year and $258 million for 1992 to provide housing and services for the homeless. And, it contains a new block grant program, authorizing $1 billion for this year and $2.1 billion for 1992 to promote partnerships by federal, state and local governments with private groups and industry to meet housing needs, the White House said. Earlier Wednesday, Kemp briefed members of the Domestic Policy Council on possible initiatives under consideration for the State of the Union address and fiscal 1992 budget. Bush named Kemp on Aug. 6 to head a task force on empowerment. The ideas that Kemp and the White House conservatives are touting, including vouchers to give parents wider choice in education, inner-city enterprise zones and tenant ownership of public housing, are hardly new. In fact, former President Reagan went to bat for most of them to no avail. But their advocates are banking on rising public dissatisfaction with government to give new life to these old ideas. ``The new paradigm enables the GOP to move forward in these areas and do good, without going back to the Great Society of noble rhetoric and unintended consequences,'' Pinkerton said in April. For Republicans, he said, ``fighting taxes and communists has brought us about as far as it can. ... The future growth of the Republican party depends on our ability to address voters' concerns about other important issues, such as health, child care, education and pollution.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leaders: 50 Dead In Clashes With Security Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD quotes from airline passengers from Dhaka, communications, flights restored. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bangladeshi security forces killed 50 people and wounded more than 1,000 in battles with protesters demanding President Hussain Muhammad Ershad's ouster, the country's opposition leaders said today. The claims were made in Bangladesh's capital, Dhaka, by Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia, who said the deaths and injuries occurred when demonstrators ignored a curfew on Wednesday. The reports could not be verified. Some previous claims by the opposition have been exaggerated. Press censorship was severe in Bangladesh. An Associated Press story from Dhaka was reduced from 14 paragraphs to four by government censors. Telephone and telex communications were restored today after being severed for nearly 24 hours. Diplomatic sources in New Delhi said they received reports that four people were killed and 15 wounded Wednesday in Dhaka. The sources said on condition of anonymity that paramilitary troops fired into a mob of 5,000 in central Dhaka, killing three people. One more died in a confrontation in the Old City, according to reports reaching the diplomats. Ershad declared a state of emergency on Tuesday night, suspending civil rights, imposing a curfew, and censoring the press after six weeks of often- violent opposition protests. Witnesses said demonstrations continued today. Kurt Hensena, a businessman based in Hong Kong, said he heard gunfire when he left his Dhaka hotel for the airport this afternoon. Fighting was heavier Wednesday. ``It was bam bam bam bam, and then it was quiet again. It was shotgun, rifle fire. I heard a lot of people shouting,'' he said upon arrival in Bangkok, Thailand. A Dutch traveler also on the first flight from Dhaka since the crackdown said he was trapped by roadblocks on Wednesday and his car was stoned as he drove through the crowd. The curfew was lifted for four hours today and residents of Dhaka, a city of 7 million people, jammed stores to stock up on food. The curfew also is in effect in the major cities of Chittagong, Khulna and Rajshahi. On Wednesday morning, just before the news blackout was enforced, reporters saw thousands of anti-Ershad activists defy the curfew and fight with the outnumbered police force. The army was then called out and continued to patrol the streets today, according to unofficial reports reaching India. Ms. Hasina claimed that 50 people were killed Wednesday when security forces opened fire in Dhaka and the smaller cities of Chittagong, Khulna, Rajshahi, Bogra and Barisal. She is the leader of the opposition Awami League. Mrs. Zia, leader of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party, claimed that government forces had wounded more than 1,000 since Tuesday. She said the government had arrested 3,000 people. Both women made their accusations in written statements that circulated in Dhaka and reached India through unofficial channels. On Oct. 10, Ms. Hasina and Mrs. Zia put aside their long-time personal and political rivalries to coordinate a new round of protests against Ershad, a former army general who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982. Hasina is the daughter of Bangladesh's first president, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, assassinated during a 1975 coup. Mrs. Zia is the widow of another president, Ziaur Rahman, killed in another coup in 1981. About 900 teachers at Bangladesh's biggest university resigned today to protest the state of emergency, according to reports reaching India. The instructors gathered at Dhaka University this morning when curfew was relaxed, according to the reports. Dhaka University has been a center of agitation against Ershad. The school and many others had been closed earlier because of the unrest. The opposition accuses Ershad of rigging the 1986 election in which he won the presidency, and subsequent parliamentary elections won by his Jatiya Party. The only official word from Bangladesh today was from state radio, which said only that the curfew was relaxed in Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna and Rajshahi. It said there had been attempts to violate the curfew. Under the state of emergency, all civil rights were suspended and news censorship was imposed. Before Wednesday, at least 10 people were confirmed killed and 1,000 injured in street clashes stemming from the six-week-old opposition campaign of demonstrations and strikes. The current campaign for Ershad's ouster was launched after he announced that new presidential elections would take place in June 1991. The opposition says Ershad must resign and a caretaker government installed before the elections are held.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Chief to Retire Early
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Job's age in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Glen Renfrew, chief executive and managing director of Reuters Holdings PLC, will retire March 1, the British-based news agency and information group announced today. Renfrew, 62, will be replaced by Peter Job, 49, who is now the Hong Kong-based managing director of Reuters Asia. Renfrew retires after nearly 39 years with the company, including 10 years in his present position. Job has been at Reuters for 27 years. A spokesman at the company's headquarters said Renfrew's decision to retire had been anticipated widely and that his departure in March would ensure an orderly succession. The mandatory retirement age at Reuters is 65. The company announced in August that Renfrew had sold 20 percent of his personal holding in the company for 1.72 milion pounds (then $3.3 million). The sale of the 210,000 shares - a 0.05 percent stake - left Renfrew with 849,378 shares.

DOC.HEAD: Former Military Leaders Caution Against Rushing to War
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs, editing to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: A former Navy secretary today called President Bush's 430,000-troop buildup in the Persian Gulf a mistake and said attacking Iraq would compound it. But the White House insisted Saddam Hussein must know ``that he could face military action at any time.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also said Bush remains reluctant to call Congress back to discuss the gulf crisis, despite recent calls for a special session. ``Let's wait and see,'' Fitzwater said, suggesting Bush would consult with members of Congress he has invited to the White House on Friday about the possibility of a special session. James Webb, a former Navy secretary in the Reagan administration, told the Senate Armed Service Committee today that ``the president's mistake in sending so many troops should not be compounded by a further error in using them in a premature, unprovoked ground offensive.'' Webb is the third former top military official to urge caution in the gulf. Two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Wednesday Bush should give sanctions against Iraq more time to work before opting for war. But Fitzwater shrugged off the comments, as well as House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt's announced opposition to any early use of force. ``We simply disagree with the congressman about that,'' Fitzwater said. The White House spokesman said the additional troop buildup was vital ``to maintain an offensive capability should it be needed.'' And Fitzwater said the resolution to be voted on later today by the UN Security Council to authorize force against Iraq is also essential. ``The fact is, we want this resolution as a way of keeping pressure on Saddam, keeping him aware of the fact that he could face military action at any time,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Following 4 grafs embargoed for 12 noon EST
DOC.TEXT: Meanwhile, Vice President Dan Quayle argued against waiting too long before using military force against Iraq. ``Does patience today risk greater American casualties tomorrow?'' Quayle asked in remarks prepared for a speech to Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J. ``Even as we exercise patience and restraint, we must also be alert to the moral costs of such a course,'' Quayle said. He said that ``with every day that passes,'' the plight of the people of Kuwait ``grows more desperate.'' Furthermore, Quayle said, ``will continued patience with Iraq help make the world vulnerable to nuclear blackmail by Saddam Hussein'' And if so, is this a moral course of action?''
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: Fitzwater said Bush has made no decisions yet about a special session of Congress, which either Bush or congressional leaders could initiate. ``There's been no decision here to hold a special session. The president obviously will discuss this'' in his Friday meeting. ``We'll continue to consult with members of Congress about it. Some feel it would be beneficial, others feel it wouldn't.'' Asked if Bush were reluctant to call such a session, Fitzwater replied: ``Reluctant is a good word.'' In his congressional testimony, Webb said the president should call for an ``immediate resumption of the draft and then a declaration of war'' by the Congress. Richard Perle, who also served in the Reagan administration as an assistant secretary of defense, said an American defeat in the gulf would do serious damage to the nation. It ``would gravely diminish the strength and authority with which the United States emerged from a half century of opposition to the idea that military power, whether it be Hitler's or Stalin's or Saddam Hussein's, can be allowed to determine the fate of nations,'' Perle said. On Wednesday, two former U.S. military chiefs bolstered Democratic demands for a go-slow approach in the gulf. ``The question is how much pain we administer and how quickly and whether we do it with the embargo or the use of force,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate minority leader, said Wednesday evening the chances were ``better than 50-50'' for a special session on the gulf crisis, probably before Christmas. The Senate hearings were prompted by Bush's decision to send 200,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf region to supplement 230,000 sent there after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I think the force is much too large to be able to be sustained politically and perhaps even logistically,'' Nunn said at the conclusion of the day's hearing. ``I counsel patience. War is not neat, it's not tidy. It's a mess,'' said retired Adm. William Crowe, who was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under Reagan. Retired Air Force Gen. David C. Jones, chairman of the joint chiefs under Carter, voiced concern with the latest troop deployment. Jones said his fear ``isn't that we might choose to fight, but rather that the deployment might cause us to fight - perhaps prematurely and perhaps unnecessarily.'' Crowe and Jones recommended that the United States give the sanctions a year to 18 months to take effect before resorting to military force.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 14 Americans to be Freed With Muhammad Ali
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 15th graf pvs, `The delegation,' to UPDATE with comment from Canadian lawmaker. Pickup 16th, `Sixty-eight...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials have promised to free at least 14 American hostages in response to a plea from former world heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali, his spokesman said. A left-wing British lawmaker, meanwhile, left Baghdad today saying 15 Britons would be released in response to a request he made in a meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. And in Finland, there were reports that a Finnish delegation had secured the release of five of the eight Finns being held. Three Canadian lawmakers negotiated the release five of the 45 Canadians trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The lawmakers said that unlike other nations that sent medicines and made overtures to Iraq in exchange for captives, they had made no deals with Saddam. They implied their stance had reduced the number of Canadians freed. Ali, who is suffering from Parkinson's disease and who traveled to Baghdad at the invitation of Iraq, met with Saddam on Tuesday for 50 minutes. Ali used hand signals to communicate with Jaber Mohammed, who speaks for him. Saddam used the meeting, which was shown on Iraqi television, to repeat that the hostages, which he calls guests, are being well treated. Ali's spokesman, Jaber Mohammed, said the 48-year-old former champion and his entourage expect to leave Baghdad on Saturday and hope to receive a list of the hostages to be freed today. He said Iraq promised Ali at least 14 hostages. The government has prevented hundreds of Westerners from leaving since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But it has allowed some captives to leave with visiting politicians, prominent public figures and peace groups. The Bush administration has condemned the sporadic releases as aimed at dividing the world alliance against Iraq. Almost 1,000 Americans remain in Iraq and Kuwait, more than 100 held as ``human shields'' at strategic military and industrial sites in Iraq. Hundreds from other nations are also being held in Iraq and the occupied emirate. British lawmaker Tony Benn, who met with the Iraqi president on Wednesday, said he was told the British hostages would be freed soon, but no specific timetable was given. The Parliament member, from Britain's opposition Labor Party, traveled to Baghdad on Sunday in search of ``possibilities of a peaceful settlement'' to the gulf crisis, he said. Canadian lawmakers said they had made no deals with Saddam. ``We have made no concessions, signed no declarations, have not been involved in bargaining or bartering,'' said Canadian lawmaker, Robert Corbett. ``We made it clear we had nothing to offer.'' The delegation arrived in Amman today with two of the five Canadians released by Iraq - Hassanain Abdul Aziz, 18, from Toronto, and Lee Binns, 38, of Calgary. The other three were expected to leave shortly. ``We came to Iraq hoping to return home with 47 Canadians,'' lawmaker Svend Robinson told reporters at Amman airport. ``But some delegations came back after having paid a fairly heavy price. There is no question about that.'' ``They were prepared to take a step that we simply as a delegation were not prepared to take,'' Robinson said. Sixty-eight Italians arrived in Rome from Iraq late Wednesday. The Syrian-born archbishop who secured their freedom, Hilarion Capucci, said he would return to Iraq for more. The Italian government also sent a plane load of medicine to Iraq. French, German and Swedish hostages were freed after the governments of those countries called for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. France and Sweden also indicated there could be some linkage between Iraq's solution of the gulf crisis and the Palestinian question - after Iraq pulls out of Kuwait. A Foreign Ministry official said in Stockholm, Sweden, that Iraqi authorities started issuing exit visas to all Swedish hostages today and they were expected to be allowed to leave Friday. In Copenhagen, Denmark, meanwhile, the Jyllands-Posten newspaper said that a group of Danes stranded in Iraq and Kuwait are looking for a prominent fellow citizen to come to Baghdad to win their release.

DOC.HEAD: Frederick Hitz Sworn in as CIA Inspector General
DOC.TEXT: Frederick P. Hitz, a lawyer and a former CIA officer, has been sworn in as the agency's inspector general, officials said today. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas S. Ellis III swore in Hitz at a ceremony at the CIA on Wednesday. Hitz, 51, has served as legislative counsel to the CIA director and as a deputy assistant secretary of defense for legislative affairs. He is a graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Ally Blames Americans For Mideast Peace Paralysis
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Cabinet minister and close ally of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today rejected U.S. demands for Israeli flexibility in stalled Middle East peace efforts and blamed the Americans for the impasse. Justice Minister Dan Meridor also said Israel would ask Washington for ``serious amounts of money'' to help finance the thousands of Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union. Meanwhile, Avi Pazner, a top Shamir aid, said Israel expected the United States to block a U.N. Security Council resolution to send an ombudsman to the West Bank and Gaza Strip to investigate human rights violations by Israel. Such a resolution is to be debated by the council on Friday. ``We don't think this will get a majority. But if necessary, we hope the Americans are going to veto it,'' Pazner said. Meridor was responding to reports that President Bush expected ``creative ideas'' from Shamir concerning the peace process when the two leaders meet Dec. 11 in Washington. Meridor said the Americans had doomed proposed Palestinian-Israeli peace talks from the outset by insisting that the PLO be given a role. Israel opposes any involvement by the PLO, which Israeli officials consider a terror group. Meridor said he hoped the Americans had ``distanced themselves from this mistake'' since the PLO has supported Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``I hope that now there is greater creativity on the American side, that they understand the realities of the Middle East and the aspirations of the PLO,'' Meridor said on Israel army radio. In April 1989, Shamir proposed a peace initiative calling for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to choose Palestinian representatives for talks with Israel on granting the territories limited autonomy. The initiative collapsed over disagreement on the composition of a Palestinian delegation to preliminary talks. Israel refused to accept an American compromise on Palestinian negotiators, saying it was an attempt to bring in the Palestine Liberation Organization through the back door. U.S. officials insisted this was not the intent. The Persian Gulf crisis temporarily pushed Middle East peace efforts to the sidelines, but Shamir's hard-line stance has proven a major stran on U.S.-Israeli relations. Shamir spokesman Yossi Ahimeir said Shamir would raise the issue of additional U.S. financial aid for Soviet immigration, but refused to say how much Shamir would ask for. ``We hope it will be discussed without connections, without conditions'' he said. The Jerusalem Post newspaper said Shamir would ask for billions of dollars in additional U.S. housing loan guarantees.

DOC.HEAD: Special Legislative Session Scheduled on California's Budget Problems
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian has called a special session of the Legislature, saying lawmakers can't afford to wait until January for his successor to handle the state's worsening budget problems. The special session, if approved by the legislators, will coincide with the beginning of the Legislature's new biennial regular session Monday, but it would allow quicker action because it sidesteps some regular session rules. The Republican governor, who did not run for re-election this year, told a news conference Wednesday that voters would be upset if legislators delayed budget action until Gov.-elect Pete Wilson takes office. ``The people did not send us here simply to delay or duck current problems,'' Deukmejian said. He said he wants the special session for action on the plan he proposed two weeks ago to cut $1 billion from the $55 billion state budget passed in July. He suggested the cuts after tax revenues fell more than $400 million short of estimates for the first four months of the fiscal year. Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, D-San Francisco, canceled a 12-day European trip so he can name committees for the special session, said press secretary Michael Reese. But he said Brown would prefer to wait to meet with the new governor rather than take immediate action at a special session. ``His feeling is that a hastily called session in the month of December is probably not the most conducive time to deal with these issues,'' Reese said. Senate Minority Leader Ken Maddy said the call was ``a sincere effort on the part of Governor Deukmejian to solve this budget crisis and the Legislature should respond.'' The current budget contains a $1.3 billion emergency reserve, but the falling revenues are expected to wipe that out. Deukmejian said the additional cuts he proposed would ``give us enough of a cushion to insure we would end up this year in the black.'' Wilson must propose a new budget on Jan. 10, taking into account a $4.3 billion gap between revenues and expenditures predicted by the Commission on State Finance. Deukmejian last week issued an executive order that asked state agencies to cut their budgets by 1 percent and froze state hiring and purchases. The governor said the state's top bond rating was in danger of being reduced if the Legislature does not act quickly.

DOC.HEAD: Officer, Once Cleared, Now Indicted in Teen-ager's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to recast, UPDATE with comments from morning news conference, add arraignment date. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Police said...'. DELETES last graf pvs, older quote from mother.
DOC.TEXT: A white policeman once cleared in the slaying of a black teen-ager faces prosecution after a second investigation, and the man's lawyer accused the state attorney general of bowing to political pressure. A grand jury Wednesday indicted Gary Spath, 29, on a charge of reckless manslaughter for shooting 16-year-old Phillip Pannell in the back. The April 10 shooting in Teaneck touched off race riots and divided the town, a New York City suburb of 39,000 that for many years prided itself on good race relations. Defense attorney Robert Galantucci accused Attorney General Robert Del Tufo of bowing to political pressure in seeking the indictment after an earlier grand jury refused to bring charges. ``This is an obvious example of the attorney general in the state of New Jersey throwing a bone to a segment of the community,'' he said. ``In the process, he's thrown Officer Spath to the wolves, but that's only temporary.'' Del Tufo, defending his handling of the case, cited errors in the autopsy report given to the original grand jury. Spath's arraignment was scheduled for Dec. 20, Del Tufo's office said. At a news conference at their Englewood home today, Pannell's parents said the indictment sent a positive message to the community, but said Spath should have been charged with murder. ``I don't like what he got, because I feel he should have got murder,'' Thelma Pannell said. ``I thank God that the truth will finally come out.'' A candlelight vigil in memory of Pannell turned into a rampage April 11. Dozens of youths overturned police cars, smashed windows and looted stores. Since then, Pannell supporters have held marches and the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan have visited. Police and other supporters of Spath also have held a rally. Police said Pannell was reaching for a gun in his pocket when he was shot. But witnesses said his hands were above his head as if in surrender, and an autopsy by a pathologist hired by Pannell's family supported that contention. Spath could get up to 10 years in prison if convicted. ``I know the truth in this matter,'' he said after the indictment. ``One good thing about this is that the truth will come out.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Sentenced to Three Life Terms for Stabbing Rampage
DOC.TEXT: A Jerusalem court today sentenced a Palestinian man to three consecutive life terms in prison plus 20 years for stabbing to death three Israelis in revenge for the Temple Mount killings. Relatives of the slain Israelis tried to attack Omar Abu Sirhan as he left Jerusalem District Court, but police whisked him away unharmed, Israel radio reported. The court imposed the maximum sentence on Abu Sirhan, 19, who went on a rampage in Jerusalem on Oct. 21 to avenge the shooting deaths of 17 Palestinians by police on the Temple Mount on Oct. 8. The victims' relatives demanded in a statement that Abu Sirhan be executed and his family deported. Israel only allows the death penalty for Nazi war criminals. The sentence does not allow for parole. In another case, Israel's Supreme Court sentenced a Jewish settler to 18 months in prison for fatally shooting a Palestinian high school girl. The three justices unanimously overruled a lower court that had given the settler, Shimon Yifrah, a seven-month suspended sentence. The victim, 17-year-old Intissar al Ataar, was killed on Nov. 10, 1987, in the Gaza Strip's Deir el Balah refugee camp. Her death was a factor contributing to the outbreak of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip a month later. Yifrah and three other people were driving past Palestinian girls throwing stones and were already out of danger when they turned around and chased after the girls, the Jerusalem Post newspaper quoted the high court as saying in its decision Wednesday. The justices rejected claims that the settlers shot in the air, noting that the bullet struck Miss al Ataar at a height of about three feet from the ground. ``It can be assumed that the respondent meant to fire in the direction that the bullet went,'' the justices said. ``A shot in the direction of the schoolyard where the girls were constituted gross negligence...and indifference to human life.'' In other developments, Palestinians observed a general strike called by the Moslem fundamentalist group Hamas to mark the 43rd anniversary of the U.N. vote to partition Palestine, paving the way for the establishment of Israel. In the territories, two Palestinians were stabbed to death by masked assailants on suspicion that they collaborated with Israel. The body of Fayez Hamdan al Attar, 27, a truck driver from Gaza's Rafah refugee camp, was found under a tree in the camp, Arab reporters said. The Moslem fundamentalist group Hamas claimed responsibility for the killing. The Black Panthers, a Palestinian death squad, claimed responsibility for killing Lufti Kamel al Sadi, 51, whose body was found in the Jenin refugee camp. He had been beaten, stabbed and burned, hospital officials said. The deaths brought to 308 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs since the start of the uprising nearly three years ago. Most were killed on suspicion of helping Israel. An additional 773 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. Fifty-two Israelis also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Tabloid Cites Plot Against Bush; Government Plays Down Report
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported today that police uncovered a plot to kill President Bush during his visit here next week, but government officials said the report was unfounded. ``There is no confirmation of supposed plans to assassinate President Bush,'' Interior Minister Julio Mera Figueroa said. The U.S. Embassy refused to comment on the report by the sensationalist daily tabloid, Diario Popular. Police arrested a Bolivian on suspicion of membership in a terrorist group. But the federal judge in charge of the case, Alberto Duran, said, ``There is no evidence of a plan against the life of Mr. Bush.'' The Bolivian was identified as Carlos Anibal Monzon Novena, 41. Diario Popular claimed Monzon Novena was the leader of a group called the ``Union of Revolutionary Workers'' that planned to attack Bush during his 22-hour visit in Argentian on Dec. 5 and 6. The paper reported that Monzon Novena was imprisoned from 1977 to 1983 during the military dictatorship for alleged guerrilla activities and that his group is a spin-off of the Revolutionary Army of the People that tried to overthrow Argentina's governments of the early 1970s. Government and U.S. Embassy officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said no evidence has been put forward that the Diario Popular report is true. ``An investigation is fully under way,'' the minister of the goverment of Buenos Aires Province, Jose Maria Diaz Bancalari, said. But ``elements to prove the affirmation (of the paper) don't exist.''

DOC.HEAD: FAA Lodged Minor Criticism Over Safety At Airport Fuel Farm
DOC.TEXT: Federal aviation officials criticized Stapleton International Airport last summer for failing to properly inspect its fueling facilities, including the tank farm ravaged by a fire this week. But Federal Avaiation Administration spokesman Mitch Baker said the criticism stemmed from minor problems. ``These are not significant items. We don't feel they are of major importance,'' he said. Firefighters are trying to determine what caused the fire, which burned for more than 50 hours before it was smothered Tuesday. The blaze broke out Sunday morning and spread to three other tanks before it was doused. Though the fire itself did not disrupt air traffic, thousands of passengers had flights delayed Sunday - one of the busiest flying days of the year - because they couldn't get enough fuel at Stapleton. Fire Capt. Gregory Taft said firefighters believe the fire broke out in a holding pit that contains the pipes and filtering valves. The city of Denver, as owner of the airport, is responsible for safety inspections at fueling facilities under FAA regulations that went into effect in January 1989. The FAA inspects the entire airport to make sure Denver is complying with safety regulations. Last June, FAA inspectors noted airport officials failed to inspect fueling facilities every three months as required. Denver Aviation Director George Doughty said the inspection problems did not contribute to the fire. He blamed the lack of inspections on manpower. The FAA letter also warned airport officials that Denver ``did not maintain its fueling standards for protecting against fire and explosions in storage and dispensing fuel on the airport.'' Doughty said that issue referred to a small leak from a fuel pump near one of the United Airlines tanks that caught fire. The leak was noted during the June 22 inspection, but Doughty said it did not contribute to the fire, which began in a different tank.

DOC.HEAD: This is the Red Army, Mr. Gorbachev: He's Colonel in Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is a colonel in the Red Army reserves, the military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda revealed Thursday. Unlike most Soviet men, Gorbachev never served on active duty. He underwent standard military training for all students at Moscow State University in the 1950s but was never drafted. Krasnaya Zvezda, which means Red Star, said Gorbachev was given his rank as a colonel in 1978, during the regime of Leonid Brezhnev. Brezhnev rose from draftee to major general between 1941 and 1945, but angered many Soviets by touting himself as a war hero once he assumed leadership of the country. In 1976, three decades after the war, he was elevated to Marshal of the Soviet Union. Two years later, he was given the jewel-encrusted Order of Victory, the nation's highest honor. But it was revoked last year, seven years after his death.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Fingerprint Village Adults for Clues to Unsolved Murder
DOC.TEXT: Police, confounded by what seems like the perfect murder, will take fingerprints this weekend of all 200 adults in the village of Montgesty, officials said Thursday. Investigators have tried for nearly a year to find the murderer of Raymonde Martignat, an elderly village woman found bound and suffocated to death with a rag Nov. 22, 1989, in a shed near her home. The motive for the crime continues to escape Investigating Judge Charles Pinarel, police sources said. Police found the victim's house ransacked, but her money, checks and identity papers were not taken. Village Mayor Rene Migayrou said the judge asked him to call all adult villagers to the municipal auditorium so police could fingerprint them. Migayrou said he had received no complaints ``and lots of people think this should have been done sooner.'' The mayor said he thinks the murderer is not among the villagers and this operation will silence the rumors running through town for the past year. Villagers whose names start with A to L are to be fingerprinted Friday, and those with names starting with M to Z get fingerprinted Saturday, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Backseat Passengers Must Wear Seatbelts Under New Law
DOC.TEXT: Passengers in the rear seats of automobiles will be required to buckle their seatbelts starting Saturday, and the maximum speed limit will be lowered in urban areas across France. Traffic officials hope the two measures will save as many as 800 lives annually. The use of seatbelts in the front seats of automobiles has been mandatory in France since July 1979. France also has required seatbelts in rear seats since 1978, but until now had not required them to be used. Under the new law, rear seat passengers must use seatbelts if available. Violators face a fine of at least $30. Also taking effect Saturday will be a new maximum speed limit of 31.1 miles per hour for all built-up areas in France. The limit previously was 37.3 mph. Drivers exceeding the limit face a minimum fine of $220 and possible suspension of their license. The seatbelt law makes exceptions only for medical reasons or for children who are provided with some other sort of security equipment. Owners of pre-1978 vehicles without rear-seat seatbelts will not be required to install them. According to government traffic experts, 900 rear-seat passengers were killed in accidents in France last year. They said the use of seatbelts could cut this figure by more than half.

DOC.HEAD: Medieval Paintings Recovered in Shack After Stakeout
DOC.TEXT: Police recovered two stolen medieval paintings in a shack outside Rome but were forced to abandon a stakeout for the thieves because of concern that bad weather might damage the works, authorities said Thursday. The 14th-century works, painted on wood with a gold background, were taken Oct. 24 from the cathedral of Nepi, a medieval hill town of Etruscan origin about 25 miles north of Rome. The paintings, by unknown artists, depicted Saints Tolomeo and Romano. The thieves also stole four 14th-century marble sculptures representing the four Gospel authors, and several gold and silver chalices, said police from the unit that tracks down stolen art. Police estimated the stolen works were worth a total of $2.8 million. An investigation of suspected fences in Italy's flourishing underground market in stolen art led to the tip that the stolen works had been taken to an abandoned shack on the outskirts of Rome, police said. Police spotted the works, wrapped in rags, inside and staked out the shack for several days in hopes of making arrests. But concern that cool, rainy weather in the unheated shack might be damaging the works led police to end the stakeout and recover the works, the police said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Admits His and Other Communists' Failures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today pronounced himself and other Communists ``guilty before the working class'' and promised immediate steps to improve food supplies. Gorbachev said he had concluded agreements for the republics of Estonia, Kazakhstan and the Ukraine to send dairy products to Moscow and Leningrad, where milk is hard to find in stores. Food shortages have caused a public outcry. The Soviet leader also said powdered milk would be taken out of storage and distributed to the people. In a wide-ranging hourlong speech before a conference of the Moscow City Communist Party organization, Gorbachev also reiterated his determination to hold the Soviet Union together. Standing on a podium with an 8-foot-tall bust of Lenin, Gorbachev told the nearly 1,000 conference delegates he realized the country's food and ethnic problems were intensifying and he urged the party to keep the common man in mind. ``We are guilty before the working class, I think, all of us, and me personally,'' the 59-year-old president and Communist Party general secretary told the audience. Answering questions delegates submitted in writing, Gorbachev reiterated his desire for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Our goal remains unchanged: to achieve a political solution,'' he said. He defended himself against criticism for spending too much time abroad, saying that when he became party leader in 1985, the Cold War was the people's foremost concern. Now, he said, their desire for him to focus on domestic problems is testimony to what he has achieved in foreign relations. While expressing willingness to redistribute power within the Soviet Union, he reiterated his opposition to secession. ``After long, long thought about what has already happened in the country with interethnic problems ... we cannot divide up the country,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Philly Fire, Police Unions Sue to Block Pension Loan
With PM-Philly Finances
DOC.TEXT: Police and fire unions filed suit today seeking to prevent use of pension assets to keep the city from going broke. The Fraternal Order of Police and the Philadelphia Fire Fighters Union, a local of the International Association of Fire Fighters, filed the lawsuit in Common Pleas Court against the pension board and its members individually. At an emergency hearing today before Judge Nicholas D'Alessandro, attorneys for the unions asked for a temporary restraining order barring the board from investing pension assets in Philadelphia short-term notes, or even voting on any proposal involving such an investment. D'Alessandro rejected the request for the temporary order and set a hearing for Monday. Ralph J. Teti, chief deputy city solicitor, had argued the motion was premature because no formal proposal had been made to the pension board. John K. Weston, representing the unions, said the court action was needed to ensure against a precipitous investment. ``Once this money is transferred, it's gone,'' Weston said. The $1.5 billion pension fund is one of four sources identified Nov. 9 by Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other Democratic leaders as potential backers of an emergency $250 million to $300 million sale of short-term notes to keep the city afloat until taxes come due next spring. The Democratic leaders also urged backing from local banks, the state treasury and private investors for the note sale. But city Finance Director Elizabeth C. Reveal has called the pension fund's role the linchpin of the deal. The pension fund normally could not invest in notes of the quality Philadelphia is able to offer, because the city's credit rating has sunk to junk-bond levels, the lowest among the nation's major cities. City Council voted 11-6 last week to authorize an investment in any Philadelphia debt obligations, regardless of quality, through July 1. The Board of Pensions and Retirement has yet to take up the issue. The loan has been opposed from the start by the police and fire unions. Two other major city unions - both affiliated with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees - last week said all options for resolving the fiscal crisis should remain open. They said they had not decided whether to support an actual purchase of city notes. In addition to the short-term notes, the Democratic leaders also urged $140 million in long-term deficit financing and the sale of $90 million in city assets to offset the fiscal 1991 deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter Says Father Stands By Earthquake Projection
DOC.TEXT: A scientist is sticking to his projection of a 50-50 chance of an earthquake in the Midwest next week, his daughter says. However, Iben Browning is most concerned about the chance of an earthquake in Japan, Evelyn Browning Garriss said Wednesday. ``That doesn't mean we stop being concerned about New Madrid or less concerned about New Madrid,'' she said in a telephone interview from her home in suburban Tijeras. ``He's probably more concerned about Japan than any other place ... including New Madrid. But he continues to see a 50-50 possibility for New Madrid, and he hasn't made any changes, except to be a little less worried about the Hayward (Fault)'' in northern California. Browning created a furor across the Midwest when he said there was a strong chance of a major earthquake Dec. 2-3 in an area that includes the New Madrid Fault, from Arkansas through Missouri to Illinois. Earthquake experts and other scientists have discounted Browning's projection, which relies on the measurement of the pull of tidal forces on the earth. But the experts have said the region will probably have a major quake eventually. The New Madrid Fault was the site of a series of severe quakes in 1811-12 that were felt as far away as the East Coast. Browning's daughter said he has always been equally concerned about the chances of quakes outside the United States, as his figures have been computed on the basis of solar-lunar gravitational stress on latitudes 30 to 60, which include most of North America, Asia and Europe. Browning, who also lives in Tijeras, was on vacation and unreachable for comment at an undisclosed location Wednesday, she said. Mrs. Garriss edits the Browning Newsletter, helping her father in his scientific consulting business.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptians Vote in Election Boycotted by Opposition
Laserphoto CAI1
DOC.TEXT: Egyptians voted for parliamentary candidates today under new election rules intended to make the procedure fairer, but opposition groups boycotted the balloting, which occurred amid sporadic violence. President Hosni Mubarak's governing New Democratic Party was expected to maintain its dominance in the 454-seat unicameral legislature, the People's Assembly. Mubarak has held majorities of more than 75 percent in the three parliaments since he became president in 1981. Mubarak suspended the old parliament in September after Egypt's Supreme Court declared the chamber was elected in 1987 under an unconstitutional law violating the principle of equal opportunity for candidates. In response, Mubarak decreed a new election law, switching from a party list system to individual campaigns by party members and independents alike. A national referendum last month authorized him to dissolve the assembly and call new elections. The moves angered opposition leaders, who complained they were not consulted and that Mubarak ignored their demand to scrap a 9-year-old emergency law giving the government extensive arbitrary police powers. They also wanted members of the judiciary to oversee all 23,000 polling stations nationwide. The government maintained that the emergency law remains a vital tool against terrorism, but promised not to use it for its political benefit. The government also said it lacked the resources to supervise the polls. While voting at a polling station in suburban Heliopolis where he lives, Mubarak criticized opposition leaders for the boycott, adding that some had circumvented the protest by running as independents. ``Maybe they know they are unable to win,'' Mubarak said. ``But a large number of candidates...entered the race (as independents) anyway.'' Mubarak added that the opposition parties ``should participate if they want democracy. They should not be passive.'' The parties that stayed away from the election included the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, which has been banned since 1954 but is tolerated by the government. The right-of-center New Wafd, left-of-center Socialist Labor and centrist Liberal parties also boycotted. In the disbanded assembly, they comprised the largest opposition ever, almost 100 seats. Besides the governing party, two small parties that have never made it into parliament ran, the Moslem fundamentalist Umma Party and the leftist National Unionist Progressive Party. Three small parties established this year and unknown to many Egyptians also campaigned - the Greens, Young Egypt and the Democratic Unionists. Balloting was interupted by two exchanges of gunfire between sympathizers of rival candidates in the Suez Canal city of Ismailia and Beni Suef in southern Egypt, security sources said. They said two people were seriously wounded in Ismailia.

DOC.HEAD: Bugatti Revives Legend of Elegant Excess for a New Generation
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: More than six decades after Ettore Bugatti produced the car that became a symbol of the high-living Roaring 20s, a firm is reviving the Bugatti. It's come a long way: The new car goes 220 mph and has six gears, is designed to resemble a jet fighter and costs up to $600,000 - if you must ask. And, in a feature of truly historic snob-appeal proportions, it can be purchased only by people deemed worthy by the company. ``You must of course have the means to acquire one,'' states Romano Artioli, chairman of the board of Bugatti Automobili. ``But above all you must have the right moral qualities. Otherwise, we don't sell to you.'' Bugatti's autos were among the most famous of the classic period, from the 1920s to early 1940s, when the luxurious, speedy motorcar reached a peak. Kings, capitalists and playboys flaunted them, from King Leopold III of Belgium to the wine baron Philippe de Rothschild. Even in the 1920s, the firm was setting records for the most expensive standard vehicle, with its long, boxy Bugatti Royale. The base price: $20,000. In fact, the highest price paid at auction for any car was $9.8 million for a 1931 Bugatti Royale, sold in 1987 at Christie's in London. Now, at a factory near Modena in the heart of Italy's sports-car industry, Bugatti is hoping to turn that legendary symbol of 1920s excess into a shiny symbol of 1990s excess. According to plans, the Bugatti 110 will be a two-seater with four-wheel drive, about 12 feet long and 3{ feet tall. Its design was inspired by a fighter-plane, according to the company. However, judging by a sneak preview in the auto magazine ``Quattro Ruote'' (Four Wheels), it more closely resembles the Batmobile. It has 12 cylinders and a 3,500-cubic-centimeter, four-turbo engine with 550 horsepower - ``the power of a Formula 1 car, but more refined,'' Artioli said in a telephone interview. Bugatti officials say the car will cost at least $450,000 - ``not a stratospheric price,'' Artioli reasons. Industry experts put the price at $600,000. While the car will not be unveiled until Sept. 15 - the 110th anniversary of Ettore Bugatti's birthday - the orders have been rolling in for months. ``We have the ambassador of an emirate that comes here every two months begging to have three cars,'' Artioli said. ``We have big industrialists, professionals. They mail us their characteristics, the details of their professions. ``Truly, a most qualified group is battling'' to buy one of the 150 cars produced each year, he said. What kind of people have the right moral qualities to part with a half-million dollars for a Bugatti? ``For example, if it's a person who has worked well in his life, has a flourishing business, if the person is esteemed, admired and has a passion for these objects ... we doubtless can give him the car,'' Artioli said.
