Some would consider it risky to produce a luxury car at a moment when some major countries are facing recessions. Not Artioli. ``When these world crises happen, there are always economic groups that grow in an outrageous way,'' he explained. ``Those who work in the oil industry, for example, earn bags of moneyin this period.'' Arms dealers, he said, ``begin to breathe anew.'' For those lacking the money or morals to buy the new Bugatti, there is one consolation. The company also plans to come out with a line of Bugatti accessories, including sunglasses and watches.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Tries to Hijack Plane to Iraq
With AM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While thousands of foreigners are trying to flee Iraq, one Soviet man wanted to go in the reverse direction and tried to hijack a plan to make the trip, Tass reported Thursday. The official Soviet news agency quoted officials of the KGB secret police as saying a 63-year-old retiree passed a note to the crew of a Soviet airliner en route from Moscow to Syktyvkar in northern Russia on Wednesday. Nikolai Pylev, a handicapped man from the city of Voronezh, demanded to be flown to Iraq, Tass said. The flight commander ignored the demand and stayed on course. Pylev was arrested after the Tupolev-134 jetliner landed in Syktyvkar, Tass said. The brief dispatch did not give Pylev's motive for demanding a trip to Iraq, which hundreds of Soviet specialists have been trying to leave since President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Tass also did not say if Pylev had a weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam: Iraq Ready to Fight U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said Thursday he was not afraid of fighting the United States in the Persian Gulf and warned that he had the technology to shoot down Stealth aircraft. ``If war breaks out, we will fight in a way which will make all Arabs and Moslems proud. We are determined not to kneel down to injustice,'' Saddam said in remarks carried by Baghdad radio. The remarks came hours before the United Nations Security Council was to vote on a U.S.-sponsored resolution authorizing the use of force to oust Iraq from Kuwait if Saddam refuses to withdraw by Jan. 15. In a defiant tone, Saddam said Iraq will fight ``the United States and its other allies in the gulf if war breaks out.'' There have been conflicting reports whether Saddam might have the ability to detect the Stealth jets, designed to sneak in under enemy radar, using technology sold to him by France. The Pentagon has sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter bombers to unspecified bases in the region.

DOC.HEAD: City Tries Orange Extract, Next Lemons to Mask Sewage Stench
DOC.TEXT: The stench from a sewage dump here is so foul that officials tried to mask it with orange extract. Next they'll try lemon, and they might even use the scent of vanilla or almonds. ``If `Evening in Paris' or `Chanel No. 5' was best we'd use that,'' said John Casey, executive director of the Lynn Water and Sewer Commission. ``Right now, lemon's the best.'' The problem arose last week after workers started dumping sludge in a landfill near a new sewage treatment plant. Officials originally intended to burn the sludge at an incinerator, but they are awaiting state permission. In the meantime, crews have covered the sludge with gravel and lime, but that hasn't stopped the odors. Casey explained that the sludge is ``soupy,'' and as bulldozers spread the gravel, they also dig up some of the slop from the day before. This does not cause too much trouble when the wind is blowing from the west, which carries the odors over the ocean. But when the wind comes from the east, the stench is blown over the city. ``It's not a pleasant smell,'' Casey said. ``I wouldn't want my bedroom windows open at night with this blowing in.'' After receiving complaints, the commission this week bought about 80 quarts of orange extract, mixed it with water, and sprayed it over the dump. This fruity smell has helped somewhat. Casey said Thursday he was awaiting a shipment of lemon extract, which is less expensive. Other alternatives are vanilla and almond extract, but Casey said he hopes to have permission to burn the sludge next week. The plant sits in an industrial area where, depending on the wind direction, people can catch scents from a potato chip factory and a fish processing plant, Casey said. ``But the smell from sludge is not a very good smell,'' he said. Yet despite the steps to eliminate the odors, some people apparently will never be satisfied. Casey said officials received an anonymous complaint about the orange smell. ``They asked why are we dumping rotten oranges,'' he said. ``But generally speaking, oranges smell better,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Would Literally Call Shots in Military Strike to Free Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The United States would literally call the shots in any military strike to free Kuwait, backed by Britain, probably France and an Arab force that symbolically would be first over the border. More than two dozen countries have sent troops to defend Saudi Arabia from an Iraqi attack, but few have said they would cross the border to liberate Kuwait. Arab governments - except Kuwait - have been noticeably silent. A resolution before the U.N. Security Council on Thursday only sets conditions for the allies to decide on military action if Iraq has not withdrawn from Kuwait by Jan. 15. It does not mandate force if Iraq refuses. The United States has publicly stressed the multinational character of the military force strung out across hundreds of miles of Saudi desert. ``If there's a military confrontation, it's not going to be America vs Iraq. It's going to be 26 nations vs Iraq,'' said Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass. He led a 20-member congressional delegation on a visit to troops Wednesday. But the U.S. military commitment is so overwhelming that it dwarfs the 150,000 other troops in Saudi Arabia. The Americans have 240,000 personnel in the region and 200,000 more coming. By mid-January, 80 U.S. warships and more than 1,000 combat aircraft will be deployed in the Middle East. At present, Saudi forces are flanked on the west by Syrian and French troops and on the east by the Egyptians, with U.S. and British troops right behind. A well-placed Saudi said on condition of anonymity that the Saudis, Kuwaitis, Egyptians and Persian Gulf nations would participate in any offensive ``and not symbolically.'' But the Syrians have never spelled out what they are prepared to do beyond the original mission of defending Saudi Arabia. Pakistan, with the only other significant Islamic force, says its troops are purely defensive. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said Nov. 27 that France would deploy its forces alongside the Americans in any military action, but did not make clear whether France would put its forces under U.S. tactical control. One strong indication that the United States isn't taking most of the multinational force seriously in military terms is that after nearly four months, there has not been one exercise involving all or even most nations. There have been some exercises with the Saudis and British. The only one close to a serious international effort was an all-arms exercise involving U.S. and Saudi marines and American, British, French and Canadian aircraft. Under an agreement between King Fahd and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, the United States would command any offensive outside Saudi Arabia but must get permission from the king to launch an attack from Saudi soil. The Saudi, U.S. and British commanders have offices in the same building in Riyadh and meet regularly, but reporters in the field have seen little evidence of similar coordination on the ground. The British commander, Lt. Gen. Sir Peter de la Billiere, said Monday that coordination of air and naval forces was working ``extremely well.'' But he indicated integrated ground operations were still only at a planning level. ``I'm quite sure if it came to an offensive operation, the right sort of arrangements for command and directing the forces would emerge,'' he said. Unquestionably, the winter months would be best for an offensive. It's cooler and the occasional rain softens the ground and diminishes dust, making clandestine operations easier. Sandstorms are a nuisance for both sides. But Col. Andrew Duncan of London's International Institute for Strategic Studies said too much was being made of the weather and noted that the allies in World War II fought through the summer in the desert. He said he did not believe, however, there would be any offensive until U.S. commanders had the mix of men and equipment they want for a strike. The allies already have air and naval superiority so the key would be the arrival of ground reinforcements to take on Iraq. The Pentagon says Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has 450,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq and is sending in 250,000 more men. The new U.S. armored divisions coming from Germany and the United States are the key to an offensive operation. Once they arrive, they will need at least two weeks to acclimatize and test equipment. In addition, the United States is changing its older M1 Abrams tanks for top-of-the-line M1A1 models, which it would undoubtedly want to use in a strike against Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Lure of Free Tickets to `Iron Bowl' Game Brings in Fugitives
DOC.TEXT: Police said they scored a touchdown with a ``sting'' that nabbed about 200 fugitives by making them think they had won tickets to Saturday's Auburn-Alabama football game. Police Chief Arthur Deutsch said people wanted for crimes including robbery and drug dealing were apprehended when they showed up for a ``winner's party'' Wednesday night at the Birmingham-Jefferson Civic Center. About 800 letters were sent from phony cable television station WGGY - whose call letters stood for ``We're Gonna Get You,'' and were signed by J.L. Byrd, or jailbird, Deutsch said. The scheme was dubbed ``Operation Touchdown,'' said police spokesman Mike Crawford. ``The idea was that if we got 10, we were at the 10-yard line,'' he said. ``If we got 20, we were at the 20-yard line. More than that would be a touchdown.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Says 50 Dead in Protests; Witnesses Describe Violence
DOC.TEXT: Gunfire crackled through the Bangladesh capital Thursday as police battled protesters demanding the ouster of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad and an end to a state of emergency, witnesses said. Opposition leaders said 50 people were killed and more than 1,000 wounded Wednesday when demonstrators swarmed into the streets of Dhaka and four other cities in defiance of curfews. The casualty toll could not be verified. The claims were made in written statements circulated in Dhaka that reached India through unofficial channels. Some previous claims of the opposition have been exaggerated. Diplomatic sources in New Delhi said they had reports of four dead and 15 wounded in the Bangladesh capital during clashes with paramilitary forces Wednesday. The curfews were imposed Tuesday night as part of a state of emergency Ershad declared to try to quash the growing movement against him. The decree also suspended civil rights and imposed press censorship after six weeks of often-violent protests. Ershad, a former general, is facing one of his worst crises since seizing power in a bloodless coup in 1982. The diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said his support in the army appeared less solid than earlier believed. Witnesses said demonstrations continued Thursday, but they did not know about casualties. Kurt Hensena, a businessman based in Hong Kong, said he heard gunfire when he left his Dhaka hotel for the airport Thursday afternoon. He said there were rumors one person was killed. ``It was bam-bam-bam-bam and then it was quiet again. It was shotgun, rifle fire. I heard a lot of people shouting,'' Hensena said upon arrival in Bangkok, Thailand. He did not give his nationality. The witnesses said fighting was heavier on Wednesday. ``Yesterday and today it was mostly rock-throwing,'' said an American, also arriving in Bangkok on the first flight from Dhaka since Ershad's crackdown Tuesday night. He and some other travelers spoke on condition they were not identified. A Dutch traveler said he had been trapped by roadblocks Wednesday, and his car was stoned as he drove through the crowd. ``There was shooting and there was some burning of cars,'' he said. About 300 students gathered outside Dhaka University during curfew hours chanting ``Down with Ershad!'' and ``We don't accept curfew, no emergency!'' said unofficial reports reaching New Delhi. Security forces were not in the area during the half-hour demonstration. Bangladeshis jammed Dhaka's food stores during a four-hour relaxation of the curfew, while army troops patrolled the streets, said another report from the city of 7 million. Press censorship was severe. An Associated Press story from Dhaka was reduced from 14 paragraphs to four by government censors. Telephone and telex communications were restored Thursday after being severed for nearly 24 hours. Ershad's political opponents want him to step aside in favor of a caretaker government which would supervise elections. They accuse him of rigging an earlier presidential election and two parliamentary elections and say a fair vote is impossible as long as he remains in office. Ershad, 60, has called another presidential election for next year and has invited international observers to attend. Though Ershad has given Bangladesh a measure of political stability after a quick succession of military-installed presidents, he has made little headway in alleviating the misery of his 110 million people, who are collectively among the world's poorest. Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, won its independence from West Pakistan in a 1971 civil war. Since then, it has never changed leaders by election.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Stagnant In October
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending, the driving force behind eight years of U.S. economic expansion, did not budge in October, the government said Thursday in a report analysts contend was further evidence of a recession. ``The consumer has retrenched,'' said economist Gilbert Benz of the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``It clearly supports those who say we're in a recession.'' John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, agreed. ``It looks like consumer spending will be negative in the fourth quarter'' and the gross national product will decline in both the current quarter and the first three months of next year, he said. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, was unchanged from September at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.73 trillion, the Commerce Department said. Personal incomes rose just 0.1 percent, to a $4.71 trillion rate. The marginal increase in incomes failed to match the 0.6 percent increase in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index in October. It also was the smallest gain since incomes were unchanged in August 1989. Spending had posted gains each month since last May, when it was unchanged. Disposable incomes, or incomes after taxes, also inched ahead 0.1 percent, down from a 0.4 percent gain the previous month. It was the smallest gain since after-tax incomes fell 0.1 percent last April. The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending actually fell 0.7 percent after a 0.2 percent increase in September. Disposable income dropped 0.5 percent, even more than the 0.4 percent declines in the previous two months. ``Consumer spending can survive a lot of things - temporary shocks, consumer confidence, oil surprises - but three months in a row of negative disposable income suggests that people are going to have to cut back even more,'' Silvia said. Indeed, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Wednesday noted that shrinking employment and the number of hours worked were causing personal income to decline while rising energy prices ``are squeezing many household budgets. ``This drop in real purchasing power, along with plunging consumer sentiment, does not bode well for the near-term trends in consumer demand,'' he told the House Banking Committee. It was the first look at consumer spending in the final quarter of the year. The department on Wednesday revised personal consumption in the third quarter down from a 3.6 percent annual rate in its initial report to 3.2 percent, suggesting spending was slowing toward the end of that period. ``There was weakness across the board'' in October, Benz noted. ``There's every indication that consumers are spending less on everything.'' Purchases of durable goods - usually expensive products expected to last at least three years - fell $8.4 billion in October. Non-durable consumption was off $1.5 billion. And while spending on services rose $8.9 billion, the advance was slower than the gains of $13.5 billion in September and $21.1 billion in August. A key component of the income category - wages and salaries - fell $9.3 billion after gaining $16.7 billion the previous month. It was the first decline since November 1989, when it dropped $7.6 billion. Silvia said the major prop in the 0.1 percent gain in overall personal income was transfer payments such as unemployment insurance and cost-of-living adjustments in the food stamp program - both further evidence of a weak economy. Americans' savings rate - savings as a percent of disposable income - edged up to 3.8 percent from 3.6 percent in September. The September rate was the lowest since a 3.5 percent rate in January 1988 and an indication that consumers having to dip into their savings to pay for their purchases. Americans' savings rate for all of 1989 was 4.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Socialist Premier Quits in Bulgaria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series with original story. ADDS background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government of former Communists resigned today, bowing to unrelenting pressure from the streets and the halls of parliament. The Socialist premier, blamed for the Balkan country's political and economic anarchy, said union and the government opposition had made it impossible for his government to implement its economic reform program. ``For me, it is therefore pointless to remain at the premier's post, and ... I resign my office,'' the state BTA news agency quoted him as saying. No replacement was immediately named for Lukanov, one of the reform-minded Socialist Party members who helped oust longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov last November. Lukanov, 52, was appointed premier in early February. Lukanov's resignation had been expected since he and other political leaders struck a deal in talks to end their stalemate that has prevented the country from tackling its worst postwar economic crisis. The accord was struck in a meeting called by President Zhelyu Zhelev, as a nationwide strike entered its fourth day and streets filled with thousands of people demanding an end to political turmoil and economic hardship. Bulgaria is suffering its worst postwar crisis. Electricity is rationed in Sofia and elsewhere. Many basic consumer items are either rationed or unavailable. The country cannot make payments on its $11 billion foreign debt. The political stalemate has blocked officials from moving quickly to improve the economic situation. ``The new government should neither be dominated by the BSP or the UDF. The premier should be a neutral personality,'' Alexander Lilov, the Socialist Party chairman, said just before the talks that produced the accord. He referred to his own party, the Bulgarian Socialist Party, and the main opposition Union of Democratic Forces, which has said it wants to take over from the Socialists and does not want to join a Socialist-dominated government. The former Communist Party, which ruled Bulgaria for four decades, renamed itself the Socialist Party during the pro-democracy movements that swept Eastern Europe late last year and went on to win June elections. Only last week, Lukanov survived a no-confidence vote in parliament and won approval of his austerity budget after the opposition walked out of the chamber. He had threatened to resign if the budget was not approved, but said he could not be heckled into quitting. During the protests today, many intersections in the capital were blocked by angry citizens who had built barricades with benches, garbage cans and large concrete planters. But the two largest trade unions - Podkrepa, which called a nationwide walkout that began Monday, and the Confederation of Independent Trade Unions - condemned the street protests. The confederation, Bulgaria's largest union, had opposed the nationwide strike but announced Wednesday it would join the walkout if the government crisis was not settled. Earlier in the day, Sofia Mayor Alexander Karakachanov, a prominent member of the opposition alliance, issued an ultimatum to the people blocking streets, saying he would instruct police to clear the intersections ``with violence.'' But the deadline passed without incident. Podkrepa claimed that by Wednesday afternoon 870,000 workers, 230,000 of them in Sofia, were on strike in 91 cities throughout the country. The government claimed only 40,000 workers were on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Damaged Bridge Closed Again As Winds Pick Up, Then Reopened When Storm Passes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that record set over weekend was wettest 24-hour period on record for November, sted wettest ever.
DOC.TEXT: High winds early today forced officials to temporarily close a damaged floating bridge, creating new woes for rush-hour commuters between Seattle and its eastern suburbs. After a storm moved out of the area, the state Transportation Department reopened westbound lanes of the $110 million bridge shortly after 8 a.m., ending a 6{-hour closure that forced many commuters living east of Lake Washington to find alternate routes into town. The bridge was being stabilized by several tugboats and a giant salvage ship. The closure was ordered when a storm with winds gusting to 30 mph moved into the area. ``We just don't want to put traffic out there with the wind this high and the movement of the bridge. It is bopping up and down quite a bit,'' state Department of Transportation spokesman Bill Southern said at the time. The westbound lanes of the Interstate 90 bridge had reopened Tuesday. The Arctic Salvor, a 949-ton salvage ship, had been brought in overnight to help anchor the damaged span against the approaching wind and rain storm. Twelve of 58 anchor cables on the 1{-mile bridge over Lake Washington were severed Sunday when an old floating bridge nearby was swamped by rising water and collapsed. The old bridge was closed for renovations at the time. Crews continued to rig cables from the new bridge to clusters of huge ship anchors 200 feet below on the lakebed, with permanent repairs to be made later. All of the boats will stay until 28 temporary anchors can be attached to the bridge. The cause of the bridge collapse is under investigation. Seattle had its wettest 24-hour period on record in November last weekend, with more than 3{ inches of rain. Flooding in Washington forced thousands from their homes.

DOC.HEAD: LA Mayor Announces Immediate Citywide Hiring Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Municipal departments in the nation's second-largest city have been ordered to enforce an immediate hiring freeze to avert a $20 million budget shortfall. The freeze imposed Wednesday lasts until June 30, 1991, and includes all city departments. Mayor Tom Bradley said he would consider exemptions ``only in those instances where critical organizational or public service problems will result.'' The 1990-91 budget shortfall could increase to $120 million for 1991-92, said City Administrative Officer Keith Comrie. The freeze could mean the loss of 500 police and 70 fire positions through attrition, Comrie told the city council's Budget and Finance Committee. Police Chief Daryl Gates said he was concerned about reducing the size of the force, but said his department would comply. Fire Battalion Chief Dave Badgett said there would be no impact on his department until May or June. ``Our process for new trainees begins at that time,'' Badgett said. ``The people that are currently in training will go through the field but there will be no people behind them.'' This is the city's second hiring freeze ordered this year. The previous one ran from April through August.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Crime-Control Bill - With Disappointment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed ``deep disappointment'' Thursday as he signed a crime-control bill that he said was a shadow of his own 1989 proposal. The bill, passed in the final hours of this year's congressional session, toughens penalties for certain white-collar crimes including a possible life prison term for some cases involving fraud by savings and loan officials. It also calls for increased penalties for offenses committed against children, including for the first time making possession of child pornography a federal offense. Stripped from the bill, however, were Bush's proposals for a death penalty for new categories of federal crimes, including mail bombing, terrorist murder and assassination of federal officers. Also gone from the final version were the administration's provisions to allow courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants, to shorten delays in carrying out executions and to impose tougher penalties for illegal firearm use. These provisions, although in earlier versions of the legislation, were jettisoned from the bill by a House-Senate conference committee as it struggled to come up with a politically acceptable compromise. Also removed from the bill was a ban on assault weapons, not proposed by the administration, which the Senate had added. ``I must note my deep disappointment over many provisions noticeably absent from the legislation,'' Bush said in a statement. ``I call on Congress to implement the remainder of the comprehensive crime package, which fell short of becoming law this session,'' Bush added. ``The American people deserve tough, new laws to help us prevail in the fight against drugs and crime.'' At the same time, Bush said, ``while this is not the crime bill I asked Congress to pass, I am pleased with the tools (it) provides for fighting financial institutions fraud.'' The measure sets up in the Justice Department an office of special counsel for financial institutions fraud. ``In addition, the bill enhances the ability of the federal banking agencies and the Department of Justice to seize the assets of wrongdoers and makes it more difficult for those wrongdoers to use bankruptcy to avoid civil or criminal penalties,'' Bush's statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Raises Count of US Forces in Gulf Area
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Thursday said the number of U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf area has grown to ``more than 240,000'' soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines. That is an increase of 10,000 from the Pentagon's last count, issued Nov. 6. Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman who announced the higher total, did not identify the specific additional forces that have arrived in the region. He reiterated that the deployment of reinforcements will contnue for several weeks. President Bush on Nov. 8 ordered large reinforcements to the gulf. The administration has refused to disclose the number of additional troops but it is believed to be about 200,000, meaning the total U.S. force in the region may hit 430,000 by January. Williams said the Pentagon estimates that about 450,000 Iraqi troops are deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. He said there is no evidence that Iraq is beginning to mobilize the 250,000 extra troops it announced Nov. 19 would be sent to Kuwait. Britain, France and other nations allied with the United States against Iraq have contributed a combined total of at least 100,000 troops to the region.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Accuses U.S. of Forcing Double Standard at U.N.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saddam's latest statement on Iraq's willingness to face the U.S. in a war. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said today he was not afraid of fighting the United States in the Persian Gulf and warned that he had the technology to shoot down Stealth aircraft. ``If war breaks out, we will fight in a way which will make all Arabs and Moslems proud. We are determined not to kneel down to injustice,'' Saddam said in remarks carried by Baghdad radio. The remarks came hours before the U.N. Security Council was to vote on a U.S.-sponsored resolution authorizing the use of force to oust Iraq from Kuwait if Saddam refuses to withdraw by Jan. 15. In a defiant tone, Saddam said Iraq will fight ``the United States and its other allies in the gulf if war breaks out.'' The radio said the speech was made to an Arab Youth Solidarity seminar. There have been conflicting reports whether Saddam might have the ability to detect the Stealth jets, designed to sneak in under enemy radar, using technology sold to him by France. The Pentagon has sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter bombers to unspecified bases in the region. Earlier today, Saddam issued a statement on the official Iraqi News Agency accusing the United States of forcing the United Nations to adopt a double standard by supporting resolutions that condemn Iraq but not Israel. Also today, Iraq's ruling party newspaper Al-Thawra lashed out at the proposed U.N. resolution, calling it a ``declaration of war.'' In his Iraqi News Agency statement, Saddam urged the 15-nation council to link any resolution of the gulf crisis with the Israeli-Palestinian problem, a position he first insisted on soon after invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United States has refused such a linkage. ``We have been and still are hoping the United Nations and the Security Council will seize the opportunity...to tackle all problems of the area seriously and lay down all united rules and arrangements that would ensure their solution on the same basis and principles,'' INA quoted Saddam as saying. The Iraqi government has said it would abide by U.N. resolutions on the gulf only if the world body enforced resolutions calling on Israel to withdraw from territories it seized in the 1967 Middle East war. In his INA statement, Saddam said: ``The United States, in addition to its protection of this entity (Israel) through vetoing resolutions that condemn its practices, pushes the Security Council to adopt dual standards in dealing with issues of the region.'' The statement, released ``on the occasion of the World Day for Solidarity with the Palestinian People,'' also applauded the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories as ``a continuation of the revolutions of the people of Palestine that started with the Balfour Declaration.'' It referred to the 1917 pledge by Lord Arthur James Balfour, the British foreign secretary, that Britain would support a Jewish state in Palestine, and the creation of the state of Israel three decades later. Saddam also condemned ``the influx of hundreds of thousands of emigrants from the Soviet Union and eastern Europe into the occupied Palestinian territories as a ... scheme for the establishment of greater Israel.'' The newspaper of Saddam's Arab Baath Socialist Party suggested the U.N. resolution could provoke a backlash.``In the final analysis, increased oppression is coupled with increased resistance by the oppressed and they become forced to confront it,'' Al-Thawra said. The newspaper recalled guerrilla operations of Palestinians, Egyptians and Lebanese and said ``the message and moral of these operations is clear.'' ``The U.S. resolution being prepared by the Security Council against Iraq is not only a blatant violation of all standards of humanity, peace, and legality, but is a declaration of war on all the good and honorable forces in the world,'' Al-Thawra said. Al-Thawra also condemned the resolution on Monday and Wednesday in the only previous official Iraqi comment on it. The United States has used ``heavy sticks to pressure other international parties or make deals to buy out their agreements in a high-demand market for buying stands and guarantees,'' the paper claimed. Iraq has amassed an estimated 450,000 troops in the region. The United States has about 230,000 soldiers in the area, mostly across the border in Saudi Arabia, along with a multinational force of about 100,000 other troops. Washington plans to send about 200,000 more soldiers in the coming weeks to place it on an offensive footing.

DOC.HEAD: Alaskans Planning Food Shipments to Soviet Neighbors
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Alaska's citizen diplomats say it's time to extend more across the Bering Strait to their Soviet neighbors than good will. They want to send food to help ease that country's food shortages. ``We're talking about our friends,'' Joe Davis, president-elect of Nome's Rotary club, said Wednesday. For business leaders in Nome - a city just 230 miles from the Soviet Far East - the news of food shortages in the Soviet Union was a call to action that also demanded a delicate touch. ``We're going to send some food as a holiday cultural gesture around Christmas,'' he said. ``That way it would help the Soviets save face, too. ``It wouldn't come across as us saying, `Hi, I heard you're starving, here's some food,''' said Davis, who spent a month last year teaching English in the Soviet Far East city of Providenya. During the past few years, Alaskans have been sponsoring school children, folk singers, business leaders, teachers, journalists, artists and pilots on dozens of friendship missions back and forth across the Bering Strait. Davis said the rotary club probably would just send food and not include a delegation to make sure it was distributed to people who need it. That was a key concern of German leaders who won assurances from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev that a delegation would oversee distribution of a massive shipment of food. Vic Fischer, a University of Alaska at Anchorage professor who directs Alaska-Soviet exchanges, said even small-scale relief should be monitored as during the huge flow of international aid after the 1988 Armenian earthquake. Fischer said he hoped to have a donation from Alaska ready in time for a flight from Anchorage to the Soviet Far East city of Magadan in January. ``Whatever we are able to collect must not wind up in the Communist Party chiefs' storerooms,'' Fischer said. Alaskans may have an edge there, he said, since many people have connections that could check losses to illicit sources such as blackmarkets.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Set to Sign Bill Calling for Boost in Immigration ^EDS: Top 6 grafs new with signing; picks up 5th graf pvs, The American Bar.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, endorsing the first major rewrite of the immigration law in a quarter-century, today approved a substantial boost in the number of immigrants allowed into the United States each year. ``This bill is good for familiies, good for business, good for crime fighting and good for America,'' Bush said at a White House signing ceremony. ``Immigration is not just a link to America's past; it is also a bridge to America's future,'' he said as he signed the bill increasing by 400,000 the number of immigrants that will be accepted over the next three years. That will make a total of 2.1 million. It also will ease restrictions on visitors once barred for being communist or having other views unacceptable to the government. The curbs dated to the anti-communist fervor of the 1950s. But the secretary of state still will be able to bar individuals for political reasons. Bush said the bill ``revises the exclusion grounds for the first time since enactment in 1952, putting an end to the kind of political litmus test that might have excluded even some of the heroes of the Eastern European revolution of 1989.'' The American Bar Association praised the bill for its general provisions, but said it was disturbed by provisions ``which may impede the ability of persons in immigration proceedings to secure representation,'' and could block some political asylum applicants. Legal scholar David Cole said the bill leaves too many loopholes for exclusion on political and ideological grounds, because it gives the administration discretionary powers in cases it deems to involve terrorism and foreign policy considerations. Cole, a professor at Georgetown University Law Center, said the law will ``continue to deny immigrants the very freedoms of belief and association upon which this nation of immigrants was founded.'' The National Gay and Lesbian Task Force lauded the reversal of a bar on homosexual immigrants. The bill also drops automatic exclusion of AIDS patients, leaving it up to the administration whether to list AIDS as a disease that prevents immigrants from entering. Gay groups are calling on Bush to refrain from listing AIDS as an exclusionary disease. ``The world is watching to see whether he is going to strike AIDS'' from that list, said gaytask force spokesman Robert Bray. ``The ball is entirely in his court,'' he said. The immigration law also will allow for naturalization of Filipinos who have served in the U.S. military or Phillipines Army or guerrilla units in World War Two. The measure aims primarily to reunite families. But it also will open the door to people with special skills and those who are wealthy. It reserves 140,000 visas a year for immigrants with special skills, up from 54,000 in the past. And 10,000 visas are set aside for those with at least $500,000 to invest in businesses that create new jobs. The measure earmarks 48,000 visas a year for individuals from Italy, Poland, Ireland and other countries virtually shut off from immigration in the last 20 years. Immigrants from these countries have been turned down largely because preference was given to those with family members here already. But many of those rejected have stayed in the United States illegally. The bill's sweeping provisions mark the first time immigration policy has been reworked since 1965. It will allows a three-year total of 2.1 million visas for permanent residence, up from 1.7 million in the previous three-year period. Congress in passing the immigration law foaused on how to balance the huge influx of Asian and Latin American immigrants with Europeans. Refugees are dealt with separately because they are not considered in the same category as immigrants. Aside from the immigration bill, a large number of permanent visas will be given to people already in this country, as the government carries out an amnesty law allowing Mexicans who are here illegally to gain legal status.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Returns to Beirut in Show of U.S. Support for Hrawi
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Ryan Crocker restaffed the U.S. Embassy on Thursday nearly 15 months after it was evacuated, underlining American support for President Elias Hrawi's efforts to end the civil war. Crocker, who presented his credentials to Hrawi in a 30-minute ceremony, said his biggest priority would be to secure the release of 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon, among them six Americans. The decision to send Crocker despite the still-tenuous security situation reflects U.S. backing for Hrawi's efforts to create a militia-free capital and end 15{ years of civil war. Crocker, 51, a career diplomat who served in Lebanon as a political officer in the early 1980s, said after the ceremony at Hrawi's temporary residence that he was returning ``at a time that I think offers the best hope any of us have seen for Lebanon since 1975.'' Asked how long he would stay in Lebanon, Crocker said: ``I'm having a good day here and will take it day by day.'' Crocker emphasised that the American hostages in Lebanon were ``very much on my mind as I take on this role. I want to see those Americans home as do all their countrymen. I will have no higher priority while I'm here than doing everything I can to secure their safe release.'' The missing Westerners, most of whom are believed held by pro-Iranian factions, also include four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Green-bereted soldiers of the Lebanese army's elite commando brigade provided security for Crocker as he crossed into Moslem west Beirut to present his credentials in the seaside Ramlet al-Baida district. They surrounded his car with seven jeeps that sped across jammed streets with lights on and horns honking. The ceremony occurred one day after Crocker was flown by helicopter from Cyprus, to the U.S. Embassy compound in Beirut's northern suburb of Aukar. Crocker told reporters it was a wonderful experience to cross the length of Beirut and see ``only Lebanese army uniforms and guns only in the hands of the Lebanese army.'' ``That is a very favorable beginning and can give us all confidence that the great Beirut plan will become the greater Lebanon plan,'' Crocker said. He was referring to the capital's militia-free zone, a linchpin of Hrawi's efforts to end the civil war. Called Greater Beirut, it stretches along a 15-mile coastal strip from the Kelb River in the north to the Damour River in the south and covers the city's immediate eastern suburbs. Crocker, who joined the State Department in 1971, reopened the embassy for the first time since former Ambassador John McCarthy and his staff evacuated on Sept. 6, 1989. The embassy was besieged at the time by supporters of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian general who battled Syrian troops backing the government. Since Aoun's defeat on Oct. 13, militias have been withdrawing from the capital. In Washington, Deputy State Department spokesman Richard Boucherd said Crocker was dispatched to Beirut after a U.S. security team inspected the situation in the Lebanese capital last weekend. Crocker, who speaks Arabic, also held diplomatic posts in Iran, Qatar, Iraq and Egypt. A state department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States has discussed its decision to send in Crocker with Syria, which backs Hrawi with 40,000 troops deployed in most of Lebanon. Lebanon's civil war has long been used as a proxy battleground for Middle East disputes and American diplomatic personnel have been frequent targets. American Ambassador Francis Meloy and an economic counselor were assassinated in 1976. Seventeen Americans, including top CIA staff, were killed by a truck bomb that destroyed the West Beirut embassy in April 1983. The Aukur embassy was damaged in September 1984 by a car bomber, killing eight. Aukar lies within the boundaries of greater Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says He Felt Pressured by Keating Five
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 15-18, Under further, with more Patriarca testimony; Should stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators faced ``a full court press'' from five senators on behalf of Charles Keating's troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan, one of the regulators told the Senate Ethics Committee today. Michael Patriarca, a savings and loan regulator based in San Francisco, said the so-called ``Keating Five'' senators seemed to have already made up their minds that the regulators were being too tough with Keating's thrift when they were summoned to meet with the senators on April 9, 1987. ``The senators seemed to have made up their minds ... that we were in fact harassing Lincoln, that we were incorrect, wrong,'' Patriarca said. ``Basically, we got the full-court press.'' Patriarca, western regional director for the Office of Thrift Supervision, took the witness stand in the ethics panel's hearing into allegations the five senators improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating's thrift, at a time when Keating was a major financial contributor to their campaigns and causes. Patriarca's initial testimony generally supported that of his former boss, Edwin J. Gray, who left the witness stand after four days of testimony. Gray, the star witness and chief accuser, stuck by his accusations that in a meeting he held with four senators, the senators improperly pressured him and that one, Arizona Democrat Dennis DeConcini, offered him a deal on behalf of Lincoln. DeConcini has strongly denied offering a deal. Gray concluded with a blast at Congress for accepting campaign contributions from special interests, and at the savings and loan industry for using that system to block his efforts to limit their risky practices. ``I think the influence of the thrift lobby killed all the reforms that we sought,'' Gray said. ``Every single reform I introduced, that I sent up to the (banking) committee, never saw the light of day.'' Patriarca described a meeting he and three other San Francisco-based regulators had with the five senators in the very building where the ethics panel is holding its hearings. That meeting was held at the suggestion of Gray, who a week earlier had been called to a meeting with four of the senators. Patriarca said that in the meeting he attended, DeConcini acted as host and talked more frequently than the others. ``It was my impression, quite frankly, that Senator DeConcini was negotiating on behalf of Lincoln ... attempting to get us, the regulators, to change our position on the examination (of Lincoln),'' Patriarca said. Besides DeConcini, other senators at the meeting and under investigation are Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio, Alan Cranston of California and Donald Riegle of Michigan. The five face allegations they improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating, who was a heavy financial contributor to their causes and campaigns. Patriarca said the regulators had found ``absolutely reckless'' practices by the Irvine, Calif.-based savings and loan. He said there was evidence the thrift's files had been stuffed with phony underwriting documents in an attempt to justify loans. Under further questioning, Patriarca said the ``full-court press'' by the senators lessened after the regulators revealed they planned to refer Lincoln's actions to the Justice Department for criminal investigation. He described later efforts by Lincoln to have its case transferred out of the jurisdiction of his San Francisco regional office. He said he opposed the move, but Jim Boland, chief of staff to Gray's successor as chief regulator, M. Danny Wall, cited political considerations in justifying the transfer. ``His response was, `There are things you don't understand. We're doing this for your own good. These guys are so well connected they can get you in ways you'll never know you've been gotten','' Patriarca said. Bennett, the special counsel, said Boland has denied making such a remark. Keating's California-based thrift was seized by the government in 1989, with a $2 billion bailout cost to taxpayers, and has become emblematic of the savings industry collapse. Gray finished his testimony today following a barrage of pointed questions from defense attorneys for the five enators who made a final attempt to discredit his testimony and integrity. Under more friendly questioning from committee counsel Robert S. Bennett, Gray reaffirmed his assertion that he was ordered to bring no staff with him when he was summoned to the April 2, 1987, meeting with four of the senators. He contends the directive came in a phone call from the office of DeConcini but that he did not know who made the call. ``I'm certain I was told not to bring staff. I was told to come alone,'' he said. Gray has contended that DeConcini suggested a ``quid pro quo,'' that Lincoln would make more home mortgage loans if he would drop a regulation that placed strict limits on Lincoln's ability to make risky speculative investments in real estate and other ventures. Bennett read the transcript of closed-door interviews two of the senators under investigation had with the committee and who were in that meeting. Both, according to Bennett, did not dispute Gray's assertion - though they did not confirm it either. Bennett quoted Glenn as saying, ``I do not recall whether that occurred or did not occur.'' And he quoted McCain as saying, ``I don't recall what happened. ... I do not claim Mr. Glenn is not telling the truth by any means.''

DOC.HEAD: New Law Gives NTSB Flexibility in Releasing Transcripts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation Thursday giving the National Transportation Safety Board more flexibility on when to release cockpit voice recorder transcripts after airline accidents. The old law required the agency to release the transcript no later than 60 days after a crash. Now, the NTSB will be able to release the transcript either when it holds a public hearing or when a majority of its staff reports on the accident are placed in the public record, whichever comes first. Bush, in a statement, expressed concern that the courts provide ``prompt and complete disclosure'' to all sides in lawsuits arising out of aircraft accidents. ``It is important to protect these materials from sensationalism and unwarranted disclosure, but it is also important that courts provide prompt and complete disclosure to litigants,'' Bush said. The measure also gives the NTSB clear authority to examine ships involved in accidents, and guarantees the agency access to the results of drug tests on any air traffic controller or other Department of Transportation employee who tests positive after an accident. It gives the board sole authority to determine what tests are conducted after an accident and who conducts them. The independent board investigates major air, sea and land accidents as well as pipeline mishaps.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Colin L. Powell has agreed to be honorary grand marshal for the annual King Week parade Jan. 21 in the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s hometown. Powell, the first black to serve as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, often quotes the slain civil rights leader in his speeches. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, criticized the King Center's decision to invite a military leader, saying it conflicted with King's teachings of non-violence. ``While I have a great deal of admiration for Colin Powell ... I think it creates an awkward set of circumstances that neither a King holiday nor General Powell ought to have to face,'' Lowery said Wednesday. King once declared the U.S. government to be ``the greatest purveyor of violence in the world'' and vehemently opposed the Vietnam War, in which Powell served two tours of duty. King Center spokesman Steve Klein defended Powell's invitation, saying the center wanted to engage ideological adversaries. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actors Helen Hayes and Dennis Weaver will share the annual Louella O. Parsons Award bestowed annually by the Hollywood Women's Press Club for recognition of their humanitarian efforts. The presentations will be a highlight of the 50th anniversary Golden Apple Awards luncheon Dec. 9 at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. The award is given to an individual ``presenting the best image of the entertainment industry to the world - having long demonstrated outstanding attributes both as a professional and as a human being.'' The 1990 award will be the first dual presentation. Earlier, the club announced that Bob Hope will be the recipient of the first All-Time Man of the Year Award. The Hollywood Women's Club was founded in 1928 by Parsons and 10 other Hollywood columnists. --- BUFFALO, N.Y. (AP) - Robin Leach, host of TV's ``Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous,' is suing a radio station over a commercial that he said imitated his voice. Leach filed a $350,000 lawsuit in federal court Tuesday against WMJQ-FM of Buffalo and the Niagara Frontier Homebuilders Association for the commercial advertising a home show last June. ``Robin Leach's voice is his trademark,'' said Daniel C. Oliverio, Leach's attorney. ``It's the way he earns his livelihood.'' Oliverio said the commercial could have led listeners to believe Leach was promoting the show. But spokesmen for the defendants said the commercial was a harmless parody. ``I'm sure there was no effort to harm Robin Leach or to deceive anyone,'' said Larry Levite, president of Algonquin Communications, the station's owner. ``It was just an effort to make something cute and a little bit creative.'' Levite added that his station did not produce the ad and was one of seven or eight stations that aired it. --- GRAND FORKS, N.D. (AP) - Author Garrison Keillor has an English class at the University of North Dakota to thank for spotting a discrepancy in one of his stories published in New Yorker magazine. Keillor thanked the class with a box full of his books and tapes of his radio show, and a letter inviting the class to dinner, his manager, Jennifer Howe, said Thursday from New York. Lecturer Lisa Lewis-Spicer's class wrote a letter two weeks ago ago asking Keillor to explain why a family suddenly grew from three to four kids in ``Zeus the Lutheran,'' a story that ran in the Oct. 29 issue. He responded in a letter with the box of gifts that they should be commended for their close reading of his story, Lewis-Spicer said. ``I was so overwhelmed,'' Lewis-Spicer said. She began handing out the gifts from Keillor to her three classes Tuesday. Lewis-Spicer said her English students plan to send Keillor a copy of a class-produced magazine along with a dinner invitation of their own. Keillor is creator of the fictional Lake Wobegon and is host of public radio's ``Garrison Keillor's American Radio Company of the Air.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Rock 'n' roll singer-songwriter John Hiatt says he admires the optimism of the under-30 crowd and has tried to appeal to them with his music. ``I'm telling you, I have not been so impressed with a generation of people as I am with this batch of 19 to 26 or 27-year olds,'' the 38-year-old Nashville native said in an interview published Thursday in the Nashville Banner. ``All the ones I've met are very enthusiastic about the possibilities before us as a country and a world, and they seem to be possessed of a real `Let's roll up our sleeves and get on with it' kind of attitude and I really like that.''

DOC.HEAD: National Guard Brigrade Gets Ready
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Dwayne Bouvier may be headed to the front line, but the worry weighing heaviest on the heart and mind of the 19-year-old National Guardsman isn't the thought of waging war. It's his wrecked wedding plans. ``My fiancee's not taking it very well. We were supposed to get married in February. The gowns are all paid for. The hall is paid for. The church was reserved. We thought about moving it up, but we couldn't get the church. It's a mess. We'll just have to wait until I get back,'' Bouvier said. Bouvier, a mechanic on a Mississippi River barge, serves in the Louisiana National Guard's 141st Field Artillery Battalion, part of the 256th Infantry Brigade. Last week, 4,800 members of the brigade were called up for active service because of the troop buildup in the Persian Gulf. Like others in the unit, Bouvier's life is taking an unexpected and risky detour since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the United States responded by sending troops to Saudi Arabia. Though he joined the combat outfit two years ago, Bouvier never imagined he might be sent away from home, perhaps never to return. ``There was no threat back then,'' Bouvier said this week in an interview at the Jackson Barracks. ``I never expected this to happen.'' The 256th, which is based in Lafayette with units scattered across the state, is a front-line infantry brigade. It heads for Fort Polk this weekend for processing and some units will go to Fort Hood, Texas, for training. Whether they will eventually be sent to the Middle East isn't known yet, officials said. Although they joined knowing they would be part of a fighting brigade, most of the guardsmen called up said they never expected to face battle. ``It bothers me a lot,'' said Spec. 4 Kenneth Lewis, 28. ``You know it's an artillery unit and you train to fire those guns, but I never did expect it to go somewhere.'' Lewis, a registered practical nurse and a minister, said it's hard to make the transition from healing to hurting. ``I'm trained to shoot those guns and if I have to I will, but I lose a lot of sleep over it,'' he said. Sgt. Robert Folk, 27, was to graduate from the University of New Orleans in May. ``I've accepted putting this part of my life on hold,'' he said. ``It's hard on my family and my girlfriend. They're afraid for me to go, afraid something will happen to me. I try to reassure them, but I have to cut it off at a point. They're afraid of the same things I might be scared of if I thought too much about them.'' Like many others, Lt. Robert Boswell, 25, joined to pay for his college education. ``It's been great. It gave me free tuition and $140 a month, plus $150 a month drill pay,'' he said. ``I thought I'd pay it back part time. You know, regular guard time. I never expected to be called up, but I don't regret it.'' For nine years, Sgt. Mike McDow has been a full-time soldier in the guard. Making the shift to active duty was easy for him, he said. The hard part was notifying weekend soldiers there lives were about to change, he said. ``The worst part is talking to the parents,'' McDow said. ``They think their son is going for six weeks of basic training then coming back and go to college.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Sees Subsidy Trade War Unless Europeans Compromise
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department's No. 2 official said Thursday an export subsidy war is likely if the European Community isn't willing to negotiate further in the final sessions of world trade talks next week. Deputy Secretary Jack C. Parnell said the bargaining nations scheduled to meet in Brussels are ``looking at the final moments in the negotiations'' for liberalizing global agricultural trade. A major hangup has been between the 12-nation community and other nations over reducing internal, trade-distorting farm supports and export subsidies. The so-called Uruguay Round of negotiations has been going on for four years under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``If the Europeans can't come to the GATT negotiating table in good faith, and discuss concrete reductions in agricultural subsidies and the real, measurable lowering of tariff walls, then they are making the initial unfriendly moves of a subsidy war,'' Parnell said. ``There is little doubt that the United States will retaliate, using every tool available to us, in order to maintain our market share,'' he said. Parnell also told the concluding session of the department's annual outlook conference that U.S. farmers could face even greater trade competition. ``Eastern Europe has been liberalized and we've all rejoiced,'' he said. ``But suppose the rest of Europe seduces these countries into joining its common agricultural policy?'' Parnell said that would mean the former East Germany, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania all would be joining the existing bloc. ``Can you imagine an 18-member common agricultural policy? American farmers have many good reasons to support a GATT agreement, not the least of which is holding onto their own financial prosperity,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Praises Brazilian, Argentinean Nuclear-Weapons Renunciation
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Thursday applauded the decisions by the presidents of Brazil and Argentina to renounce the manufacture of nuclear weapons. ``The prospects for a Latin America forever free from the dangers of nuclear weapons have brightened,'' said a White House statement by presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Presidents Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina signed an accord Wednesday to begin negotiations with the International Atomic Energy Agency to apply safeguards to all nuclear activities within their countries. They also vowed to use their nuclear potential ``exclusively for peaceful ends'' and to work toward setting up a nuclear-weapon-free zone in South America. ``President Menem and President Collor have acted boldly to enhance regional and world stability by pledging to use nuclear energy only for peaceful purposes,'' the White House statement said. Bush will visit both countries next week as part of a six-day South American tour. ``President Bush will visit the region next week and looks forward to discussing these issues in greater detail with Presidents Menem and Collor,'' Fitzwater's statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate's Book Advocates Nuclear Arms for Poland
LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: The businessman challenging Lech Walesa for the presidency advocates arming Poland with 100 medium-range nuclear missiles to ward off aggression and guard the country's sovereignty. Stanislaw Tyminski makes the argument in ``Sacred Dogs,'' a self-published book which outlines his pro-business, anti-tax and anti-union philosophies. The 260-page paperback, initially printed in July and distributed by his campaign, appears to contradict denials made during the campaign. In an interview Monday with The Associated Press, Tyminski denied he advocates nuclear weapons for Poland. Tyminsmki was not available Thursday to discuss his book. Campaign aide Krzysztof Pawlisz said that only the candidate could comment on the apparent contradiction. Tyminski also has branded as ``lies, lies, lies'' published reports that he traveled to Poland at least seven times in the 1980s on visas issued by the Polish consulate in Tripoli, Libya. However, Polish Interior Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski said Thursday that Tyminski did make the seven trips via Libya between 1980 and 1989. Tyminski's book is filled with military imagery, portraying Poland as a country under attack that must battle for its very existence, especially against German economic dominance. The first chapter is titled: ``I Put a Weapon in Your Hand'' and the second is, ``Go to War!'' Tyminski, until recently a political unknown who returned to Poland in September after 21 years in Canada and Peru, came from nowhere in a field of six to reach the second round of the country's first popular presidential election. He obtained 23 percent of the votes Sunday, defeating Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazsowiecki. The owner of several computer and communications companies, Tyminski leads the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada and has Polish, Peruvian and Canadian citizenship. His sharp criticism of alleged government mismanagement and his claims to economic expertise as a self-made millionaire have struck a responsive chord, especially among rural voters and the young. The rapid rise of his campaign has startled Solidarity leader Walesa, who is trying to decide how best to counter the outsider's unexpected success before the Dec. 9 runoff. ``I can fight against any serious opponent and this man is an amateur. ... I don't know how to react to it,'' Walesa said Wednesday night. Walesa on Thursday accused former Communists of mounting a ``counterrevolution'' by supporting Tyminski, and said a Tyminski victory could lead to ``something like a civil war.'' In his book, Tyminski devotes a full chapter to the need for nuclear weapons in Poland. He says the bomb really should be called the Z-bomb. ``Most physicists who worked on the A-bomb were forced to leave Germany by Hitler due to racist policy. ... That is why the `A' bomb really should be named the `Z' bomb,'' he said, alluding to the word ``Zyd,'' Polish for Jew. He said it isn't surprising that Israel ``is one of the most prominent countries in production of nuclear arms of highest quality.'' He writes: ``The most effective weapon for Poland is today an intelligent rocket of middle range equipped with a nuclear warhead of one megaton.'' One megaton is the equivalent of 1 million tons of TNT. He notes that the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima in 1945 was only the equivalent of 13,000 tons of TNT, and it killed 130,000 people. ``The H-bomb is so effective that it kills 10 million people at the small cost of 12 American cents for one human life,'' he says. ``Poland, a large, flat country threatened with invasion for centuries, also should possess this deterrent weapon,'' he says. ``Let us hope it will never have to be used.'' Nuclear weapons, he said, are ``needed by us to prevent aggressive appetites and to secure our sovereignty so that we can work in peace and feel ourselves fully independent and equal to other free countries.'' He says the weapon should not be possessed only by the superpowers, and that once it is acquired by Poland, the country's international prestige will rise. ``To possess nuclear weapons is to find oneself in the club of enviable nations which enjoy significant international esteem,'' Tyminski writes. His book is mainly a compilation of self-help recommendations and advice on how Poland could benefit from business lessons learned in the West. Quoting Mao Tse-tung and Che Guevera, he devotes much time to saying that the country should adopt an aggressive and disciplined ``guerrilla'' business campaign, including using private intelligence companies to discover gaps in Western markets. ``Wake up, Poles,'' he writes. ``Poles are not aware that today Poland is the target of serious aggression. The world has changed since World War II, and the world's contemporary soldier is a man in a suit with a briefcase, looking for economic possibilities of exploitation.'' ``We shall either go to this war together or we will be destroyed and wiped off the map of Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: EPA Cites Cleanup Progress
DOC.TEXT: Significant progress was made last year in getting polluters to assume a larger share of the cost of cleaning up toxic waste sites, the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday. The problem remains enormous, but EPA Administrator William Reilly said ``we are making real progress addressing the worst problems at the worst sites.'' Polluters, after negotiations with the government, agreed in fiscal 1990 to commit $1.3 billion for cleanup under the Superfund program, the EPA said. That was about a 30 percent increase over fiscal 1989. At the same time, there were increases in the number of cases in which the EPA sought reimbursements from polluters for past cleanup efforts paid by the government, and in the number of administrative orders for cleanup activities. Reilly said the statistics for fiscal 1990 show ``significant cleanup activity'' at about a third of the toxic waste sites on the agency's priority cleanup list. The priority list of toxic waste sites under the Superfund program includes more than 1,200 sites. Cleanup activities have been completed at only 63 sites, with work under way at another 360 sites, according to EPA figures. Officials estimate about 100 sites a year will be added to the list through the end of the decade. The cost of cleaning up the sites on the current list has been estimated by the EPA at more than $27 billion and is expected to take at least seven more years. The Superfund program, which began 10 years ago, so far has cost the government about $10 billion. Reilly said a more aggressive enforcement policy by the EPA has prompted polluters to more easily agree to cleanup plans. The EPA said the agency's enforcement office won 285 settlements in fiscal 1990 in which polluters agreed to commit $1.3 billion for Superfund cleanup efforts. At the same time, the EPA took action in 79 cases to recover $185 million from polluters for past cleanup activities paid for by the government. Meanwhile, Reilly said that the agency's overall enforcement activities involving water, air and other pollution also increased in the fiscal year that ended Oct. 1. During the year, 65 criminal cases were referred to the Justice Department for prosecution and 100 individuals were formally charged with criminal violations of environmental laws. Both figures represented slight increases over the previous year, but more than double the number of such cases in the mid-1980s. During the year, however, the number of criminal cases successfully prosecuted declined from 43 in fiscal 1989 to 32 last year, and the number of defendants convicted declined from 72 to 55. Officials said they could not explain the sharp drop, but noted that some cases can take a long time to conclude.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Religious Groups Urge Bush Against Mideast War
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of 18 religious organizations urged the administration on Thursday not to launch war against Iraq and to let the United Nations seek a diplomatic solution to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. All U.S. and other forces deployed in the Persian Gulf region should be placed under command of the United Nations, which should then seek a negotiated solution to the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait, said a statement issued by the interreligious grouping. ``The United States should not presume or accept the role of police in this conflict,'' it said. U.S. military action not only wouldn't achieve President Bush's goals of removing Iraqi troops and restoring Kuwait's legitimate government, it would ``most probably kill more Americans than are now hostages'' in Iraq, the statement said. Iraq is preventing some 900 Americans from leaving, effectively holding them hostage. An American attack would ``destroy Kuwait rather than save it'' and would risk spreading the conflict to other parts of the volatile Middle East, the group warned. It also condemned prejudice against Arab-Americans resulting from the administration's campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``This anti-Arab furor fuels American chauvinism and feeds racism on all levels,'' the statement said. The coalition includes American Baptist Churches USA, the American Friends Service Committee, the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, the National Council of Churches and the Commission on Social Action of Reform Judaism.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Debates `Use of Force' Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Kuwaiti comments. Pickup 4th pvs, `The resolution...' Vote not expected until around 5 p.m. EST.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today urged the Security Council to approve a resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, saying Saddam Hussein must realize time is running out. ``If Iraq does not reverse its course peacefully, then other military measures, including the use of force, should be authorized,'' Baker said. ``We must put the choice to Saddam Hussein in unmistakeable terms,'' said Baker, who presided over the opening of the Security Council session. After Baker's brief speech, Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber denounced the ``wild beasts'' from Iraq whom he said were pillaging and destroying his country, and raping, torturing and murdering his people. He said, ``The intransigence of the Iraqi regime is pushing the region to a conflagration which we do not want, but which appears to be the only avenue to restore our rights. He accused Iraq of using its hostages as bargaining chips to try to blackmail other nations into easing trade sanctions against Baghdad. The resolution, expected to pass overwhelmingly, would authorize an attack if Iraqi troops do not withdraw by Jan. 15, diplomats say. The only other time the Security Council has sanctioned force was to counter aggression during the Korean War. On Wednesday night, Baker met with Cuba's foreign minister, Isidoro Malmierca, then with China's top envoy, Qian Qichen. Both countries have said they would not vote in favor of the measure, although U.S. officials say China was not expected to exercise the veto power it wields as one of five permanent Security Council members. Iraq today renewed its bitter criticism of the proposed resolution, which the ruling party newspaper called a ``declaration of war.'' President Saddam Hussein accused the United States of pushing the United Nations into using ``double standrrds'' - supporting resolutions against Iraq but not those against Israel. The Arab Baath Socialist Party newspaper Al-Thawra suggested the resolution could provoke a backlash: ``increased resistance by the oppressed.'' In other gulf-related developments: -A former Navy secretary said today that President Bush must not add to his ``error'' of ordering 430,000 troops to the region by attacking Iraq. ``The president's mistake in sending so many troops should not be compounded by a further error in using them in a premature, unprovoked ground offensive,'' James Webb told the Senate Armed Services Committee. Webb, who served in the Reagan administration, is the third former top military official to urge caution in the gulf. Two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Wednesday Bush should give sanctions against Iraq more time to work before going to war. ``I counsel patience. War is not neat, it's not tidy. It's a mess,'' said retired Adm. William Crowe. -Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate minority leader, said in a statement Wednesday the chances were ``better than 50-50'' for a special congressional session on the gulf crisis, probably before Christmas. The use-of-force resolution remained on track after the United States, presiding over the council this month, delayed a vote Wednesday on whether to deploy U.N. observers to protect Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands. Seeking to maintain its alliance with Arab countries opposing Iraq, Washington wants to avoid having to veto or abstain in a vote that would offend Israel. U.S. officials also wanted to pass the use-of-force resolution before Saturday, when the council presidency passes to Yemen, which has sympathized with Iraq. The use-of-force resolution is the 12th pertaining to the Persian Gulf crisis to be taken up by the Security Council since Saddam Hussein's troops seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. Baker's talk Wednesday with Malmierca was the first formal U.S.-Cuban meeting in more than 30 years. The two countries still lack formal relations. It also meant Baker has personally consulted all 14 other Security Council members. At least 12 appeared solidly behind the resolution. With nine votes needed to pass, Cuba, Yemen and China were the holdouts. Malmierca said after meeting with Baker that he found the resolution ``not acceptable.'' Baker and Qian refused to answer reporters' questions when they got together at midnight Wednesday at a New York hotel. Earlier in the day, Qian said he would not vote in favor of the use-of-force resolution. China had not said publicly before that how it would vote. Qian's statement was widely viewed as a move to win political concessions from Washington, which imposed sanctions on China after its June 1989 military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. In a possibly related development, the Asian Development Bank today granted China a $50 million agricultural loan, its first to the Beijing government since the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. The United States is a principal shareholder in the Manila-based bank. Of the other permanent Security Council members - the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain - the Soviets have just this week come out strongly behind the use-of-force resolution. ``Either we will build civilized relations between states, a new world order and new policy, or will live by the law of the jungle,'' Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told reporters on arriving in New York on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: New British Prime Minister Criticized for Male-Only Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in more than a decade there are no women in the British Cabinet, emphasizing the abrupt end of the Thatcher era and prompting angry reactions Thursday from women's groups and some legislators. To many accustomed to Margaret Thatcher being in charge, Prime Minister John Major's all-male lineup just seems strange. ``It is extremely peculiar,'' said Caroline Bullingham, a 27-year-old psychology student. ``We are so used to the main woman there and now, no women at all.'' The glaring absence of a female in the Cabinet quickly became a target for the rival Labor Party, with one Labor legislator, Robert Hughes, asking whether the only woman in Major's Cabinet would be ``the back-seat driver.'' He referred to Mrs. Thatcher, Major's mentor and the woman largely responsible for his political ascendence. Major defended the all-male appointments during his first appearance in the House of Commons on Thursday, saying women were gaining a higher profile in law, commerce, civil service and politics. ``And as those women would wish it to be, they will reach the top on merit,'' he said, promising there would be ``women aplenty'' in his government. If Hughes had waited, Major added, ``perhaps even to the end of today, he may not have asked that question.'' Although Major did not announce a female appointee at day's end, he did say that Gillian Shephard had been given a lower-ranking executive job in the Treasury. Mrs. Shephard, who helped organize Major's leadership campaign, defended his appointments. ``You will see women in the Cabinet, there will be women there,'' she said in an interview on BBC television. ``The men had better look out.'' Although feminists criticized Mrs. Thatcher for appointing only one woman to the Cabinet in 11{ years, her own position at the head of government was a beacon of what could be achieved. The absence of even one woman in Major's Cabinet prompted squabbling between women legislators in Major's own Conservative Party. ``I'm hopping mad. We want a seat at the top table,'' complained Teresa Gorman, a Conservative lawmaker who threatened to organize protests at the House of Commons. ``Every aspect of the economy and government has a bearing on women. We don't want a few crumbs dropped from the table by the men any more,'' Mrs. Gorman said. Her criticism prompted a sharp rebuke from Dame Jill Knight, another Tory lawmaker, who accused Mrs. Gorman in a statement of ``a stupid rocking of the boat.'' The statement was signed by five other Conservative women legislators. Not surprisingly, Labor Party lawmakers were quick to issue criticism. ``This shows Mr. Major's contempt for women and his lack of recognition that women are half the population,'' said Jo Richardson, Labor's minister for women, adding that his actions belied his words. Another Labor legislator, Brian Sedgemore, said Major had taken the party back to the 19th century. ``After the way the Tories treated Mrs. Thatcher, they have now shown what they really think of women politicians,'' Sedgemore told the London-based Daily Telegraph. But Angela Rumbold, the Home Office minister responsible for women's issues and a former minister in Mrs. Thatcher's government, defended the new prime minister. ``We're talking now about people getting places ... people getting in there because they are a woman, no, no. They are there because they are the best people to do the job and that's the way they should be chosen,'' she told BBC television. There are 17 women among the 372 Conservative legislators in the House, and 43 women overall among Parliament's 650 members. Only eight women have served in the Cabinet, starting in 1929 with Margaret Bondfield. Barbara Castle was appointed to the Cabinet in 1964 and remained until 1976. She was replaced by Shirley Williams, and since then women had served every year until the present newly-appointed Cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officer Convicted in Colombian Arms Deal
