DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army officer accused by Colombia of arming and training drug traffickers was convicted Thursday by an Israeli court of illegally exporting weapons and his military expertise. The magistrate's court convicted the reservist, Lt. Col. Yair Klein, of selling the arms to a group called the ``Farmers' Organization.'' He has denied any involvement with drug traffickers. However, the Colombian government, which has declared Klein a fugitive, may try him in absentia on charges he trained private armies for drug lords. Klein's case has prompted wide debate in Israel over the practice of retired military officers working as mercenaries overseas. Thursday's conviction came after Klein, a former army counter-terrorist expert, agreed to change his plea to guilty on three charges against him and his company, Hod Hahanit, or ``Spearhead.'' Klein pleaded guilty to negotiating to sell military expertise without a license, the actual sale of expertise, and the unlawful sale of equipment such as weapons, belts and night gun-scopes. The charge said Klein's dealings with the Farmers' Organization were in April 1988 but gave no details on the group. Klein has maintained he believed he was hired by a ranchers organization to defend against leftist guerrillas. Klein, who faces a maximum three-year sentence, refused to speak to reporters Thursday. ``It's not as if e committed a murder or anything,'' his lawyer Yigal Shapira said. ``This is like a contractor who builds without a license. We are talking about a two to five month suspended sentence.'' A sentencing hearing has been set for December 27. Shapira read aloud a statement in Klein's name before the court explaining why he changed his plea: ``I decided to plead guilty in an effort to end the witch hunt that is being carried out in the press on the basis of rumors and speculation and which is causing damage to the state and myself.'' Israeli prosecutors are also considering charging Klein in connection with an Israeli arms shipment sent to the Caribbean island of Antigua that ended up with Colombian drug lord Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. He was killed nearly a year ago in a gun battle with police. Klein has denied diverting those weapons to Colombia. He has said the shipment was intended for a training school he wanted to set up in Antigua for Panamanian rebels, but that the shipment went awry. Klein's partner, Yizhak Shoshani, is also charged in connection with arms exports. A hearing for him was postponed until next month.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 to DELETE extraneous computer paragraph marks.
DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Specialists Face Unusual Teaching Split
DOC.TEXT: Here's a dilemma. How do you keep people from being frightened of an earthquake, while trying to convince them one could occur at any time? That's the quandary faced by emergency management specialists because of a projected major earthquake along the New Madrid Fault next week. Word of the projection has sent a wave of anxiety across much of the central United States. Scientists say the projection by New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning is worthless. Yet they also say a damaging tremor along the quake-prone fault is likely to shake things up some day. ``We're trying to calm people down. At the same time, we don't want them so calm they forget about the long-range possibility of an earthquake,'' said Robert Self, a geologist with the University of Tennessee-Martin. The cause of a great deal of nervous anticipation is Browning's thery. Based on gravitational forces of the sun and moon, he says there's a 50-50 chance of a quake measuring 7 or more on the Richter scale along the New Madrid Fault for the 48 hours either side of Dec. 3. The fault, running from Marked Tree, Ark., to Cairo, Ill., and touching parts of Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Illinois and Kentucky, was the source of a series of severe quakes in the early 19th century. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread damage in a populated region. Memphis is 35 miles from the fault, and with 650,000 people the largest city nearest the fault. ``We're trying to tell people there's nothing special about December 3rd, but at the same time we're trying to tell them to upgrade their building codes. That's hard to do,'' Self said. Earthquake specialists at the U.S. Geological Survey, Memphis State University and St. Louis University say Browning is only guessing. But other people aren't taking chances. Schools around the region are planning to be closed, primarily in small towns and rural areas. Communities are running disaster drills. People are stocking up on bottled water and other supplies. Earthquake specialists put the chances of a damaging New Madrid temblor at up to 60 percent over the next 15 years. Over the next 50 years, the chances climb to better than 95 percent. Such a quake likely would cause damage comparable to the temblor that hit the San Francisco Bay area last year. The jitters reached into eastern Ohio on Thursday. Residents of Lancaster, near Columbus, said they felt a quake, one seismologist said he found a blip to suggest it, but no one could confirm that a tremor hit the region. One caller to a radio station said the shaking knocked dishes over and pictures off the wall of her home. Others said they felt the earth move. John Minsch, a geophysicist at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said his agency had no evidence to suggest an earthquake hit Ohio. ``As near as we can tell, there was no activity there today,'' he said. ``Almost anything could have caused the ground to shake - construction, a sonic boom.''

DOC.HEAD: Interim Liberia Leader Optimistic About Peace Prospects
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a West African-backed interim government for Liberia headed to that country Thursday, optimistic that a newly signed cease-fire will end the 11-month-old civil war. The interim leader, Amos Sawyer, brushed aside rebel leader Charles Taylor's refusal to accept his administration. The truce ``is a big step forward, and I'm optimistic,'' Sawyer said before he boarded a helicopter belonging to a West African regional force sent to end the war, which has left at least 10,000 dead. ``If the cease-fire holds, it provides the opportunity to reach the necessary political solution,'' he said. Sawyer was picked as president in August by a conference of Liberian exiles. But others among the 200,000 Liberian refugees in Sierra Leone were less optimistic about the cease-fire that Taylor signed with two other warring parties at a summit of West African leaders Wednesday in Bamako, Mali. ``Taylor lost my support and that of many Liberians when he started killing innocent civilians. ... They are all killers,'' said Liberian refugee Lucy Shaw, a midwife. Sawyer's foreign minister, Gabriel Bacchus Matthews, acknowledged that many problems loom. He said the truce ``is a small step on a 1,000-mile journey to peace,'' Despite the signing, Matthews said Taylor had refused to discuss putting the cease-fire into effect and agreed only to another meeting. Within an hour of signing the accord, Taylor told reporters he did not recognize Sawyer's administration. Taylor has set himself up as president of a rival interim government, and he wants to organize Liberian elections. Sawyer rejects Taylor's plan. The Bamako summit was convened by the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, which authorized the deployment in Liberia of 8,000 soldiers from five member nations. ``Taylor may not have accepted our government, but all the West Africans, including his chief supporters, Burkina Faso and Ivory Coast, have, and that is significant,'' Sawyer said. He predicted Taylor ``will continue to try to find a solution, rather than be confrontational.'' In August, Taylor refused to join President Samuel Doe and breakaway rebel leader Prince Johnson in a cease-fire. In September, Johnson's men captured and killed Doe, but Taylor continued fighting Johnson and the West African force. Under the West African plan, Sawyer and his vice president, Lutheran bishop Ronald Diggs, are not permitted to run in elections scheduled for next year. Taylor invaded Liberia from Ivory Coast on Dec. 23 and quickly won over thousands of peasants who took up arms to help him overthrow Doe, long accused of corruption and brutal repression. However, the rebellion degenerated into a tribal conflict pitting fighters loyal to Doe, Taylor and Johnson against each other.

DOC.HEAD: President, Stars Encourage Community Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dian in graf 9 is cq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, with a boost from the Beach Boys and other pop stars, helped launch a celebrity-backed effort Thursday to entice America's youth to perform community service. The program is called StarServe - Students Taking Action and Responsibility in Service - and organizers said they have sent sign-up materials to 100,000 schools. ``To all young Americans I say: Answer the call to serve your community and be a star,'' Bush said. The president and a chorus of celebrities, including pop singer Tiffany, actress Sally Kirkland, actor Chad Allen and Baltimore Orioles shortstop Cal Ripken Jr., shared the East Room with a dozen youths and a Nebraska teacher deeply involved in community service. ``I want every young American from 5 to 25 to be a point of light in his or her community, whether it's lonely senior citizens, a troubled classmate or acquaintance, someone who's burdened by drug use, illiteracy, homelessness or hunger,'' Bush said. ``There's a need right next door, down the hall or in your own back yard that you can meet.'' He applauded the efforts of ``the worlds of entertainment and media ... (to) use their influence to make service a pervasive part of the popular culture.'' The White House last year began naming daily ``points of light'' as part of Bush's crusade to encourage community service. Dian Wurst, a Polk, Neb., teacher was on hand with one of her third graders, Trent Stevens, to talk about how the class won a ``point of light'' award Jan. 23. The third-graders call home-bound senior citizens each morning to make sure they are all right. Trent Stevens said tee calls helped get aid for one elderly woman who had fallen and broken her hip during the night. ``This is a serious job and people are depending on them,'' Ms. Wurst said, adding that her pupils learn responsibility and compassion from the project, as well as telephone manners. Bush said there is ``no better example'' of just how much good young people can do than the work done by Ms. Wurst's class. The Kraft General Foods Foundation has provided a $1.5 million grant to launch StarServe in partnership with the Love Foundation and United Way of America. Among the celebrities who have signed on to visit schools to encourage participation are New Kids on the Block, basketball stars Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics and Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks, wrestler Hulk Hogan and tennis star Zina Garrison.

DOC.HEAD: Germany to Help Ward Off Hunger in The Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 1, 7 and 18 to change to today sted Thursday to conform to style.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 40 years after Moscow tried to starve West Berlin into submission, Germany said Thursday it would help ward off hunger in the Soviet Union by donating huge food reserves built up because of the infamous blockade. A daily airlift of supplies and tens of thousands of food packages sent by CARE, the international relief organization, will also aid the crippled Communist nation, as part of a large-scale assistance program. ``The situation in the country is catastrophic. People have to fight for food. People already are going hungry,'' the ZDF television network said in a campaign for private donations. Although Germans routinely rush to the aid of victims of natural disasters and other emergencies, the current wave of support is unprecedented. Companies are contributing goods and services. German businesses and ordinary citizens pledged more than $4 million in donations during a 45-minute telethon on ZDF, the network said late Thursday. Newspapers are running their own donation campaigns, and the money is still flowing to various organizations. ``A Heart for Russia - We're Taking Part,'' read the headline Thursday in the mass-circulation Bild newspaper. Below the headline were pictures of prominent Germans explaining their reasons for contributing money to the Bild campaign. The state of Lower Saxony pledged help totaling $5 million, while the Maltese aid organization said it was sending field kitchens to cook meals for needy Ukrainians. Even before the latest actions, Germany had promised the Soviets $19.5 billion in financial aid this year alone. Pictures of food being loaded for the Soviet Union are daily fare in the German news media. In public, German officials have been playing on the nation's gratitude for the Soviet approval of German unification, as well as humanitarian motives. ``Please, help relieve the need in the Soviet Union. This is a work of charity and of good neighborliness,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in an appeal broadcast late Wednesday on ZDF television. Kohl also called to mind the Soviets' role in clearing the way for the merger of East Germany and West Germany on Oct. 3. ``We all have to thank the Soviet Union in these months. I am certain that we all are ready to help,'' said Kohl, who met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev earlier this month in Germany. Even then, Gorbachev had been reduced from the leader of a once monolithic superpower to an imperiled leader in need of a rich Western patron. While German politicians are not saying so directly, their support for the current relief efforts might be aimed at propping up Gorbachev as his country faces a possibly decisive winter. Germany has been flooded with hundreds of thousands of immigrants, refugees and other newcomers. The Germans are eager to prevent another wave of newcomers - this time Soviets fleeing hunger and civil strife at home. Thursday, there was a nearly non-stop stream of announcements of relief efforts that could amount to Germany's largest humanitarian program ever. In Bonn, Kohl's top foreign policy adviser Horst Teltschik said Germany would give the Soviets the so-called ``Berlin reserves,'' replenished over the years in case of another blockade. Those reserves include, among other items, 66,000 tons of rye, 26,000 tons of canned meat and 7,500 tons of butter. Berlin officials, who urged Bonn to donate the food, estimate it could feed 10 million Soviets for one month. A huge U.S.-led airlift broke the 1948-49 Soviet blockade, aimed at bringing West Berlin to its knees and driving out the Western powers. Germans are worried, however, that their donations could wind up in the Soviet Union's growing black market. ``We are supervising things ourselves,'' said Klaus Noeldner, head of the German branch of CARE. ``We will be distributing with the help of citizens committees in schools,'' Noeldner said. ``We are distributing only to individuals, those who because they are too old, or handicapped or weak can't stand on line.'' He estimated that 1.2 million people in Moscow alone fall into that category. Noeldner says the organization already has enough money to send 60,000 CARE packages. CARE packages are a part of German history and have become nearly legendary, after millions of the American-sent boxes filled with food helped save Germans from starvation after World War II. Also Thursday, an Aeroflot transport plane filled with 37 tons of food left northern Hanover bound for Moscow. The plane is part of a relief airlift that organizers say will fly daily to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam: U.S. May Think It's Rambo, But Gulf War Won't Be Easy
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said Thursday that Americans have been duped by Rambo movies into thinking war will be easy, but Iraq has weapons to beat even the most advanced U.S. systems, such as the Stealth bomber. Speaking in a defiant tone, Saddam said the United States is wrong if it thinks Iraq will tremble over the U.N. Security Council sanctioning the use of military force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. He said his armed forces had the technology to defeat even the most sophisticated American weapons systems, specifically citing the Stealth fighter bomber. There have been conflicting reports over whether Iraq has the ability to detect the Stealth fighters, which are designed to sneak in under enemy radar. Some reports have said the Iraqis may have acquired the means for detection by using technology sold by France. The Pentagon has sent 22 F117A Stealth aircraft to unspecified bases in the region. In his remarks carried by Baghdad radio, the president also lashed out at the ruling family in Saudi Arabia, saying they are not fit to be the guardians of holy Islamic shrines. The remarks, addressed to an Arab Youth Solidarity seminar, came hours before the Security Council was to vote on the U.S.-sponsored resolution authorizing the use of force to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait if they do not withdraw by Jan. 15. Diplomats in Baghdad said they believed the speech was aimed largely at lifting the morale of the Iraqi people, many of whom have been concerned over the U.N. resolution. The speech was not accorded special status by the official Iraqi News Agency, which summarized it in a few hundred words. Major speeches are carried verbatim. Referring to earlier U.N. resolutions condemning the occupation of Kuwait and demanding Iraqi withdrawal, Saddam said the United Nations is trying to foist on Iraq ``unjust and rejected resolutions.'' He said that by passing another resolution authorizing military action, ``they believe that we will be scared and that we will call on others to help us.'' But, Saddam said, ``We will fight and fight on in a way which will make all Arabs and Moslems proud.'' In the speech, Saddam referred to the ``so-called'' U.N. Security Council and said it has become a tool of the United States. ``I am sorry to say that it is no longer a Security Council, but an obedient instrument to be used by those who dictate its resolutions,'' he said. He added that while Iraq respected the American military might, the situation in the Persian Gulf should not be viewed as a war movie that ends with a quick victory. ``The Americans are still influenced by Rambo movies, but this is not a Rambo movie. This is something different,'' Saddam said. ``We do not underestimate American military power, but we scorn their evil intentions.'' Saddam added that the Iraqi military had the ability to fight high-tech American weapons, saying: ``We are not deprived of military technology. ... We can see the Stealth very clearly, and we hope (the U.S.) will not be dragged into using it because we will shoot it down like any hostile warplane.'' Saddam also attacked the Saudi royal family, saying, ``How dare they call theArab peninsula after their grandfather Saud, forgetting that this land has a long history. They consider the holy land as the feudal possession in full disregard to its people and history.'' Saddam reiterated his position that all Middle Eastern conflicts should be resolved simultaneously, including the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. In a statement earlier Thursday, Saddam accused the United States of forcing the United Nations into adopting a double standard by supporting resolutions condemning Iraq but not those on Israel. The Iraqi government has insisted it would abide by U.N. resolutions on the gulf only if the United Nations enforced those calling on Israel to withdraw from the territories it occupied in the 1967 Middle East war. The United States and its allies have rejected the linkage.

DOC.HEAD: From Wheelchairs, Sportsmen Hunt for Deer
DOC.TEXT: The first year they tried it, their wheelchairs got stuck in the mud. But after 18 seasons, the state's special deer hunt for paraplegic sportsmen is a smooth operation with all the camaraderie and thrills of more conventional quests for the white-tailed quarry, organizers say. ``Male bonding, is that what you call it?'' joked Tom Early, an 18-year veteran of the state's Division of Fisheries and Wildlife and a regular on the special hunts held before the official season opens. ``We've had a couple of people that were really down in the dumps until they got involved in the hunt. It perks them up. It gives them something to look forward to,'' said Leo Daly, a wildlife official and hunt leader. Even those who aren't too excited at the prospect of hunting approve. ``I think it's a good opportunity for people with disabilities to get out in the woods,'' said Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commissioner Elmer Bartels. ``I always hoped that they were lousy shots.'' For hunter Fred Marchegiani, 100 percent disabled since suffering a nerve disease in 1980, the adventure in the Berkshires offers a rare chance to revisit the old days. ``To be able to hunt again and be in the outdoors and enjoy something that I've done all my life - actually it gives you a new lease on life,'' he said Thursday. Overall, 10 deer were taken by the 26 hunters who attended the 3-day hunt earlier this month. That's more than in the early years, Daly said. ``When we first put them in the woods they couldn't do anything. They were stuck in the ruts,'' he said. Game wardens devised a plywood platform to use as a base. Participants range from people who have jobs and are normally active to people who have very limited mobility and rarely go outside at all, Early said. Some of the regulars hunted before becoming disabled, but others have never hunted. ``A lot of them are on the verge of being sick all the time anyway. They come out of the hospital to go hunting and they go back in the hospitals afterward. We try to be as careful as we can,'' Early said. The hunt is a low-profile affair. ``We can't handle a lot more people than we have because it's pretty labor intensive,'' Early said. ``We have four-wheel drive vehicles and get them as close as we can and then you've got to wheel them through the woods,'' he said. The hunters are given permission by private landowners to hunt property that has ``high deer density,'' Early said. ``It's nothing to see 40 pair of eyes out there in the morning,'' said Daly, who noted that some of the landowners are not hunters themselves, but are willing to open their property to allow the hunt and to keep the population manageable. Hunting from a wheelchair is not always a disadvantage. ``Often sitting there and not being able to move can be an advantage in that you're not scaring deer,'' Early said. Early and Daly said no one has been injured during a hunt, but some of the hunters have circulation problems and must be brought in if it gets rainy and cold. Volunteers and state wildlife officials monitor hunters through binoculars. Benefits from the hunt aren't just one-way, said volunteer Shaun Smith, who has been going on the hunt for 15 years, but was uneasy at first about working with the disabled. ``I found out that they're regular people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: West Germany ... its borders:
DOC.TEXT:
DENMARK - It has sent a corvette, the Olfert Fischer. Danish merchant ships are helping in the U.S. sealift. ---
NORWAY - It has sent the Coast Guard cutter Andenes to support the Danish corvette. Norway has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment. --- PORTUGAL - It has commited a naval support ship to the gulf. --- POLAND - It will send a military field hospital and a hospital ship to the gulf. ---
CZECHOSLOVAKIA - It has sent a 200-man army unit with anti-chemical warfare equipment. --- GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait) - A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops is based at Hafr al-Batin, Saudi Arabia, 40 miles south of the Kuwait border. They and allied Arab-Islamic forces form the first line of defense. The GCC force has been beefed up with about 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-man army who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. Most of their heavy weapons were captured by Iraq, but some combat jets and tanks were saved. The GCC and other Gulf Arab forces total around 144,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units. They are supported by: EGYPT - It has pledged up to 20,000 troops with tanks and heavy artillery. About 14,000 troops - including paratroopers, commandos, chemical warfare specialists and infantry - are in Saudi Arabia. Several thousand more soldiers from the 3rd Armored Division and the 3rd Mechanized Infantry Division, are expected in the next few days. Five hundred troops are in the United Arab Emirates. --- SYRIA - About 6,500 troops, mostly elite Special Forces units who have fought the Israelis and others in Lebanon, are in Saudi Arabia. A 15,000-man armored division, with about 420 tanks and heavy artillery, is preparing to go to Saudi Arabia. Some troops are based in the United Arab Emirates. --- PAKISTAN - It has pledged to send 5,000 troops, with 2,000 already in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 in the United Arab Emirates, along with 1,000 advisers. About 5,000 advisers are already attached to the Saudi armed forces. --- MOROCCO - It has 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the United Arab Emirates. --- BANGLADESH - It has 2,000 troops, including engineering and infantry units, in Saudi Arabia. --- IRAQ - The army has seven corps totaling 55 divisions. There are 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Regular forces include seven divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. Saddam Hussein has 5,500 tanks, including about 500 high-quality T-72s and 1,000 medium-quality T-62s; 3,500 artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; more than 330 surface-to-air missile launchers, including captured Kuwaiti systems; 500-plus combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors. The equipment is spread around an estimated 25 airbases. Its main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats. Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 10 divisions, four of them armored, totaling 170,000 troops; 3,500 T-55 and T-62 tanks, and 1,700 artillery pieces in what appear to be defensive positions. About 250,000 men, including the seven Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,300 tanks and 750 guns, are in southern Iraq as a tactical reserve. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. FROG-7 battlefield missiles have also been deployed, including batteries captured in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's Not Considering Draft
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday the nation's all-volunteer army ``is as strong as it can be'' and he has no plans to ask Congress to reinstitute the draft. In an interview at the White House with Univision, the Spanish language network, Bush said he was ``definitely not'' considering bringing back the draft. ``Because we don't need it. We have an all-volunteer army. It is as strong as it can be,'' the president said. ``We don't need a draft.'' Bush also said he wanted to confer further with congressional leaders on the subject of a possible ``lame duck'' session of Congress to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. He meets Friday with congressional leaders. ``I am very anxious to know what they think would be productive because it is important that we send a solid signal,'' Bush said. The president indicated he was not considering calling Congress back into session and would prefer not to do so.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Bill Expanding Number of Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday signed a massive revamp of the nation's immigration law that increases the number of people allowed to immigrate and strikes down exclusion of entry on the basis of sexual orientation and political views. Bush hailed the first major overhaul of immigration law since 1965 as a ``complementary blending of our tradition of family reunification with increased immigration of skilled individuals to meet our economic needs.'' It changes the 1950s-era immigration ban against communists and homosexuals, but would still allow the secretary of state discretion to bar legal status to those considered to be terrorist or foreign policy threats. The bill will increase overall immigration from 540,000 in 1989 to 700,000 people a year for each of the next three years and stabilize the annual total at 675,000 after that. The bill's three-year total of 2.1 million visas for permanent residence is up from 1.7 million in the previous three-year period. The changes Bush signed into law were hailed by Irish and other European immigrant interests who stand to benefit from the increase, gay groups, Filipino veterans and Salvadorans fleeing their war-torn country. The provisions of the new law emphasize reuniting separated families, with immigrants sponsored by family members increasing to 520,000 per year through 1994, and at least 480,000 a year thereafter. The bill will also: - Allow more people to immigrate on the basis of desirable employment skills, reserving 140,000 visas a year for immigrants with special skills, up from 54,000 in the past. - Give special status to wealthy investors, setting aside 10,000 visas for those with at least $500,000 to invest in businesses that create new jobs. - Eliminate the automatic exclusion of AIDS sufferers from legal status. The legislation leaves it up to the Health and Human Services Department to decide whether to list AIDS as an excludable disease. - Earmark 40,000 visas a year for individuals from Italy, Poland, Ireland and other countries virtually shut off from immigration in the last 20 years because priority was given to people with family here, most of whom were from Asian and Latin countries. - Reserves at least 16,000 of those 40,000 visas a year for Irish immigrants, making Ireland the only country with a guaranteed number of visas. - Grant a special ``temporary protected status'' until July 1992 for Salvadorans. For several years, Salvadorans fleeing domestic violence, including from right-wing death squads, have waged an uphill struggle against deportation. - Allow for naturalization of Filipinos who served in the U.S. military or Philippine Army or guerrilla units in World War II. - Expedite deportation of aliens convicted of criminal activity, and grant general arrest authority to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. - Ease restrictions on visitors once barred for communist or ideological viewpoints. ``This bill is good for families, good for business, good for crime fighting and ood for America,'' Bush said at a White House signing ceremony on Thursday. Bush said the bill ``revises the exclusion grounds for the first time since enactment in 1952, putting end to the kind of political litmus test that might have excluded even some of the heroes of the Eastern European revolution of 1989.'' The American Bar Association praised the bill, but voiced opposition to some provisions that it said would ``impede the ability of persons in immigration proceedings to secure representation,'' and could block some political asylum applicants. Georgetown University law professor David Cole said the bill leaves too many loopholes for exclusion on political and ideological grounds, because of the discretion left to the secretary of state in areas of terrorism and national security concerns. ``Far from repudiating the ideological litmus test, Congress merely adjusted it to today's paranoias,'' he said. The National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, praised the bill for permitting homosexuals to immigrate, but also called on the Bush administration to use its newly granted powers to keep AIDS and HIV infection off the list of excludable diseases. Bush and HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan have not taken official positions, but administration officials said it is expected they will not put the disease on the list. The law improves the prospects of citizenship for thousands of illegal Irish immigrants living in Boston, New York and other cities. ``This historic legislation is good news for Ireland and the Irish people,'' Irish Foreign Minister Gerard Collins said in Dublin Thursday. Under an earlier amnesty law, a large number of permanent visas will be given to Mexicans already here illegally.

DOC.HEAD: Tower Memoirs: Reagan Apparently Participated in Cover-Up
DOC.TEXT: President Reagan and his top aides tried to mislead the Tower Commission and cover up White House involvement in a key aspect of the Iran-Contra affair, former U.S. Sen. John Tower says. In his soon-to-be-published memoirs, Tower said he was shocked when Reagan denied the White House gave advance approval for an August 1985 shipment of missiles to Iran, in contradiction of an earlier statement by the former president. Portions of Tower's book ``Consequences: A Personal and Political Memoir'' were published in Thursday's Dallas Times Herald. The book is scheduled to be published in February, the newspaper said. The longtime Republican lawmaker wrote that Reagan's about-face seemed part of a ``deliberate effort'' to cover up then-White House Chief of Staff Donald Regan's involvement in the affair. Tower was appointed by the Reagan administration in 1986 to investigate the scandal. The Tower Commission's report had noted Reagan's shifting stories about the missile sale. But the book marks the first time a principal figure has suggested the changes in the president's story were part of a deliberate cover-up. In a Jan. 26, 1987, meeting with the Tower board, Reagan said that sometime in August 1986, he approved a shipment of arms by Israel to Iran. In a meeting with the commission two weeks later, Reagan said that he and Regan had gone over the matter a number of times and that Regan had a firm recollection that the president had not authorized the August shipment in advance. The president said he didn't recall authorizing the August shipment, either. Then on Feb. 20, 1987, the president wrote the board a letter, changing his story again. In the letter, he said he simply couldn't recall whether he approved the August shipment in advance or not. Tower also said Reagan offered to appoint him ambassador to West Germany when he retired from the Senate in 1984, but he declined the offer. Tower also wrote that he sent his wife and children into hiding on FBI advice when anger against Texas conservatives grew after President Kennedy's 1963 assassination in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Newly Appointed Chief Quits Big NYC Hospital
DOC.TEXT: The newly appointed chief of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center resigned abruptly after questions were raised about his spending in office, the hospital said Thursday. Michael Bradley's departure as president and chief executive officer of the financially troubled hospital came amid reports that he exercised bad judgment in his use of a $250,000 discretionary fund. Bradley, who came to Columbia Presbyterian in August from Philadelphia's Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, submitted his resignation Wednesday, said spokeswoman Susan Parker. ``(It) resulted from policy differences with the Board of Trustees concerning certain hospital expenditures totaling less than $100,000,'' the board said in a statement. ``In accepting his resignation, the hospital's board did not call into question Bradley's overall management capability.'' Bradley was unavailable for comment, his secretary said. A source close to the hospital who spoke on condition of anonymity confirmed published reports that Bradley had spent $25,000 on china for a hospital dining room and $60,000 stocking a wine cellar for entertaining potential donors. ``There was no wrongdoing but there was a question of judgment,'' the source said. Bradley was hired to turn around the struggling hospital, the largest in the city with about 1,200 beds. ``He had a good reputation in financial management circles,'' said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. Raske said Bradley's resignation was a surprise. Bradley's predecessor, Thomas Q. Morris, resigned in May after a dispute over the hospital's financial woes and inability to staff its new Allen Pavilion Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Touching All Bases Helped in U.S. Gulf Diplomacy
With AM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The stakes were never higher - war or peace - and while it's far too early to know how the showdown will play out, Secretary of State James A. Baker III can take credit for succeeding in very difficult diplomacy over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Baker rounded up the votes for the U.S. resolution to threaten Iraq with force by lobbying all 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council. He made two long trips abroad and then, in an 11th-hour drive, held eight separate meetings with foreign ministers in New York in advance of the vote. Baker apparently cut no private deals, but he gave some ground on the Palestinian issue. ``We should be willing at all times to confront the problems that exist.'' However, he rejected an effort by the Palestine Liberation Organization to link Iraq's invasion of Kuwait with Arab demands on Israel. The PLO had tried to seize on the crisis in the Persian Gulf to make some headway of its own - with support from Yemen, the only Arab country on the council, and a few other sympathizers. Baker's main task was to make sure the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain, all permament members of the council, would not block the resolution with a veto. Britain and France have joined the United States in committing troops to defend Saudi Arabia and were never in doubt. They have stood alongside the Bush administration from the outset, although French President Francois Mitterrand preferred putting more emphasis on diplomacy. China played an ambiguous game. Baker met with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen twice - in Cairo earlier in the month and then in New York at midnight Wednesday. The Chinese are skeptical about using force to liberate Kuwait. But Baker solicited a pledge not to block the resolution. After making his pitch, he told reporters, ``I didn't detect a whole lot of expressions of unhappiness'' with the resolution. A poker-faced politician who helped lift his old Texas country-club buddy, George Bush, to the presidency, Baker has never run a graver risk than the threat to go to war over Kuwait if Iraq does not pull out by Jan. 15. After the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, Baker's skills were put to a slightly different test. His task was to assemble the odd alliance that has confronted Iraq at the United Nations and in the gulf itself. This brought together such disparate elements as Syria, still branded by the State Department as a sponsor of terrorism; the Saudi monarchy; Western democracies and the ousted Kuwaiti regime. Baker even tried to enlist Cuba to at least support the resolution. But in the first, formal, high-level U.S.-Cuban meeting in more than 30 years, Foreign Minister Isodoro Malmierca told Baker the resolution was unacceptable. The question now is, ``What next?'' Douglas Hurd, the British foreign secretary, said the United Nations had sent Iraqi President Saddam Hussein a clear message. ``We are making a strong bid for peace on the basis of him withdrawing, cutting away all the confusion,'' Hurd said. ``There is a period of time during which he has the peaceful options in his hands.'' And yet, Hurd said of the Jan. 15 deadline: ``It's not indefinite.'' Standing defiantly within range of Iraqi missiles on Thanksgiving, President Bush acknowledged the dangers as he told U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia: ``No one knows precisely when this dictator may acquire atomic weapons or exactly whom theyt may be aimed at down the road. But we do know this for sure: He has never possessed a weapon that he didn't use.'' In the meantime, Baker and the administration have had the kind of break that any political operative relishes falling into his lap. The Soviet Union, after insisting for months that diplomacy should be given more time, now has turned on Saddam with a fury matching Bush's. Incensed that Baghdad has trapped more than 3,000 Soviet citizens in Iraq, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev demanded on Monday that Saddam withdraw from Kuwait and free foreign hostages. ``The fate of Iraq is in the hands of its leadership,'' he said. ``Time is running out.'' Until Gorbachev leveled the threat at Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Moscow, the Soviets were very cautious about threatening to use force. But the caution Gorbachev and his foreign minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, showed in their meetings with Baker now has given way to unqualified support for the Bush administration. Shifting the deadline from Jan. 1 to Jan. 15 represents a slight concession to the Soviets and others hesitant to threaten Iraq with ``all necessary means.'' It also gives U.S. troops more time they need to get ready to fight. The additional two weeks could make a difference only if Saddam were to do a 180-degree turn and obey the resolutions he has ignored since the invasion. Since Baker already has repeatedly rejected ``partial solutions,'' there may be no face-saving way out for Iraq. THe hand held by Bush and Baker will have been called. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Barry Schweid has covered diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Updated Homeless Legislation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday signed updated legislation to help the homeless, authorizing $2 billion for programs that incorporate housing with health and counseling services. The bill, Bush said in a statement, ``recognizes that the homeless often have needs that go beyond housing assistance.'' ``By providing health services, substance abuse services and counseling in addition to housing assistance, this act enhances the administration's ability to address the needs of the homeless in all their complexity,'' he said. The Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Amendments Act authorizes $993 million for the 1991 fiscal year and $1.1 billion in 1992. The money will pay for such things as the Shelter Care Plus Program, which links rental housing assistance to other support systems for the homeless, including treatment for mental illness and programs for drug abusers. The legislation also authorizes the Health and Human Services Department to establish centers offering services for the homeless and those people in danger of becoming homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Trying To Close Loophole In S&L Bailout Law
DOC.TEXT: Regulators are moving to close a loophole that threatened to allow savings and loans to evade some of the changes in last year's thrift bailout law. The board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. voted 5-0 to ask for public comment on a regulation that would prevent S&Ls from avoiding certain restrictions by becoming state-chartered savings banks. If given final approval, the rule likely would become effective in about two months. Office of Thrift Supervision Director Timothy Ryan vowed to block S&L conversions until then. State savings banks, common in Northeastern states and the Pacific Northwest, are hybrid institutions, a cross between a commercial bank and a savings and loan. Depending on the state, many have retained broad investment powers, including the right to buy junk bonds and, in some instances, own subsidiaries engaging in activities normally considered too risky for banks, such as commercial real estate speculation. Since passage of the S&L law in August 1989, there's been a growing movement by S&Ls to change their status to state savings banks. Nineteen states have passed or are considering laws permitting S&L conversions. The industry argues that S&Ls trying to convert are doing so not to evade last year's law, but to avoid the expensive examination fees imposed by Ryan's agency. The proposed rules would prohibit S&Ls that convert to savings banks from investing in junk bonds or from using federally insured deposits to finance high-risk subsidiaries. It would also sharply limit the amount they are allowed to lend to a single borrower. However, converted institutions would not have to abide by rules requiring S&Ls to devote 70 percent of their assets to housing. If the rule goes through it would be one more factor forcing the end of savings and loans as a separately regulated industry. Savings banks are overseen by bank agencies, rather than S&L agencies. At this time, the FDIC board is not proposing to extend the junk bond and other restrictions to the 400 state savings banks already in existence. However, the agency's staff said it was studying that idea. Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, who oversees nationally-chartered commercial banks and is a member of the FDIC board, said activities that pose a threat in converted S&Ls logically should pose a threat in existing state savings banks. ``It seems to me it would be better if we had all of these institutions similarly limited,'' he said. Ryan, who sits on the FDIC board, also favors extending the restrictions. ``This proposed regulation is a good effective first step,'' he said.
