DOC.HEAD: Drug Gaining in Illicit Use; CDC Says Users in Nine States Sick
DOC.TEXT: A drug called GHB, which is gaining popularity among illicit users, has sickened people in at least nine states, federal health officials said Thursday. The Centers for Disease Control began surveying poisoning from gamma hydroxy butyrate, or GHB, in August after San Francisco officials reported a series of poisonings resulting from use of the drug. GHB is illegal for use in the United States, except in government-sanctioned research, said Dr. Steven Auerbach, a medical epidemiologist at the CDC's Center for Environmental Health and Injury Control. But he said it has become popular among illicit users in the last few months because it produces a trance-like state. It also has been sought by body-builders for weight control and as a sleep aid. The drug has turned up in the Atlanta area in a ``cocktail,'' mixed with amphetamines and called Max, Auerbach said. The Atlanta-based agency has received reports of ailments include vomiting, drowsiness, seizures and loss of consciousness after people ingested GHB. Twenty-five reports came from California, 15 from Georgia, seven from Florida, three from South Carolina, two each from Minnesota and Arizona, and one each from Ohio, Texas and Virginia. In most cases, the individuals dissolved up to three teaspoons of GHB in water and drank the mixture. Among the reported cases, 11 people were hospitalized, but there have been no deaths, the CDC said. ``The bottom-line, take-home message is ... if a product is being marketed for having a pharmacological effect, it is acting as a drug and any and all drugs are going to have some side effects,'' Auerbach said. Auerbach said he did not know how people were getting GHB, though some body builders apparently got it through mail-order advertisements in fitness magazines. The drug has a relatively simple molecular structure. ``You don't need to be a fancy pharmaceutical company to make it. I could see how somebody could make it on a smaller scale,'' he said. The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning earlier this month that GHB used outside certain approved situations, such as in narcolepsy research, is illicit and must stop. GHB sales also have been banned in California and Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Stands By Speech; Gingrich Says Darman Should Resign
DOC.TEXT: Budget director Richard Darman stands by a recent speech that infuriated GOP conservatives and led one prominent Republican to call for his resignation, the White House said Thursday. Darman, in a Nov. 16 speech, ridiculed efforts by administration conservatives to promote self-help programs for the poor as a major Bush domestic initiative in the new year. On Wednesday, Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia accused Darman of making ``an assault on members of his own party'' and said the budget director should either recant or resign. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that Darman and Gingrich, the Republican whip, spoke by telephone for 45 minutes and smoothed over their differences. ``Director Darman and Newt had a long conversation this morning and they are great and good friends, and there's no problem,'' Fitzwater said. However, Fitzwater said Darman was not withdrawing the comment he made in his speech and a Gingrich spokesman said ``Newt stands by his earlier statement.'' Tony Blankley, Gingrich's press secretary, said the two have agreed to try to resolve their policy differences. Conservatives, including Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, want Bush to call for radical welfare, housing and education reforms as a domestic centerpiece of his January State of the Union address. James P. Pinkerton, Bush's deputy assistant for policy planning, gave a speech in Los Angeles last spring laying out the agenda under the title, ``the new paradigm.'' ``The new paradigm enables the GOP to move forward'' to address major social problems, Pinkerton said. ``Fighting taxes and communists has brought us about as far as it can.'' Darman ridiculed ``the new paradigm'' as an empty slogan, and said its emphasis on decentralization was a throwback to ideas that failed in the war on poverty in the 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: Union Contests Ethics Law Banning Federal Workers From Outside Speeches
DOC.TEXT: A union brought suit Thursday to block enforcement of a new ethics law it contends unconstitutionally bars federal workers from being paid for writing articles or giving speeches unrelated to their jobs. The lawsuit will test the scope of provisions set to take effect Jan. 1 that were intended to prevent high-level officials from being paid to write articles or make speeches by individuals or companies that do business with the government. The suit, filed in federal court here by the National Treasury Employees Union, seeks a declaration that the honoraria ban unconstitutionally bars federal workers from being paid for writings, speeches or appearances unrelated to their jobs. ``The ethics law stopped the gravy train for members of Congress but it also derailed ordinary, enterprising federal workers from using their right to free speech to make an honest buck - on their own time and in totally non-government related ways,'' said Robert M. Tobias, president of the union representing 140,000 federal workers. Joining in the suit is a part-time Internal Revenue Service worker who earns outside income writing articles about camping and the environment for such popular magazines as Woman's Day, Sierra, and Camping Today. Jan Adams Grant, who is employed as a seasonal employee of the IRS service center in Ogden, Utah, also earns money for giving speeches about earthquake preparedness to local church groups, according tothe complaint. Another IRS employee named in the complaint, Thomas C. Fishell, is an ordained minister who earns money performing weddings, funerals and delivering sermons in churches near his home in Garland, Texas. The new honoraria ban, which was enacted by Congress as part of the Ethics in Government Act of 1989, bans government employees from accepting a payment of money or anything of value for an appearance, speech or article. It eliminated honoraria for House members and sharply curtailed it for senators. ``We have members who do freelance work who have written articles on matters that have nothing to do with their jobs that are now being penalized by this law,'' said Gregory O'Duden, the union's chief lawyer. Grant, a low-income tax examining assistant, earned nearly $3,000 last year from her outside writings and appearances. ``She counts on this added income,'' O'Duden said. Donald Campbell, the deputy director of the Office of Government Ethics, said the agency has advised government employees that the new honoraria ban applies to all speeches, articles or appearances. ``I think the language and so forth and what Congress passed is rather clear,'' he said. ``They didn't make a distinction in the act as between high-level and low-level employees so I don't think they have given us the opportunity to make a distinction.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Admits His, Other Communists' Failures
LaserPhoto MOS21
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday pronounced himself and other Communists ``guilty before the working class'' in a candid admission of blame for the country's worsening economy and political paralysis. He told nearly 1,000 delegates to the 28th Moscow City Communist Party Conference that the Soviet Union faced increasing difficulties with food supplies, ethnic conflicts, crime and ``a battle of laws that has led to a paralysis of power.'' ``The reasons,'' Gorbachev said, were ``errors in the actions of central organs, above all in the Central Committee of the Communist Party, and including the actions of the general secretary and president.'' Gorbachev, 59, is both the country's president and general-secretary of the 18-million-member party. In his hourlong speech, he promised immediate steps to increase food supplies, reiterated his determination to hold the restive republics together, and urged the delegates to keep the common man in mind. He said failure by the party leadership to address workers' concerns was responsible for its defeat in recent elections around the country. ``We are guilty before the working class, I think, all of us, and I personally take responsibility,'' he said. But Gorbachev told the delegates earlier Thursday he had no intention of quitting as party leader. He also said he was firmly for maintaining the party's dominance in society. Standing on a podium near an 8-foot bust of Lenin, he spoke confidently and extemporaneously, occasionally referring to hand-written notes taken while listening to seven hours of earlier debate at the conference. The speech appeared aimed at disarming his critics, led by Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin, by accepting a measure of blame while vigorously asserting that the party is on the road to renewal and can solve the country's problems. A poll published Thursday in the government newspaper Izvestia indicated the number of people who ``fully trust'' the party fell from 27 percent in December 1989 to 14 percent in July. Izvestia gave no details on the polling. Gorbachev and Yeltsin differ on how to go about achieving a market economy, and Yeltsin's Russian Parliament claims the right to pass laws superseding national ones. Nearly all of the 15 Soviet republics have taken similar steps toward autonomy. Several have stopped shipping food outside their borders, aggravating the shortages in major cities. Gorbachev announced that agreements were reached Wednesday with the republics of Estonia, Kazakhstan and the Ukraine to send dairy products to Moscow and Leningrad, where milk has all but disappeared from stores this month. He also said the country's two largest cities would receive first priority for food purchased or donated abroad, and indicated that powdered milk would be taken out of storage and distributed to the people. Some delegates jeered when he said supplies of key non-dairy products - meat, bread and vegetables - have remained the same or risen since last year in Moscow. ``Then why isn't there anything in the stores?'' one man shouted. ``Quiet down,'' Gorbachev replied. ``Summaries from Moscow and Leningrad are on my desk every day.'' Answering delegates' written questions, the Soviet president reiterated his desire for a political solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. But he also toughened his position, calling for military pressure to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. ``Everything must be done, including military pressure - pressure, I am using that word exactly - to force the Hussein regime to understand that the annexation must be halted.'' Gorbachev defended his frequent trips abroad and took some credit for ending the Cold War. He said that when he assumed power in 1985, ``people were saying, `We are willing to endure anything, Mikhail Sergeyevich, if only there is no war.''' Now, he said, ``No one remembers that, and what's more, they've decided that Gorbachev travels abroad too much, and (say) `Enough of this travel ... it's time to take care of our own problems at home.''' Pointing at the delegates as if to shame them, Gorbachev said the criticism was actually testimony to how far the nation has come in improving relations with the West. ``It's the best praise possible,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Has Failed To Keep American Control Of Fishing Vessels
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old law has failed to keep U.S. fishing boats under American ownership because of the way the Coast Guard interprets the legislation, a congressional report said on Thursday. The General Accounting Office report also suggested that Congress ``may wish to consider changes'' to the Anti-Reflagging Act. The act was passed in 1987 to establish more stringent requirements for making a vessel legally under American control and thus eligible for the priority given U.S. fishermen and vessels on fish quotas within the 200-mile territorial limit. Under previous law, the requirements could be met even though a company's stock was totally owned by foreigners. The 1987 act required that the controlling interest in the vessel, as measured by a majority of voting stock, be owned by U.S. citizens. It also laid down a number of new requirements but contained several grandfather clauses to protect the financial interests of owners who had become involved in U.S. fisheries under the previous law. The Coast Guard has interpreted these grandfather exemptions to apply to the vessel, not its owner. Several U.S. fishing and shipbuilding groups have challenged this interpretation in a lawsuit pending in U.S. District Court in Washington. The GAO said the Coast Guard's interpretation ``means that the vessel can be bought and sold repeatedly without losing fishery privileges, regardless of whether the new owner is a corporation with totally foreign-owned voting stock or other arrangements that offer potential for foreign control.'' It said an estimated 29,000 U.S.-built vessels were licensed for catching fish at the time the act was passed in 1987 and nearly all of them could probably be grandfathered by virtue of past fishing within the 200-mile limit. The GAO added, however, that the act's prohibitions against foreign rebuilding are likely to have a significant effect. It said some of the vessels participating in the groundfish industry off the coast of Alaska were apparently rebuilt under the grandfather exemptions but no more such rebuilding seems likely. ``The Anti-Reflagging Act's American control provisions have had little impact on ensuring that U.S. fishery operations are controlled by U.S. citizens,'' the GAO said. ``This is a result of the Coast Guard's interpretation allowing the grandfather exemption to remain with a vessel even if the vessel is subsequently sold to a foreign-owned company. Consequently, should the Congress desire another result, it may wish to consider changes to the existing legislation.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Brings the United Nations a Check
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III took advantage of his U.N. visit for Thursday's anti-Iraqi vote to clear up a small administrative matter: $185.7 million in late dues. His check for that amount substantially reduced what the United States owes the United Nations, where Washington has turned repeatedly for international backing in its stand against Iraq. Beginning in 1985, the United States withheld much of its U.N. dues to protest what it called anti-Western bias, inefficiency and budget overruns. Including overdue peacekeeping payments, U.S. arrears grew to nearly $1 billion before President Ronald Reagan decided in 1988 that the United Nations had made sufficient progress on reforms to resume full funding. Reagan left the details of paying the arrears to President Bush, his successor. With Thursday's check, U.S. officials cut their U.N. dues debt to $296.2 million. That still amounts to about 72 percent of the arrears owed by all 159 member nations. The U.S. government now plans to pay its full U.N. assessment each year. This year, that amounts to $233.6 million, one-fourth of the regular U.N. budget. Bush and Baker also want total U.S. arrears repaid over a five-year period.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Security Council in 12-2 Vote Authorizes Use of Anti-Iraq Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES bulletin series a0671, a0673, a0675, with minor editing. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council, led by the United States, on Thursday authorized military action to liberate Kuwait if Iraq does not withdraw its troops and release all hostages by Jan. 15. The only other time the council in its 45-year history has sanctioned force to counter aggression was during the Korean War. The vote was 12-2, with an abstention by China. Cuba and Yemen voted ``no.'' In an extradordinary meeting of 13 foreign ministers, the council handed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein an ultimatum to vacate the small oil-rich sheikdom that his troops invaded Aug. 2, or risk military conflict with U.S.-led forces. The Security Council gave Baghdad ``one final opportunity'' until Jan. 15 to obey its demands for unconditional withdrawal of its 450,000 troops from Kuwait. After that date, nations allied with Kuwait are authorized ``to use all necessary means'' to drive Iraq out of the emirate. All members of the council agree that could include an allied military campaign by the U.S.-led multinational forces in the Persian Gulf, though they said they hope it will not become necessary. Secretary of State James A. Baker III presided over the council meeting, which was also attended by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and eight other foreign ministers. The so-called ``use of force resolution'' was co-sponsored by the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and Canada, which voted for it, along with Colombia, Ethiopia, France, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: France Sends Reinforcements to Chad, Says Rebels Gaining Power
DOC.TEXT: Saying a rebel offensive in Chad is growing, French officials Thursday ordered 150 more troops to that North African country but said they won't join the fighting. Chad's government contends the rebels are backed by Libya, a view endorsed this week by the U.S. State Department. However, France has described the 3-week-old war as an internal conflict between Chadians, and Libya denies backing the rebels. A French Foreign Ministry spokesman said Thursday that ``the situation is worsening, and the battles are more severe.'' He said the rebel offensive has grown in size, ``and government forces are encountering difficulties on the ground.'' Other French sources said rebel leader Idriss Deby's forces are moving steadily westward, away from the border with Sudan and toward the Chadian capital, N'Djamena. The French Defense Ministry said a 150-member company of the Second Foreign Parachutist Regiment of the Foreign Legionnaires would be sent to N'Djamena. The move is aimed at ``bettering the security of our troops and assuring, if need be, the protection of our nationals.'' There are an estimated 1,250 French civilians in Chad, a former French colony. France already had 1,000 troops in Chad. It recently shifted a company from N'Djamena to the northeastern town of Abeche near the main combat zone. Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement said France is studying requests from Chad for arms, but he did not say what the response would be. ``It's clear the Chadian army could have substantial needs,'' he said without elaborating. However, he also said French policy is to refrain from defending even friendly governments from internal opposition. France has said that President Hissene Habre's troops suffered considerable losses in the recent fighting. The two sides have claimed to take and retake several eastern towns, but neither has offered casualty figures. Habre visited the war zone last week and, according to some accounts, narrowly escaped the hands of the rebels. However, Habre was seen on Chad TV Wednesday welcoming a foreign dignitary to N'Djamena. Deby helped Habre take power in 1982 and formerly served as a military adviser to the president, but he fled in April 1989 amid allegations he helped plot a coup. France sent thousands of troops to Chad in February 1986 at the height of fighting in the north against Libyan-backed rebels. Libya at that time occupied the northern part of the poor, landlocked country, but it was chased out in a series of battles in 1987. The U.S. State Department on Wednesday said the new battles ``represent the latest example of Libya's ongoing efforts to destabilize legitimate governments.'' During the recent tensions, Libya has accused the United States of ``premeditated hostile intentions.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor in Central Park Jogger Trial Rejects Charges of Racism
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor in the Central Park jogger trial on Thursday rejected defense arguments that two teen-age defendants were arrested because they were black. ``If you look objectively and rationally at the evidence ... the defendants will be found guilty,'' Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer said. The teen-agers were arrested not because of their race but because they participated in ``a violent outburst of destruction'' that left the woman near death in a wooded area of the park, Ms. Lederer said. The trial is the second stemming from the April 19, 1989, attack. Kharey Wise, 18, and Kevin Richardson, 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape and related counts in the attack on the woman and with robbery and assault in attacks on two male joggers. In the first trial, three other youths were convicted Aug. 18 on rape, assault and related charges. They were sentenced to the juvenile maximum of five to 10 years in prison. Another youth, 16-year-old Steven Lopez, will be tried in the case early next year. The case was expected to go to the jury after Ms. Lederer finishes her closing statement Friday. Defense attorneys Colin Moore and Howard Diller told the jury Wednesday their clients were charged because they were black and because police needed suspects. Black and hispanic suspects were swept up and accused by police anxious to resolve the case, Moore said. Ms. Lederer said the charges of racism were an insult to jurors' intelligence. The 30-year-old jogger, who testified during the trial, has recovered from most of her injuries and has returned to work as an investment banker. She has said she still suffers vision and balance problems and lost her sense of smell. Ms. Lederer disputed Wise's claim that police bullied him into signing a false confession. She played back a taped confession, in which Wise admitted holding and fondling the jogger's leg while she was being raped and battered. ``That is a person speaking freely,'' Ms. Lederer said. ``He is answering open-ended questions candidly and of his own free will.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA OKs Sleeping Sickness Drug
DOC.TEXT: The government Thursday approved a U.S.-manufactured drug for treating a variety of African Sleeping Sickness, a disease that afflicts 25,000 people annually. The drug, Ornidyl, was cleared for use by the Food and Drug Administration and will be available by the end of the year in the sub-Saharan region of Africa, the World Health Organization said in a news release. This is the first approval of the drug in any country. An estimated 50 million people in 36 countries are at risk of contracting the disease, caused by parasites transmitted by tsetse flies. There are usually fewer than 10 cases of the disease per year in the United States, but the drug each year could save 3,000 people infected with the West African variety of the sickness, the World Health Organization said. Ornidyl is known as a ``resurrection drug'' because it can cure patients who have fallen into comas from the disease, said WHO's Dr. Tore Godal. Given intravenously, Ornidyl inhibits the growth of theparasite. The drug manufactured by Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals of Cincinnati, Ohio. Other drugs used against sleeping sickness aren't effective in the late stages, when the disease reaches the central nervous system. The new drug does have a potential for anemia and, on occasion, dangerous decreases in the numbers of white blood cells and platelets in the blood, the FDA said. A warning label says blood cell count monitoring should be done twice a week.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Blames Iraq For Economic Woes, Says Any Recession Will Be Short
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, blaming the nation's economic slowdown in part on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, told a group of bank officials on Thursday that any recession will be a short one. ``I am confident that it will run its course,'' Bush said. He defined ``it'' as ``the slowdown or the recession or whatever one would call exactly what we're in now.'' At the same time, Bush expressed disappointment that interest rates had not come down further in response to enactment of a bipartisan, five-year $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts. ``Interest rates, frankly, are higher than any of us would like them to be,'' Bush said, adding that he didn't want to be seen ``as a Fed basher or anything of that nature.'' He said he was glad the Fed helped to nudge rates down a bit following passage of the plan, which he conceded was ``not the world's most popular piece of legislation.'' And he said he hopes the agreement will eventually lead to even lower rates. Speaking to the Association of Bank Holding Companies, Bush said that oil price increases in the aftermath of the four-month-long Iraqi occupation of Kuwait were battering the economies of both large and small nations. ``And it's very clear that they are having a very bad effect on our economy,'' he said. Bush renewed his determination to prevail in the Iraqi confrontation and said, ``there's an economic side to this equation and economic effects are devastating those who can afford it the least.'' As he has done in the past, Bush sidestepped the issue of whether the nation's economy has already slipped into a recession. ``I suspect that each one of you here has economists that you believe in; some are saying recession and some saying downturn.'' ``But one positive thing is that most if not all people are suggesting that whatever it is, it won't be long lasting. And I think that is very important to the overall good of the American people.'' Bush told the bankers that he hoped a bank law overhaul package his administration will unveil in January would provide ``significant structural reform'' to help banks be more competitive. ``In the age of the ATM (automatic teller machine) and the 800 number, and in the face of intense competition from non-banks to meet the consumer's credit needs, we must rethink and re-examine our existing regulations,'' Bush said. ``The legislation we will propose will maee a significant contribution to the long-term health of the banking system,'' Bush said. He said that he would propose a variety of measures, including ``provisions on deposit insurance.'' Treasury officials have said that, among other possible changes, they are considering restricting depositors to no more than three federally insured accounts. Currently, there are no limits on the number of different accounts that an individual may maintain, while up to $100,000 in each account is insured. ``What's at stake is not just the confidence of the American people in the banking system, but the profitability and competitiveness of a key industry,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Buildup Hit; Bush Praises UN Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 6 grafs with Bush comments, picking up in 5th graf pvs, Meanwhile Vice
DOC.TEXT: A former Navy secretary from the Reagan administration joined the parade of former military officials attacking President Bush's Persian Gulf buildup Thursday. Bush focused on the U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq, calling it a move ``closer to peace.'' Bush and House Speaker Thomas Foley both expressed opposition to the idea of calling Congress back for a special session to address the gulf crisis. The president met with House leaders while keeping an eye on the United Nations, saying he hoped Security Council approval of the resolution would ``send perhaps the strongest signal of all to Saddam Hussein.'' Asked if the vote, authorizing attack if Iraqi troops don't leave Kuwait by mid-January, made a shooting war more likely, Bush said: ``I hope we're closer to peace and that this will drive home the point to him that he's got to get out of Kuwait.'' Earlier, in an interview with the Spanish language network Univision, Bush said he preferred not bringing Congress back for a special session but wanted to sound out congressional leaders more fully. Foley, D-Wash., and Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., had lunch with Bush, and Foley said afterward, ``I hope the president doesn't call back the 101st Congress. ... Reports of that may be premature.'' Meanwhile, Vice President Dan Quayle took a swipe at critics who have said Bush has moved too quickly in the gulf and have advised against an outright attack. ``Does patience today risk greater American casualties tomorrow?'' Quayle asked in a speech at Seton Hall University in New Jersey. ``With every day that passes,'' the plight of the people of Kuwait ``grows more and more desperate,'' he said. ``Is this a moral course of action?'' Hearings on the gulf crisis continued on Capitol Hill, with criticism dominating in testimony before the Armed Services Committee of Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. ``The president's mistake in sending so many troops should not be compounded by a further error in using them in a premature, unprovoked ground offensive,'' said former Navy Secretary James Webb. The president's decision to send 200,000 troops to Saudi Arabia earlier this month in addition to the more than 240,000 deployed after the invasion caused Democrats to question whether the United States is careening toward war. ``Every single witness we've had here with differing views on other things, all of them have felt we've overdeployed,'' Nunn said. ``Almost all witnesses have said it tends to drive you to a olicy whether or not you're ready for that policy.'' Webb told the panel that if Bush decides to use military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait, ``he should call for an immediate resumption of the draft and then for a declaration of war'' by the Congress. He also recommended that the United States reduce the size of its gulf force and call on the allies to commit a representative number of troops. ``I worry about the shape of the new world order,'' Webb said. ``The United States is becoming the weapon of choice.'' Bush, in the Univision interview, said the all-volunteer army is ``as strong as it can be'' and he had no intention of trying to reinstitute a military draft to help deal with the crisis. Richard Perle, who served in the Reagan administration as assistant secretary of defense, told the Senate committee he did not believe United Nations sanctions against Iraq would work and bring ``Saddam Hussein to his knees.'' Perle said an American defeat in the gulf would do serious damage to the nation. Their testimony came one day after two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff urged Bush to give the sanctions a year to 18 months to work before opting for war. Bush, in remarks to a banking group, said Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait touched off an increase in oil prices that is rocking the economies of many countries. ``It is clear to me that those who can afford it the least are those who are getting hurt the worst by the speculation that has resulted in these higher oil prices,'' Bush said. He added that price rises ``are having a very bad effect'' on the U.S. economy, which many private economists say has slipped into recession. As for a special session, Republicans led by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole have urged such a move as a way to support Bush. But the White House says Bush needs no congressional resolution to authorize the use of force against Saddam and has shown no inclination to call a special session. And Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said, ``Airing all of our differences at this time in an official session of Congress would give heart to Saddam Hussein and doubts to our allies.'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., endorsed a special session, recommending that Congress approve a resolution authorizing force after Aug. 2, 1991, thus giving the sanctions one year to work. ``The United Nations cannot decide when America goes to war ... only Congress and the administration can make that decision for our country,'' said Kennedy, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. The U.N. Security Council resolution authorizes a military strike to liberate Kuwait if Iraq refuses to withdraw from the emirate by Jan. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Galileo Spacecraft Speeds Toward Earth for Gravity Slingshot to Jupiter
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo spacecraft, racing toward a close encounter with Earth next week so it can reach Jupiter in 1995, will explore its home planet like an alien world, scientists said Thursday. The camera-bearing planetary spacecraft will be the first to approach Earth from space, so the Dec. 8 flyby will be ``our first chance to look at Earth as we have at other planets in the solar system,'' Torrence Johnson, Galileo's chief scientist, said during a news conference. ``It gives humankind a vantage point to look at their world as they've never seen it before,'' Bill O'Neil, Galileo project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said earlier. Galileo is the most sophisticated planetary spacecraft ever built. It was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on Oct. 18, 1989, starting its $1.4 billion, 2.4 billion-mile journey to Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet. Starting in December 1995, the Galileo orbiter will spend two years exploring Jupiter and 10 of its moons after deploying a probe that will make measurements in Jupiter's atmosphere until it is crushed by intense pressure there. Galileo's route was designed so the unmanned spacecraft could use Venus and Earth as ``gravity slingshots'' to expand its orbit around the sun and reach Jupiter. It will use Earth for that purpose Dec. 8 and again in December 1992. It used Venus as a gravity slingshot last February. Scientists decided to take advantage of the close encounters to make pictures and measurements of Venus and Earth. Data collected at Venus was stored on Galileo's tape recorder and sent to Earth last week. Galileo's optical camera made detailed pictures of the uppermost layer of Venus' sulfuric acid clouds, as did spacecraft that visited Venus previously. But Galileo's infrared camera made the first still pictures and a movie showing clouds moving in 150 mph winds in Venus' middle and lower cloud decks. Severe turbulence that may be caused by thunderstorms was detected in the middle cloud layer, NASA scientist Robert Carlson said. Studying Venus' acid clouds and its carbon dioxide atmosphere may help scientists understand how increasing carbon dioxide levels in Earth's atmosphere will warm the planet like glass traps heat in a greenhouse, said Arizona astronomer Michael Belton. Galileo also discovered remarkably fast high-energy particles flowing away from Venus, a surprise because space around the planet was thought to be placid, said University of Iowa physicist Louis Frank. The spacecraft also recorded scratchy and screechy sounds created by waves in electrically charged solar wind particles that sweep around Venus. Scientists played the tape Thursday. Galileo will swoop about 593 miles above the southwest Atlantic Ocean at 3:35 p.m. EST Dec. 8. Galileo was 4.46 million miles from Earth on Thursday. The spacecraft will measure gases that cause ``greenhouse effect'' warming of Earth's atmosphere, and study high-altitude water vapor that helps create and destroy Earth's protective ozone layer, Johnson said. Galileo also will be the first spacecraft with modern instruments to study the far side of the moon, which is always pointed away from Earth, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Since Aug. 2 Invasion, 12 Security Council Resolutions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Thursday's passage of 12th resolution, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the U.N. Security Council has passed 12 resolutions condemning Baghdad's government. The latest, which authorizes the use of military force, was adopted Thursday. Aug. 3 - One day after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion and demand the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq's troops. Yemen, the only Arab member of the council, did not vote on Resolution 660, saying it did not have instructions. Aug. 6 - The council voted 13-0 to order a trade and financial embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Cuba and Yemen abstained on Resolution 661. Aug. 9 - In Resolution 662, the council voted 15-0 to declare Iraq's annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law. Aug. 18 - In No. 664, the council voted 15-0 to demand that Iraq free all detained foreigners. Aug. 25 - The council voted 13-0 to give the United States and other naval powers the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq and Kuwait by halting shipping to those countries. Cuba and Yemen abstained on Resolution 665. Sept. 13 - The council voted 13-2 to allow humanitarian food aid into Iraq or Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering,'' and said only the council could decide when those circumstances exist. Cuba and Yemen voted against Resolution 666. Sept. 16 - The council voted 15-0 on Resolution 667 to condemn Iraq's aggressive acts against diplomatic missions in Kuwait, including the abduction of foreigners in the buildings. Sept. 24 - On Resolution 669, the council voted 15-0 to stress that only its Sanctions Committee has the power to permit food, medicine or other humanitarian aid to be sent into Iraq or occupied Kuwait. Sept. 25 - The council voted 14-1 to explicitly expand its economic embargo to include all air cargo traffic in or out of Iraq and Kuwait, except for cargoes of humanitarian aid specifically authorized by its Sanctions Committee. It also calls on U.N. member nations to detain any Iraqi ships that may be used to break the naval embargo. Cuba voted against Resolution 670. Oct. 29 - The council voted 13-0 to hold Iraq liable for war damages and economic losses, to ask nations to collect evidence of grave human rights abuses by the occupying forces, to demand that the Western embassies in Kuwait City be restocked with food and water, and to demand that all hostages be released. Cuba and Yemen abstained on Resolution 674. Nov. 28 - The council voted 15-0 on Resolution 677 to condemn Iraq's alleged attempts to drive out Kuwaitis and repopulate their country, and it asked U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to take possession of Kuwait's census and citizenship records for safekeeping. Nov. 29 - The council voted 12-2, with one abstention, to give Baghdad ``one final opportunity'' until Jan. 15 to comply with all previous resolutions. After that date, nations allied with Kuwait are authorized ``to use all necessary means'' to force Iraq to withdraw and honor the resolutions, a phrase that all council members agree would permit a military strike. China abstained on Resolution 678; Cuba and Yemen voted against it.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Water Project Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday signed a $2.5 billion bill authorizing new water projects for flood control, storm damage reduction, inland navigation and port development. ``In addition to authorizing worthwhile water resources projects, the legislation includes a number of provisions that protect and restore this nation's environment, which I wholeheartedly support,'' Bush said in a statement. Even so, Bush said, the legislation ``contains a number of special-interest provisions'' in some of the projects. He said these included developing recreation facilities, levee beautification, agricultural land improvements and, in one instance, replacing a bridge. ``Because I believe in a strong water resources program, and despite my concerns about a number of inappropriate provisions, I have approved this bill,'' Bush said. Bush also signed legislation designed to protect coastal inland waters from the zebra mussel and other so-called ``nuisance species'' It contains provisions for wetlands restoration and protection, especially in Louisiana, and fish and wildlife conservation in the Great Lakes.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie Remembered, Doctors Urge More Work on Multiorgan Transplants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf and 4th graf to CORRECT spelling of Starzl, sted Starzyl.
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was remembered Thursday as a determined teen-ager who shunned publicity and wanted more than anything to be normal. Transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas Starzl, who said he would shift his efforts to research because he was emotionally drained by Stormie's death, remembered the White Settlement, Texas, girl at a monthly memorial service at the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh along with 19 other children who died recently. Stormie received her historic transplant at the hospital Feb. 14, 1984, at the age of 6. She received a second liver transplant in February and died of sudden heart rejection Nov. 11. ``She was the beautiful St. Valentine's Day card of Feb. 14, 1984, the 6-year-old God-sent child with a name that movie starlets must have envied, a smile which no one who saw it could ever forget,'' Starzl told about 50 people gathered in the hospital auditorium. Hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo said Stormie ``overcame so many major obstacles that she just almost began to seem invincible. To me the unfortunate thing is that's not based on reality.'' Doctors said more medical breakthroughs may be needed to offer patients like Stormie the promise of a long and vigorous life. ``With current techniques of immunosuppression, it's not possible to project out to 10 or 15 years yet. It awaits to be seen if we can transfer the very good short-term and intermediate results into long-term survival,'' said Dr. James Kirklin, chairman of the heart committee of the United Network for Organ Sharing in Richmond, Va. Kirklin said the problem inherent in multiorgan transplants is finding the right levels of anti-rejection medication, which vary with each patient and with each transplanted organ. For instance, kidneys and hearts require lower doses of anti-rejection medication than do livers, said Dr. Byers Shaw, chief of the liver transplant program at the University of Nebraska. Shaw worked with Stormie while in Pittsburgh. ``The real challenge in multiorgan transplantation is to continue to evolve our understanding of the proper combination of therapy that will allow both organs to survive and prevent infectious complications,'' Kirklin said. Starzl said Stormie's life was ``a glorious one, and triumphant, because her case revealed the liver's role in metabolizing cholesterol. ``We wanted more for her than this, but it was not to be,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Breakdown of Opposing Forces in Gulf Region
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 `Amphibious capability ... Norfolk, Va.' with three grafs to clarify breakdown of Marine forces. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The U.S...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a breakdown of the opposing forces gathered in the Persian Gulf:

UNITED STATES - Officials say about 300,000 troops, including those aboard ships, are in the gulf region or en route. The deployment could reach 400,000 troops. Ground forces in Saudi Arabia include the 82nd ``All American'' Airborne Division; the 101st ``Screaming Eagles'' Airborne Division; the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, with about 200 M-1 Abrams tanks and 300 Bradley Fighting Vehicles; the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade; 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade; the 1st Cavalry Division and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. Additional Army troops being sent from Germany and the U.S. include the 7th Corps Headquarters; the 1st Armored Division; the 3rd Armored Division; a brigade-size unit from the 2nd Armored Division; the 2nd Armored Cavalry Regiment, and the 2nd Corps Support Command. These units will be joined by the 1st Mechanized Infantry Division from Fort Riley, Kan. Amphibious capability is provided by the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, and the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, which is divided into the 1st Marine Division, the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, and 1st Force Service Support Group. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command. The Marine Corps is additionally sending the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force from Camp Lejeune, N.C.; the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade from Camp Pendleton, Calif., and the Maritime Prepositioning Ship Squadron One, from Norfolk, Va. A Marine Expeditionary Force is made up of 30,000 to 60,000 men and a Marine Expeditionary Brigade has 4,000 to 18,000 men. The U.S. fleet in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean totals about 55 ships. They include the aircraft carriers America, Roosevelt, Ranger, Midway, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy; the battleship Wisconsin with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, the battleship Missouri, five missile cruisers, four destroyers, several frigates, plus supply ships and six to eight nuclear submarines. The aircraft carriers have a combined strike force of approximately 300 A-6 Intruder fighters, F/A-18 Hornet fighters, A-7 Corsair II's, and F-14 Tomcats. The Marines have about 120 AV-8B Harrier jump-jets. The Pentagon has also sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers to unspecified bases; 14 long-range F-111F bombers to Incirlik airbase in southwest Turkey, and another squadron to Spain. There are an estimated 150 F-16s and F-15s; more than 70 A-10 tank-killing Thunderbolts, and unspecified numbers of F-4 Wild Weasel air-defense suppression jets and other combat aircraft deployed at 30 airbases in the region. A squadron of 6-8 B-52G strategic bombers is on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia.

BRITAHN - A three-ship flotilla permanently stationed in the gulf has been beefed up to 12 ships, including a missile destroyer, two missile frigates and three minesweepers. They have support ships. Four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaissance aircraft are in Oman. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, have 120 Challenger tanks and 9,500 troops. The 4th Brigade, currently stationed in Germany, division headquarters supporting arms will join the 7th Armored Brigade to form the 1st Armored Division. The additional brigade will include an armored regiment of Challenger Tanks, two armored infantry battalions with Warrior fighting vehicles, an armored reconnaissance squadron, a Royal Artillery field regiment, engineers and other supporting services. The government is sending anti-tank Lynx helicopters and the army's most potent artillery system, the Multiple Launch Rocket system. British troop strength is expected to reach 30,000.

FRANCE - It has about 14 ships and 13,000 troops in the gulf region. The warships include a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, two frigates and one corvette with support vessels. France is sending three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers. The 4,000-troop Rapid Action Force is deployed with Arab forces in Saudi Arabia's northeastern desert. It includes the 5th Combat Helicopter Regiment with 42 gunships; the Foreign Legion's 3rd Infantry Regiment with anti-tank missiles; the 1st Spahis Cavalry Regiment with armored vehicles, and an anti-aircraft missile unit. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. The French deployment is the nation's biggest overseas operation since the Algerian war in the early 1960s.

ITALY - The frigates Libeccio, Orsa and Zeffiro and a support ship, the Stromboli, are in the gulf. The corvettes Minerva and Stinge are in the eastern Mediterranean replacing U.S. units assigned to the gulf. A squadron of eight Tornado fighters is based near Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, to provide air cover for Italian warships. No ground force deployment is planned.

CANADA - The destroyers Athabaskan and Terra Nova and the supply ship Protecteur are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 18 CF-18 fighter jets and 450 military personnel based in West Germany are in Saudi Arabia.
NETHERLANDS - The frigates Witte de With and Pieter Florisz are in the Gulf of Oman. The combat supply ship Zuiderkruis is expected there in November.
SPAIN - The frigate Santa Maria is in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes Cazadora and Descubierta are in the Bab el Mandeb Strait in the southern Red Sea.
AUSTRALIA - The guided-missile frigates Adelaide and Darwin and the supply ship Success are in the gulf region.
BELGIUM - The minehunters Iris and Myosotis with the supply ship Zinnia are in the Gulf of Oman. The Belgians have also commited four C-130 military transport planes.

ARGENTINA - The destroyer Almirante Brown and the frigate Spiro are expected to arrive in the gulf region soon. Both West German-built warships are armed with anti-ship Exocet missiles. A 100-man army unit will also be sent.

SOVIET UNION - The Udaloy-class destroyer Admiral Tributs and an anti-submarine ship are in the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command. The Slava-class missile cruiser Chervona Ukraina and the Sovremenny-class destroyer Bystry passed through the Suez Canal Oct.4, ostensibly en route to join the Soviet Pacific Fleet. But they could be deployed in the gulf region.
GREECE - Greece has sent its most advanced frigate, the Limnos, to the eastern Mediterranean. Greece is supplying merchant ships for the U.S. sealift.

WEST GERMANY - It is providing merchant ships to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and has provided $2 billion toward the multinational force. Germany's constitution prohibits it from sending military forces outside its borders.
picks up AM-Gulf-Opposing Forces, 1st Add pvs

DOC.HEAD: Dinosaur Remains Stir More Debate Over Cause of Dinosaur Extinction
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of two giant dinosaurs in Wyoming is reigniting debate over why the huge beasts became extinct. Colorado paleontologist Robert Bakker, who led the team that found the dinosaur remains, said Thursday the discoveries reinforce his theory that dinosaurs became extinct gradually. A scientist at the Smithsonian Institution who supports the theory that dinosaurs met their end suddenly, in a cosmic collision, says the latest finds prove nothing of the sort. The extinction of dinosaurs is ``a big area of controversy right now in science,'' said Dr. Richard Stucky, paleontologist at the Denver Museum of Natural History. Scientists offer dozens of theories about the mysterious mass extinctions, including a change in the Earth's motion, famine, parasites, poisons, climatic changes, meteorites and even extraterrestrial hunters. The debate is on again since Bakker's team of University of Colorado scientists unearthed a 70-foot-long, 25-foot-high Haplocanthosaurus. A member of the cetiosaur or ``whale dinosaur'' family. The ``Carlin Giant'' found near McFadden, Wyo., was the largest cetiosaur ever located, Bakker said. The second find is the only brontosaurus scientists have placed in the Cretaceous Period, which began 135 million years ago. Before that discovery, near Rock River, Wyo., in a fossil deposit known as Breakfast Bench, no brontosaur had been found that was less than 137 million years old. Bakker announced the discoveries Wednesday. The remains were found last summer. ``The fossil record clearly indicates that these mass extinctions were not the result of a Saturday night of cosmic mayhem,'' Bakker said. ``The last remains of different (dinosaur) families are strewn through millions of years of rock,'' he said. Nicholaus Hotton, a curator of paleobiology at the Smithsonian Institution, disagrees. He still subscribes to a collision theory, which he said is evidenced by iridium-rich sediments in the deposits marking the end of the Cretaceous Period. Iridium is a heavy metal found in platinum ores. ``The crustal rocks in the top kilometers of the earth are very poor in iridium, but meteors and things are very rich in iridium. So why do you find that in that zone?'' Hotton said. ``The argument is that they were brought in from the outside ... an asteroid, comet, or one hell of a big meteorite that struck the Earth. And in doing so it disrupted the ecology,'' he said. Bakker believes extensive migration and subsequent disease epidemics may have wiped out dinosaurs. He said Hotton is missing the ``frog facts.'' ``If a comet or asteroid hit the earth and killed all the dinosaurs, how then were the deaths so selective?'' he asked. ``The fact (is) that the little delicate animals - like frogs - survived and the large aggressive animals didn't.'' According to Bakker, dinosaurs became extinct because of worldwide diseases. ``Dinosaurs didn't go out with a bang, they went out with worldwide diarrhea,'' he said. The cetiosaur bones eventually will be displayed at the University of Wyoming and at North Carolina State University, which assisted the fieldwork. The brontosaurus is still being unearthed.

DOC.HEAD: First Food Aid Arrives in Moscow as Soviets Scramble for Supplies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to RECAST, raising details of Thursday's flight. Picks up 15th graf, Western officials ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A planeload of food arrived in Moscow Thursday in the first shipment by German charities aimed at easing the chaotic food situation in the Soviet Union. The planeload of 25,000 pre-packaged meals was being sent to children's hospitals and orphanages, said Valeria Kuprina, deputy chairman of the Moscow branch of the Soviet Children's Fund. She said food deliveries to the children's institutions are becoming irregular, so officials decided the first shipment of Western food should go to them rather than the barren shops. In the face of widespread worries that the foreign food shipments might be stolen or simply stalled and left to rot, the Children's Fund made highly unusual arrangements for supplies to be delivered to the institutions within hours of landing at the airport. Trucks quickly met the Aeroflot cargo flight and delivered the food packages immediately, Ms. Kuprina said. A vanload of food arrived after 11 p.m. at a children's home in western Moscow, but there was no joyous welcome. The kids were all asleep. The food was to be distributed Friday to the 150 children, aged 4 to 18, at Children's Boarding Home No. 24. Director Tatiana Vyedyokhina said the home has been receiving supplies from its regular domestic sources, but that she worried about the future. ``The situation in Moscow is getting worse and worse,'' she said in a late-night interview. ``I think it will affect the children's home eventually.'' Despite the start of aid from West Europe that is just beginning to arrive in Moscow, the supply situation is unlikely to change rapidly for most Soviet shoppers. The same day the German supplies arrived, bleary-eyed shoppers were trundling between empty metal food cages at the Gastronom store across from the Kiev Railroad Station in Moscow. Thirty people slumped dejectedly in line in a supermarket that by 7 p.m. contained only lemonade, tiny red apples, five fancy cakes, and a counter full of mix for home-brewed kvas, a type of beer. The line woke up when a clerk appeared with a shopping cart containing unrecognizable cuts of mutton. Within moments, the clerk was screaming. ``I'll just throw it out and you can grab the one you want!'' she shouted, tossing plastic packages of bony meat at the crowd and dashing back to sanctuary. Fearing ever-worsening shortages and rising prices, consumers are snapping up every item within minutes of its arrival on shop shelves. Western officials want assurances that the outpouring of aid now making its way to the Soviet Union is properly used. Horst Teltschik, a top aide to German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said Wednesday that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had promised to allow Germans to accompany their shipments all the way to their destinations. Across the globe, individuals, charities and governments were rushing to send supplies. The German government planned to ship huge food reserves collected as a safeguard against a repeat of the Soviet blockade of Berlin in 1948. Ordinary Germans pledged $2.7 million on a telethon. An Italian group planned to send 90 tons of food and medicine. Japan said it would provide hundreds of millions of dollars in medical supplies. Soviet officials say the country actually has no less food than last year, but the distribution system is collapsing as the country lurches toward a market economy. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh blamed in part ``disorganizing forces in the country.'' ``In my opinion, they represent different political forces, but they think that it is necessary to make the situation very grave in the country. From a political point of view, for them, it is very convenient and necessary.'' Many Soviets are convinced the country's problems are the result of deliberate sabotage by Communist Party bureaucrats who fear losing their power and privileges. Asked whether the West is overreacting to the shortages, Gremitskikh said: ``Common people would like to help.'' ``We do not view this as alms. ... This is an expression of solidarity and sympathy and we cannot reject it. To the contrary, I think that we should ... receive everything gratefully.''

DOC.HEAD: New Treatment Reduces Aneurysm-Related Strokes, Researchers Say
DOC.TEXT: The rate of death and debilitating strokes from blood vessels that burst in the brain can be significantly reduced by immediate surgery and boosting patients' blood pressure, researchers said Thursday. A study at Loyola University Medical Center found the two-part treatment reduced stroke risk for patients with burst brain aneurysms, which are bubble-like weak points in the brain's blood vessels. The study was published in November's Neurosurgery, the journal of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons. Dr. Jack P. Whisnant, a neurological specialist not connected to the study, said elements of the treatment have been used for some time, but hadn't been tried together and should be studied further. An estimated 5 million Americans have brain aneurysms, and about 28,000 a year suffer ruptures. About half of those suffering ruptures die within the first month after a vessel bursts, said Whisnant, chairman of the Mayo Clinic's health sciences research department. The Loyola researchers estimated about a third of patients with burst aneurysms suffer serious strokes as a result. In their study of 43 patients with burst aneurysms, two died and two others suffered strokes, according to the report issued six months after the study ended. ``We initially found that early surgery for an aneurysm minimized the risk of further bleeding, but did nothing to prevent a patient from later suffering a stroke,'' Loyola neurosurgeon Dr. Thomas Origitano, the study's lead author, said in a telephone interview on Thursday. That early surgery consists of ``clipping'' the aneurysm by shutting off the leaking blood vessel. Early surgery was critical to the two-part treatment's success, the researchers said. Some neurosurgeons traditionally have waited seven to 10 days to operate after a patient's aneurysm bursts, to see if circulation will stabilize in the brain, Origitano said. Apart from early surgery, Loyola researchers diluted patients' blood by removing red cells, allowing better circulation within the brain, they said. They then pumped extra blood into the patients to increase blood pressure. Quicker surgery and blood pressure treatment stabilizes the brain's blood supply sooner and helps avert strokes, Origitano said. Aneurysm patients run a high risk of stroke for two weeks after a rupture because the brain's blood vessels fail to regulate circulation. That allows pressure to drop and deprives the brain of blood, said Dr. O. Howard Reichman, chief neurosurgeon at Loyola. ``If the blood flow falls below a critical threshold, a stroke can occur,'' Reichman said. Of the 43 people in the 2{-year Loyola study, 30 were operated on within two days of arrival at a hospital. Eight others were operated on within a week. Five could not undergo surgery because of unrelated medical conditions, the researchers said. Whisnant said elements of the approach taken at Loyola are commonly used, but not as a comprehensive treatment. Diluting the blood has been tried, but not necessarily in conjunction with quick surgery and increasing blood pressure, he said. He called the Loyola report interesting, but said a larger study is needed to determine the success of the approach.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Network Pays Fine For Hard-Porn Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: A company that beamed hard-core pornographic movies via satellite to home television viewers pleaded guilty to a federal obscenity charge and agreed to pay a $150,000 fine, the Justice Department said Thursday. Home Dish Only Satellite Networks Inc., which once beamed such movies as ``Hard Core Girlfriends'' and ``Ramb-Ohh Sex Platoon'' to 30,000 subscribers to its American Exxxtasy Channel, entered the guilty plea in federal court in Buffalo, N.Y. The company agreed to pay $150,000 in fines and its operators, Paul L. Klein and Jeffrey Younger, promised to forever refrain from promoting or distributing sexually explicit films or publications. HDO's guilty plea marked the first prosecution under a 1988 law that bars distribution of obscene material by cable or subscription television. Until investigators pulled the plug on the operation last March, HDO was the only nationwide satellite network beaming hard-core pornography to home television viewers, the Justice Department said. The movies were transmitted from the company's Buffalo office to a satellite uplink station operated by U.S. Satellite Inc. in Salt Lake City, that relayed them to the GTE Spacenet Corp. satellite, the Justice Department said. In Buffalo, the company pleaded guilty to one felony count of transmitting an obscene promotional movie, ``Hot Shorts,'' on Feb. 25, 1990 from Buffalo. It also agreed to plead guilty to a separate felony charge in Salt Lake City, Utah, of transmitting the movie ``Hardcore Girlfriends'' the next day. The ``Hot Shorts'' promotional films were beamed in the early evening to owners of satellite dish receivers to advertise the explicit nature of the films available from American Exxxtasy, the department said. ``The proliferation of cable and satellite dish technology has made it necessary for the Congress and the Department of Justice to act to prevent the pollution of the public airwaves with hard-core pornography,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. U.S. Satellite was not prosecuted because it cooperated with the investigation and shut down the transmissions last March, said Dee V. Benson, the U.S. attorney in Utah. Last month, HDO pleaded guilty to a state obscenity charge in Montgomery, Ala., and was fined $5,000. Klein, Younger and two other HDO officials were also indicted in Alabama but New York Gov. Mario Cuomo last June refused to honor Alabama's request for their extradition. Federal prosecutors decided not to charge Klein and Younger individually because of their willingness to stay out of the business and cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation of the pornography industry, Benson said. The company agreed to turn over its inventory of pornographic movies for destruction by the government. Klein and Younger will be questioned about where they obtained the films to help federal prosecutors identify the producers of obscene movies, said Patrick A. Trueman, head of the Justice Department's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section. ``We would like information about where they are getting the movies from,'' Trueman said. Prosecutors expect to question the two about ``the companies they dealt with'' as well as the individuals who sold them the movies, Trueman said.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Delayed for Retired CIA Agent
DOC.TEXT: Sentencing of a retired CIA agent on charges stemming from the Iran-Contra affair was postponed Thursday at the request of a defense attorney angry about a letter the prosecution wrote to the judge. Thoas G. Clines, 62, faced up to 16 years in prison and a $1 million fine for underreporting to the Internal Revenue Service the money he made selling weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels. His attorney, Paula Junghans, asked for a sentencing delay so she could respond to a prosecution letter containing ``serious and incorrect allegations'' that her client lied to a probation officer. U.S. District Judge Norman P. Ramsey postponed sentencing until Dec. 13. ``I think it's utterly silly ... but you got your week,'' he said. Neither prosecutors, led by Stuart Abrams, nor Junghans would discuss the letter's contents. Ramsey said from the bench the letter indicated that Clines told the probation officer his financial status had undergone a ``remarkable decline.'' Clines was convicted Sept. 18 on two charges of failure to report profits of at least $203,431 in 1985 and $57,009 in 1986. He also was found guilty of not telling U.S. tax collectors about overseas financial accounts and failing to file tax forms required for them. During a 10-day trial, prosecutors characterized Clines as a sophisticated businessman who set up dummy foreign corporations to hide his dealings from the IRS. Defense attorneys argued that Clines, from Middleburg, Va., misunderstood how to report his earnings and was unfamiliar with IRS regulations that require foreign accounts to be reported. Junghans said Clines was a victim of selective government prosecution. She accused Independent Counsel Lawrence E. Walsh of going after Clines for political reasons. Walsh's office and IRS agents spent three years tracing the Iran-Contra money trail. Clines test-fired, bought and arranged shipments of rifles, machines guns, grenades and explosives to the Contra rebels at a time such shipments were outlawed by Congress. Witnesses testified that Clines was in the arms business with retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord and his business partner, Albert Hakim. The three shared some of their profits with Canadian arms dealer Emanuel Weigensberg. The operation was directed by former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter and retired Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North. The prosecution is seeking an unspecified prison term and fine against Clines. So far, eight people and one corporation have either been found guilty or pleaded guilty to crimes arising out of the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Allies Praise U.N. Resolution Authorizing Force Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: U.S. allies overseas were quick to praise the passage Thursday of a U.N. resolution authorizing military force, saying it was major victory in the campaign to oust Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait. A Saudi Arabia government spokesman said Iraq has until Jan. 15 to vacate Kuwait, which it was occupied since Aug. 2, or ``it may have to suffer grave consequences.'' In Cairo, Egypt's minister of state for foreign affairs, Butros Ghali, said, ``The Security Council resolution is a victory for the peace cause and will contribute to the enforcement of the rules of international law.'' He added, ``The resolution is a clear signal to the Iraqi government concerning the necessity of its withdrawal from Kuwaiti territories and the return of legitimacy as it was before Aug. 1, and the release of all hostages.'' In Dhahran, Saudi spokesman Adel Al-Jubeir said the vote ``shows that there is a united front to confront aggression, that the world is determined in trying to get Iraq to withdraw unconditionally and completely from Kuwait,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Premier Resigns, New Leader to Be Non-Communist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from Lukanov, general strike called off. ADDS details, color, trims. No pickup. Changes byline
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government of former Communists resigned Thursday under unrelenting pressure from strikes, street protests and the halls of Parliament. Lukanov said his successor will come from outside the party. ``This represents the true end to Communism in Bulgaria,'' Petar Beron, leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, told The Associated Press. Tens of thousands of demonstrators, eagerly awaiting word on Lukanov's resignation around the Grand National Assembly, burst into cheers after hearing the news of the government's fall. Police estimated the crowd at up to 70,000. ``Lukanov KGB spy'' and ``Down with Communists'' chanted the jubilant crowd, waving blue flags of the main opposition alliance. Some uncorked champagne bottles. Sofia radio played John Lennon's ``Let it Be,'' and television showed the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. After Lukanov and his Cabinet announced their resignations, the opposition trade union Podkrepa and the Confederation of Independent Trade Unions immediately called off a general strike. The action started Monday to force Lukanov out of office. The 52-year-old premier, whom many Bulgarians associated with postwar Communist rule, stepped down after three hours of consultations with President Zhelyu Zhelev and other political leaders. The Socialist premier, blamed for the Balkan country's political and economic anarchy, accused unions and the opposition of making it impossible for him to govern. ``For me, it is therefore pointless to remain at the premier's post, and ... I resign my office,'' he said in his resignation speech. Parliament must formally approve Lukanov's resignation Friday, the official BTA news agency reported. Lukanov said political leaders had agreed that a new coalition government be formed soon and that his successor should not belong to his own party or the main opposition alliance. No one was immediately named. The agreement that brought down the government came in a meeting organized by Zhelev. Outside, the strike was on, and Sofia's streets filled with thousands of people demanding an end to political turmoil and economic hardship. Lukanov was one of a group of reform communists who helped oust longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in November. He was appointed premier in early February and then presided over increasing polarization, deteriorating living stadards and growing public anger. The opposition alliance has long criticized Lukanov for allegedly mismanaging the economy, demanding that he step down. In announcing his departure, Lukanov said, ``My resignation is not only in the interest of society, but also in the interest of my Socialist Party.'' He said that he will continue his work as a parliamentary deputy. Bulgaria is suffering through its worst postwar crisis. Electricity is rationed in Sofia and elsewhere. Foodstuffs and many basic consumer items are either rationed or unavailable. The country cannot make payments on its $11 billion foreign debt. BTA said political leaders of all parties had agreed that ``an immediate change of government is indispensible for the formation of a new national government for the peaceful transition to democracy.'' It said leaders also agreed that they will draft the outlines of a further accord to define the status of political parties, protect people from political persecution, and formulate a social program and the rights of ethnic minorities. Podkrepa claimed earlier Thursday that almost 1.3 million of Bulgaria's 9 million people were on strike. Public transport in Sofia and Plovdiv had stopped work, creating chaos in the streets of Bulgaria's two largest cities. Many intersections in the capital were blocked Thursday by angry citizens, who had built barricades with benches, garbage cans and large concrete planters. ``It is important that finally we are free of Communists,'' said Violeta Petrova, a housewife.

DOC.HEAD: Harry Caudill, Appalachian Author, Dead at 68
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with detail, EDITS to conform
DOC.TEXT: Author Harry M. Caudill, whose book ``Night Comes to the Cumberlands'' helped inspire President Johnson's war on poverty, fatally shot himself Thursday in view of the mountains he loved so fiercely. He was 68. Caudill, who suffered from Parkinson's disease, shot himself in the head in his yard, said Edison Banks Jr., Letcher County assistant commonwealth attorney. ``He did it in typical Harry style,'' said Banks, a former student of Caudill's. ``He was looking at the mountains and shot himself once in the temple area.'' He was found by his wife, Anne, Banks said. Caudill was pronounced dead about 3{ hours later when he was removed from life support systems at Whitesburg Appalachian Regional Hospital. He had asked in a living will not to be kept alive by such systems, said longtime friend Pat Gish. The author killed himself while seated in his yard in the Mayking community with a dramatic view of Pine Mountain, an imposing 125-mile ridge along the Virginia-Kentucky border. Mrs. Gish, who publishes The Mountain Eagle newspaper in Whitesburg with her husband, Tom, said Caudill's death ``was the result of a long struggle with poor health.'' Caudill's struggle with Parkinson's disease, a degenerative disease, and a World War II injury to his foot greatly restricted his mobility in recent months, said Gish, who described the author as depressed. ``He had been depressed for several months with the development of his illnesses,'' Gish said. A retired lawyer and state legislator, Caudill taught Appalachian history for eight years at the University of Kentucky until 1985. Caudill (pronounced caw'-dill) is best known for ``Night Comes to the Cumberlands,'' published in 1963. The book so vividly described Appalachia's problems that it brought the region into the national spotlight. President Johnson subsequently backed an array of social programs designed to develop the region and improve living standards for its people. Caudill vividly described environmental problems caused by strip mining, criticized absentee landowners and preached to improve the region's schools. He was widely admired for taking courageous stands against injustice despite huge huge obstacles and in a hostile political climate. By last spring, Caudill had written 10 books, 80 essays and editorials and some 50 magazine articles railing against injustices facing Appalachian residents. He is survived by his wife, a daughter and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Visit Moldavia in First Domestic Trip in Months
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will take his first domestic trip in three months to visit the strife-torn southern republic of Moldavia, Tass reported Thursday. The official Soviet news agency said the chief executive would visit Moldavia, on the border with Romania, on Friday and speak to the republic's parliament about ``the social-political situation.'' He is also scheduled to meet with intellectuals in the Moldavian capital, Kishinev. In recent months, as his popularity among the Soviet people plummets, Gorbachev has been concentrating on traveling abroad, especially to Western Europe. Some Soviet politicians have criticized him for not paying enough attention to domestic issues. Gorbachev last took a domestic trip Aug. 17, when he traveled to the Black Sea port of Odessa to tell Soviet troops about planned changes in the military. Moldavia is one of the many republics where ethnic groups are fighting each other and trying to gain a measure of independence. The independent news agency Interfax said Moldavian activists plan demonstrations during Gorbachev's visit. Ethnic tensions turned violent last month when Moldavian security troops clashed with activists in the Dniester region, leaving four dead.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Of Zebra Mussels In Hudson River Startles Scientists
DOC.TEXT: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. (AP) - The discovery of zebra mussels in the brackish waters of the Hudson River startled scientists, who said Thursday the pests weren't supposed to get this far south this soon. ``We've just thrown the book out now,'' Avery Klauber, a spokesman for New York Sea Grant at the State University of New York in Stony Brook. ``There's no way of knowing how far and how fast they're going to travel.'' Experts didn't expect the tiny mussel, named for its striped shell, to appear in the Hudson until next year or the year after. Scientists also had hoped the waters of the lower Hudson, with a salinity of eight parts per thousand, would be too salty for the mussels. They have been spreading through the Great Lakes since 1988, when scientists think European ships released them with ballast water. The mussels have few natural predators and breed rapidly, causing problems for industries, power plants, public water systems and boaters by clogging water intakes. They can also wreak havoc on aquatic food chains. Federal officials have estimated that control of the mussels could cost as much as $5 billion over the next decade in the Great Lakes region. The Hudson River discovery is the first North American sighting of the pest outside the Great Lakes drainage basin, said Charles O'Neill, supervisor of the New York Zebra Mussel Information Clearinghouse at the State University of New York at Brockport. ``Everybody was watching to see where they'd turn up out of the Great Lakes,'' O'Neill said. ``This one being such a jump opens up the possibility that the mussels can be really widely scattered.'' The animals were discovered by accident on a piece of wood collected for an museum exhibit from Haverstraw Bay, about 25 miles north of New York City, O'Neill said, adding it was too early to tell the extent of the infestation. He said the mussels may have been brought to the river by a Great Lakes pleasure boat or a European ship, or even by a piece of wood floating from the Erie Canal to the Mohawk River and on into the Hudson. The discovery of the mussels is particularly worrisome to officials of four major power plants near the discovery site, O'Neill said. Experts expect zebra mussels eventually to find their way into the Mississippi River through canals connecting it to the Great Lakes. From there, they could spread across the United States. ``We're looking at a critter that within the next couple generations could very possibly be found throughout North America,'' O'Neill said. In Washington, Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., issued a plea to President Bush Thursday to sign legislation authorizing $60 million for project grants and research funding to control the mussels.

DOC.HEAD: Probe Of Cryonics Case Involving Woman's Head Ends Without Charges Filed
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have decided against filing charges in the death of an elderly woman whose head was cut off and frozen by a laboratory hoping to give her a second chance at life. Questions raised about Dora Kent's death led to an investigation by prosecutors, but they found nothing to take to court. ``We evaluated all the evidence there was and there simply wasn't enough for us to prosecute,'' Assistant District Attorney Don Inskeep said Wednesday. Dora Kent was 83 and ailing when her son, Saul Kent, a devotee of cryonics, moved her from a convalescent home to the Alcor Life Extension Foundation laboratory here. Cryonics is the practice of freezing the dead to preserve them for possible future resuscitation, such as when a cure for the ailment that caused their death is found. Many scientists discount cryonics as fantasy. Alcor officials say they severed Mrs. Kent's head after she died of pneumonia Dec. 11, 1987. Their hope was that scientific advances would one day make it possible attach her head to a healthy body. The coroner's office decided to investigate the death because Mrs. Kent died without a doctor present. Coroner Raymond Carrillo found Mrs. Kent died of a lethal dose of barbiturates and ruled her death a homicide. He then asked the district attorney's office to investigate.
