Alcor officials said the drug, Nembutol, was administered after her death to preserve brain cells. Alcor research director, Mike Darwin, called the end of the investigation ``a wonderful Christmas present that is long overdue.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Reported on Alert in Persian Gulf, But Report Questioned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Saudi denial of British report, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Commanders of the anti-Iraqi multinational force ordered their troops on alert for the first time Thursday, a British news agency reported. But a Saudi official denied his country's forces had made such a move. Asked about the British report, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams in Washington declined comment, saying it's a matter of policy not to discuss alert status of troops worldwide. However, another source, speaking on condition of anonymity, denied U.S. forces are on heightened alert. The British news agency quoted unidentified military sources as saying an unspecified movement of Iraqi forces triggered the alert. Its report said the alert stems from fears of an Iraqi air attack in retaliation for Thursday's U.N. revolution authorizing use of force unless Iraq withdraws from Kuwait by Jan. 15. The Defense Ministry in London refused immediate comment on the report by the Press Association's defense correspondent. The correspondent said troops in the gulf were put on yellow alert, one stage down from full alert. ``We are on alert for an attack from the air,'' Maj. Peter Cross, chief-of-staff at a British base at the port of Al Jubayl, was quoted as saying. ``Obviously, the Iraqis have the capability to attack us wth missiles and aircraft and the likelihood of this is perceived as being higher today than previously.'' The agency said all troops were ordered to carry nuclear, biological and chemical protective suits and respirators at all times. Saudi forces have been on alert since August, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, said a Saudi official on condition of anonymity. But there is no heightened status because of the U.N. action, he said. ``Are we on alert? Yes. Is it any more of an alert than it was yesterday? No,'' the official said. There are about 430,000 troops from 26 nations facing off Iraqi troops in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian President Asks Elections in Cuba as Andean Leaders Meet
DOC.TEXT: An Andean summit that listed a common market and anti-drug trafficking efforts at the top of its agenda brought together the presidents of Venezuela, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia on Thursday. President Bush's ``initiative of the Americas'' to create a hemisphere-wide zone for free trade within North and South America will also be discussed during the two days of meetings opening Thursday. President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia is host of the summit, attended by presidents Cesar Gaviria of Colombia, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Alberto Fujimori of Peru and Rodrigo Borja of Ecuador. ``Our principal proposition during this historical summit is the creation of a common and free market in the region,'' Paz Zamora said. It is the fourth such summit since the Andean pact came into being in 1988. La Paz is 13,000 feet up in the Andean mountains. The government has provided emergency oxygen equipment should visiting dignitaries be affected by the rarefied air. At a news conference shortly after arriving here, Gaviria called for democratic elections in Cuba. ``I would be pleased if Cuba became a full member of the international community through the implementation in Cuba of a democratic electoral system,'' Gaviria said. ``We respect the self determination of nations and in that sense we respect the Cuban system, but I hope that they enter a democratic electoral system.'' The fight against cocaine trafficking in the region is expected to a prime topic in the presidential talks. Peru and Bolivia produce 80 percent of the coca leaf that forms the basis of cocaine. Colombia is the world's largest processor of cocaine. Peru has rejected involving the military in the anti-drug battle. Bolivia has agreed that the military can take part. Fujimori and Paz Zamora were expected to emphasize alternative economic development for coca farmers. Both believe farmers must be provided with other sources of income to wean them from coca leaf cultivation. Gaviria told reporters in La Paz he is interested in having Colombian drug traffickers tried in Colombia instead of other nations. ``We are working to strengthen the Colombian judicial system and to complement that reinforcement, we would like criminals tried in Colombia and not in other nations,'' he said. ``We are putting this into practice with the support of the international community.'' He said ``this new mechanism'' was being used first in the cases of lesser criminals. Regarding trade, plans are under way to create a common Andean market by 1992, although Ecuador has opposed such a plan. Another obstacle is that member nations maintain protectionist duties on hundreds of products and controls on the import and export of certain products. Bolivia's planning minister, Enrique Garcia, said, ``The fundamental principle for Andean integration has to be consistent with free market economic policies that regional economies are on the road to implementing. It is not possible to maintain subsidies or protections of any type.''

DOC.HEAD: Procurement Violations Found At Nuclear Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Energy has cracked down on the manager of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant after significant procurement violations were found, an internal memo showed. The violations turned up during a DOE survey before Thanksgiving that showed four major subcontractors at the plant were working without contracts, according to a copy of the memo obtained by The Associated Press. The plant is the only one in the United States that makes plutonium detonators for nuclear weapons. Plutonium processing at the plant has been shut down since last December because of safety problems. On orders from DOE, acting plant manager Jim Zane issued the memo to his assistant general managers saying, ``It is imperative that EG&G-Rocky Flats Inc. initiate a more disciplined and organized approach to the acquisition needs of RFP (Rocky Flats plant).'' Zane ordered his managers to ``immediately cease personally contacting subcontractors and directing them to report to this site or to perform any services. Procurement policies must be followed. If not, such subcontractors will be denied site access and ordered to stop work.'' Zane did not immediately return a telephone call Thursday seeking additional comment. Francis Allhoff, the plant's assistant general manager for support operations, confirmed Thursday that the DOE ordered EG&G to halt improper subcontracting practices, and said EG&G has issued stop work orders for the contractors. About 170 workers have been barred from the site until they get proper contracts, he said. ``The DOE took exception, and I think rightly so, to the way we were handling certain procurement vehicles,'' Allhoff said. ``These practices do not constitute really good management control.'' Beth Brainard, a DOE spokeswoman at the plant, said Thursday that the four subcontractors were doing work based on previous contracts. She said plant operations did not suffer because of EG&G's lack of legal contracts. She said EG&G officials were two months behind in getting approval for their budget, which began in October, and have been preoccupied with other problems. The companies working without contracts were identified as NUS Corp. of Gaithersburg, Md., Tenera Advanced Services of Knoxville, Tenn., Cygna Energy Services of Walnut Creek, Calif., and Stone & Webster Engineering Corp. of Boston. Allhoff said he did not know how much the contracts were worth. Rob Robinson, a spokesman for Stone and Webster, said the company had a contract for work at the plant, but funds ran out. ``All I know is that efforts are being made to get us back on as soon as possible, possibly as early as next week,'' Robinson said. He said workers were ordered to stop work on projects ranging from planning and scheduling to engineering to restart the plant. Spokesmen for the other companies did not immediately return calls Thursday. DOE officials said the order to clean up subcontracting work was delivered at a meeting held with defense contractors from around the nation to try to resolve problems interfering with efforts to restart the plant. Plutonium processing at the plant, located 16 miles northeast of Denver, will not resume until the facility is deemed safe, the DOE has said. The DOE sharply criticized the EG&G last month when a report by Cermack, Fletcher and Associates cited significant management failures at the plant. Zane replaced Phil Warner as plant manager after the report became public, but plant officials said the management shakeup wasn't related to the report.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Predict `Free-For-All' Following Bangerter's Decision To Retire
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Norm Bangerter announced Thursday that he won't seek a third term and a Republican party leader said the decision would mean a free-for-all in Utah politics in 1992. Bangerter shocked friends and foes alike when he announced he would retire from politics after 18 years in state office when his current term ends. ``Someone once told me that politics is dependent on a never-ending supply of people who don't know what they're in for. After six years, I know too well,'' Bangerter said at a hastily arranged news conference at the Capitol. By dropping out of the political picture so early, the governor has set the stage for ``the most wide open election year any of us can remember,'' said state GOP chairman Richard Snelgrove. ``It will be a free-for-all,'' he said. If Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, decides not to seek re-election in 1992, the state's most popular politicians would be forced to choose which office to seek. The announcement buoyed Democrats' hopes of occupying the statehouse after an eight-year absence. ``We have momentum going our way, but we can't forget we're still a minority party,'' said state Democratic Party Chairman Peter Billings Jr. At the news conference, Bangerter, 57, said the rigors of public office have interfered with his role as a father and grandfather. He has seven children. His wife, Coleen, was at his side. He said that once his term was over in January 1993, he planned to return to the jobs he left for the governor's chair, those of builder and contractor. Polls showed his job approval rating drop severely after a record $168 million tax increase he pushed through the Legislature in 1987. But it climbed after his re-election until this year. In August, a Deseret News-KSL-TV poll by Dan Jones & Associates showed Bangerter's popularity had fallen from 61 percent in December 1989 to 56 percent. The disapproval rating of 41 percent he got in the latter survey was by far the highest of any of the state's elected officials, Jones found. But lawmakers praised him Thursday. ``I'm not quite ready to eulogize him,'' said Republican state Senate President Arnold Christensen. ``Some of the things we're proud of as a Legislature, like Utah being ranked No. 2 fiscally in the nation and Salt Lake being the best place to do business, I think that's a credit to the governor.'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, was in London. His press secretary, Laurie Snow-Turner, said the senator was surprised by the announcement. Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, said he believes Bangerter will leave a remarkable legacy. ``Knowing Norm as well as I do, I'm sure he will remain active in the state and will continue to operate as one of Utah's esteemed statesmen,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-led Resolution Passed in U.N. to Authorize Use of Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with tough statements from Eduard Shevardnadze. Picks up graf 9 pvs `If war' and edits thereafter to trim and conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos UN1,NY19
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council, led by the United States, voted 12-2 Thursday to authorize military action to free Kuwait if Iraq does not withdraw its occupying troops and release all foreign hostages by Jan. 15. The only other time the council, created 45 years ago to iron out international disputes, has sanctioned force in its history to counter aggression was during the Korean War. China abstained, to the disappointment of the Bush administration, while Cuba and Yemen cast dissenting votes in a session arranged by the United States in a show of international solidarity against Iraq. In an extradordinary meeting of 13 foreign ministers, the council handed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein an ultimatum to vacate the small oil-rich sheikdom that his troops invaded Aug. 2, or risk military conflict with U.S.-led forces. The session ended with a round of handshakes and embraces. In Washington, President Bush called the U.N. vote ``a very strong and powerful message. It will go around the world loud and clear that this guy's got to get out of there. ``Once again, the United Nations, exercising its proper responsibility and its peacekeeping function, made a very powerful statement. Everybody ought to understand how strong it is and how important it is,'' Bush said minutes after the vote. ``Our aim today must be to convince Saddam Hussein that the just, humane demands of the Council and the international community cannot be ignored,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker III, top representative for the United States as president of the council. ``If Iraq does not reverse its course peacefully, then other necessary measures, including the use of force, should be authorized,'' said Baker. ``We must put the choice to Saddam Hussein in unmistakable terms.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in a speech both tough and philosophical, warned that Saddam would be held ``personally responsible'' for any use of chemical weapons and breaches of the Fourth Geneva Convention guaranteeing the rights of civilians in time of war. He said the international community has shown ``genuine magnanimity in giving the side which breached the peace time to think again. ... We have started the countdown of the pause of good will ... ``Those who breached the peace should know that all necessary means will, indeed, inexorably be used against them.'' Shevardnadze later told reporters that the Soviet Union would not consider committing any Soviet troops to an international force at this time. He cited painful memories of World War II. The resolution gives Saddam ``one final opportunity, as a pause of good will,'' to retreat. But the Iraqis appeared intransigent. ``If war is imposed upon us by the United States, this will be our destiny,'' said Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari. ``Our people will not kneel, we will rise to this responsibility.'' Baker at this juncture appeared to glare at the Iraqi representative and flipped through a copy of the U.N. Charter. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd twirled his earphone. All the ministers in session wore dark suits and sat somberly around a circular table in the vaulted council chamber. The chamber is decorated with a mural of a peaceful world arising from the ashes of war. Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber, however, was not pacified, saying, ``The intransigence of the Iraqi regime is pushing the region to a conflagration which we do not want, but which appears to be the only avenue to restore our rights.'' The Kuwaiti representative denounced the ``wild beasts'' from Iraq whom he said were pillaging his country and murdering his people. ``The Iraqi aggressor showed no sense of mercy or compassion, indeed, no respect for the divine or human codes of conduct.'' Previewing the U.N. vote, Bush said: ``I think the main thing that I hope will come out of today's session of the United Nation is that we send perhaps the clearest signal of all to Saddam Hussein that the world is deadly serious about reversing this aggression and this economic oppression that he's wought on many, many countries that can ill afford it.'' Iraq's ambassador accused the council of preparing to let the U.S.-led multinational forces ``lynch'' his country. ``The council is but a willing tool in the hands of the American administration,'' al-Anbari said. ``Iraq calls for peace, it desires peace, not for us alone but for the entire Middle East region,'' he said. He linked Iraq's willingness to cooperate with a broader Mideast peace settlement that would include a homeland for Palestinians. ``This would be the most dangerous resolution ever passed by the Security Council,'' al-Anbari said before the meeting, ``and a violation of the U.N. Charter.'' Iraq has said it would defy the resolution, as it has the previous 11 adopted since the invasion. This latest council resolution strengthens Bush's hand with Congress and the American people in calling for offensive action against Baghdad. Nine affirmative votes were required for passage. Any of the five permanent council members could have vetoed the measure. Three - the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain - sponsored the brief resolution. The other permanent members are China and France. Saddam responded defiantly to the developments at the United Nations. He declared he was not afraid of fighting the United States, which he said had been overly influenced by ``Rambo'' movies. ``The Americans are still influenced by Rambo movies but this is not a Rambo movie. This is something different,'' he said. ``We do not underestimate American military power, but we scorn their evil intentions,'' he said in remarks carried by official Baghdad radio. Saddam said his army had the technology to defeat sophisticated weapons like the Stealth fighter bomber. There have been conflicting reports about whether Saddam might have the ability to detect those weapons. In other gulf-related developments Thursday: -Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has urged patience in the gulf crisis, shifted his tone and called for ``military pressure'' to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. However, he repeated his desire to avoid war, and did not elaborate on what he meant by military pressure. He spoke to a Communist Party organization in Moscow. -In Washington, there were more appeals for caution in the gulf. James Webb, a former Navy secretary in the Reagan administration, called the buildup of 430,000 troops in the gulf a mistake and said attacking Iraq would compound it. The U.N. resolution does not explicitly mention the use of force, but authorizes member states ``to use all necessary means'' to implement council resolutions which demand Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Diplomats understand that to mean the use of force, similar to the resolution calling for enforcement of a maritime embargo against Iraq. All diplomats have emphasized, however, that they are committed to a peaceful settlement if at all possible. While critics called the measure a ``war resolution,'' it does not mandate military force to evict Iraq, only sanctions it. The resolution made no mention of a U.N. military command or any U.N. role in overseeing a possible international military operation. The Soviet Union has sought to activate the Security Council's military staff committee and has said that Soviet forces only would be committed to an international military operation under U.N. auspices. The council includes the five permanent members and 10 rotating members: Canada, Cuba, Colombia, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of U.N. Security Council Statements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Soviet, Chinese comments.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here the highlights of the statements made Thursday by foreign ministers, ambassadors and the secretary-general on the passage of a U.N. resolution giving Iraq an ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait:

Secretary of State James A. Baker III: ``Our aim today must be to convince Saddam Hussein that the just, humane demands of the Council and the international community cannot be ignored. ``If Iraq does not reverse its course peacefully, then other necessary measures, including the use of force, should be authorized. We must put the choice to Saddam Hussein in unmistakable terms.''

Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari: ``If war is imposed upon us by the United States, this will be our destiny. Our people will not kneel, we will rise to this responsibility. ... ``The Council is but a willing tool in the hands of the American administration. ... ``Iraq calls for peace, it desires peace, not for us alone but for the entire Middle East region. ... ``This would be the most dangerous resolution ever passed by the Security Council ... and a violation of the U.N. Charter.''

Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber: ``The intransigence of the Iraqi regime is pushing the region to a conflagration which we do not want, but which appears to be the only avenue to restore our rights. ... ``The Iraqi aggressor showed no sense of mercy or compassion, indeed, no respect for the divine or human codes of conduct.''

French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas: ``Can we then tolerate such a blatant challenge for any extended period of time, especially in a region which is highly sensitive, where the expectations for security and stability call for special consideration? ... ``Aggression should no longer be considered the privilege of the strong, the misfortune of the weak and the object of resignation for all the rest. ``This text is also consistent with the logic of the attitude Iraq has displayed. If Iraq chooses to remain deaf to the appeal for reason and respect for law, that is to say remains locked into the use of force, what other choice are we left with but to resort to this same means,m which would appear to be the only ones it recognizes?''

Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar: ``The Security Council has taken a decision of immense portent. I would like to stress that, even on the most stringent reading, the resolution just adopted envisages at least 45 days of earnest effort to achieve a peaceful solution of the crisis. ... ``To my mind, the situation requires that diplomatic effort be undertaken with renewed determination to put the present crisis o the road to a peaceful outcome.''

Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen: ``I feel deeply that members of the international community share common grounds on the Gulf crisis on two points, namely, they all oppose the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait and call on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait immediately, while at the same time they all wish to see that the Gulf crisis be settled through peaceful means. ... ``The United Nations ... should act with great caution and avoid taking hasty actions on such a major question as authorizing some member states to take military actions against another member state.''

Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze: ``We have been faced with the first grave test of the post-Cold War period and we are coping with it. ... ``We want begin the pause of good will, by calling upon Iraq and President Saddam Hussein to rise above considerations of prestige, to display wisdom and foresight and place above all else the interest of the country and fate of its people. ... ``Those who break the peace should know that all necessary means will indeed, inexorably, be used against them. ... ``All of us would only be happy, if the need to resort to such means did not arise.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Sues Union Group, Drivers on RICO Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from Kheel, detail from lawsuit, explanation of triple damages.
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News filed a $150 million civil racketeering lawsuit Thursday against a group representing striking workers and 23 drivers for allegedly conspiring to force the News to accept wasteful contracts or to sell the paper to them. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, alleges a conspiracy including attempted murder, coercion, arson and robbery. The filing comes three days after police said there was no evidence of a conspiracy in 229 strike-related incidents since the walkout began five weeks ago. The lawsuit asserted that the unions had one of two intentions. The News claimed they want to coerce the tabloid into accepting a featherbedding settlement that contained abuses the News has striven to eliminate in 10 months of negotiations. The News also claimed that through violence the unions hoped to implement a buyout plan organized by Theodore Kheel, the unions' unpaid legal adviser. Kheel is not named in the lawsuit. Named are the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity, the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group representing the nine striking unions, and 23 drivers, some of whom have been arrested during the course of the strike. Kheel said ``the underpinning of this lawsuit was blown out of the water'' when top police officials said at a legislative hearing they had found no conspiracy. Richard Weiss, a spokesman for the Allied, said there would be no comment until the unions had seen the lawsuit. ``This lawsuit is a response to a conspiracy of violence and intimidation that has victimized the News, its dealers, advertisers and readers since the strike began,'' said News Publisher James Hoge in a statement given reporters. ``We intend to resist this campaign of violence and coercion with every legal means at our disposal.'' The 23 drivers named in the action include individuals who have been arrested in connection with specific acts of violence in the bitter strike. Nine of the newspaper's 10 unions representing some 2,100 strikers have been off the job since Oct. 25. The newspaper has published daily despite distribution problems, some of which have been linked to threats against vendors and attacks on trucks and replacement workers. RICO, or Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act, has been used successfully by federal prosecutors. Provisions of the act that enable law enforcement officials to assess stiff civil penalties tying up the assets of alleged organized crime figures made it popular. In recent years it has been seen as part of more civil actions but use in a labor dispute is very rare. Under RICO a series of criminal acts must be determined to be part of an ongoing pattern of criminal conduct. The lawsuit said drivers wanted to ``extort the News into preserving payments to drivers' union members for fictitious and unwanted labor services.'' The lawsuit also said through a pattern of violence and intimidation, Kheel sought to get the News to sell to him and a group of investors. The News seeks $50 million but under RICO, a plaintiff can ask for triple damages, or $150 million.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Warns of Communist `Counterrevolution'
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa on Thursday accused former Communists of mounting a ``counterrevolution'' by supporting emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, his rival in the Dec. 9 runoff of Poland's first popular presidential election. ``Today this is a challenge from the old nomenklatura, security service, and activists of old Poland who surround Tyminski,'' Solidarity chairman Walesa told a meeting of his union's National Commission in Gdansk. ``In my opinion this is a counterrevolution.'' Excerpts of Walesa's remarks were broadcast on Polish radio news. He said a Tyminski victory could lead to ``something like a civil war'' and said his opponent was ``unable to solve Polish problems.'' ``The state of affairs is really very serious. I am terrified by the fact how far the society is dissatisfied with us and everything what is happening in Poland,'' Walesa told the union leaders. Tyminski could not be immediately reached for comment, but his campaign office said he may respond to Walesa's remarks at a news conference next week. The Solidarity leadership held an extraordinary meeting Thursday to discuss the situation following Sunday's first round of presidential voting in which Tyminski, considered an outsider, defeated Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Walesa and Tyminski are to take part in a nationally telecast news conference Saturday, the state PAP news agency said. A campaign commercial for Walesa said a debate by the candidates would be broadcast Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: German-Built Hospital Opens in Quake-Devastated City
DOC.TEXT: A prefabricated 60-bed hospital erected by a German military unit began operating in earthquake-devastated Roudbar in northwestern Iran on Thursday, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The June 21 earthquake completely destroyed Roudbar, killing 40,000 people and injuring up to 100,000. The hospital, a gift from the German government, is equipped with surgical, pediatric and obstetric wards, and an operating area. It was formally opened by Health Minister Iraj Fazel and German Ambassador Armin Freitag, according to IRNA, monitored in Nicosia. The agency quoted Fazel as saying construction of the hospital ``shows that humanity is still alive on this earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Excused From Testifying Against One-Time Confidante
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Coleman Young won't take the stand in the fraud trial of a one-time confidante now accused of being a con man, a federal judge ruled Thursday. Young's lawyers told U.S. District Judge John Feikens in a letter that the mayor would exercise his Fifth Amendment rights and refuse to answer all questions if called as a witness in Kenneth Weiner's trial. Feikens excused Young from taking the stand because his testimony could be self-incriminating. Alvin Gendelman and Steven Lewin, who also are on trial, wanted Young to testify in their defense. The three men are charged with organizing a precious metals scheme that bilked wealthy investors of millions of dollars. Peter J. Kelley, a lawyer for Young, said the mayor exercised his constitutional rights because of an ongoing federal grand jury probe of alleged corruption and mishandling of funds at the Police Department. The grand jury has subpoenaed financial records of Young's private consulting company, Detroit Technologies and Investment Inc. The government hasn't disclosed whether Young is targeted in that investigation, which also involves Weiner, Kelley said. Young spokesman Robert Berg didn't immediately return a reporter's telephone call Thursday. ``I am not on trial over there,'' Young said last week. ``I don't know a damn thing about what's going on over there. And I have nothing to ay about what's going on over there. Period.'' Young's ties to Weiner go back several years while Weiner was deputy police chief. Weiner in 1986 promised to provide incriminating evidence on Young if the government agreed to grant Weiner immunity in the fraud scheme, court records show.

DOC.HEAD: $44 Million Approved for Work on Italy's Tower of Pisa
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday gave final parliamentary approval to the allocation of $44 million for work aimed at preventing the leaning Tower of Pisa from toppling. However, it will be at least several months before work begins, since experts haven't decided how to proceed. The committee of experts is scheduled to meet in January. The popular tourist attraction in the Tuscan city was closed to the public in January in anticipation of the work, and tourist-dependent Pisa has been anxious for work to get underway. The 180-foot-tall tower, begun by Bonnano Pisano in 1173, started to lean almost immediately when the ground shifted and now leans about 13 feet off a 90-degree angle. Studies have indicated that without intervention the tower might topple sometime next century. One plan calls for a wheel-shaped support to be placed around the base and connected by concrete spokes to the foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Diverse Anti-War Activists Protest UN Vote on Gulf
DOC.TEXT: James Yates, a foe of aggression since his days as a member of the Abraham Lincoln brigade in the Spanish civil war, stood quietly Thursday across from the United Nations to protest the use of force against Iraq. ``I'm here by myself. I often participate in these things,'' he said, explaining his presence among the sign-waving, chanting demonstrators. The Security Council voted 12-2 to authorize military action to liberate Kuwait if Iraq fails to withdraw its troops and release all hostages by Jan. 15. Yates was part of a diverse group of about 45 people who gathered behind the blue police sawhorses earlier in the day. ``Stop the U.S. War Machine No Matter What It Takes,'' said the largest banner, depicting Uncle Sam with blood dripping from fangs in his mouth and clutching containers of oil and blood. ``No war, no way. We won't fight for the USA,'' chanted the dozen young people gathered around the poster. ``I've been fighting against war since the 1930s,'' said the soft-spoken Yates, 84. By his own count, he is one of about six American blacks still living of about 100 who went to Spain in 1936 to help the royalists in their losing cause against fascist dictator Francisco Franco. Yates, who also erved in the U.S. Army in World War II, said President Bush had not justified the use of force. ``If it's oil, or jobs, I'm against it,'' he said. ``These are not good reasons for people to die.'' Michael Immerso, a spokesman for the group SANE-FREEZE, said his group's protesters were part of the National Campaign for Peace in the Middle East, a loose coalition of groups opposed to war. The group includes the American Friends Service Committee, the War Resisters League, Pax Christi and Church Women United. ``One of the major issues is that the peace dividend has gone down the tubes,'' said Carol Barton, a spokeswoman for Church Women United, which claims 1,500 chapters in towns and cities nationwide and is conducting a petition drive against war in the Gulf. Robert Bates, a 63-year-old civil servant from Jersey City, N.J., was another solo protester. Bates, who served in the Merchant Marine during World War II, said he thought U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq should be given more time. He carried a sign that said ``Hold On There. Jan. 15 Is Too Soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Announces 10 New Teaching Chairs
DOC.TEXT: Columbia University will use gifts totaling more than $12 million to create 10 new teaching positions as part of a new program to ``honor the art of teaching,'' President Michael I. Sovern announced Thursday. Two of the new chairs were named for literary critic Lionel Trilling and cultural historian Jacques Barzun. Trilling, who once taught at Columbia, died in 1975. Barzun, a former provost at the university, is a professor emeritus. ``Great universities like ours are at risk of tilting in favor of research at the expense of teaching,'' Sovern said. ``And we must not let that happen.'' Sovern said university officials see themselves as conservationists trying to preserve ``the great teacher,'' which he called an endangered species. The new professorship honoring Trilling will be filled by Edward W. Tayler, who has taught English at Columbia since 1960 and is an author and authority on Milton, Shakespeare, John Donne and the Renaissance. The Barzun professorship will go to Kenneth T. Jackson, an urban historian and author who has taught at Columbia since 1968. The other chairs are in liberal arts, psychology, music, humanities, English and literature and history.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Fires Traffic Court Official Who Took Over a Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: A traffic court official who took over a courtroom and sat down in the judge's chair to protest the handling of his 26 tickets was fired Thursday. The official, T. Milton Street, yelled at the judge handling his case Wednesday, then sat in her chair for most of the afternoon in protest. President Judge George Twardy, who suspended Street last week, said he decided to fire Street when he saw pictures of Street in Judge Lillian Podgorski's chair. ``That is not right,'' Twardy said. ``I'll tell you the truth, I'm not going to stand for it.'' Street, a former state senator, was an assistant budget director for the court. Twardy also fired Street's son, T. Milton Street Jr., a court officer who was suspended when he wouldn't pay for nine tickets. The son accompanied his father during Wednesday's sit-in, which ended when police asked them to leave as the office closed for the day. Street was back in Traffic Court on Thursday, getting paperwork for an appeal of his case. He said he also would challenge the firing. ``Even with my big mouth, I have rights,'' Street said. Street has 26 outstanding tickets and owes $2,559 in fines. Twardy also said Street had six outstanding tickets in other counties, including one from the Poconos. ``Not only that, but over the last 11 years, he hasn't had a license or insurance,'' Twardy said. Street, who is black, has maintained that requiring a deposit - $100 in his case - for a Traffic Court hearing is unconstitutional and unfair to poor people, notably blacks and Hispanics. ``Poor people think I'm a hero,'' he said. Street said that he and his son would start a consulting service for people facing Traffic Court. ``I'd save them thousands of dollars,'' he said. ``I'd advise them of their rights.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Has Case of Man Accused of Killing Daughter's Playmate
DOC.TEXT:
Jurors on Thursday began deliberating the fate of a man whose daughter accused him of killing her young playmate 21 years ago. ``It's never too late for justice,'' a prosecutor told the jury Wednesday during closing arguments. Defense attorney Douglas Horngard said there was ``not one shred of evidence'' to support a guilty verdict against George Franklin Sr. Franklin, 51, was charged with killing 8-year-old Susan Nason after his daughter told police she suddenly remembered the 1969 attack. His daughter, Eileen Franklin-Lipsker, now 29, claims her father threatened to kill her if she told anyone about the crime. She testifed the memory flooded back last year as she looked at her own young daughter. Nason's body was discovered in a ravine three months after she was reported missing. A blood-stained rock was discovered nearby.
Franklin, a former firefighter, could be sentenced to life in prison if convicted of the murder charge. Elaine Tipton, San Mateo County assistant district attorney, told jurors that a guilty verdict on a first-degree murder charge would resolve ``20 years of unanswered questions, silence and fear.'' Horngrad contended Franklin's daughter had given several different versions of her story, altering accounts to fit news reports of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Man Held for Allegedly Plotting to Kill Bush, Destroy Military Installations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Terence in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. soldier with relatives in Kuwait and Iraq was ordered held without bail Thursday on charges he plotted to kill President Bush and other government officials, and attack military installations. Jamal Mohamed Warrayat, 32, allegedly discussed a plan to kill Bush, Secretary of State James Baker and members of Congress with an undercover FBI agent. Court papers also said he conspired, as the leader of a group of seven people, to attack unspecified military installations in North Carolina and Texas. ``At this point in time there is no evidence to show that any foreign government promoted or assisted in this activity,'' said U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff. He would not comment further or suggest a possible motive. Warrayat's attorney, Terence Scott, said his client denies all charges. He said Warrayat was born in Kuwait, came to the United States in the early 1970s and served about four years in the Army until 1979. Scott said his client worked as a taxi driver until recently but was unemployed at the time of his arrest. Warrayat, from Rutherford, spoke to a special undercover agent of the FBI near the end of August, according to court papers, and allegedly told the agent in Arabic that he and members of his group had weapons and materials to carry out small terrorist operations. During the conversation, Warrayat said his group was ready to attack the government officials and was looking for help obtaining explosives, money and technical training, according to court papers. Warrayat said he had drawings and diagrams of the military targets that he made while in the U.S. Army, according to the court papers. He said he had several machine guns but needed more weapons. He was arrested at his home Tuesday and was held in a hospital until Thursday because he said he needed treatment for tuberculosis. Warrayat is now in federal custody. U.S. Magistrate Donald Haneke set a probable cause hearing for Dec. 7.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Moving Among Top 5 Causes of Death for Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th, 8th and 9th grafs to ADD detail.
DOC.TEXT: AIDS is steadily spreading among U.S. women and by next year will become the fifth leading cause of death for women of childbearing age, federal health researchers reported Thursday. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control study is the latest to show that AIDS has become a serious health threat for women. Another study, released Thursday in Geneva by the World Health Organization, said the incidence of AIDS among women will increase dramatically worldwide, mostly because women don't suspect they can contract the disease from heterosexual contact. ``I think these findings are a cause for alarm for almost everyone,'' said Dr. Constance Wofsy, an AIDS specialist at the University of California, San Francisco. The CDC said in its weekly report that by the end of 1990, more than 15,000 women will have AIDS, accounting for 11 percent of all reported cases. More than 9,000 will have died from the disease. It said 85 percent of women with AIDS infections are between ages 15 and 44. ``In 1982, AIDS wasn't even on the chart,'' said Dr. James Curran, director of the agency's AIDS program. ``In 1987 it was eighth leading cause of death among women 15-44, and we project it to be fifth by 1991.'' Cancer is the No. 1 killer of women of childbearing age, followed by accidental deaths, heart disease, homicide and suicide, the CDC said. Curran estimated AIDS is currently the sixth or seventh leading cause. In the last year, AIDS in women increased 29 percent, to an average of 4.3 cases and about 2.7 deaths per 100,000. AIDS rose 18 percent among men, according to the CDC. The disease is most prevalent among women who are poor or minorities, the CDC said. Though black and Hispanic women make up 19 percent of all U.S. women, they represent 72 percent of women with AIDS. Women are most likely to become infected from sexual contact with men who have the AIDS virus. The disease, which destroys the body's ability to fight disease, still occurs mostly among homosexual men and intravenous drug users. The share of AIDS infections around the world resulting from sex between men and women will rise from 60 percent to 75 percent to 80 percent by the year 2000, the World Health Organization report said. The organization forecast that by the end of the decade the number of HIV carriers would rise to between 25 million and 30 million worldwide, including 10 million children born to infected mothers. The organization said about a third of the 9 million to 11 million people now carrying the virus are women. Ms. Wofsy said that, because women tend to get AIDS from heterosexual contact, few ever suspect they're at risk and many fail to take advantage of preventive measures. When women get sick, they usually go to doctors who are not inclined to look for HIV infection, she said. ``Physicians are going to have to become detectives,'' Ms. Wofsy said. ``It's here now.'' The latest reports on AIDS and women came just two days before World AIDS Day will be observed, with this year's theme being the disease's impact on women. In other AIDS reports: - The CDC said a study in New York has provided more evidence of an association between the AIDS virus and cervical disease in women. But the CDC stopped short of saying that HIV-infected women are at an increased risk for cervical cancer. The study found that among patients receiving care at two city clinics for HIV-infected women, the prevalence of cervical disease was eight and 11 times greater than for women living in the respective communities. - Based on the first nationwide survey of AIDS at colleges, the CDC reported in the New England Journal of Medicine that between 25,000 and 35,000 of the nation's 13 million college students are infected with the AIDS virus.

DOC.HEAD: Attacker in Near-Fatal Stabbing Goes on Trial for Menacing Actress, Rescuer
DOC.TEXT: The attacker in the near-fatal stabbing of actress Theresa Saldana began trial Thursday on charges of sending death-threat letters to the movie star and her rescuer. Jury selection began in the trial of Arthur R. Jackson, 55, who faces six years in prison if convicted of sending the letters to Miss Saldana and Jeff Fenn, the water deliveryman who subdued Jackson and held him for police. In the letters, Jackson said it was his ``divine mission'' from God to kill Miss Saldana for a future heavenly rendezvous with him. The Scottish drifter, who has a history of mental problems, entered the United States illegally in 1982 to stalk the actress. Jackson was convicted of attempted murder after the March 15, 1982, knife attack outside her West Hollywood apartment. He was sentenced to 12 years in prison, which was halved for good behavior. Authorities learned about the letters just weeks before his scheduled June 1989 release. The 16 felony counts of menacing the actress and Fenn were subsequently filed and he was ordered held without bail. Once a jury is selected, trial should last about eight days, said Deputy District Attorney William W. Hodgman.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Governor Signs Lethal Injection Bill
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey on Thursday signed a bill replacing the electric chair with lethal injection as the new form of execution for convicted murderers. Casey signed the bill without comment. It becomes effective immediately. Under the new lethal injection law, death-row inmates will die from a dose of lethal chemicals instead of electric shock. Nationwide, 20 other states have lethal injection as their means of execution. Proponents advocate lethal injection as a more humane way of carrying out the death penalty. Pennsylvania has 118 people on death row. Pennsylvania last used the electric chair in 1962. It was dismantled in 1971 and not put back together again until former Gov. Dick Thornburgh ordered it reassembled in 1985. Casey has signed 10 death warrants for eight individuals but all the warrants have been stayed. Susan Frietsche, deputy director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Pennsylvania, said her group would continue to fight the death penalty in Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Guerrillas Kill Four
DOC.TEXT: About 80 leftist guerrillas attacked an army and a police outpost Thursday a few miles from Buenaventura, Colombia's main port on the Pacific Ocean, killing three marines and an 8-year-old boy, the army said. The army bulletin said the rebels kidnapped a marine and three police, that one rebel was killed in the fighting, and two were captured. The raiders belonged to the pro-Cuban National Liberation Army and the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia (FARC), the only two guerrilla outfits still fighting the government. Three other groups have declared cease-fires and are holding peace talks with the administration of President Cesar Gaviria. Last March, M-19 rebels signed a peace treaty and their organization became a legally recognized political party. The Liberation Army on Monday kidnapped four oil engineers, including three Americans, in eastern Colombia, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Outgoing Premier Favored Reform, Stumbled on His Communist Past
With AM-Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Andrei Lukanov, the Moscow-educated man who headed Bulgaria's first freely elected government, stumbled over his Communist past in a country paying dearly for 44 years' allegiance to Stalinist doctrine. Lukanov, 52, came to prominence early this year when he was appointed to head a new government in February, four months after longtime Communist Party strongman Todor Zhivkov was forced out of power in a Politburo coup. Lukanov was said to have been one of those involved in ousting Zhivkov on Nov. 10, 1989. Six days later, Lukanov was promoted to the ruling Politburo and was said to be No. 2 in the party hierarchy, in charge of party organization. From the start of his rocky 10 months as head of government, which ended Thursday with his resignation, Lukanov sought cooperation from the opposition, still in the throes of organizing as a political force. But the anti-Communist opposition has steadfastly refused to cooperate with the communists or their successors, the Socialists. That has been its greatest strength. Rallying ever-increasing support, the opposition parties, grouped in the Union of Democratic Forces alliance, threaten to eclipse the flickering power of the Socialists. The Communists renamed their party the Socialist Party in April and won free elections in June, now holding 210 seats in the 400-seat Parliament. Lukanov promised to move the country to a market economy when he and his all-Communist government were sworn into office in February. He reiterated his commitment to reform when his new, all-Socialist government took office last September. But the opposition's refusal to support the former Communists or give its blessing to Lukanov's reform program led to a political stalemate. Lukanov's popularity - due to his vigor, statesmanlike manner and commitment to reform - waned sharply with the decline in Bulgarians' living standards. Store shelves are bare, electricity is cut several times a day because of shortages, and staples such as sugar, cooking oiland gasoline are rationed. Lukanov has blamed his inability to pull the country out of economic quicksand on the parliamentary opposition's refusal to back his economic reform plans. Last week, the opposition forced a vote of no-confidence in Lukanov's government. He survived with a one-vote margin. That did not satisfy Bulgarians, who were tired of Communist accolades and unwilling to hear further pledges that the Socialists are not the Communists they once were. Hundreds of thousands joined a general strike called by the opposition trade union Podkrepa, and after four days, Lukanov finally backed down. Lukanov was born in Moscow, the son of a senior Communist official. He received his degree from the Institute of International Relations in Moscow and began his diplomatic career as a junior employee at the foreign ministry. Fluent in several languages, Lukanov subsequently worked in Bulgaria's mission to the United Nations in Geneva, as deputy minister of trade, and later minister, and deputy premier in charge of economics. He was a member of the Communist Party's policy-setting Central Committee from 1977. It was his Communist past that made him unacceptable to the opposition, despite his Western style as a statesman and his economic credentials. ``The opposition has never called into question his accomplishments as an erudite and an astute politician,'' the state BTA news agency commented recently. ``He is suspected, however, of being unable to oppose conservatism and primitivism in his party,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Found Guilty of Killing Ex-Husband in Custody Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A woman accused of shooting her ex-husband after he won custody of a child born under a surrogate contract was convicted Thursday of voluntary manslaughter. Beverly Seymour had been charged with murder in the death of Richard Reams, but the jury convicted her of the lesser charge. She faces a maximum sentence of 28 years in prison, including a three-year term for use of a gun in the crime. ``The jury reviewed the case carefully. This is their verdict; we will accept it,'' prosecutor Randy Knece said. He said he would push for the maximum sentence. The child custody case involved a three-way battle for custody of 5-year-old Tessa Reams. The woman who gave birth to the girl also sought custody. ``It is sad for Tessa,'' Knece said. ``You have to hope she can go on and live a normal life.'' Defense attorneys could not immediately be reached for comment Thursday. Jurors left the courthouse without speaking to reporters. Reams, 47, was shot Aug. 27 when he went to Ms. Seymour's apartment in Ashville, about 15 miles south of Columbus, to pick up Tessa after winning permanent custody of the child. Ms. Seymour had extensive visitation rights. Judge William Ammer had instructed the jury to decide whether Ms. Seymour, 45, was guilty of murder, voluntary manslaughter or negligent homicide, or whether the gun went off accidentally as she acted in self-defense during an alleged assault by Reams. Knece told jurors during closing arguments Wednesday that the evidence proved Ms. Seymour was angry that Reams had won custody and shot her former husband without provocation. He noted the shooting occurred on the first visitation exchange involving the child after the court ruling. Defense lawyer Robert Head criticized prosecutors for what he said was heavy-handed treatment of witnesses and tactics that kept them from investigating all angles of the case. Ms. Seymour had testified that her former husband had beaten her and was about to do so again when she shot him. Head had said during the trial that Reams was shot when Ms. Seymour went for her gun and it accidentally discharged. Tessa was born in 1985 to Norma Lee Stotski, who was artificially inseminated and was paid $10,000 to be a surrogate mother. A court-ordered paternity test revealed that a sperm donor other than Reams was used. The Reamses divorced in 1986. In the custody fight that ensued, Juvenile Court Judge Ronald Solove ruled Aug. 20 in favor of Reams, who already had temporary custody. The baby's biological father, who was an acquaintance of Ms. Stotski's, did not seek custody. Ms. Stotski asked for custody of Tessa after the shooting, but permanent custody was awarded Oct. 3 to the Franklin County Children's Services Board.

DOC.HEAD: Baker: Resolution Threatening Iraq With Force is Self-Executing
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday night the U.N. resolution approving force to liberate Kuwait could be implemented without further action by the Security Council. Baker told reporters the resolution, which was approved 12-2 with China abstaining, was ``self-executing.'' Baker said before taking action the United States would consult with Congress as well as countries that would participate in the military operation. The United States and 25 other countries have sent troops or other units to the Persian Gulf. But, Baker said, ``We don't have to come back to the Security Council for additional resolutions before force could be used.'' At the same time, Baker said there would be further diplomatic efforts to persuade Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to quit Kuwait in the more than six weeks until Jan. 15, the deadline set in the resolution. From the news conference at the U.S. mission, he said he was going to dinner with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China to discuss what might be done next. ``We are not giving him the chance of being rewarded for his aggression,'' Baker said of the Iraqi leader. But, Baker said, that does not rule out more diplomacy. On another subject, Baker denied reports he had made a commitment not to oppose a resolution backed by the Palestine Liberation Organization. The resolution calls for U.N. peacekeepers to monitor the treatment of Palestinians by the Israeli government in Jerusalem. Baker called the resolution unacceptable in its present form. He said the United States would hold further talks on the subject at the United Nations next week. ``There should be a willingness and a commitment to do exerything we can to move the peace process in the Middle East,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Body To Be Exhumed in Brach Case
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have been given permission to exhume an unidentified body found 12 years ago to determine whether it might be that of candy heiress Helen Brach, who vanished in 1977. Authorities were hopeful that DNA tests, which weren't available when the body was discovered in a forest preserve in 1978, may help them identify the body. Wednesday, investigators recevied a federal court order allowing authorities to exhume the body. Brach, heir to the Brach Cancy Co. fortune, disappeared in February 1977 at age 65. Her net worth at the time of her death was estimated at $17 million. The body buried in a Cook County cemetery probably will be exhumed within the next week.

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Arrives in Washington To Accept Drug Czar Position
Precede TALLAHASSEE, Fla.
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 5 new grafs to update with Martinez arrival in Washington, picking up 7th graf pvs: Martinez, 55; Also Inserts 3 new grafs after 8th graf pvs with Rangel comment., picking up 9th graf pvs: Martinez etc.
DOC.TEXT: Florida Gov. Bob Martinez arrived in the nation's capital Thursday to be nominated as the nation's next drug czar. Bush administration officials acknowleged that Martinez, who lost a re-election bid earlier this month, would be announced Friday as the next director of the Office of Drug Enforcement. He replaces William Bennett, who President Bush wants as the next chairman of the Republican National Committee. Martinez arrived in the nation's capital Thursday. His chief of staff, Brian Ballard, said only that Martinez will be in Washington for two days. But Bush administration officials, speaking on the condition they not be identified further, acknowledged that Martinez' appointment would be announced Friday at the White House. The position is subject to Senate confirmation. Martinez, 55, was accompanied by his wife, Mary Jane. After the appointment is formally announced, he is expected to visit with congressional leaders before returning to Florida for the weekend. Martinez was defeated in the Nov. 6 gubernatorial election by Democrat Lawton Chiles. The selection of Martinez for the drug post already has its strong critics in Congress. ``I'm disappointed the president chose a political reject to give this awesome responsibility,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control in a telephone interview. But Rangel conceded that the appointment is expected to be confirmed. ``I hope he (Bush) gives him more authority and clout than he did Bennett,'' said Rangel. Martinez, a staunch supporter of the Bush administration, moved quickly to the top of the list of candidates for head of the Office of National Drug Control Policy after Bennett resigned and Martinez lost his re-election bid. Bennett's salary this year was $99,500, slightly less than the $100,883 the governor earned in 1990. During his four years in office, Martinez initiated several high-profile anti-drug policies and even took a drug test himself to set an example for state workers. Martinez also got the Legislature to pass a law mandating the death penalty for drug kingpins in certain cases and pushed through a bill requiring tougher penalties for drug dealers who traffick near schools. The governor also is chairman of the National Governors Association task force on substance abuse and drug trafficking. He visited Bolivia and Colombia in 1988 with the National Guard on a drug fact-finding mission. When news of the appointment surfaced, it drew some criticism from congressmen who saw it as a political payback rather than a decision based on the Republican Martinez's experience. Bush campaigned hard for Martinez in his failed re-election bid and Barbara Bush even made a campaign commercial for him. But even Democrats in Florida supported the Martinez choice, including Chiles ``He knows so well how important Florida would be in fighting that battle. I'd like to see him appointed,'' Chiles said recently. Before his election in 1986, Martinez served two terms as mayor of Tampa. A longtime Democrat, he switched to the Republican Party in 1983. The governor's single term was beset by problems, the worst of which was a proposal to extend the sales tax on services. Martinez fought for the tax, then reversed himself and led a repeal under pressure from advertisers who didn't want to pay it. Relations with the Legislature were never the same. Martinez made national headlines in 1989 when he called a special session to restrict access to abortion, the first state to do so after the U.S. Supreme Court gave states more power to regulate abortion. But the Legislature rejected his proposals in a defeat for anti-abortion forces.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Admits He Was `Politically Stupid' In Keating Dealings
With AM-Keating-Senators
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston told the Senate Ethics Committee he was ``politically stupid'' but ethically correct in soliciting large contributions from former S&L owner Charles H. Keating Jr., according to testimony released Thursday. Cranston, in testimony given in closed session last April 30, also said it was unwise of his chief fund-raiser to link the solicitations to Keating's battle with thrift regulators. Several memos from the fund-raiser to the senator made that connection. The California Democrat solicited Keating for donations to three voter registration projects he supported, and received $850,000. Keating or his associates also donated $39,000 to Cranston's own campaigns. ``I see nothing ethically, morally or legally wrong with the amounts that were involved,'' Cranston said. ``I will grant that it turned out to be politically stupid and unwise, because it's caused an uproar that I regret. But being politically stupid or unwise is quite different from being ethically improper.'' Cranston received more from Keating than any of the four other senators under investigation for intervening with banking regulators on Keating's behalf. The businessman was responsible for funneling a total of $1.3 million for the campaigns or causes of all five - much of it while regulators were investigating his failing Lincoln Savings and Loan, of Irvine, Calif. While all five senators testified previously in private, all except Cranston are scheduled to testify in the public hearings now in their third week. Cranston is expected to answer questions in writing, because he's undergoing treatment for prostate cancer in California. The other four senators are Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Cranston said Keating gave to the voter projects because he ``considers himself a patriot.'' Cranston had been asked by a committee counsel why a conservative Republican - seeking support in his fight with regulators - would support a liberal senator's voter registration causes. Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett read to Cranston a memo that has been cited previously in news stories - in which Joy Jacobson, the senator's fund-raiser, wrote the senator in September 1987, that Keating would soon be coming to Washington. ``I have attached an article from the Wall Street Journal which talks about the views of the new FHLBB (Federal Home Loan Bank Board) chairman, Danny Wall. Views that obviously are good news to Keating. You should ask Keating for $250,000,'' the memo said. Cranston said Ms. Jacobson was ``covering two different topics'' and admitted, ``perhaps it would be better not to cover them in the same memo.'' The senator also said that Keating or his associates never linked their donations with their attempts - supported by Cranston - to get rid of the bank board's rule limiting risky investments like those made by Lincoln. ``It would be illegal for them to say we will raise money for you if you will do so-and-so,'' Cranston said. ``It would be illegal for me to agree to any such thing. But that was never suggested to me.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Citizens Warned Against Traveling to Chad
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Thursday warned U.S. citizens to postpone non-essential travel to the North African nation of Chad because of fighting there between rebels and government forces. ``Troop movement, along with the potential for open conflict, makes the situation dangerous for travelers,'' the State Department said in a statement. The State Department and Chad's government contend the rebels are backed by Libya. The statement said Chad's northern frontier with Libya is heavily militarized and mined and that government forces have set up roadblocks in the southern part of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Indonesia Warns Foreign Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Information Minister Harmoko was quoted Thursday as defending government restrictions on foreign journalists, saying it will continue to ban those who offend Indonesia's leader. The comment followed government banning of a New York Times reporter who wrote an article saying President Suharto's children enjoy lucrative business ties to most major government projects. ``We will consistent. I will blacklist such journalists,'' Harmoko said Wednesday, according to news reports. He spoke after the intallation of Indonesian Press Council members. Harmoko said the policy applied only to foreign publications circulated in Indonesia. ``If such stories are circulated overseas, it is not a problem. It's their right. But if such stories are circulated in this country, it amounts to interfering with our press law,'' he said. The government has prohibited New York Times reporter Steven Erlanger from visiting Indonesia. Harmoko said Erlanger's story, printed in the Nov. 12 issue of the International Herald Tribune, ``is insulting to the president.'' Harmoko - who uses one name, as does Suharto - said a similar story by Erlanger also appeared in the Australian Financial Review on Nov. 13. In 1986, the government blacklisted an Australian journalist after the Sydney Morning Herald published a story saying Suharto's family and associates had amassed vast wealth.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Five Pushed for Change in S&L Findings, Regulator Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th graf, bgng: The five xxx to UPDATE with newly released Cranston testimony.
DOC.TEXT: The ``Keating Five'' senators hit savings and loan examiners with a ``full court press'' of criticism at a 1987 meeting, and one of the lawmakers pushed for changes in unfavorable findings on an embattled S&L, one of the regulators testified Thursday. Michael Patriarca told the Senate Ethics Committee, which is investigating the senators' conduct on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. and his Lincoln Savings and Loan, that the lawmakers appeared to have decided ``that we were in fact harassing Lincoln, that we were incorrect, wrong.'' Patriarca said Dennis DeConcini at the April 9, 1987, meeting acted as ``master of ceremonies,'' and added, ``It was my impression quite frankly that Sen. DeConcini was negotiating on behalf of Lincoln.'' He said the senator was ``attempting to get us, the regulators to change our position on the examination, the examination findings and conclusions to more closely align with the position that Lincoln espoused.'' Keating was contending during this period that Lincoln was sound and that regulators were trying to harass the institution, which was seized by the government in April 1989 at a potential cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion. The regulators told the five senators at the meeting, according to a transcript, that allegations against Lincoln were so serious that criminal referrals would be made to the Justice Department. However, Patriarca said, ``The tone that the meeting took was that the senators seemed to have made up their minds, on the basis of information acquired before the meeting, that we were in fact harassing Lincoln, that we were incorrect, wrong and basically we got the full court press.'' He said the senators became ``less aggressive'' after learning of the potential criminality. ``The full-court press that challenged our conclusions about the exam was reduced significantly,'' he testified. Patriarca said the Justice Department initially declined to bring criminal prosecutions based on the referrals, but ``it is my understanding that it is currently the subject of an ongoing investigation.'' The role the senators played in the meeting with four regulators will be important in the Ethics Committee's determination whether they intervened improperly on Keating's behalf. The committee completed an eighth day of hearings on the conduct of DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif. and John Glenn, D-Ohio. The five received a combined total of $1.3 million from Keating and his associates for their campaigns and causes - most of it donated while regulators from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board were examining the failing Lincoln. Cranston, who accounted for $889,000 of that total, said in testimony released Thursday that his involvement with Keating was ``politically stupid.'' Cranston gave the testimony last April in a closed session with the committee. ``I see nothing ethically, morally or legally wrong with the amounts that were involved,'' Cranston testified last spring. ``I will grant that it turned out to be politically stupid and unwise, because it's caused an uproar that I regret. But being politically stupid or unwise is quite different from being ethically improper.'' A week before the meeting with the examiners, all the senators except Riegle had met with Edwin J. Gray, then chairman of the Bank Board. Gray has testified that DeConcini offered him a deal to benefit Lincoln and that Cranston, McCain and Glenn quietly acquiesced. DeConcini, in whose office both meetings took place, has vigorously denied making the offer, involving withdrawal of a board regulation, and the other three senators said they did not recall the proposal. The meeting on April 9, with San Francisco-based regulators, was scheduled because Gray was unable to answer questions about the examination of Lincoln in the previous week's get-together. Commenting on the four senators other than DeConcini, Patriarca said: -Glenn was ``blunt'' at the meeting and ``seemed to have also made up his mind our behavior was somehow wrong.'' -McCain appeared ``uncomfortable being at the meeting and made statements to the effect of wanting to establish it was okay to be there.'' -``Sen. Riegle did what I would characterize as cross-examination to probe the basis for the findings that we were saying we reached.'' -Cranston made only a brief appearance because he was managing legislation on the Senate floor. Patriarca, now western regional director for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said regulators had found ``absolutely reckless'' practices by the Irvine, Calif.-based savings and loan. He said there was evidence the thrift's files had been stuffed with phony underwriting documents in an attempt to justify loans. In the spring of 1988, Patriarca testified, he received indications that Keating's political clout went beyond persuading five senators to meet with regulators. Patriarca said he urged the bank board chief of staff to deny Lincoln's request to transfer the case away from San Francisco. According to Patriarca, the chief of staff, Jim Boland, replied, ``These guys are so well connected they can get you in ways you'll never know you've been gotten.'' ``I took that to mean Mr. Boland thought the political connections of Lincoln warranted transferring jurisdiction of Lincoln to some other place,'' Patriarca said.'' Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett said Boland denied making the remark. The Lincoln case was transferred from San Francisco to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Says Prosecutor Tried To Stop Iran-Contra Revelations
DOC.TEXT: A publisher filed a lawsuit against the Iran-Contra special prosecutor that accuses him of threatening criminal action to stifle a book about Oliver North's case. The lawsuit filed Wednesday by Penguin Books seeks to bar Lawrence Walsh, the independent counsel, from interfering with publication of Jeffrey Toobin's ``Opening Arguments: A Young Lawyer's First Case - United States v. Oliver North.'' Toobin's 384-page book is ready for distribution to reviewers and is scheduled for publication by Viking early next year, said Paul Slovak, spokesman for Viking and its parent corporation, Penguin USA. The lawsuit seeks to bar Walsh from threatening, harassing and stonewalling Toobin, whose book is an account of his two years with Walsh's office. The lawsuit also asks that a judge declare in advance that the book does not violate laws about disclosing confidential information and that the government may not attempt to tie up Toobin's royalties. Toobin, 30, now an assistant U.S. attorney in Brooklyn, was part of Walsh's team from 1987 until last year. Former Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North was convicted last year of three felonies, including aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress and the destruction of government documents. The charges arose out of North's involvement in the Iran-Contra scandal, which involved covert military assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels known as the Contras and the sale of U.S. arms to Iran. The lawsuit said Walsh claims the final version of the book improperly discloses staff discussions and internal memos of the office and violates grand jury secrecy. Upon leaving Walsh's office, Toobin signed an agreement to submit anything he wrote for government review, the lawsuit said. Toobin and Michael Jacobs, president of Viking-Penguin, would not talk about the book's contents. The lawsuit denies the book contains illegal disclosures. Speaking for Walsh in Washington, Mary Belcher said Toobin's manuscript revealed ``nonpublic aspects of criminal investigations,'' identified persons investigated but not indicted and talked about criminal charges considered but not made. ``We believe that such disclosures not only would violate Mr. Toobin's legal obligations, but also would be unfair to the individuals involved and harmful to the continuing work of this office,'' Ms. Belcher said. The lawsuit said that while Toobin and Walsh haggled over the content of ``Opening Arguments'' for more than a year, the Justice Department and the CIA both had read and cleared it. It said Toobin made changes Walsh requested, but Walsh has continued to object to the book without giving specifics. ``It is both ironic and unfortunate that Mr. Walsh - who has sought to unveil government secrets in his investigation - is now attempting to prevent publication of book that sheds light on a matter of great public importance,'' said Martin Garbus, Penguin's lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: Case of Seven Deputies in Drug Money Skimming Case Goes to the Jury
DOC.TEXT: The case of seven sheriff's deputies accused of skimming $1.4 million in drug money went to a jury Thursday with a prosecutor calling them corrupt and the defense saying the government used unreliable witnesses. The trial lasted seven weeks and focused the spotlight on a scandal which embarrassed Sheriff Sherman Block and his department in the nation's most populous county. ``With all the power the government has, they have not proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt,'' attorney Harland Braun told jurors. ``And that is because the defendants are innocent.'' Braun, who represents former deputy Daniel Garner, blamed Robert Sobel, the government's star witness against the deputies and the former chief of the elite narcotics squad called Major Violators II. Braun portrayed Sobel as a thug and a liar. ``Sobel is worthless,'' Braun told the jury. ``It would demean our history, our jury system if you based a verdict on someone like Robert Sobel.'' The seven defendants, Terrell Amers, James Bauder, Eufrasio Cortez, Ronald Daub, John Dickenson, Garner and Macario Duran are charged with conspiracy, theft, racketeering, tax fraud and money laundering. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered the jury to begin their deliberations Friday. Braun criticized prosecutors for using drug suspects as witnesses and said testimony had shown the government operated its own undercover money laundering operation, returning drug profits to the Colombians. Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas A. Hagemann said, `There are some things the government does that aren't very pretty. ... But it's done according to the book and approved at the highest level of government. Washington says, `OK' because it's a drug war and there are benefits. So there is an undercover money laundering operation.'' As for the drug suspects, Hagemann said the government didn't choose them as witnesses. He said the defendants caused such people to become witnesses in the case by allegedly stealing money from them. During the trial, the deputies testified that they made luxury purchases of boats, cars and vacatins by legitimate means, with money obtained from savings, relatives, overtime work and yard sales. ``These are the defenses of wishful thinking,'' Hagemann said of the deputies evidence, ``a defense made up of nonsense.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Officer Sues Over Tower Sniper Movie
DOC.TEXT: A former police officer who helped kill a sniper at the University of Texas in 1966 is suing to stop broadcast of a movie about the incident that he says portrays him as a coward. In the lawsuit against Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc., Houston McCoy seeks $14 million for emotional distress and damage to his reputation. McCoy, who lives in Menard in West Texas, filed the federal lawsuit Wednesday in Austin. The lawsuit contends the 1975 movie, ``The Deadly Tower,'' has caused McCoy to become an alcoholic and lose self-respect. McCoy claims the film depicts him as a coward, although he says he was commended for bravery after the sniper incident. Turner Broadcasting did not immediately return a telephone call Thursday. On Aug. 1, 1966, University of Texas student Charles Whitman climbed 27 floors to the top of the clock tower in the center of the campus and opened fire with a high-powered rifle. Fourteen people were shot to death and 34 were wounded. Authorities also discovered the bodies of Whitman's wife and mother in their Austin homes. Both had been slain by Whitman before the tower rampage. Whitman was stopped when city police officers Ramiro Martinez and McCoy climbed to the top of the tower and shot him. McCoy claimed in the lawsuit that he was portrayed as a coward to ``enhance the dramatic character of the movie's hero (Martinez).'' Martinez, now a Texas Ranger, had no comment on McCoy's lawsuit. Martinez said he filed a lawsuit against the producers of the movie in 1975 ``because there was so much in the movie that was untruthful ... just fiction.'' That lawsuit was settled out of court, he said. Turner Broadcasting showed the movie on television in August 1988, April 1989 and July 1990, McCoy said in his lawsuit. It aired again Tuesday on Turner's station. ``Had (Turner Broadcasting) investigated the facts of the incident, it would have discovered that the movie contained factual inaccuracies,'' McCoy said. The former officer said he is unable to see or hear about the movie ``without slipping into deep depression.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Drops Gentle Language, Endorses `Military Pressure' on Iraq
With AM-UN-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday dropped his calls for patience in the Persian Gulf and called for military pressure to force Iraq from Kuwait. But he repeated his desire to avoid war.
