DOC.HEAD: MCA Purchase to Help Matsushita Battle Sony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The purchase of entertainment giant MCA Inc. should help Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. shake off its conservative ways and weather the sluggish consumer electronics market until the next popular product arrives, analysts say. Arch-rival Sony Corp. learned the importance of ``software'' - the industry's name for pre-recorded videotapes, records or compact discs - when its Beta format lost a battle for videocassette supremacy to Matsushita's VHS. With sales of VCRs flattening out, Matsushita has followed Sony's lead in purchasing a Hollywood studio and record company to acquire the software rights to music recordings, a film library and future movie releases. Some Americans have expressed concern that Matsushita's $6.6 billion purchase of MCA could affect the U.S. compny's policies, although most analysts say they expect little change. But the deal could have a much wider impact on tradition-bound Matsushita. The purchase marks a dramatic shift for Osaka-based Matsushita, which for years prided itself in not taking risks. ``They've taken a step away from being a conservative company and now will have to see where it takes them,'' said Mike Jeremy, an analyst for Baring Securities. ``But perhaps they haven't put a lot of thought into what they will do next.'' Sony learned from its Beta defeat that it could no longer single-handedly persuade consumers to try innovative technologies. It joined with other companies to set standards for new electronic ``hardware'' such as 8-millimeter video and digital audiotape recorders, in part to encourage the development of more software. With televisions or radios, consumers could simply buy a set and turn it on. But new products that depend on software won't sell unless it is readily available. Sony was successful in launching compact disc players in Japan, for instance, because it could start selling CDs immediately through its Japanese CBS-Sony subsidiary. ``Without that, it might have been a really hard sell to get an independent record company to invest millions of dollars in a new plant and start producing a product for which there was no market yet,'' said one industry official who asked not to be identified. Both Matsushita and Sony depend on video equipment, which accounted for about 26.6 percent of Matsushita's sales last year. With VCR sales leveling off, the chief reason for Matsushita's purchase of MCA was ``to maintain momentum until the next major electronic product comes onto the market,'' said Colin Mills, a research analyst for W.I. Carr in Tokyo. That next product is expected to be high-definition television, which will provide clearer images, wider pictures and digital sound - and require a new generation of software such as videocassettes and laser discs. ``But that market won't amount to anything until into the 21st century. There's got to be something else in the interim, and that's likely to be video software'' for use on today's video systems, the industry official said. Under the financial and philosophical leadership of Konosuke Matsushita, who founded the company in 1918 and died last year at age 94, Matsushita grew into the world's biggest consumer electronics maker, eschewing the acquisition of outside companies. Typically, Matsushita waited for other firms to develop new products and to create consumer demand before unleashing its powerful manufacturing might to take a share of the market through its 24,000 Japanese retail shops. That earned Matsushita the nickname ``maneshita,'' or ``copycat,'' from rivals, who nevertheless respected the company's reputation for quality products sold under the popular brand names Technics, Quasar and Panasonic. ``Until a year ago they hadn't bought anything,'' Jeremy said. ``Because of the dullness of the company, we never even had anyone following it on a regular basis. Sony was always the company that was the innovator.'' But the electronics industry has changed, and along with it, Sony and Matsushita. New Matsushita President Akio Tanii ``is gearing up to take the company in another direction,'' said an official at a competing electronics company who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They're trying to create a leading-edge image and become a bigger player overseas.'' But the bureaucracy and corporate inflexibility that were a part of founder Matsushita's legacy are likely to slow the changes, said Mills. ``It's like a giant oil tanker. Tanii is pulling on the rudder but it will be about two miles down the road before it will start to take effect,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chances of Agreement on New World Trading Order Are Uncertain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: In September 1986, trade ministers from more than 100 countries assembled at an Uruguayan seaside resort and vowed to ``develop a more open, durable and viable'' international trading system. In a meeting that begins Monday in the chillier climes of Brussels, Belgium, prospects for a successful conclusion to the so-called Uruguay Round of trade negotiations look uncertain at best. Economists have warned that collapse of the talks would have huge implications. According to U.S. estimates, a successful trade liberalization package would boost world economic output by $4 trillion over the next 10 years. By contrast, failure to reach agreement is likely to lead to an upsurge in protectionism, inward-looking trading blocs and damaging trade wars. Trade officials point out that Third World and reformist eastern European countries would be hit first, but the West would also suffer. ``It will be difficult, I think, to generate the international cooperation that we need to deal with tomorrow's problems if we're at each others throats on economic and trade issues,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills has said. Ministers attending the five-day Brussels meeting will have before them a 391-page document meant to serve as the basis of a Uruguay Round accord spanning 15 sectors of world trade. The sectors range from traditionally protected areas like agriculture and textiles to others like trade in commercial services and patent protection. But the ``draft final act'' is generously sprinkled with squre brackets, indicating alternative and often conflicting policy options. More seriously, there is no negotiating text on three areas, prompting one diplomat to call the document an ``unfinished symphony.'' Negotiators say that problems in two of these areas - anti-dumping and trade-related investment measures - will be difficult to solve but carry insufficient political weight to take center stage at Brussels. On anti-dumping, Western nations want tougher restrictions to prevent goods being sold on their markets at artificially low prices. Japan and its Southeast Asian neighbors say the West uses existing anti-dumping duties merely to protect high-cost industries. Deadlock on investment measures is characterized by a North-South split. Third World countries cite development reasons for keeping controls over foreign investment. The United States is not convinced and says many such controls distort trade. The third issue, agricultural supports, is the most explosive. Ministers at the 1986 meeting at Punta del Este, Uruguay, managed to include farm subsidies on the agenda only after bitter resistance from France. At a meeting in April 1989, governments agreed to ``substantial progressive reductions in agricultural support and protection,'' but they remain divided over what this means in practice. The European Community has offered 30 percent cuts in internal support, but no firm commitments on reducing export subsidies or import barriers. The United States, some Latin American countries and some other agricultural exporters say this is not enough. Japan, meanwhile, is sitting quietly on the sidelines, relieved that the international dispute has diverted attention from its own import ban on rice. There is no sign of flexibility in the opposing viewpoints, and the Bush administration has repeated earlier warnings that it will walk away from the round of talks if there is no satisfactory deal on agriculture. For its part, the European Community says Washington must accept the overwhelming view that a planned accord to govern the $680 billion service sector must contain a general non-discrimination provision. Principles of ``most favored nation'' status now rule world trade. Developed and developing countries alike say more progress must be made toward the goal of cutting overall import tariffs by one third. Seven previous trade rounds helped cut duties on industrialized goods from postwar levels of about 40 percent to about 5 percent in developed countries. Arthur Dunkel, director-general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that is sponsoring the talks, has stressed the deadlock over the main issues must be overcome in the ``first hours or days'' of the meeting. His view is echoed by a senior European Community official who said that without a political breakthrough in the first two days of the meeting, the chances of the talks succeeding would be less than 50-50. The official said the Community is not prepared to extend the December deadline for the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Subsidies are Latin America's Worry in Trade Talks
With PM-GATT-World Trade
DOC.TEXT: At next week's international trade talks, Latin America hopes to pry open the gates of European countries to farm exports from this continent. The country's of Latin America say the question of European farm subsidies is No. 1 on their agenda for the talks, beginning Monday, as part of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. Brazil, Argentina, Chile and other nations on the continent depend on agricultural exports to earn hard currency. But officials say price supports by the European Economic Community are unfair competition. ``Brazil is in condition to compete with the production of these countries,'' said Celso Amorim, head of the commerce department of Brazil's Foreign Ministry. ``But we have no chance if we also must compete with their treasuries.'' Brazil is the world's No. 2 soy producer after the United States and earned $3.647 billion in sales of soy last year. Argentina could sell 25 percent more grain - $1.5 billion worth - if world export subsidies were abolished, Agriculture Secretary Felipe Sola said. Chile, Bolivia and Peru also have called for lower agricultural subsidies and tariffs by Europe, Japan and the United States. Another important issue for Latin America is a proposal to include patents, or intellectual property rights, in the GATT accord. The United States has threatened to impose sanctions on Argentine exports if Buenos Aires doesn't honor U.S. pharmaceutical patents. New governments in Brazil and Peru generally favor recognizing patents. Brazil and Mexico are also pushing for the elimination of export quotas for textiles and clothing in industrial nations' markets. Many Latin countries are already voluntarily lowering their trade barriers. For example, Mexico has reduced 4,090 of its 4,400 import tariffs from 100 percent to 20 percent or less since 1988. Brazil, Bolivia and Argentina have lowered tariffs, while Chile and Colombia say they will accept cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Bound to Hurt Business and Consumers, Fed Chairman Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan can only do so much to ease the pain of oil-price problems from the Persian Gulf crisis, analysts say. He can cut interest rates a bit in hopes of stimulating the flagging economy, but he and his fellow monetary policy makers must move cautiously for fear of fueling inflation and scaring foreign investors away from U.S. securities, they say. Greenspan delivered a double message to the House Banking Committee on Wednesday. He acknowledged the oil shock had pushed the economy into what he called ``a meaningful downturn.'' At the same time, he warned, ``There is no policy initiative that can in the end prevent the ... cut in our standard of living that stems from higher prices for imported oil.'' Consumers and businesses forced to pay more for gasoline and fuel oil will have less to spend on other goods and services, he said. Economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Inc., a New York government securities dealer, said the Fed is in a bind. In the past month, it sought to pep up the economy by nudging short-term interest rates down by half a percentage point and, Jones said, it most likely will push them down an additional quarter point before Christmas. To do more, however, could fuel inflation, already hit with the effects of higher oil prices. By making U.S. rates lower in comparison with foreign rates, it would also discourage Japanese and Europeans from buying the Treasury securities sold to finance the national debt. ``Greenspan came as close as a Fed chairman can come in suggesting that we are in a recession, but he also suggested the Fed is going to be very cautious in responding to it,'' Jones said. Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, suggested that now may be the best time to push down interest rates, even if it caused some inflation, because federal spending restrictions established in the recent budget deficit reduction agreement are blunting another source of inflation. Greenspan responded, ``The best thing to do is to try to craft a very stable policy which creates an environment in the long run that is not inflationary.'' By steering a middle course, however, the Fed may end up with a combination of accelerating inflation and economic weakness - called stagflation, said economist Allen Sinai of The Boston Company, who appeared after Greenspan. During previous oil shocks in 1973 and 1979, ``the U.S. economy suffered from stagflation-recession, rising inflation and rising unemployment, summarized in extraordinarily high `discomfort' or `misery' index levels,'' he said. ``There is not much cushion for the Federal Reserve because of a recession that already was in place before the Iraqi oil shock,'' Sinai said. Even if Greenspan personally wanted to do more to stimulate the economy, he faces another problem, according to Jones: unusual dissension among Fed policy makers. The Federal Open Market Committee, which meets eight times a year to craft monetary policy, usually approves its directives unanimously, or with perhaps one, at most two, dissenting votes. But in its early October meeting, the last for which minutes have been released to the public, the committee approved its directive by only a 7-4 vote. Three of the dissenters objected to the directive, which provided for an easier monetary policy if Congress and President Bush reached a budget agreement later in the month. One dissenter wanted a more immediate relaxation of credit. ``Greenspan still has somewhat of a split to deal with,'' Jones said.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Growers Sue ``60 Minutes'' and Consumer Group Over Alar Scare
DOC.TEXT: Apple growers filed a multimillion dollar lawsuit against the CBS program ``60 Minutes'' and a consumer group, seeking compensation for sagging sales during a scare over the growth chemical Alar. The industry has estimated growers lost more than $100 million following the news program's Feb. 26, 1989, release of a report entitled ``Intolerable Risk: Pesticides In Our Children's Food.'' The report was done by the Natural Resources Defense Council, which is named as a defendant in the lawsuit with CBS and the network's ``60 Minutes.'' Officials for the Washington-based consumer group and the news show said Wednbesday they stood by the Alar report. The report concluded that Alar, which is sprayed on trees to improve the appearance and shelf life of apples, increased the cancer risk in children. It criticized the Environmental Protection Agency for failing to take into account the high consumption of fruit and fruit juices among children when it set chemical guidelines. The report was hotly disputed at the time, but sales and wholesale prices of apples plummeted. Some school districts temporarily pulled apples from lunchrooms. Signs appeared in grocery stores advertising Alar-free apples. Alar, the marketing name of the chemical daminozide, was voluntarily removed from the market in October 1989 by Uniroyal Chemical Co. The EPA banned it from all food uses in May. The scare was felt most acutely in Washington, where more than 60 percent of the nation's supermarket apple crop is produced. The class-action lawsuit filed Wednesday in Superior Court seeks to represent the estimated 4,700 growers of red apples in Washington. It seeks unspecified damages running to millions of dollars. The lawsuit contends unfair business practices, especially product disparagement, caused apple growers to lose profits. Growers suffered economic losses as a direct result of ``false, misleading, scientifically unreliable statements of the defendants,'' the lawsuit said. ``The gain is for agriculture in general nationwide, that we stop this misleading information by the media and scare tactics by environmental groups,'' said Burt Chestnut, a Wenatchee apple grower who is a plaintiff. ``We want the media to be responsible.'' Also named as defendants were Fenton Communications Inc., a Washington, D.C., public relations firm that planned the Alar campaign for the consumer group, and CBS affiliate stations KIRO of Seattle, KREM of Spokane and KIMA of Yakima, all of which broadcast the ``60 Minutes'' show. The lawsuit was brought in state court to take advantage of Washington's Unfair Business Practices Act, which outlaws unfair or deceptive trade practices, said the growers' attorney, Jay Sandlin. Steven Berzon, an attorney representing the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the lawsuit could have a chilling effect on public activism. ``Beyond Alar, this suit threatened by a small group of Washington growers raises fundamental issues of free speech and the right of citizens to petition the government on important questions of public policy,'' Berzon said. ``We believe the broadcast highlighted an important public health matter,'' said Roy Brunett, spokesman for ``60 Minutes.'' ``It was well researched and well documented and we expect a lawsuit ... to be dismissed.''

DOC.HEAD: USX Chief In No Hurry To Meet with Icahn Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `Pound, director ... to DELETE reference to not returning phone calls; picks up 9th graf, `Icahn said ...
DOC.TEXT: Two professors financier Carl Icahn is threatening to nominate to the board of USX Corp. want to meet with Chairman Charles A. Corry, but Corry isn't rushing to accept the offer. John Pound of Harvard University and Ronald J. Gilson of Stanford University requested the meeting Nov. 15 in a letter to Corry, who responded in a letter released Wednesday. ``I have difficulty understanding the purpose of having a meeting as you suggest,'' Corry wrote. ``It is difficult to imagine that the views and demands of your committee would be any different than those of Mr. Icahn.'' Corry said it was clear the two were ``acting as Mr. Icahn's agents.'' He noted the five members of the USX Shareholders Enhancement Committee are being paid by Icahn, who also would pay for a proxy fight. According to the chairman, the company has met many times with Icahn and discussed his views ``at great length and in significant detail'' during the past four years. Icahn, who with a 13.3 percent stake is USX's largest shareholder, announced Nov. 14 he had formed the committee to represent shareholders who want to boost the price of USX stock by creating a separate steel unit. He threatened to nominate the five committee members as directors at USX's next annual meeting in May unless the company quickly moves to restructure its steel business. Pound is director of the Corporate Voting Research Project at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, and Gilson is a law professor. Icahn said he does not control the two, although he paid each man $25,000 in cash and USX stock. He said he considers the payments to be campaign contributions in their efforts to be elected as directors. ``They are completely independent of me. They stand in general for what I stand for, which is free elections,'' Icahn said. Icahn said he took exception to the USX chairman's letter and said Corry is trying to make the committee a personal issue between himself and Icahn. Pound said he will continue to attempt to arrange a meeting with Corry to discuss company policies. ``I'm not quite sure how Mr. Corry arrives at an understanding of what our views are,'' Pound said, adding, ``We don't have a specific agenda as yet and had hoped to speak with Mr. Corry to learn his views about the company.'' The committee would poll USX stockholders on whether the company should separate its steel and energy businesses, whether it should solicit bids for all or part of its Marathon Oil energy unit, and what the company's dividend policy should be, Icahn said. USX put Icahn's steel-spinoff proposal to a shareholder vote in May after Icahn agreed not to launch a proxy vote. The proposal was rejected by 57 percent of those voting. USX's board said Oct. 30 it had approved converting the steel division into a wholly owned subsidiary, a move Corry said would ``provide the flexibility for any steel restructuring.'' Corry said he would consider meeting with the committee after members provided a detailed agenda. ``I am particularly interested in knowing how the items on your agenda vary from the items we have thoroughly discussed on numerous previous occasions with Mr. Icahn,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Pushes EC Inflation Rate To 6.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's average annual inflation rate rose to 6.3 percent in October from 6.1 percent the previous month and 5.2 percent in October 1989, the EC statistics agency said Thursday. Across the EC, consumer prices rose an average of 0.7 percent last month, Eurostat said in its monthly inflation report. Eurostat said the EC's 6.3 percent inflation rate in October matched the U.S. rate but was far above Japan's 3.2 percent. Annual inflation rates in the 12 EC states ranged from a low of 2.7 percent in Denmark to 22.3 percent in Greece. Eurostat gave these annual inflation rates for the EC states in October with the corresponding figures for October, 1989 in brackets: Denmark, 2.7 percent (5.1 percent); Netherlands, 2.9 (1.3); Germany, 3.3 (3.2); France 3.8 (3.6); Luxembourg, 4.2 (3.9); Belgium, 4.3 (3.6); Italy, 6.8 (6.3); Spain, 7.1 (7.1); Britain, 10.9 (7.3); Portugal, 14.4 (12.3); Greece, 22.3 ( 13.8). Eurostat gave no October inflation figure for Ireland which calculates its consumer price index quarterly.

DOC.HEAD: Nestle, Coca-Cola Sign Deal for Joint Venture in Beverages
DOC.TEXT: The world's biggest food company, Nestle SA, and the largest soft drink concern, The Coca-Cola Co., have signed a deal to set up a joint venture in beverages, the companies said Thursday. The statement said the two multinationals would be equal partners in the new company which would manufacture and market bases and concentrates for the production of ready-to-drink coffee and tea drinks. The statement issued by Nestle's Swiss headquarters said the new company would likely have an initial capitalization of $100 million, equally contributed by the founders. It said the company would market its products under the brand names Nescafe and Nestea throughout the world, with the exception of Japan. ``This is intended to be a clearly defined and long standing relationship to successfully develop a new business,'' said a joint statement issued by Roberto Goizueta, chairman and chief executive of Atlanta-based Coca-Cola, and Helmut Maucher, chairman and chief executive at Nestle SA. ``The joint venture company will operate as a separate business unit, drawing on the unique and complementary strengths of our two companies.'' the statement said. Coca-Cola supplies syrups and concentrates to bottling partners in nearly 170 countries. Nestle has operations in every continent. Products include drinks, dairy goods, chocolate and confectionary, frozen food and infant foods.

DOC.HEAD: Union Agrees to Freight Crew Reductions on Santa Fe Railway
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Railway officials are promising $75,000 severance payments to workers who voluntarily resign as the railroad moves to reduce crew sizes on freight trains along its eastern region routes. Under an agreement with the United Transportation Union, trains on the eastern half of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway will operate with at most one conductor and one brakeman in addition to the engineer. About 20 percent of the trains will operate without a brakeman, the company said Wednesday in announcing the agreement. Trains now run with two brakemen, said spokeswoman Kris Rabe. The agreement, effective Dec. 12, won approval of 88 percent of the voting members. It prohibits the company from arbitrarily firing about 2,250 conductors, trainmen and yardmen covered by the agreement. Engineers are not covered by the new pact. The agreement also calls for $75,000 severance payments to workers who resign voluntarily within 90 days. And all remaining employees will receive $5,000 cash up front. The company agreed to create reserve boards for employees who wish to stay with the company but whose seniority does not qualify them for regular service. The agreement follows approval of other crew reduction plans on the railway's Texas and Coast lines in August 1989. The eastern region includes Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska and parts of Oklahoma and Texas, Ms. Rabe said. The railway reported operating income of $71.5 million for the third quarter, down slightly from $73 million for the same quarter last year. Year-to-date operating income is up from $161.1 million last year to $166.8 million through October 1990, said Bob Gehrt, spokesman for the parent Santa Fe Pacific Corp. Santa Fe Pacific laid off 1,150 railway workers earlier this year and plans to cut an additional 1,200 jobs by the end of 1992. Those cuts would reduce the railway's work force to 15,000. The layoffs were part of corporation-wide changes that also included spinning off two major subsidiaries, Santa Fe Energy Resources and Santa Fe Realty Co., to shareholders. Those moves were announced in April. The railway's general offices are in Topeka, Kan.

The stock market showed a modest drop this morning in a continuation of a slight dip that began late Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 6.44 points at 2,528.71 after a half hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Decliners outnumbers gainers by almost 2 to 1, with 326 up, 575 down and 525 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.2 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The NYSE's composite index was down .41 at 173.50. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .57 at 298.40. Traders were still responding in part to a slip in the bond market a day earlier and comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who all but said the U.S. economy had entered a recession. ``We had a market that began pulling back yesterday, and I think it's partly a continuation of that,'' said Jack Solomon, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``What is taking place here is a little bit of spinning in place by some of the blue chips.'' Among actively traded issues this morning, General Electric was up ] to 53, and Boeing was down \ at 42|. In the previous session, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell near the close to finish 8.66 points lower at 2,535.15, after trading slightly higher through much of the day. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 4 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 843 up, 664 down and 496 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.49 million shares on Wednesday, against 147.59 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose .04 to 173.91. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.97 to 298.97.

DOC.HEAD: Steelcase Names New President, CEO
DOC.TEXT: Steelcase Inc., the world's largest office furniture manufacturer, has appointed Jerry K. Myers as its president and chief executive officer, the company announced Thursday. Myers succeeds Frank H. Merlotti, who retires Friday after 29 years with the company. Myers, 49, was most recently executive vice president and general manager of TRW's Automotive Sector in Cleveland. He was responsible for a company with 29,000 employees worldwide and 115 plants in 21 countries. A graduate of Michigan State and Northwestern universities, Myers also is a director of Great Lakes Construction Co., based in Cleveland. In his new role, Myers will oversee a private company with annual sales of about $1.9 billion and nearly 21,000 employees worldwide. Merlotti, 64, who began at Steelcase as production control manager in 1961, has been president of the company since 1980 and chief executive officer since 1988. Since 1980, the company's sales have tripled. Merlotti will remain on Steelcase's board of directors and chair its executive committee.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Flat; Personal Incomes Up Slightly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf, It was ... to eliminate reference to spending gain. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending, which makes up two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, was flat in October, the government said today. Personal incomes, meanwhile, inched up 0.1 percent, failing to keep pace with inflation. The Commerce Department said spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.73 trillion, unchanged from expenditures in September, which had risen 0.9 percent from the previous month. At the same time, incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.71 trillion, up $5.7 billion from September when incomes rose 0.5 percent. But the advance did not match the 0.6 percent increase in the Labor Department's consumer price index in October. Spending had advanced every month since last May, when consumption also was unchanged. The meager gain in incomes was the poorest showing since incomes were unchanged in August 1989. It was the first look at consumer spending in the final quarter of the year when many analysts believe the economy has skidded into a recession. The department Wednesday revised personal consumption in the third quarter down from 3.6 percent in its initial report to 3.2 percent. Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health because it represents such a large percentage of the nation's economic activity. Surveys show consumer confidence has plummeted during the Persian Gulf crisis at the same time the unemployment rate was growing and the number of hours worked was shrinking. Americans' savings rate - savings as a percent of disposable income - edged up to 3.8 percent from 3.5 percent in September. The September rate was the lowest in three years, indicating that consumers were dipping into their savings to pay for their purchases. Americans' savings rate for all of 1989 was 4.6 percent. The report said Americans' disposable incomes, or incomes after taxes, inched ahead 0.1 percent, down from a 0.4 percent gain the previous month. It was the smallest gain since after-tax incomes fell 0.1 percent last April. The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending fell 0.7 percent after a 0.2 percent increase in September. Disposable income dropped 0.5 percent, even more than the 0.4 percent decline a month earlier. A key component of the income category - wages and salaries - fell $9.3 billion after gaining $16.7 billion the previous month. Spending on durable goods - usually expensive products expected to last at least three years - fell $8.4 billion in October. Non-durable purchases were off $1.5 billion. Spending on services rose $8.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dunlop Says Composite Components Plant Will Employ 100
DOC.TEXT: A joint venture of Ford Motor Co. and Britain's BTR Group will build a plant in Benton Harbor to make composite engine parts, Ford said Thursday. The Dunlop Automotive Composites Inc. plant will begin production in 1992 and employ about 100 workers when it reaches full production in the mid-1990s, said Bob Tamburrino, Dunlop Automotive Composites general manager. The companies didn't disclose the cost of the plant. It will make engine parts such as thermostat housings and intake manifolds of reinforced composite plastics. Ford and BTR's Schlegel subsidiary formed Dunlop Automotive Composites in August 1989. The company produces composite engine components including intake manifolds for Ford's European automotive operations and for Jaguar Ltd.

The stock market declined early today as investors took profits and retreated to the sidelines to await further developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 5.94 points at 2,529.21 around midmorning on the New York Stock Exchange. Decliners outnumbers gainers by about 4 to 3, with 668 down, 497 up and 568 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 39.95 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts had expected some profit-taking following the spotty gains the market posted earlier in the week. Concern is brewing about a United Nations resolution, which is expected to pass this afternoon, authorizing military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Also weighing on the market is Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's recent gloomy assessment of the economy. ``Uncertainty in the Middle East has added excess baggage to a market already suffering from a weak economy and Greenspan's unenthusiastic'' comments, said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc. Among actively traded Big Board issues, McDonalds was off 1\ at 27~; Upjohn was up ~ at 37; Texas Instruments was up [ at 32 and Pepsi was down ] at 25. The NYSE's composite index was down 0.35 at 173.56. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.40 at 299.37.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Proposes Green Labeling For Consumer Goods
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission on Thursday proposed developing a green-labeling system for consumer goods that would denote products that are environmentally sound. EC Environment Commissioner Carlo Ripa de Meana said the proposal would put industries under pressure to make ecologically sound products. He said a panel of scientists and other experts from the 12 EC states would identify which products could sport the label showing a daisy encircled by 12 stars. The EC institution that would oversee the labeling scheme, the European Environmental Agency, does not yet exist, however. De Meana told reporters EC states should agree quickly on where to locate the agency. That will be discussed at a Dec. 14-15 EC summit meeting in Rome. As immediate candidates for a green label, De Meana cited detergents, paints, varnishes and other products used in the building trade as well as washing machines and lawn mowers. De Meana said foodstuffs and drinks would eventually be candidates for green labels. He said the awarding of such a label would depend on the products' ``overall impact on the environment'' during their manufacture and use and after they had been discarded. The labels would be issued based on uniform criteria to be applied to products made across the EC, de Meana said. The green labeling plan would incorporate national programs in EC states either already in place or under study. The EC-wide project ``contains the necessary seeds to become the exclusive system'' of ecological labeling in the Community.

DOC.HEAD: Field Execs Say Deal May Be Near on Buyout
DOC.TEXT: A New York publishing firm is negotiating to buy Field Publications, the company that publishes Weekly Reader, a news magazine read by more than 10 million schoolchildren each week. Field Corp., the Chicago-based parent of the Middletown-based publishing arm, is in the final stages of negotiations with K-III Holdings Inc., Field executives said Wednesday. Field has been looking for buyer for its Middletown subsidiary since summer. ``It's not final, but hopefully it will be final soon,'' said Bruce Seide, president of Field Publications. Field Publications employs more than 300 people in Middletown and more than 500 at the company's warehouses in Ohio. The sale of the 88-year-old company would be its fourth. Seide declined to release any details of the negotiations, saying no contracts have been signed. The negotiations also involve Funk & Wagnalls Inc., Field's encyclopedia affiliate in Ramsey , N.J. The family of Marshall Field IV, which owns Field Corp., decided to consider selling Field Publications to raise cash and not because the subsidiary's performance, Seide said. Field Publications' revenues for 1990 are expected to be about $300 million, he said. Ned Zachar, an analyst with Duff & Phelps of Chicago, estimated last summer that Field would fetch between $275 million and $300, Calif., in early November on a military ship bound for Saudi Arabia - along with instructions on how to play ``Ultimate Frisbee'' and ``Disc Golf.'' Scheduled dispersal date: Christmas Day. ``They'll have to use their imagination'' for playing in the sand, said Frank Kappler, spokesman for Kransco Group Companies, whose Wham-O subsidiary makes the Frisbees. A decidedly unusual donation was planned by Hair Farming, a Pompano Beach, Fla., company that said it is shipping over instructions on how servicemen can keep their hair from falling out in the extreme desert heat. Another company, Kiwi Brands in Douglassville, Pa., said it rushed off a case of black shoe polish to an army unit in ``desperate'' need because its men's boots were drying out in the heat. Kiwi, which calls itself the largest producer of shoe care products in the United States, said it previously sent a large shipment of shoe polish for distribution in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Chief To Retire Early
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Job's age in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Glen Renfrew, chief executive and managing director of Reuters Holdings PLC, will retire March 1, the British-based news agency and information group announced today. Renfew, 62, will be replaced by Peter Job, 49, who is now the Hong Kong-based managing director of Reuters Asia. Renfrew retires after nearly 39 years with the company, including 10 years in his present position. Job has been at Reuters for 27 years. A spokesman at the company's headquarters said Renfrew's decision to retire had been anticipated widely and that his departure next March would ensure an orderly succession. The mandatory retirement age at Reuters is 65. The company announced in August that Renfrew had sold 20 percent of his personal holding in the company for 1.72 million pounds, then worth $3.3 million. The sale of the 210,000 shares left Renfrew with 849,378 shares.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip On Profit-Taking, Soviet Loan News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking and pessimism about the prospects for Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. Analysts said many traders were cashing out of the market ahead of first notice day Friday for the December wheat, corn, oats, soybean oil and soybean meal contracts. First notice day is the first opportunity for players to declare their intentions to deliver physical commodities against a futures contract. Large deliveries of corn and wheat are expected, said Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Further selling was linked to a Washington Post report that Saudi Arabia initially plans to lend the Soviet Union less than $1 billion, not $4 billion as reported Wednesday by the Soviet news agency Tass, he said. The crop markets rallied Wednesday on ideas the Soviets would use some of the Saudi money to buy U.S. grains. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.40{ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.19 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with December at $1.05 a bushel; and soybeans were 2{ cents to 5 cents lower with January at $5.81} a bushel. Pork futures were sharply lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, extending Wednesday's losses. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed. Live cattle were .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 78.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .15 cent higher with January at 87.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .65 cent to .90 cent lower with December at 50.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.65 cents lower with February at 66.50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures retreated Wednesday.

The stock market moved slighly lower today, but trading was trendless as investors mulled over developments in the Persian Gulf and the state of the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 2.23 points at 2,532.92 around midday on the New York Stock Exchange. Decliners outnumbers gainers by about 7 to 6, with 679 down, 584 up and 563 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 58.15 million shares as of noon on Wall Street, compared with 68.85 million shares in the previous session. Analysts had expected some profit-taking following the spotty gains posted earlier in the week, but the market had no clear direction. ``It's not grabbing you by the lapels and saying `Here's my message,''' said Larry Wachtel, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Traders awaited this afternoon's vote on a United Nations resolution authorizing military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. But Wachtel said he was puzzled by their interest in the resolution, since it is virtually certain to pass. Also continuing to weigh on the market is Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's recent gloomy assessment of the economy. Bond prices recovered somewhat from an early decline today, and stocks also were lifted off their worst levels by midday. Among actively traded Big Board issues, McDonalds was off 1\ at 27~; Upjohn was up 1] at 37{; Pepsi was down ] at 25, and Philip Morris was up \ at 48~. The NYSE's composite index was down 0.10 at 173.81. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.88 at 299.85.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt to Meet Non-OPEC Oil-Exporting Countries in Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Egypt will meet with seven other oil-exporting countries that are not members of OPEC next week in Mexico to discuss world oil prices, the Middle East News Agency said Thursday. The agency said the two-day meeting starting Dec. 5 would involve technical experts from the eight countries. It said that beside the Egyptian and Mexican delegations, the meeting will be attended by Norway, Columbia, Malaysia, Oman, the Soviet Union and Brunei. Subroto, the secretray general of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, will also attend, the news agency said. It said similiar meetings involving non-OPEC oil exporting countries have been held in the past in London, Moscow and Muscat, Oman. The report said that discussions would center on the world oil market, especially the amount of crude available on the world market and its price. Egypt produces around 860,000 barrels of oil, half of which are consumed locally and the rest are exported. It is not a member of OPEC but sets its prices takjing into account the cartel and the world oil market.

DOC.HEAD: MBB to Cut 10 Percent of its Workforce
DOC.TEXT: Aerospace giant Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GmbH plans to cut 10 percent of its workforce at its main German production complex at Ottobrunn, the IG Metall labor union said Thursday. The company, also known as MBB, is the aerospace subsidiary of Germany's largest industrial group, Daimler-Benz AG. Company oficials were not immediately available to comment on the report from the country's largest labor union. At Ottobrunn, MBB's main production complex, the union said the company plans to trim 700 jobs in the aircraft construction sector and another 300 jobs in the defense technology section during 1991. The planned job reductions would be the result of declining military orders and the strength of the mark, especially against the dollar, which has hurt sales and earnings through currency translation losses, the country's largest labor union said. In an article published in the latest edition of the union magazine, IG Metall said that Daimler's Deutsche Aerospace AG aerospace and defense division plans to restructure not only the 65 percent-owned MBB, but also the 57.6 percent-owned Dornier GmbH aircraft subsidiaries. The job reductions are part of an overall restructuring of Daimler's aerospace sector, the union added.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 173,931 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 123,379, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 207,113 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 108,302 cars this week, compared with 76,504 a week ago and 127,002 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 65,629, compared with last week's 46,875 and last year's 80,111. Canadian automakers were to build 26,473 cars this week, up from 24,819 a week ago and from last year's 24,113. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,406, compared with 14,279 a week ago and 19,340 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Fall in Slow Session

At the end of trading, the broad-based Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 8.7 points, or 0.40 percent at 2,135.6. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was down 11.4 points at 1,674.8, while the Financial Times 500-share index was down 1.21 at 1,130.60. Volume registered 415.4 million issues, compared with the 381.5 million shares transacted a session ago.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 15.35 points at 2,519.80 at midafternoon on the New York Stock Exchange. Decliners outnumbers gainers by about 3 to 2, with 849 down, 554 up and 530 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 101.49 million shares as of 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Analysts had expected some profit-taking following the spotty gains posted earlier in the week, and prices were marginally lower from the opening. But by early afternoon equities fell sharply, with the Dow off more than 23 points. Rumors about an escalation of tension in the Perian Gulf coupled with extremely light trading encouraged the market to move ``further than it normally would,'' said James Schroeder, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. But many market-watchers were puzzled by the interest in the resolution, since it is virtually certain to pass. Also continuing to weigh on the market is Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's recent gloomy assessment of the economy. Bond prices turned lower again after a midday recovery, and stocks mirrored the downturn. The NYSE's composite index was down 1.02 at 172.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.13 at 299.10.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Says It Won't Interfere in MCA Creative Moves
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese electronics giant that is buying MCA Inc. reiterated Thursday that it has no intention of trying to influence creativity at the entertainment conglomerate. In a statement released in Osaka, Japan, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. said: ``Matsushita has no intention of becoming involved in decisions regarding the subject or content of creative products at MCA.'' The statement from President Akio Tanii came in response to reports questioning the impact of foreign ownership on MCA and other movie studios owned by overseas companies. ``There should be no misunderstanding of Matsushita's position in this important area,'' Tanii said. ``Creative decisions for MCA will be made by MCA management.'' Both MCA and Matsushita said when they announced the $6.6 billion buyout of MCA on Monday that MCA would be operated independently. Meanwhile, reports surfaced that the Italian buyer of another Hollywood studio also considered a bid for MCA. Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti was reported to have expressed interest in MCA just after the entertainment conglomerate was closing the sale to Matsushita. Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. labored to buy MGM-UA Communication Co. for $1.3 billion earlier this month. The financier, who parceled off many of Pathe's and MGM-UA's assets to finance his purchase of MGM-UA, presented the new offer to MCA Chairman Lew R. Wasserman only hours after the Matsushita deal was signed Monday, according to the news reports. A representative for Parretti told the New York Times that the offer fell between an expression of interest and a formal bid. ``There should be an incredible amount of skepticism about the validity of any of this,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, a stock analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities. ``There's no bid.''
