DOC.HEAD: Hopes to Reach Debt Agreement with Bankers by Early January
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. says it hopes to reach an agreement with bankers by early January on a new financing agreement that would defer repayment on about $5 billion in debt for the next three years. The Australian-based company has amassed a large debt by aggressively expanding internationally into newspapers, book publishing, movie and TV production, television stations and magazines. But unexpectedly slow assets sales, economic weakness in Britain and Australia and a sluggish advertising market in the United States have made it tough to keep up with debt payments. Murdoch has met over the past few weeks with groups of bankers in Australia, Europe and the United States to outline a proposal to consolidate some $6.5 billion in bank loans otherwise due by mid-1993. An executive source close to the News Corp. chief executive but speaking on condition of anonymity said Thursday that Murdoch made the proposal because principal payments are coming due that the company would have trouble paying. Under terms of the proposed package, only $1.4 billion in bank loans would have to be repaid by December 1993, the executive said. The company would then hope to renegotiate the remainder by early 1994, he said. In exchange for permitting the debt deferral, the bankers would get higher rates of interest and other fees. The company has also told the bankers it plans to sell about $1 billion in assets over the next two years. As part of the refinancing proposal, News Corp. would get a $600 million bridge loan that would have to be repaid in mid-1992. The bridge loan would give the company the ability to make interest payments, meet business expenses and allow extra time to arrange asset sales. ``We hope to have it finalized by the end of December or early January,'' the executive source said. He said he was hopeful the banks would go along, but cautioned ``We are very much in the middle of the process.'' News Corp. purchased the book publisher Harper & Row, 20th Century Fox Film Corp., several television stations and Triangle Publications, the owner of TV Guide and The Daily Racing Form, in the past few years. Under its existing loan agreemnt, News Corp. would have had to pay back $2.4 billion in both bank loans and public debt by next June, another $1.4 billion by June 1992 and another $3 billion by June 1993. The new agreement would require no repayments by next June, $1.2 billion including the bridge loan by June 1992 and another $800 million by June 1993 with the chance for delaying the final payment until December 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Futures Jump on Rumored Soviet Interest
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices closed sharply higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid renewed speculation that the Soviet Union soon may buy more U.S. grain. Wheat futures fell moderately on expectations that large amounts of wheat will be delivered against the December contract. Friday is first notice day for all December grain and soybean-product contracts, the first opportunity for traders to declare their intentions to satisfy the contracts through physical delivery. Rumors of Soviet buying interest were fanned by indications that a grain exporter had arranged shipment for two cargoes of corn with specifications that met Soviet requirements, said Steve Freed, a grain market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Speculation about the Soviet Union has dominated the grain markets this week. Moscow is seeking U.S. food credits to buy grain but the Bush administration has repeatedly said it will not offer the credits unless the Soviets formally liberalize their emigration policies. At the close, wheat futures were 3\ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.39{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 5{ cents higher with December at $2.26 a bushel; oats were 4 cents lower to 1{ cents higher with December at $1.07{ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 9 cents higher with January at $5.94 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Volkswagen Discussing Joint-Venture In Portugal
DOC.TEXT: Automobile giants Ford and Volkswagen are negotiating to jointly produce a new multipurpose vehicle in Portugal, the President of Ford Europe said Thursday. Lindsey Halstead said a final decision on the $2.5 billion project depended on ongoing economic feasibility studies by the U.S. and German car makers, as well as support from the European Community. Halstead and Paul Weber, Volkswagen's director for foreign investment, met Thursday with Portuguese Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva. The two companies are expected to take a firm decision on the project early next year, said a Portuguese trade official. The new plant would become the biggest single foreign investment in Portugal. It would make 190,000 vehicles a year, 90 percent for export, and would create 5,000 jobs. Portuguese press reports said the Cavaco Silva government has offered up to $1 billion in incentives to clinch the investment. Portugal faced stiff competition from neighboring Spain for the plant.

DOC.HEAD: By Land, Air, Sea, Taxes on the Rise
DOC.TEXT: Tax collectors start shaking a little more cash out of airline passengers and motorists this weekend. But most people facing higher taxes in the skies don't seem to be rushing to buy tickets ahead of time, perhaps because they are ignorant of the latest levy. Likewise, tax-dodging drivers don't appear to be lining up en masse at the nation's service stations to top off one last tank at the old rate. Not that the new taxes are playing well among businesses that might catch some of the flack from consumers who will pay more to fly and drive, or even to operate a motorboat. Travel agents have been urging air travelers to buy quickly and beat the tax that kicks in Saturday. But several said Thursday that few customers seem aware of the 25 percent increase in the federal tax imposed on air fares as part of the government's effort to trim the budget deficit by nearly $500 billion over the next five years. ``They have no idea on it,'' said Eric Munro, chief executive of Uniglobe Wide-World Travel in San Diego, which has warned customers by phone to get tickets early. ``The government is very sly about it. They have not advertised it.'' At Travel Professionals, in St. Paul, Minn., workers sent faxes and a newsletter to corporate customers advising them of the rise in the tax, from 8 percent to 10 percent of the cost of a ticket. ``There are a few companies that are buying their tickets ahead of time,'' manager Peggy Siqveland said. ``The leisure traveler isn't too affected. I don't think too many people are aware of it.'' The tax could become something of a windfall for the airlines, however, because many will choose to raise ticket prices to round numbers that will bring in a little extra money on top of the levy, Munro said. ``Instead of making it $322.22, they'll make it $325,'' he said. ``So you're looking at not only 2 percent, but maybe 3 or 4 percent.'' The tax might not seem all that bad to travelers who have already absorbed three rounds of air fare increases totaling about 15 percent. The industry raised fares across the board after fuel prices shot up following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``I think people are more worried about the fuel increases,'' Siqveland said. Anyone who tries to avoid higher taxes in the air won't be able to do so by staying on the ground or getting in a boat, unless they fill their gas tank quickly. Starting Saturday, drivers will pay as much as 5.1 cents more for each gallon of gasoline, as the federal gasoline tax rises by that amount to a total of 14.1 cents a gallon. Service-station owners don't have to pass along the taxes, but they are expected to. Major oil companies said Thursday they have no choice but to pass on the taxes, and at least one expressed unhappiness about that. A vice president at Amoco Corp., Robert J. Rauscher, said the higher gasoline tax ``allows government at all levels to avoid resolving the underlying problem of overspending.'' Even though pump prices will rise, the American Automobile Association doubts many, if any, motorists will fill up early to avoid paying. ``I would hope people wouldn't run out and top off their tanks,'' AAA spokesman Jerry Cheske said. ``If everybody, and I'm talking everybody, went out and topped off their tanks, that could cause a problem with a lot of stations, and it could create a perception there is a problem with supply, which is not the case.'' In addition, the taxes on other fuels also rise Saturday. The tax on diesel fuel for highway use, for example, will rise by 5 cents to 20.1 cents a gallon, while diesel used by trains will face a new 2{-cent tax.

The stock market lost ground today in light, skittish dealings punctuated by nervousness over the Middle East. Stock prices were off throughout the session but managed to recover from their worst levels late in the session. Analysts said the market was buffeted by a series of rumors that tensions had escalated in the Middle East. There were unconfirmed reports that British and French troops in the Persian Gulf region had been put on alert as well as rumors that shots had been fired. ``Money on the sidelines had a wonderful excuse to stay on the sidelines,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. Traders were awaiting results of a United Nations Security Council vote on a resolution authorizing the use of force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Analysts were puzzled by the interest in the vote, however, since it is widely expected to pass without difficulty. Trading was light, and analysts said the thin volume exacerbated the downward move. Goldman noted that higher-quality issues were benefitting from the widespread investor nervousness.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Operation Desert Sleigh: U.S. Companies Send Christmas Gifts to the Gulf
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Persian Gulf troops are finding Christmas stockings stuffed with 10,000 hand-held video games, 150,000 pre-recorded music tapes, 50,000 free phone calls home, 100,000 packets of Kool-Aid, one case of army boot polish and free instructions to avoid going bald in the desert heat. Corporate America is coming to town. Roughly 835 donors ranging from RJR Nabisco to Burger King to Wham-O to AT&T have given millions of dollars in goods and services to troops assigned to Operation Desert Shield, says the Defense Logistics Agency in Alexandria, Va., the Defense Department unit that is coordinating donations. ``The last time we had something of this magnitude was in World War II,'' said Lt. Col. Henry Wyatt, a Defense Department spokesman. Beneath their Santa Claus outfits, though, Persian Gulf gift-givers hope to reap the sort of benefits once reserved for world-class events like the U.S. Olympics or the New York Marathon. The charitable outpouring means valuable positive publicity in an age when many Americans tend to distrust expensive corporate advertising. Many of these donations were arranged by company marketing departments. ``Millions of readers will see the fact that AT&T did something nice,'' said Greg Farrell, editor of Adweek's eastern edition, a trade publication. ``Everytime AT&T is mentioned, that's good public relations.'' The approach got off to a rocky start for some companies. In October, AT&T cut short its offer for U.S. troops in Saudia Arabia to phone home for free after Saudi communications officials complained their long-distance lines were clogged. But AT&T repeated its offer this Thanksgiving, letting slide $1 million in free phone calls in an 8-day operation that went more smoothly. About 130,000 calls were made in the first five days, an AT&T spokesman said. Similarly, Philip Morris U.S.A. announced in October that it had donated 2 million cigarettes to the Persian Gulf forces, but the move prompted a big outcry from health groups who said the corporation was trying to hook a new generation of smokers. Now Philip Morris has come back with a less controversial approach, but its marketing value is less clear. The tobacco and food conglomerate has sent overseas nearly 80,000 holiday greeting cards outfitted with computer chips that can play back recorded messages from family members and friends. That donation ``seems like less of a logical promotional fit,'' said Farrell. Not to be outdone by AT&T, U.S. Sprint teamed up with Burger King in a promotion with 50 U.S. radio stations that has folks reciting messages to soldiers over the air. The messages will be recorded and shipped over to Saudi Arabia for broadcast to the troops, a Burger King spokeswoman said. Around 20,000 or $100,000 worth of blue, purple, red and orange Frisbees left Long Beach, Calif., in early November on a military ship bound for Saudi Arabia - along with instructions on how to play ``Ultimate Frisbee'' and ``Disc Golf.'' Scheduled dispersal date: Christmas Day. ``They'll have to use their imagination'' for playing in the sand, said Frank Kappler, spokesman for Kransco Group Companies, whose Wham-O subsidiary makes the Frisbees. A decidedly unusual donation was planned by Hair Farming, a Pompano Beach, Fla., company that said it is shipping over instructions on how servicemen can keep their hair from falling out in the extreme desert heat. Another company, Kiwi Brands in Douglassville, Pa., said it rushed off a case of black shoe polish to an army unit in ``desperate'' need because its men's boots were drying out in the heat. Kiwi, which calls itself the largest producer of shoe care products in the United States, said it previously sent a large shipment of shoe polish for distribution in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: investor nervousness.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.34 to 2,518.81. Losing issues outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 849 down, 638 up and 511 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 140.92 million shares, against 145.49 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index slipped 0.76 to 173.15. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index advanced 0.90 to 299.87.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $198 Million in Latest Week to New Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 526 money market mutual funds rose by $198.0 million in the latest week to a new record of $423.76 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday broke the record set the previous week, when fund assets reached $423.56 billion. That total originally was reported as $423.52 billion but was subsequently revised upward by the institute, a Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 262 general purpose funds fell by $105.8 million to $149.92 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $87.2 million to $166.38 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose by $216.6 million to $107.45 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.27 percent from 7.35 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.34 percent from 7.38 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 50 days, down from 51 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 5.99 percent as of Wednesday from 6.00 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.07 percent from 5.08 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.53 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.55 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.62 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.66 percent; 7.73 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.77 percent; and 7.97 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.01 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana-Pacific to Curtail Production
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana-Pacific Corp. said Thursday it would temporarily curtail production at many of its mills because of the slump in the housing market. ``The record decline in the homebuilding market and sharply lower prices for building products have forced the company to curtail production at many plants for varying periods of time during the fourth quarter,'' the forest products company said in a statement. ``Some of those curtailments may continue into the first quarter of 1991.'' The company said fourth-quarter earnings could be near or below the break-even level because of the cutbacks and continued declines in the pulp division. Company spokesman Barry Lacter said officials had not decided which mills to close or how long they will be shut down. ``In some instances it's going to be a few days around the holidays and in other instances it's going to be a number of weeks,'' he said. Lacter said the furloughs would affect operations nationwide. The company has mills in Oregon, California, Washington, Idaho, the South and the Upper Midwest. Louisiana-Pacific's stock fell $1.25 to $23.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday. Trading was halted temporarily as the company announcement was made. Louisiana-Pacific, with $2 billion in 1989 revenue, reported third-quarter earnings of $21.2 million, down nearly 60 percent from the year before.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Rally On Rumored Soviet Interest
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices leaped Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade on new signs of Soviet buying interest, but wheat futures fell to new 13-year lows under the weight of abundant world supplies. On other commodity markets, pork futures posted fresh losses; cattle futures gained; energy futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. In Chicago, corn futures settled unchanged to 4{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.25 a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 8{ cents higher with January at $5.94} a bushel; wheat was 3} cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.39 a bushel, the lowest settlement of a near-term wheat contract since mid-1977; oats were \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $1.07\ a bushel. Analysts said buying activity surged late in the session amid a flurry of rumors and reports that pointed toward an increased likelihood the United States will sell grain to the Soviet Union. Steve Freed, a grain market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said there were indications a U.S. grain exporter had arranged shipment from a Great Lakes port to an ocean port for two cargoes of corn with specifications that met Soviet requirements. Freed said the corn might represent grain the Soviets previously purchased but had not yet received. But even in that case, he said, the movement of corn could indicate the Soviets were cleaning up their backlog to make way for new purchases. Speculation about the Soviet Union has dominated the grain markets this week. Moscow is seeking U.S. food credits to buy about 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and 1.2 million metric tons of wheat by the end of the year to fulfill a long-term grain agreement. But the Bush administration repeatedly has said it will not offer the credits unless the Soviets formally liberalize their emigration policies. Crop prices opened lower in reaction to a Washington Post report that Saudi Arabia initially plans to lend the Soviet Union a maximum of $1 billion, not $4 billion as reported previously by the Soviet news agency Tass. Crop futures had rallied Wednesday, partly on ideas the Soviets would use the Saudi loan to buy U.S. grain. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Thursday he did not know how the Soviets would spend the money. Pork futures finished sharply lower for the second straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with lower cash hog prices and ideas that high slaughter rates will continue. Hog and pork belly prices rose from their session lows late in the session, though, prompting a rally in the neighboring cattle pits. Live cattle were .23 cent to .50 cent higher with December at 79.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .42 cent higher with January at 87.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent to 1.2 cents lower with December at 50.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.25 cents to 1.75 cents lower with February at 66.40 cents a pound. Crude oil futures ended modestly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange after profit-taking erased gains that had mounted during the session amid rising tensions in the Iraqi-U.S. standoff in the Middle East. Light sweet crude oil settled 31 cents to 78 cents lower with January at $32.91 a barrel; heating oil was .57 cent lower to .81 cent higher with December at 93.52 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .38 cent lower to .60 cent higher with December at 83.37 cents a gallon; natural gas was .8 cent to 1.5 cents lower with January at $2.49 per 1,000 cubic feet. Fears of war in the Persian Gulf helped boost gold futures on New York's Commodity Exchange but silver futures swung lower in lackluster trading. Gold finished $3.10 to $3.50 higher with December at $388.90 a troy ounce; silver was 3.2 cents to 4 cents lower with December at $4.085 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Brethen Defends Stock Sale in Insider Trading Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former Philips Industries Inc. executive accused of insider trading defended the sale of his stock Thursday, saying he had no inside information and was simply trying to protect himself from financial loss. Robert H. Brethen, former vice chairman of Philips, testified on the fifth day of his civil trial in U.S. District Court. The Securities and Exchange Commission alleges he used non-public information to avoid $570,000 in losses by selling about half his Philips stock before a proposed buyout of Philips collapsed for lack of financing. Brethen said that after his retirement from Philips, he consulted with attorneys on the legality of selling his stock. He said he was advised not to sell it if he thought he possessed inside information. ``I felt that I had no inside information,'' he said. Brethen said he authorized the sale after reading various financial publications and becoming concerned that the failure of an impending buyout of Philips by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners could send the value of the stock plummeting. ``I decided I would like to protect myself,'' Brethen said. ``I was concerned that there was a possibility the (buyout) might not take place.'' However, he said he didn't know whether or not the buyout would be successful. ``I had no information either way,'' he said. Brethen said he expected the stock sale to be investigated by either the SEC or the New York Stock Exchange. He also said he had the stock sold under a ``street name'' to protect the privacy of his personal finances within the local community. On Wednesday, an investment banker testified that information Brethen had would have been important to an investor trying to decide what to do with Philips stock. Charles Davis, an investment banker with Whitman, Heffernan, Rhein & Co. in New York, said that the private information included sales forecasts, an internal company memo about a $250,000 expense and a conversation Brethen allegedly had with Philips' chief executive officer about Merrill Lynch's disappointment with the company's November results.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Mixed
DOC.TEXT: One of the broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose and the other fell in the week ended Nov. 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fe said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,319.0 billion from $3,316.3 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,083.0 billion from $4,083.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $823.6 billion from $820.0 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 3.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.3 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,318.6 billion, a 3.8 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,090.3 billion, up 1.3 percent, while M1 rose 5.2 percent to an average of $820.7 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $168 million. -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $184 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $154 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $886 million in the two weeks ended Nov. 21, up from $733 million in the previous two-week period. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.7 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, down from $320.1 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market lost ground Thursday in a seesaw session punctuated by rumors and technical selling. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.34 points to llose at 2,518.81. Losing issues outnumbered gaining ones by about 9 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 839 down, 655 up and 514 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 140.92 million shares, down from 145.49 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 172.07 million shares. Stock prices moved lower on the opening bell amid some profit-taking. As the session wore one, prices fluctuated as equities tried to recover from bouts of computer-driven sell programs and rumors that tensions had escalated in the Middle East. ``It was somewhat of a rollercoaster today with a negative bias,'' said Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. At one point, the Dow Jones average was off about 25 points. Jarrett said at least some of the decline was attributable to nervousness over the Middle East. There were unconfirmed reports that British and French troops in the Persian Gulf region had been put on alert as well as rumors that shots had been fired. The rumors made for a wonderful excuse for ``money on the sidelines ... to stay on the sidelines,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. Elsewhere, bond prices declined while the dollar advanced, painting a confusing picture for traders. ``The market was not quite sure how to factor in all these new pieces of information,'' Jarrett said. Volume was relatively light, indicating that investors lacked the conviction to make any decisive moves. Among actively traded Big Board issues, McDonald's fell 1[ to 28 amid rumors that the chain was considering cutting prices at its restaurants. BankAmerica fell 1| to 21~; Philip Morris was down | at 48; Pepsi lost ] at 25; Johnson & Johnson advanced 1 to 68 following a positive analyst's report, and General Electric was up { at 53[. The paper sector was particularly hard hit. Georgia Pacific lost 1 to 33[; International Paper fell 1[ to 48|; Louisana Pacific was down 1\ at 23} and Weyerhaeuser was down { at 19[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $9.23 billion, or 0.31 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.77 to 173.14. Standard & Poor's industrial index declined 1.59 to 371.25, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 1.53 to close at 316.42. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 0.69 to 355.75. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 299.87, up 0.90.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Advances Sharply; Gold Mostly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs with resolution approved; picks up 4th graf, Analysts said.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar bounded higher Thursday as nervous investors sought a safe haven before the U.N. Security Council approved a resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Gold prices also gained before the Security Council meeting, which was held in New York after the U.S. financial markets closed. By a vote of 12-2, the council authorized military action to liberate Kuwait if Iraq does not withdraw its troops and release all hostages by Jan. 15. Traders, who generally consider the dollar a safe haven in times of international turmoil, wanted to increase their holdings of the U.S. currency before the council vote. Analysts said traders were also prompted to snap up dollars by a more militant stance toward Iraq by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. The Soviet leader, who has urged patience in the Middle East, shifted his tone and called for ``military pressure'' to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Economic factors were also behind the dollar's advance. Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for Bank of New York Co., said the dollar continued to draw support from comments Wednesday by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan, who told Congress he was concerned by the currency's recent sharp slide. The dollar surged against the Japanese yen, which is seen as particularly vulnerable in the event of a Middle East war. Japan imports virtually all of its oil, and if supplies are disrupted and the price of crude soars, the Japanese economy could suffer. In New York, the dollar jumped to 133.25 yen from 130.10 yen late Wednesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 130.15 yen from 128.90 Wednesday, and it was quoted in London at 130.55 yen. The British pound, which has fallen amid concerns about interest rates under the incoming Major government, continued to slide against the dollar. Sterling fell to $1.9435 in New York from late Wednesday's $1.9695. In London earlier, the pound fell to $1.9485 from $1.9723. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5040 German marks, up from 1.4860; 1.2805 Swiss francs, up from 1.2700; 5.0775 French francs, up from 5.0140; 1,129.50 Italian lire, up from 1,118.10; and 1.16445 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.5025 German marks, up from 1.4880; 1.2805 Swiss francs, up from 1.2685; 5.0820 French francs, up from 5.0237; 1.6860 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6760; 1,122.75 Italian lire, up from 1,117.50; and 1.1645 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1650. Gold, considered another safe investment in times of international strife, rose in New York, picking up $3.20 and closing at $388.90 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $387.00, up $2.30. In London earlier, gold rose to a late bid price of $386.75 from $385.50 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $386.75 from $384.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.40 to close at a bid $384.83. Silver slipped 4 cents on the Commodity Exchange to close at $4.085 a troy ounce. In earlier London trading, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.13 from $4.10 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Will Reopen Toledo Plant, Layoff 1,600 in St. Louis
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. will shut down its St. Louis I assembly plant in Fenton, Mo., Dec. 3-7, idling 1,600 employees, the company said Thursday. The plant is being closed to trim inventories of the Chrysler LeBaron and Dodge Daytona cars it manufactures, and will reopen Dec. 10, the company said. Chrysler also said its Toledo, Ohio, assembly plant, where 4,700 people are employed making Jeep Comanche, Cherokee, Wagoneer and Grand Wagoneer models, would reopen Dec. 3. The Toledo plant was closed this week. It was one of 14 assembly plant shutdowns by the Big Three that idled about 38,000 workers starting Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Armand Hammer, 92, to Celebrate Bar Mitzvah Amid Latest Health Worries
DOC.TEXT: Seventy nine years late, Occidental Petroleum's chieftain Armand Hammer will celebrate the bar mitzvah Jewish rite of male adulthood in a swank ceremony studded with Hollywood celebrities. The ceremony next month comes as concerns grow about the health of the 92-year-old industrialist, one of America's best known business figures. It will be held not in a temple but at a Beverly Hills benefit for two Jewish institutions, before a black-tie dinner crowd including Merv Griffin, Lee Iacocca, Bob Hope and Gov.-elect Pete Wilson. The bar mitzvah, a Jewish male's public acceptance of religious duties, is traditionally held on a Saturday morning at a synagogue. It's generally celebrated at age 13. But that's jus custom. The unusual has been customary throughout the life of Hammer, a physician, philanthropist, art collector and peace crusader, who's known every Soviet leader since Lenin - and rarely lets anyone forget it. ``It is never too late,'' said Meyer Denn, the executive director of the Pacific Jewish Center in Los Angeles, which will be a beneficiary of the fund-raising dinner along with the Jerusalem College of Technology. Hammer didn't immediately respond to a request for an interview about the bar mitzvah. He appeared feeble at a bash Sunday night celebrating the opening of his new art museum, and Occidental officials acknowledged getting inquiries about his health. But Occidental spokesman Frank Ashley and Denn said the benefit had been planned for several months, and warned against reading too much into it. ``I think it's just Dr. Hammer standing up and saying, `I'm proud to be a Jew.' I think it will be a very emotional thing for him,'' Denn said. Ted Turner is the honorary chairman and Elliot Gould the emcee at the dinner Dec. 11, the first night of Hanukkah, at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Hammer and Ida Nudel, a noted Jewish activist he helped escape the Soviet Union, will light the ``festival of lights'' Hanukkah candle, Denn said. He promised other ``very emotional moments'' but wouldn't reveal details. Hammer's health is a central concern of longtime Occidental shareholders and stock speculators alike. The oil, chemical and agribusiness company is regarded as a near-certain takeover candidate when he dies. Hammer didn't appear last week at a press preview of the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Culture, the new $96 million facility housing his personal art collection.

DOC.HEAD: Oldsmobile Extends Incentive Package
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s Oldsmobile Division said Thursday it would extend rebates on its 1990 and 1991 cars through Jan. 7. Oldsmobile offers rebates ranging from $1,500 to $2,500 on 1990 models and from $500 to $1,500 on 1991 cars. The incentive program would have expired Dec. 13. Oldsmobile buyers may forego rebates and opt for loan rates ranging from 4.8 percent to 10.9 percent, depending on the term of the loan, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Gerber Reshuffles Top Management, Adds P&G Exec
DOC.TEXT: James T. Smith, general manager of Procter & Gamble Co.'s health and beauty aids division in Germany, has been named president of Gerber Products Co.'s baby food division. Smith, who has been with Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble 19 years, will take the helm of the baby food company's $1.13 billion-a-year division on Jan. 1, officials said Wednesday. The division represents about 60 percent of Gerber's overall annual sales. Smith, 43, will replace Robert Johnston, who has held the title of corporate vice president since 1986 and president of the products division since 1989. Johnston, 35, will take on the title of vice chairman and will become a member of the board's executive committee. Smith said he will try to boost Gerber's fortunes in the international arena, with the company's domestic market penetration in baby food peaking at 70 percent. He also said he will try to steer the company toward broader sales through new foods for toddlers. ``I don't see why Gerber can't expand two, three, four or five times its current size,'' Johnston said.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Stock Climbs After Report of Possible Stock Buyback
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. stock climbed Thursday for the third consecutive day after a published report said the company was considering a stock buyback. The company said it had no comment on the report, but its stock jumped $4.87{ a share to $165.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. That followed a $5.87{ a share advance on Wednesday and a $2.25 rise on Tuesday. The media company's stock remains well below its high for the year of $206 a share, however. It has sunk over the past few months along with other media stocks, which have fallen into disfavor as the economy and the advertising environment have soured. CBS lost more ground in the past two weeks after announcing that it expected a loss for the fourth quarter and lower earnings in 1991. But The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that people familiar with the proposal said CBS is considering a stock repurchase program. The story said a so-called Dutch auction is one share buyback option. In a Dutch auction, a company states the number of shares it wants to buy in a specified period and gives a price range within which shareholders may tender their shares. The company then selects a price in the range that will enable it to buy all the shares it needs. That type of buyback might enable CBS to buy back part or all of the 8 percent stake held by the estate of the late CBS founder, William S. Paley. Paley's shares are to be divided among his six children but may have to be sold to cover tax obligations. CBS spokeswoman Ann Morfogen said the company had no comment on the report. Media analyst Peter Appert of the investment firm C.J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell said a stock repurchase ``would be one of the more logical uses of their cash flow'' given the lack of other appealing investment opportunities. CBS raised about $3 billion in cash through the sale in recent years of its records, music publishing, toys and magazine divisions. But Appert said the stock buyback is not the only reason CBS stock has done well this week. Media and entertainment stocks have generally risen in the wake of the $6.6 billion buyout agreement for MCA Inc. The takeover bid by Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. triggered speculation about combinations involving other media companies. One rumor that has circulated periodically is that Walt Disney Co. may be interested in bidding for CBS. In the earnings forecast Nov. 14, CBS said it expected to post a loss in the fourth quarter compared with earnings of about $60 million in the same period a year ago because of losses at its CBS Television Network. CBS has only posted one other quarterly loss from continuing operations in its history, and that was $20 million in the fourth quarter of 1986. The company also said it expects its earnings from continuing operations in 1991 will be down from this year because of a weak ad climate and rising costs for entertainment programs and sports rights.

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Charged in Scheme To Distribute $550 Million in Securities
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday charged 12 people with attempting to distribute more than $500 million in securities stolen from companies in New York and London. Those charged were accused of taking part in a conspiracy to distribute about 291 million British pounds (about $550 million) in treasury bills and certificates of deposit issued by the Bank of England. The bank's employees had been robbed of the money at knife point on May 2, according to the indictment, which was returned by a federal grand jury in Manhattan on Nov. 9 and unsealed Thursday. The indictment also accused the ring of trying to distribute $7 million in various bonds and notes stolen from Salomon Brothers Inc. in Manhattan in 1989. It alleges that in March 1989, Robert R. Rosenfeld, 46, of Woodbury, N.Y., and Ted R. Ballison, 44, of Brooklyn, tried to collect a gambling debt from Anthony J. Lama, 36, of Staten Island, a former Salomon employee. The indictment alleged that the men forced Lama to steal about $7 million in securities from Salomon under threat of death. The others were accused of taking or arranging for the stolen securities to be taken to the late John Mark Lee Osborne in Houston, where they were hidden. According to the indictment, some of the co-conspirators then arranged for some of the securities to be moved to W. Keith Cheeseman, 48, in the United Kingdom and to Erwin Kettmann, 33, of the Netherlands. The indictment says some securities also were taken to Antwerp, Belgium; Lugano, Switzerland; and back to the United States. The government will seek to extradite Cheeseman, who was arrested on Tuesday in London, authorities said. Rosenfeld and Ballison were arrested Nov. 23 and charged in a complaint with threatening a government witness with death, the indictment said. Both men were being held without bail. The indictment also alleges that Rosenfeld and Osborne on or about July 31 tried to sell about $19 million worth of stolen Bank of England securities to a FBI undercover agent posing as a narcotics dealer. The indictment resulted from an 18-month investigation by the FBI, the U.S. Attorney's Office and authorities in the United Kingdom, including the London police and the director of public prosecutions in London. The others charged were identified as Bernard F. Blessing, 50, Roger D. Armstrong, 46, Robert J. Black, 61, and Vincent J. Vallone, 54, all of Houston; Raymond Ketteridge, 45, of London; Jeffrey A. Kirschel, 43, of London; and Han Van Tinteren, no age or hometown provided. All those indicted were charged with conspiracy. Individually, some were charged with crimes ranging from extortion to money laundering. Black, Armstrong, Kirschel, Kettmann and Van Tinteren were listed as fugitives. Lama and Blessing were expected to surrender to authorities on Thursday. The rest either had already been arrested or were expected to be arrested shortly. Lawyers for the defendants could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: USAir, All Nippon Airways Plan Links in Florida
DOC.TEXT: USAir and All Nippon Airways signed a cooperation agreement Thursday that could lead to some guaranteed business for the American carrier and a link to DisneyWorld for the Japanese airline. In a letter of intent signed in Tokyo, All Nippon and USAir executives agreed to explore the exchange of passenger and cargo traffic between the Orient and the United States. The agreement contemplates numerous cooperative ventures such as coordinated schedules, joint promotional and advertising activities and the development of joint tour packages. In anticipation of a system linking All Nippon flights from Tokyo to Washington's Dulles International Airport with Orlando, Fla., USAir plans to begin daily Boeing 737-300 nonstop service between Dulles and Orlando International Airport on Dec. 15. The agreement to cooperate with a U.S. airline was a first for All Nippon and USAir's first marketing relationship with a major Japanese airline. ``We are going to be looking more and more at this type of liaison,'' said David Shipley, a spokesman for the airline's parent, USAir Group Inc. He noted that previously, USAir announced cooperative agreements with Alitalia Airlines and Air France. ``More than likely there will be others down the road,'' said Shipley. Laboring under the expense of acquiring both Piedmont Aviation Inc. and Pacific Southwest Airlines in 1987, as well as a jump in fuel prices and a falloff in air travel, USAir went from a $258.3 million operating profit in the first half of 1989 to a $100.8 million loss for the same period in 1990. Earlier this year the company announced plans to layoff 3,600 workers, suspend its 12-cents-a-year stock dividend and delayed acquiring 16 new planes. If approved by U.S. and Japanese transportation officials, USAir and All Nippon plan to link flights from Tokyo to Washington and Orlando, Fla., and Washington, permitting All Nippon to offer roundtrip transportation between Japan and the home city of Disney World. Under a proposed ``blocked space agreement,'' All Nippon would guarantee a fixed number of passengers on the USAir Orlando run. USAir would guarantee a matching number of seats for which it would be paid even if All Nippon fell short of the number of passengers promised.

DOC.HEAD: Price-Cut Rumors Take Bite Out of McDonald's Stock
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. stock dropped more than $1 a share Thursday after an analyst said the fast-food chain is considering permanent price cuts on most of its basic menu items. McDonald's disputed the report. Jack M. Greenberg, McDonald's chief financial officer, said the Oak Brook-based company is testing ``a variety of value strategies'' in local markets but has not settled on a system-wide plan. He said the report distributed late Wednesday by analyst Caroline Levy of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. was ``factually inaccurate.'' Ms. Levy was reported to be out of her office Thursday and did not return telephone calls. McDonald's shares fell $1.12{ to close at $28 on the New York Stock Exchange. McDonald's is seeking ways to stimulate domestic sales, which have been slowing steadily since 1988. Its stock price has fallen more than 20 percent since late July, when the company announced U.S. sales that were lower than many market analysts expected. Most analysts believe McDonald's will announce price cuts early next year on selected items, as the Wendy's hamburger chain has done. But they said across-the-board discounts, such as those used at the Taco Bell chain, would cut too deeply into McDonald's profits. ``They're going to want to reduce prices permanently on items that can still stimulate additional sales of other items,'' said analyst Leslie Steppel of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``You might see them roll back prices on hamburgers but I'd be surprised if they roll back prices on soft drinks and french fries.'' She said McDonald's has been selling hamburgers for 49 cents and cheeseburgers for 59 cents in Kansas City in one test of new pricing strategies. Greenberg said a new price strategy ``could include meal combinations, it could include some price adjustments.'' But he stressed that whatever changes McDonald's makes will not be temporary discounts and will be done with an expectation of improved profits.

DOC.HEAD: EC Slaps Anti-Dumping Duties On US, Japanese Aspartame Imports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Makes ``aspartame'' lower case throughout to conform to style.
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Thursday imposed penalties known as anti-dumping duties on U.S. and Japanese imports of aspartame, an artificial sweetener used in soft drinks and food. The EC Commission said NutraSweet Co., the U.S. exporter, charged less than half in Europe for its product than in the United States causing ``material injury'' to Holland Sweetener Co, the EC's only aspartame maker. It imposed a duty of 27.55 European currency units, or about $38, on each kilogram NutraSweet imports into the 12-nation EC and of 29.95 ECUs or $41.30 on aspartame from Japan's Ajinomoto Co. The two companies jointly market aspartame in Europe through a Swiss venture called NutraSweet AG. Jan Bergman, president of NutraSweet AG, protested the anti-dumping duties as unwarranted and unfair. ``This is the highest duty ever imposed by the commission on a food product,'' he said in a statement. ``It will cause an immediate and dramatic increase in the cost of aspartame to EC food and beverage manufacturers. ``We are shocked,'' he said. ``We do not understand the basis for the commission's determination and we will meet with members of the commission at their earliest opportunity to clarify their position and register our concern.'' The duties stem from an EC investigation, begun in March 3, into the prices NutraSweet and Ajinomoto charge in the EC after a complaint by the Dutch rival. ``Although the EC producer increased its sales and market share from nothing when it entered the market in 1988, it was faced by price undercutting by the U.S. and Japanese exporters,'' the Commission said in a statement. ``Unless measures were taken, the Community would be entirely dependent on one source of supply, i.e. the imports from Japan and the USA.'' Holland Sweetener Co. General Manager Winfried Vermijs said aspartame costs up to $70 a kilo in the EC and about $150 in the United States. In a statement issued by his office in Maastricht, he welcomed the EC duties as ``good news for the European but also the U.S. food industry for the move by the Commission guarantees the presence in the aspartame market of more than one supplier, now and in the future.'' The EC Commission acknowledged its duties will raise prices for consumers but said it was in the EC's``general interest ... to maintain the presence of a Community industry in this important product.'' NutraSweet Co., part of Monsanto's G.D. Searle division, has a monopoly on aspartame in the United States where its patent on the product expires in 1992. Dumping refers to the practice by exporters of selling goods on foreign markets at unreasonably low prices to gain a significant market share in those markets or sell off excess production. The EC calculated the duty on Ajinomoto Co. based on NutraSweet's prices ``as the Japanese exporter refused to provide essential information on its domestic prices and costs.'' Holland Sweetener Co. and NutraSweet are the biggest providers of aspartame in the EC where annual consumption is about 1,000 tons, compared with 6,000 to 7,000 tons in the United States. Aspartame's sweetening power far exceeds that of sugar and has made rapid inroads in recent years as an ingredient in light soft drinks.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Surges, Stock Prices Decline in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar surged sharply against the Japanese yen in early trading Friday, while stock prices declined. The dollar began trading at 133.70 yen, up 3.55 yen from Thursday's close of 130.15 yen. Earlier, the dollar jumped to 33.25 yen in New York overnight from late Wednesday's 130.10 yen. ``It's a rough trading day,'' said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The dollar rose as high as 133.90 briefly in early trading before retreating slightly.'' Traders said the dollar's surge came as investors sought a safe haven in advance of a U.N. Security Council meeting on the Persian Gulf. The Security Council late Thursday afternoon in New York adopted a resolution authorizing the use of military force to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The dollar was in demand by traders who wanted to increase their holdings in case the council approved the resolution and the possibility of war increased. The dollar tends to rise in times of international tensions because it is seen as a safe investment. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 358.50 points, or 1.57 percent, to move to 22,354.10 in the first 15 minutes of trading. The index lost 341.28 points Thursday. In early bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 85.51, down from Thursday's close of 86.11. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.605 percent from 7.480 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Surges, Stock Prices Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE figures.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar surged sharply against the Japanese yen Friday morning, while stock prices declined. The dollar was quoted at 133.35 yen at 11:30 a.m., up 3.20 yen from Thursday's close of 130.15 yen. After opening at 133.70 yen, it ranged between 133.00 yen and 133.85 yen in the morning. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed the morning session at 21,933.99 points, down 778.61 points, or 3.4 percent, from Thursday's finish of 22,712.60 points. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 85.62 points as of midmorning, down from Thursday's close of 86.11 points. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.58 percent from 7.48 percent. The resolution adopted by the United Nations Security Council on Thursday authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait encouraged dollar buying, traders said. The dollar is seen as a safe investment in times of international tensions, while the yen is weakened by possibility of war in the Gulf because Japan imports virtually all its oil. The dollar's jump followed its overnight advance in New York, where it closed at 133.25 yen, as investors sought a safe haven in anticipation of the U.N. decision. Jumpei Ishii, a foreign exchange dealer at the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said the dollar was staying close to its New York finish in the absence of fresh market-driving forces. He said investors were generally not taking big risks this late in the year. The lower yen and possibility of war in the Middle East helped push share prices down on the Tokyo stock market, said a dealer at Cosmo Securities, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said a further plunge may follow because the Nikkei average has hit below the 22,000-point level. ``We see severe times ahead,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Black & Decker Sues Over Product Placement in ``Die Hard 2''
DOC.TEXT: Black & Decker Inc. hasn't taken lightly to what it considers the unkindest cut of all - the elimination of a scene featuring one of its products from a movie triller. The toolmaker has filed suit in U.S. District Court in Baltimore accusing 20th Century Fox Film Corp. and the marketing firm Krown-Young & Rubicam of failing to fulfill a promise that a Black & Decker drill would appear in ``Die Hard 2.'' According to court papers filed Nov. 7, star Bruce Willis was to remove an air-duct grill in an airport tunnel with a Black & Decker cordless drill. Black & Decker commissioned an advertising and sales promotion campaign for the drill built around the movie to capitalize on the ``Father's Day gift-buying season,'' it said it its suit. But the scene was cut from the film. The company, based in Towson, is seeking at least $150,000 in damages, plus interest and court costs. It charges Fox, the film's distributor, and Krown-Young & Rubicam with negligence and breach of contract. The suit claims that Krown-Young & Rubicam obtained a commitment from Fox that the product would appear in ``Die Hard 2.'' The suit said that the company did not pay Fox a promotional fee to showcase the drill in the movie. But after assurances the tool would ``achieve strong positioning,'' Black & Decker agreed to become ``promotional partners'' with the two firms. Fox spokesman Dennis Petroskey in Los Angeles declined to comment. ``We don't comment on mtters of litigation,'' he said. Attempts to reach Krown-Young & Rubicam after business hours Thursday were unsuccessful.

DOC.HEAD: Super 8 Motel Chain Sold To Hong Kong Investors
DOC.TEXT: Motel operator Super 8 Enterprises Inc. will be sold to an unidentified group of Hong Kong investors for an undisclosed amount of money, Super 8 Chairman Ronald J. Rivett announced Thursday. ``It was an ideal time to consider a sale,'' Rivett said in a news release. ``Our occupancy rates are up, our franchise sales are up and our average room rate is up.'' Rivett, a company o-founder and majority stockholder, said the sale will be an all-cash transaction and he expects it to be final in January. One source said the sale price is more than $100 million. Privately owned Super 8 is one of the largest franchised motel chains in North America. It has 775 motels in 47 states and four Canadian provinces. It opened a record 125 new motels this year. The sale agreement stipulates that the company headquarters will remain in Aberdeen for at least the next five years and that the current management team and board of directors be retained for the same period. Rivett will continue to serve on the board. Rivett said the new owners have established a $250 million development fund for new construction and long-term financing for franchisees in the United States and Canada. ``This gives Super 8 extraordinary financial and management stability during a difficult time for the lodging industry,'' he said. ``We will be in an excellent position to build new properties or convert properties from those chains that are now struggling with heavy debts.'' In the United States, development is under way in Hawaii, Rhode Island and Delaware. The 16-year-old chain's first Mexican property is expected to open early next year. It plans to begin expanding overseas in 1991, beginning in Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Australia Plans To Kill 10 Percent Of Sheep To Ease Wool Surplus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Burdened by too many sheep and too much wool, Australia's wool industry - the world's largest exporter - is preparing a controversial program to do something about it. Starting next week, the industry says it will kill 10 percent of the nation's sheep under a plan that has provoked damaging publicity. Most of the old, underweight and poor wool-producing sheep will be shot and buried in mass graves in farmers' fields across the country. The $3.1-billion-a-year industry says the slaughter is needed because it is producing twice as much wool as it can sell and is saddled with 20 million excess sheep. The Australian Wool Corp., concerned with its image around the world, has hired a public relations firm to ensure that the ``correct story'' is told about the slaughter. High interest rates, a sharp downturn in demand for wool and a weak market for mutton have combined to put the industry in trouble. Even its live sheep exports to Middle East countries have been plagued with problems, the most recent when a shipment was refused by Saudi Arabian authorities this week because of disease. In addition, nearly three years after the wool growers were given the right to set the price of their product, there are calls for the debt-laden and depressed industry to lose the privilege. Wool corporation executives and some farmers were quick to criticize a report this week commissioned by a rebel wool grower, Jim Maple-Brown, and his committee called Wool into the 21st Century. The report, authored by a former federal government agricultural adviser, recommended that a wool floor price set by the corporation be dropped and that a free market be established. The report said the government should acquire the wool corporation's 4.4-million bale stockpile and take over the corporation's $1.8 billion debt. On Thursday, federal Primary Industries Minister John Kerin rejected calls to scrap the floor price. He also criticized Stoeckel's report for not taking into account other factors, including the country's textile industry that relies heavily on a stable wool industry. Wool prices in Australia are currently at a four-year low, 20 percent below those six months ago.
